HEADLINE: Latest Data May Indicate The Economy Is Cooling Off

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Policy makers and the financial markets received a flurry of new reports today suggesting that the economy was cooling from its overheated pace earlier this year.
The figures showed that the growth of industrial production slowed last month, that higher interest rates were finally putting a crimp in what had been a booming housing market and that the low unemployment rate might be heading upward. 
 The Federal Reserve and investors have been nervous for months that the economy was growing so fast that it would ignite inflation if it did not slow to a more sustainable pace. But signs of accelerating inflation have been scant so far, and the additions today to the body of evidence that growth is slowing has further reduced the chances that Fed policy makers will raise interest rates when it meets next on Nov. 13.
"All the talk from economists about a slowdown has been akin to the hollow refrain about the bogyman coming," said Kenneth T. Mayland, the chief economist for Keycorp, a Cleveland-based banking company. "Well, the bogyman is here."
Today's round of economic statistics set off a bond market rally and helped push stock prices to new levels. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 22/32 , to 9913/32 , sending its yield -- a benchmark for mortgages and other consumer interest rates -- down to 6.8 percent from 6.85 percent. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions from each other. The decline in interest rates bolstered stocks, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 38.39 points, to 6,059.20.
The Commerce Department reported that housing starts fell 6 percent in September, the steepest decline in 21 months. The drop was the third in the last five months, and left housing starts running at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.438 million, its lowest level since last December.
The housing market had remained relatively robust all year long despite a rise of 1.2 percentage points in mortgage rates since the beginning of the year, to an average of 8.23 percent last month for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage.
The fall-off in housing starts covered all regions of the country except the Northeast, where starts edged up by 1.4 percent last month. Starts of single-family homes dropped 8.9 percent, while starts of multifamily buildings rose 6.4 percent.
In its report on industrial production, the Federal Reserve said that the output from the nation's factories, mines and utilities grew two-tenths of a percent last month, half the rate at which it grew in August. The August figures was revised down to four-tenths of a percent from five-tenths.
Although last month's gain was somewhat higher than analysts had expected, much of it came from an increase of four-tenths of a percent in output from utilities. Manufacturing output was up two-tenths of a percent, but automobile and truck production declined for the second consecutive month. Computer production was up 2.3 percent as businesses continued to invest heavily in technology.
Although industrial production continues to increase, albeit at a slower pace, the nation's production capacity has been growing even faster -- 4 percent this year.
As a result, the capacity utilization rate fell slightly in September, to 83.3 percent from 83.4 percent, well below the level where inflationary bottlenecks start pushing prices up.
Another report from the Commerce Department suggested that demand was slackening faster than production. Business inventories in August grew five-tenths of a percent after a revised five-tenths of a percent increase in July, while business sales fell by three-tenths of a percent in August after a 1 percent gain in July.
In a tentative sign that the strong job growth that has driven the economy for much of the year could be easing, the Labor Department said initial claims for unemployment benefits rose by 18,000 last week, to 340,000.
The increase may have been partly a result of the strike at against General Motors in Canada, which has caused suppliers in the United States to curtail production and lay off some workers.
Still, most analysts said employment growth was moderating. Merrill Lynch & Company estimated that payroll employment for October would rise by 150,000, a level that would cause few inflationary fears.
Strong job growth for most of this year and the low unemployment rate -- 5.2 percent in September -- has raised concern at the Fed that tight labor markets would send wages upward, setting off an inflationary spiral.
"Yes, the slowdown is for real, and it looks like it could last long enough to drive the unemployment rate up to a level the Fed is more comfortable with," Macroeconomic Advisers, a St. Louis consulting firm, told its clients today.
Most economists now estimate that the gross domestic product grew around 2 percent in the third quarter, down sharply from the growth rate of 4.7 percent that the economy recorded in the second quarter.

HEADLINE: Decision Reduces Penalty On Chrysler in California

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
A California regulator yesterday ordered the Chrysler Corporation to halt shipments of cars and trucks to the state for 45 days -- rather than the 60 days that had been proposed -- as punishment for selling 116 used vehicles without disclosing that they had been repurchased under the state's "lemon law."
Chrysler said it intended to appeal the ruling to a state board that reviews disputes involving car makers. The penalty, the harshest so far by any state for violations of lemon laws, is scheduled to begin on Nov. 26, but could be delayed considerably or reversed during the appeal. 
 "We maintain that we were in full compliance then and still are," said James L. Crawford, a company spokesman.
The decision would also prohibit Chrysler from reselling lemons in California for three years. Chrysler has said it buys back thousands of vehicles from dissatisfied customers each year under state lemon laws and simply out of good will. The company would not estimate how many come from California.
Rosemary Shahan, president of Consumers for Auto Reliability and Safety, a group based in Sacramento, Calif., praised the decision. "It's the first time a state has suspended an auto maker's license," she said. Ms. Shahan said the length of the suspension was less significant than its potential effect on customer attitudes.
The order, by Sally R. Reed, the director of the State Department of Motor Vehicles, came after a hearing in August when a Chrysler expert testified that a 60-day ban on shipments would cost California dealers up to $26 million in lost sales. Ms. Reed estimated that the shorter ban would cost the state's 240 Chrysler dealers about $15.5 million.
The California Motor Car Dealers Association had asked for forbearance. "Thinly capitalized dealers may not be able to financially weather such a state-inflicted cutoff," the group said in a letter to Ms. Reed.
Chrysler dealers could continue to sell vehicles from their inventories if the ban on shipments were upheld. Still, any suspension is likely to hurt Chrysler in California, where its market share is lower than in the rest of the nation. In this year's first half, Chrysler had a 9.5 percent market share, compared with 14 percent nationally. But its Ram pickups and Town and Country mini-vans are among the top-selling vehicles in the state, according to a September report by J. D. Power & Associates.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Pearson Picks An American As Executive

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
Marjorie M. Scardino, chief executive of the Economist Group, which publishes The Economist magazine, was named chief executive yesterday of Pearson P.L.C., the British media conglomerate that owns 50 percent of the Economist Group.
Ms. Scardino, 49, will be the first American to head Pearson and the only woman heading one of Britain's largest publicly traded companies. 
 "She's a very strong character; she's a successful manager; she's very profit-oriented, and has been very successful at The Economist," said Michael Blakenham, the chairman of Pearson. "I think she'll be a strong leader of the team."
Ms. Scardino will succeed Frank Barlow, who is retiring at the end of the year. Pearson also named Dennis Stevenson deputy chairman -- effective immediately -- and said he would succeed Mr. Blakenham at Pearson's annual general meeting next May. Mr. Stevenson had been a director of the company.
Among Pearson's other media holdings are The Financial Times, as well as newspapers in France and Spain; the Penguin Group, one of the largest trade book publishers, and a production and distribution television company. Pearson also bought the educational side of HarperCollins Publishers earlier this year from the News Corporation for $580 million and merged it with the educational publisher Addison-Wesley Longman.
In addition, MCA Inc., the entertainment division of the Seagram Company, is reportedly in talks to sell its Putnam Berkeley Publishing Group to Pearson for more than $300 million.
The job Ms. Scardino faces, analysts say, is a formidable one. Pearson, a $6.2 billion company, has experienced some growing pains over the last few years in shifting its emphasis from a wide array of businesses -- including engineering, fine china and insurance -- to information, education and entertainment. Some analysts are wary of the company's volatile profits and say it lacks focus.
Last summer, the company reported a 40 percent drop in profits from the first half of the year, due largely to losses at Mindscape, formerly called Software Tools Inc., which develops Internet software and computer games. Pearson bought the California-based Mindscape in May 1994 for $460 million. In August, Pearson said that the unit had a first-half operating loss of 38.8 million, or $61.48 million, and estimated the full-year loss at 44.8 million, or $71 million.
Seemingly in response, the company decided to sell its Westminster Press regional newspaper unit for $470.4 million to Newsquest Media Group, which is backed by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company.
And it looks as if it will take some time for Ms. Scardino to build support in London's financial community. Pearson shares dropped yesterday on the London Stock Exchange 11.5 pence, or 18.25 cents, to 676.5 pence, or $10.72, following the announcement of Ms. Scardino's appointment.
Analysts said the negative market reaction was largely due to the fact that they are not familiar with Ms. Scardino and that they were expecting the appointment of a heavy-hitter from outside the company.
"She's an unknown quantity," said David Forster, an analyst with Salomon Brothers in London.
Indeed, Ms. Scardino herself -- who became head of the Economist Group in 1992 after serving as president of the company's North American operations -- attributed her cool reception to the low profile she maintained at The Economist, where the magazine does not have a masthead and Ms. Scardino avoided press attention. "I spent the last decade saying no to profiles and interviews and now I'm paying for it," Ms. Scardino said. "I still think I was right, but it means they don't know me."
Although Mr. Blakenham credits Ms. Scardino with taking The Economist's profits from about $19 million three and a half years ago to $38 million last year, The Economist amounts to a small part of Pearson's operations, and Ms. Scardino concedes she has a lot to learn about the company as a whole. "I don't know the company very well," she said. "So I will have to get to know it."
Nevertheless, there are those who believe Ms. Scardino could be just the person to give Pearson the push it needs. "I think the market's reaction is a bit shortsighted," said Rebecca Winnington-Ingram of Morgan Stanley & Company, who gave Pearson an underperform rating in her report on the stock last month. "Yes, she isn't a man and she isn't a complete outsider and she's not a heavy-hitter. But she's done some remarkable things with The Economist. I think she's very good news."

HEADLINE: Suffolk Officers Awarded Large Raise

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

 BODY:
An arbitrator this week awarded Suffolk County police officers an 18.6 percent wage increase over the next four years, raising fears among New York City officials that the increase might complicate negotiations with their officers and spur an exodus from the city force.
City officers have long complained that they are paid far less than their counterparts in the Suffolk and Nassau County departments, even though city officers say they have a far more dangerous job. To gain parity, the city officers have sought to have a state board take up the issue of their salaries in hopes that they would be granted wages similar to the suburban forces. 
 The gap between the city and suburban forces grows even larger with the arbitrator's ruling, which increases the base pay for officers, from $59,540 in 1996 to $70,658.
City officers with five years' experience receive base pay of $44,500, according to a spokesman for the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. In addition, officers with 20 years or more experience receive $5,000 annual longevity bonuses.
The president of the P.B.A., Lou Matarazzo, stopped short of saying he would refuse any contract proposal that did not match the Suffolk officers' gains. But he did reiterate the union's longstanding complaint that city officers were underpaid and that suburban pay rates should be used as a gauge for the city's contract talks.
"I have no problem with suburban forces' making the kind of money they do," Mr. Matarazzo said. "I would just like some equity."
Publicly, city officials and police commanders say the salaries of suburban officers should not affect negotiations with city officers, because the city's bargaining position is dictated by its own budget concerns.
The city's contract with the police union expired in March 1995, and talks are at a standstill. City officials have said they expect the police to accept the pattern of wages that other city unions have agreed to. The teachers, for example, agreed to a two-year wage freeze followed by a 13 percent increase over the last three years of a five-year contract.
"This administration has been ready and willing to come to the bargaining table to discuss the issue of raises." A. Dwight Williams, a spokesman for Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, said. "Unfortunately, the P.B.A. has not."
Some police commanders worry that the growing wage gap between city and suburban departments could add to the growing number of city officers who leave for better paying positions in the suburbs, where many city officers live anyway.
Officer Kenneth Franz, who has been on the city force for 11 years, said he was exasperated that the Giuliani administration had asked the police to work harder, with the crackdown on low-level crimes, while balking at rewarding officers with raises.
"I'll take the Suffolk test," Officer Franz said. "What have I got to lose? If they call me, they call me. You'll see a lot more city cops taking the test. The city spends all this money to train cops here, and they go somewhere else."
Even in other suburban departments, where the pay is close to the Suffolk scale, officers were surprised, albeit pleasantly, at the size of the raises. Nassau officers, who have a top minimum of $59,522 a year and recently began mediation, consider the Suffolk pact "a fair deal," said Gary DelaRaba, the president of the Nassau P.B.A.
In Westchester County, where the 237 county officers are paid $54,000 a year after four years on the job, union leaders said they were awed by the Suffolk deal.
"All the world is talking about Suffolk County," the president of the Westchester P.B.A., Gary T. McGrath, said. "They deserve it. We wish we could join it."
The arbitrator in the case, Martin F. Scheinman, said he arrived at his decision by studying the county's recent contract agreement with police supervisors and other county employees.
The pact calls for a 5.5 percent increase retroactive from Feb. 1, 1996, followed by 4 percent raises for each of the next three years.
Although the raises exceed the 2.9 percent-a-year inflation rate on Long Island, Mr. Scheinman said, the 5.5 percent raise matches the new contract given to the superior officers. "Once that happens," he said, "that's the pattern."
Union officials in New York City have tried to gain similar salaries for their members. In the last year the leaders have engaged an increasingly contentious battle with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki.
After a fierce lobbying campaign in Albany, legislators passed a bill to let state arbitrators, whom many labor leaders consider friendly to unions, to determine city officers' salaries. When Mr. Pataki vetoed the bill, the Legislature overrode the veto.
A city judge struck down the law after the city had argued that it undercut the city's ability to control union negotiations. The P.B.A. is appealing that ruling.
"This is a high-risk job, and police should be paid accordingly," Mr. Matarazzo said. "And the same should be done for police officers in the City of New York."
But many officers acknowledge that the excitement of the city and the New York Police Department's national reputation sometime compensate for the lower pay.
"I have no interest in working in Suffolk," said an officer in the 23d Precinct who would not give his name. "I want to work in the city. I like the challenge."
At least 650 officers have left the force for other police jobs from 1990 to 1995, according to department figures, with 351 joining the Nassau and Suffolk departments. That migration is troubling, because it costs the city $25,000 to recruit and train each officer.
Police Commissioner Howard Safir declined to comment on the issue.

HEADLINE: New York City Sues Big Tobacco Companies to Recoup Health Costs

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
New York City sued the major tobacco companies yesterday to recoup the billions of dollars that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said the city has spent to care for people with illnesses caused by smoking.
The suit angered one of the city's largest and most influential corporations, Philip Morris, which is the biggest maker of cigarettes in the world. 
 Mr. Giuliani joins a growing movement by officials across the country to seek damages from tobacco companies for the health care costs of smoking. Seventeen states and more than a dozen localities have already filed similar suits, trying to end the companies' long record of courtroom successes.
At a news conference, the Mayor asserted that the major tobacco companies had waged a decades-long campaign to dupe the public into believing that cigarettes were not addictive or harmful. He brushed aside the possibility that Philip Morris, which is based in Manhattan and donates millions of dollars a year to cultural groups in the city, might retaliate.
"I never am affected by people who threaten," he said. "If they want to leave the city of New York, we can replace those jobs with other jobs. We will do just as well."
Philip Morris assailed the lawsuit but said it was not considering shifting jobs from the city at this time. In 1994, the company had suggested that it might leave after the city approved tough restrictions on smoking in restaurants and other public places.
Charles R. Wall, a senior vice president at Philip Morris, said, "It is regrettable that a duly elected official feels so little constraint by law or fact that he willingly jumps on what is perceived by some to be the politically correct bandwagon of tobacco litigation."
Of the lawsuits in the 17 states, three are scheduled to go to trial next year, said Richard A. Daynard, chairman of the Tobacco Products Liability Project at Northeastern University in Boston. Trial in the first, Mississippi's, is expected to open in March, he said.
Mr. Giuliani said he wanted to recover money that the city has spent on Medicaid, care for the indigent and health insurance premiums for city workers. As the Mayor noted, a Columbia University study had found that tobacco use costs the city $300 million a year. The Health and Hospitals Corporation, the quasi-public agency that runs the municipal hospitals, is also bringing the lawsuit, which was filed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.
The Mayor acknowledged that the legal battle against the tobacco companies would be long and difficult, but he said he was acting to protect the fiscal health of the city and the physical health of its residents. "In New York City, this deceit has caused enormous suffering and death," he said. "And it has huge economic repercussions."
New York State is not among those that have filed lawsuits against the tobacco companies, while New Jersey and Connecticut are. The New York Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, has questioned whether such lawsuits would be successful, contending that it might be better to negotiate settlements with the tobacco companies.
In a statement, Mr. Vacco, a Republican, emphasized that he had not ruled out filing a suit.
Some Democrats in Albany have charged that Mr. Vacco wants to keep good relations with the tobacco companies, which have contributed heavily to Republicans leaders in New York and nationally.
Soon after Mr. Vacco took office in 1995, he hired the husband of one of Philip Morris's top lobbyists in the state, Sharon Portnoy. Her husband, Steven Portnoy, worked in Mr. Vacco's community affairs office in New York City before stepping down earlier this year.
Christopher McKenna, a spokesman for Mr. Vacco, said the Attorney General did not give the job to Mr. Portnoy to curry favor with Philip Morris. Mr. Portnoy, he said, "is well known and has a great deal of experience in government."
The Portnoys declined to comment.
Mr. Giuliani, who has tried in recent months to improve his relationship with fellow Republicans in Albany, said he would "advise the state to file a lawsuit for the same reasons that we did." But he added, "They have to make their own decisions."
The city's Public Advocate, Mark Green, a Democrat, was one of the first city officials to push for the lawsuit. He and two Democratic Assemblymen from Manhattan, Richard N. Gottfried and Alexander B. Grannis, praised the Mayor while attacking Mr. Vacco. They said that in addition to New York City, Erie County, which includes Buffalo, was filing a suit against the tobacco companies.
"The Attorney General has dropped the ball on this issue," Mr. Grannis said. "While he continues to coddle the cigarette companies, the chief executives of two big counties have stepped into the void."
Mr. Vacco's aides dismissed such talk as political posturing. And the Attorney General said in his statement that he would monitor the city's lawsuit.
"I plan to carefully study today's action by Mayor Giuliani to measure if it will contribute to achieving my primary goal of reducing the incidence of teen-age smoking," Mr. Vacco said.
In the confrontation between the city and Philip Morris in 1994, the company was said to have pressured the many arts and cultural groups that it supports with grants to lobby city officials on its behalf. Philip Morris executives did not say yesterday whether they would adopt a similar strategy this time, but they did go out of their way to stress the company's financial contributions to the city.
They said Philip Morris had 1,500 workers in the city who earned $165 million a year in wages, generating $50 million in taxes. They added that the company spent millions on philanthropy.
"Philip Morris believes that the city will lose," a company statement said of the lawsuit. "In the end, it will be the taxpayers of New York City who will pay the price for Mayor Giuliani's blatant political grandstanding."

HEADLINE: SHAKE-UP IN RUSSIA: IN WASHINGTON;
For White House, Lebed's Dismissal Is a Case of Dogs Fighting Under a Carpet

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Senior American officials have long expected that President Boris N. Yeltsin would eventually oust his national security chief, Aleksandr I. Lebed, but they were surprised by the timing, several said today.
The United States is being very careful not to get involved in what it regards a matter of internal Russian politics, the officials stressed, but they are worried that the popular but controversial peace settlement Mr. Lebed negotiated with seessionists in Chechnya could unravel. 
 They see little effect on Russian-American relations, where Mr. Lebed had not yet become an important player. Defense Secretary William J. Perry, in Moscow to urge the Russian Parliament to ratify the second strategic arms reduction treaty, or Start-2, told reporters that the personal and security ties among high Russian and American officials are "strong and growing."
"I don't see any fundamental change in the U.S.-Russian relationship in terms of this announcement," he said.
But Mr. Lebed's sudden ouster only adds to the uncertainty about Russia's stability while Mr. Yeltsin is awaiting a heart operation, the officials say.
They have no evidence that Mr. Lebed, as alleged, was planning a military coup, and they compare the intricate and shadowy power struggle in Moscow, as Churchill once did, to dogs fighting under a carpet.
But they stress that Mr. Lebed, who has recently fought with both Defense Minister Igor N. Rodionov and Interior Minister Anatoly Kulikov, will find little support in the Yeltsin Government. And they expect that his lavish coverage in the mainstream Russian press will sharply diminish.
"It's clear Lebed's ambitions are titanic, but it's not clear he has the talents to match," a senior American official said. "This is no longer the Soviet Union, and the key is whether Lebed can turn his personal popularity into a lasting political organization with big financing that works for him. He doesn't strike me as someone who builds organizations. Douglas MacArthur was a very popular general, too, but never made it politically."
Mr. Lebed, whose presidential candidacy was in part promoted and financed by a Yeltsin team worried about the revived Communist Party, lost a great deal of his appeal to Mr. Yeltsin after the Russian runoff election on July 3, the officials say.
"It was clear he was no team player and did not like being a loyal subordinate, so it was always a combustible mix," an official said.
As for the immediate spark, it was likely to have been a combination of Mr. Yeltsin's approaching surgery and Mr. Lebed's overreaching, including his relationship with a former Yeltsin crony, Aleksandr Korzhakov, and the public suggestion that Mr. Yeltsin hand over his powers while under hospital care.
Mr. Yeltsin was never going to take kindly to the implication that his second term was already over, the officials say, and his top aides, from the chief of staff, Anatoly B. Chubais, to Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, were likely to have reminded Mr. Yeltsin of his struggle with another general in Afghanistan whom Mr. Yeltsin elevated, the former Vice President Aleksandr Rutskoi, who led a 1993 coup attempt.
Dimitri Simes, of the Nixon Center for Peace and Freedom, a Washington research institute, said Yeltsin aides probably judged it better to get rid of the ambitious Mr. Lebed now, while Mr. Yeltsin is well enough to do it personally and on camera, rather than risk having Mr. Lebed challenge presidential decisions and competence after the surgery.
Jack F. Matlock, a former American Ambassador in Moscow, said the ouster will only make Mr. Lebed more popular.
"This may be as bad a blunder as Gorbachev throwing Yeltsin out in 1987, giving Lebed no alternative but to go into public opposition," Mr. Matlock said. "Who knows what stories they peddled to Yeltsin about Lebed? In the byzantine intrigue characteristic there, one can only guess. And Yeltsin tends to act quickly and be more mercurial."
But the Clinton Administration position, so close to the American Presidential election, did not allow for speculation. The State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said: "The Russian Government is stable, led by President Yeltsin. This is dramatic. It's important. We're not exactly sure where it's going to lead in the future but the relationship is stable and this is what matters ultimately to the American people."
A White House official added, "Yeltsin stepped in and made a presidential decision, within his constitutional prerogatives, to put his own house in order. Clinton has a strong relationship with Yeltsin." The same official said the regular contacts between Prime Minister Chernomyrdin and Vice President Al Gore are "one of the most effective channels we have."
But given Mr. Lebed's popularity and Mr. Yeltsin's ill health, American officials see no reason to take sides in this battle. They are aware that should Mr. Yeltsin die in office, Mr. Chernomyrdin, who would take over as Acting President, must call elections within three months, and that Mr. Lebed would have a good chance of winning.
Stephen Sestanovich of the Carnegie Endowment, now in Moscow, wondered if the Government could keep the Lebed dismissal from "spilling out into the Parliament or the society at large."
Communist and other opposition legislators are bound to try to investigate the dismissal, he said, which may give Mr. Lebed the chance to focus larger opposition to the Government on questions of corruption, crime and economic distress.

HEADLINE: Top Democrat Proposes Plan On Preschool Access for All

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The top Democratic leader in the General Assembly today proposed making preschool available to every 4-year-old in the state, saying that it would ultimately save tens of millions of dollars on education, social programs and prisons.
State Representative Thomas D. Ritter, the Speaker of the House, said that about one-third of the children entering kindergarten in Connecticut had not attended any preschool program, increasing the likelihood that they would need special assistance in school later and might end up on welfare or in prison. 
 "Politicians always talk about how you save money," Mr. Ritter said at a news conference. "This is how you do it. It's a double win. You take care of our youngsters now and keep them out of the criminal justice system and off welfare later."
The remarks came at an event in which Mr. Ritter and State Representative Ellen Scalettar proposed presenting the state budget in a new way that would place greater emphasis on "preventive" programs. Under the plan, which Gov. John G. Rowland has agreed to implement, a host of programs that agencies classify as preventive will be listed in a separate section of the budget.
In discussing the new budget format, Mr. Ritter cited preschool as perhaps the best example of how increased attention to preventive measures is sound fiscal policy. While Mr. Ritter had no specific proposal for expanding preschool, he said it would be his "biggest priority" next year.
Mr. Ritter, a politician who chooses his issues carefully, rarely makes such statements, and several top lawmakers said the time appeared ripe for legislation to expand preschool education.
Over the years, Connecticut has lagged behind other states in its pre-school policy. Elaine Zimmerman, executive director of the State Commission on Children, a nonpartisan legislative agency, said that unlike 40 other states, Connecticut had failed to develop a comprehensive policy on early childhood education for disadvantaged children.
But in the last two years, two developments have increased the pressure on Connecticut to expand its preschool offerings. First, the state adopted a new welfare program that required recipients to find work, increasing the need for child-care placements. Second, a landmark State Supreme Court decision three months ago in the case known as Sheff v. O'Neill has been widely interpreted as an order to improve the quality of education offered to children in the state's cities.
Some top Republicans have embraced the idea of expanding preschool opportunities.
While saying that universal access to preschool may not be needed, State Senator Judith G. Freedman, the Republican co-chairwoman of the legislature's education committee, said the state needed to insure its availability to needy children. "I'm a believer in this," she said.
And Dean Pagani, Governor Rowland's spokesman, said Mr. Rowland was "in favor of expanding educational opportunities for everyone, and that would include preschool," though he added that it remained to be seen whether money could be found for it in tight fiscal times.
Mr. Ritter said today that the state was expecting a windfall of $65 million to $80 million under the new Federal welfare block grants. He estimated that it would cost about $75 million to provide preschool for many of the 15,000 children who currently do not attend. While some parents may prefer to keep their children at home, many others do not enroll their children in preschool because they cannot afford it.
Mr. Ritter said that national and state studies had shown that $1 in preschool spending saved up to $6 in future spending for special education, social services, and court and prison costs. He estimated that putting all of Connecticut's children in preschool would save $425 million over the course of their lifetimes.
"If we know we will save substantial taxpayer dollars in years to come by spending more on preschool now, and we know preschool has social and personal benefits for society," he said, "then why can't we look at covering the remaining one-third of children who are not getting preschool?"

HEADLINE: Dole Gives Impetus to Changing the Tax Code

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
In Bob Dole's rhetorical shorthand, the issue comes down to a few snappy phrases that draw sustained cheers whenever he uses them on the campaign trail: a tax system that is "simpler, flatter and fairer," and "ending the I.R.S. as we know it."
But despite making replacement of the tax code a central element of his plan to strengthen the economy, Mr. Dole has neither offered nor endorsed any specific alternative to the current income tax system. Instead he stays with generalities, largely because he recognizes that any big change would produce a lot of losers as well as winners. 
 To some degree, of course, Mr. Dole's decision to give the issue no more than a tentative embrace -- despite its apparent popular appeal -- reflects his pledge to address taxes first by cutting rates 15 percent under the existing system.
But there are clearly other factors at play. Mr. Dole's running mate, Jack Kemp, is a fervent advocate of scrapping the entire tax code and starting over with a new system, preferably a single rate "flat" tax. Mr. Dole, a former chairman of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee, is much more a legislative pragmatist who recognizes, aides said, just how complex and politically charged the topic is.
Any serious effort to change the way the Federal Government raises revenue has immense economic and political implications and would set off an epic battle among interest groups, catching proponents of any new system in the middle.
Still, even if he loses the Presidential race, Mr. Dole has given added prominence to the issue, which has long preoccupied the Republican Party's tax-cutting wing and has recently been taken up by some liberal Democrats, like Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader in the House. Republican leaders in Congress say that if they retain control of the House, where tax legislation originates, they will press ahead next year with a concerted effort to toss out the tax code.
"The nation is fed up with the existing tax code and we all know it," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader who is one of the most prominent advocates of a flat tax. "We're going to replace it with something, as soon as possible."
Ever since Steve Forbes sought the Republican Presidential nomination on a flat tax platform, a debate has been raging about how to deal with the issue that all of the leading alternatives, whatever their overall economic benefit, tend to favor the wealthy over the middle class.
Moreover, any effort to scrap the system would set off fights over whether, say, homeowners should lose the mortgage interest deduction or whether all corporate loopholes should be closed. Congress would have to make tough decisions about balancing lower overall tax rates against further spending cuts.
"The political reality is that revenue-neutral tax reform is bound to have losers as well as winners," said Joel Slemrod, director of the Office of Tax Policy Research at the University of Michigan.
Part of the drive for a new tax system is what many politicians view as widespread discontent with the system's complexity and loopholes. But many supporters of change argue that the primary rationale for a new system is economic. The current system, they say, inhibits savings and investment and encourages consumption -- exactly the opposite of what the nation needs if it is to improve living standards and enhance its global competitiveness. All the alternatives reduce or eliminate taxes on savings and investment, a shift that advocates contend will result in improved productivity and growth rates, but which opponents warn also risks greater inequality.
"I believe it will launch economic growth the like of which we have not seen since right after World War II," said Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
Mr. Archer favors a "consumption" tax that would put levies on goods and services rather than income, thereby creating incentives for more savings and investment. A consumption tax could be a national sales tax, for example, or a European-style value added tax.
Mr. Armey's flat tax would have a similar effect, but would do so by exempting income from profits, interest and dividends while imposing a single rate on earnings and pensions, after large exemptions for many taxpayers. Senators Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat, and Pete V. Domenici, a Republican from New Mexico, have proposed keeping the basic income tax system but with exemptions for savings and some educational costs.
The Clinton Administration has so far been unenthusiastic about a fundamental change, saying that all the alternatives are flawed.
"Nothing we've seen so far at least meets the criteria of being clearly better than what we have today," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said. "Every single taxpayer would have interests at stake, sometimes in complex ways." He added that any serious effort at change would take up so much time and political capital that other pressing issues would be pushed aside.
But fearful of ceding a politically popular issue to the Republicans, Congressional Democrats have been drafting proposals of their own. Representative Gephardt recently proposed sweeping changes to the system that he said would allow three-quarters of taxpayers to pay a 10 percent rate without the need to file a lengthy return.
"Democrats must not fight this crucial tax debate on Republican ground," Mr. Gephardt said.
If elected, Mr. Dole would settle on a specific plan only after wide consultations, aides said. But his campaign has issued a list of goals. They include ending special interest loopholes, reducing income tax rates, allowing most taxpayers to file on a form no bigger than a postcard or not to file a return at all, and allowing Social Security taxes to be deducted from income.

HEADLINE: Two Different Pleas for Change: Excerpts From a Second Senate Debate

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from last night's debate in Trenton between Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat, and Richard A. Zimmer, a Republican, as transcribed by The New York Times.
 
Opening Statements
TORRICELLI For several months Dick Zimmer and I have been campaigning around New Jersey, asking for your help to get elected to the United States Senate. I know you're disappointed in the campaign. So am I. It's deteriorated into personal accusations and acrimony. But in truth, this campaign isn't about me. And it's not about Dick Zimmer. It's about you, your families and your future. It's also not about taxes or spending. I voted for a tax cut last year. So did Dick Zimmer. I voted for the balanced budget amendment. And so did Dick Zimmer. Ultimately this election is about who will be on your side when the difficult decisions are made that affect your family. . . .
Tonight is a last chance to raise the level of this debate and the campaign. I intend to seize it. It's an important moment for your state and a last chance for us.
ZIMMER I believe that this campaign is about nothing less than the future of the American dream. I grew up in modest circumstances. My dad was a mailman. My mother sold encyclopedias. But I was able to live the American dream. And I'm concerned that children growing up now and in the future have that same opportunity. And they will, but only if we fundamentally change the way Government does business. We've got to reduce taxes and balance the budget, not just talk about it but do it so that we can have a brighter future for our children and so families can help make ends meet. We've got to be able to have a cleaner and healthier environment for our children than the one that we grew up in. We have to assure that our families are safe in the streets and in their homes. And we have to have representatives that reflect the views of the people they represent, who show up and vote for you and actually participate in the great decisions that affect this country. If we do those things, we will be able to restore the American dream.
 
Tone of the Campaign
TORRICELLI I think that indeed it has gotten so bad that whoever wins this contest may serve in the United States Senate but not really have the confidence of the people of this state and be able to govern. A group of ministers came to each of us a week ago and asked us to sign a pledge that we would stop all negative advertising. I did so in a second, so we could just talk about the families of this state, the future, Medicare, environmental protection and education. Mr. Zimmer wouldn't sign that pledge. So I made a universal pledge but complied only to myself, and that is that I would only talk about Federal issues and votes in the United States Congress. . . .
ZIMMER Well, I signed the pledge against negative campaigning last month when it was presented to me by the Perot organization. And I've kept that pledge, because my ads are true and they are relevant to the job of United States senator.
I believe that people are responsible for their own actions. And the advertisements that are running in my name, that describe Bob Torricelli's actions, are true. And I can understand why he wouldn't want people to see some of these things. But unfortunately for him, they've been reported by reputable organizations and he did conceal evidence about a South Korean, a fugitive from justice. He did speak to a radical Hamas-oriented group. He did bounce more checks that anybody else in the House bank. . . .
 
Education
ZIMMER I'm concerned that there are schools, particularly in some of our urban areas in this state, that are betraying the children they're supposed to serve. The children are graduating, through no fault of their own, without the skills that they need to cope in the new global economy. And that's why they need the same right that the wealthy have already had by being able to send their kids to prep school, that the middle class have always had by being able to move to a community with good public schools, but the poor can't have because they can't move out and they're sending their kids to schools which the teachers themselves won't send their own children to.
I believe that the best thing that we could do for the public schools is to give them a dose of competition. And just like any other monopoly, the public schools have become arrogant and expensive and unresponsive to the people they're supposed to serve. And that's why I'm in favor of vouchers. . . .
TORRICELLI Dick, the public schools don't need your compliments. We need your vote. The voucher system would give up on public education in this state. It would take needed resources away from schools in suburban and urban districts that are already struggling to survive. Competition among public schools makes sense. Use vouchers among different school districts to see who has the best program. . . .
 
Harvard Jee
TORRICELLIThere are times in life when your character is tested. I got a call from a family that I had known years before that I did legal work for as a private attorney that told me that a little girl didn't have a place to go to school. And she didn't have a place to live. She had been abandoned. I found her a school. I haven't seen or known of her father in many, many years. And I hold no grief for her father. He abandoned his child. I did the best I could, had a lawyer send documents to the American Embassy in order to get permission to send her into school. Those documents came back signed and notarized. There have been outrageous charges made in this. The fact of the matter is, I did what I thought was right. . . .
ZIMMER Well, The Record of Hackensack ran an editorial about Bob Torricelli's answers to these questions and they called it Torricelli's tap dance. The fact is that Bob has not answered these questions adequately. . . .
 
Closing Statements
 ZIMMER The difference between Bob Torricelli and me is that Bob Torricelli believes that more government will create a greater America. Well, he's wrong. The only thing we'll get from more government and more taxes and more regulation and litigation is a bigger bureaucracy. I'd like to take this country down a different path. I'd like to take it down a path that, of more freedom and opportunity and growth and personal responsibility. . . .
TORRICELLI You know, when I hear a candidate engaged in personal attacks or distorting somebody's record, I get a little suspicious. Dick, you know that you've missed more votes than I have. . . .
In our state, we've never engaged in this kind of politics. Democrats and Republicans have had their differences, but we stayed on issues. Something is going wrong. We can build a wonderful future in this country, but we've got to make the public discourse decent again. . . .

HEADLINE: Kansas City Looks for Silver Lining

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 13

 BODY:
Jazz and food have always been hot in this city, home of Charlie (Bird) Parker and spicy barbecue. Lately the economy has been heating up, too, with a low unemployment rate and a high level of noise coming from new construction sites.
Still, it is not hard to find people here who say they are worried that Kansas City is headed in the wrong direction. For starters, the ghosts of the legendary corrupt days of Boss Tom Pendergast are once again rattling their handcuffs in the halls of local government. 
 In the last 18 months, four former or current members of the City Council have been indicted on Federal or state corruption charges in the biggest storm of subpoenas, suspicion and scandal to hit this town since the end of the Pendergast era in the late 1930's.
But what has made old men here weep and younger ones wonder about loyalty was the news last month that the blue jackets would be leaving town. For nearly 70 years, thousands of fresh-faced farmers to be, dressed in blue corduroy jackets and good manners, came to Kansas City early each November for the annual convention of the Future Farmers of America, now known officially only by its initials, F.F.A.
The invasion of blue was a heartland ritual of autumn, a tradition that made the old feel young and everyone else remember that life on the farm made life in the big city possible. But the F.F.A. is taking its sprawling convention to Louisville, Ky., in 1999, wooed away like a professional sports team or corporation by a pot of perks and promises.
F.F.A. leaders said they had simply obtained a better package of convention space and hotel rooms from Louisville, which has signed a seven-year contract with the organization. Mayor Emanuel Cleaver, a minister, likened the departure to the sad end of a long and happy marriage broken up by a new suitor.
"It hurt," Mr. Cleaver said in an interview. "It was like a divorce. The F.F.A. was born here. It's almost as Kansas City as the Missouri River."
More than just sentiment was at stake. The F.F.A. meeting is the largest convention here. Last year, 35,000 people attended it and spent an estimated $14 million in restaurants, hotels and shops. The organizers say they expect that by 2000, the convention will draw 50,000.
"It's not about losing a major convention and millions of dollars," Mr. Cleaver said. "They're teaching kids to be disloyal."
It was a civic slap in the face that stung all the more because of bad times in City Hall. The F.F.A. announced that it was leaving on the September day that one of the fallen Council members, D. Jeanne Robinson, pleaded guilty to mail fraud.
Bitterness and a sense of betrayal were in the air. Yael T. Abouhalkah, a columnist for The Kansas City Star, wrote "good riddance" to both the "greedy" politicians and the "greedy leaders" of the young farmers' group. "In both cases," Mr. Abouhalkah said, "Kansas Citians have been hurt and stunned by decisions outside their control."
It was a tag-team day of bad publicity for this city, where the jazz soars like a bird and the barbecue sauce is red hot and world famous.
"I'm into my 90th year as Mayor," said Mr. Cleaver, who is really in his second four-year term. "This has not been an easy time."
No one knows when the parade from politics to court will stop. A Federal grand jury has been looking into charges of influence peddling across the state involving government dealings with casinos, landfills, hospitals and more casinos.
According to The Star on Oct. 11, indictments are expected to be handed up for some of the "biggest political power brokers" in Kansas City and throughout the state when the grand jury is finished in a few weeks.
Civic pride has received other blows as well. Last year, the headquarters of the Big Eight sports conference, now the Big Twelve, left town for Dallas, where the head of the conference lives. Like the F.F.A., the conference has deep roots here. Its championship basketball tournament for men and women remains here, but many fear that it may eventually follow the pencil pushers in the headquarters.
In September, the National Severe Storms Forecast Center announced that it was leaving here after 42 years, moving to Norman, Okla., to consolidate tornado research. And some fear that the Kansas City Royals baseball team may also leave if a local buyer is not found.
But for some, all the bad news has obscured the truth that Kansas City is doing quite well over all. The unemployment rate is low (4 percent). New buildings are going up. The city of 443,878 residents has gained 9,000 people since the early 1990's. And several corporations, including Transamerica, Gateway 2000 and Harley-Davidson, have moved major divisions to town. Harley-Davidson is building an $82 million plant.
Still, when a sweetheart leaves and takes the pretty blue coat, it can be hard to notice the sunshine. "There is a feeling as we approach the next century," said Jim Scott, a 40-year-old architect, "that we aren't the city that we used to be."
Mr. Cleaver would agree. He said that Kansas City was better than ever and that was why he was so concerned about the cloud of shame drifting over City Hall.
"We are in the middle of our greatest building and economic boom in the last 75 years," he said, "and I don't want what is arguably the best moment in Kansas City history to be tainted by political corruption."
Many people here, however, do not seem too surprised or overly upset by the headlines about City Hall.
"There's a feeling in the public of 'What else is new?' " said Bill Worley, a researcher of local history at the University of Missouri campus here. "There's a perception of a lot of folks that corruption is endemic to Kansas City politics."
Mr. Worley said another reason people had not been too shaken was that the corruption exposed so far was "peanuts" compared with what went on when the Pendergast machine turned Kansas City into its personal piggy bank. The four politicians are accused of taking a total of less than $200,000 through bribes and fraud. Two politicians are accused in the same case; the other two cases are separate.
Mr. Worley said Pendergast and his men had stolen millions of dollars in the 20's and 30's and had even killed a few people on one Election Day. The era was captured most recently in Robert Altman's film "Kansas City."
But even in those days, the F.F.A. convention made people feel good about the future. Harry Cleberg, who will become chairman of the Chamber of Commerce in November, said the sight of the blue coats "renewed everyone's confidence in the youth of this country, who will ultimately become the leaders of America."
"The kids in the F.F.A.," Mr. Cleberg added, "are some of the finest, most vibrant, outgoing, polite young people you would every meet. Losing the convention is like losing a very dear friend."
A majority of members come from the countryside and suburbs. But the federation also has many urban chapters around the nation, including a large one here at East Magnet High School, where three members -- Jennifer Petrus, 17; Sheri Hopkins, 16, and Damonien Gleason, 18, the chapter president -- discussed recently what the convention had meant to their hometown.
"I remember my first convention back in 1994," Ms. Hopkins said, petting one of the school's six sheep as a brown rooster with a head of red feathers made a racket nearby. "Every time people saw me in my blue jacket, they'd come up and say how proud they felt when they were in the F.F.A. It helped them learn how to live. It brought the city together."
Ms. Hopkins said she wanted to be a lawyer specializing in agricultural and would love to go to court to keep the National F.F.A. Organization's convention in Kansas City. "The convention reminds old people of when they were young," she said. "Nobody wants to lose it. I know when I get gray, I want something like that to remind of my younger days."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Future Farmers of America, or F.F.A., plans to move its convention from Kansas City, Mo., to Louisville, Ky. Members in Kansas City include, from left, Damonien Gleason, Jennifer Petrus and Sheri Hopkins. (Jeff Roberson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REFORM PARTY;
Humor and Energy in Team's Second Spot

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Tex.

 BODY:
Standing in the aisle of the Rosebud Theater, the woman at the microphone recently asked a brutally blunt question of Pat Choate, the Vice-Presidential half of Ross Perot's Reform Party ticket: With Mr. Perot's single-digit standing in the polls, how did the two of them plan, after the election, to champion their ideas of fiscal responsibility?
Unfazed and with his professorial tongue firmly in his cheek, Dr. Choate responded, "How would we go about that in the unlikely prospect we don't win?" His one-liner set off gales of laughter among the several hundred students on hand for his speech at his alma mater, the University of Texas at Arlington, a Dallas suburb. 
 Disarming his audiences with flashes of humor may be an indispensable weapon these days as the political economist and outspoken critic of the North American Free Trade Agreement and other trade accords goes about the lonely, uphill task of trying to persuade voters to listen to the party's message.
The ticket's standing in the polls is no comfort. And if his Rosebud audience is typical, people seem attracted more out of curiosity than potential commitment. Unlike Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, Dr. Choate does not have a traveling group of reporters watching his every move.
But none of this has sapped his enthusiasm. In his speech here, Dr. Choate pushed the party agenda, including a call for tightening campaign finance laws.
After telling the students that none of them had raised or could raise the more than $600,000 they would need to seek a House seat or the $4 million required for a Senate race, he told them: "I come from this school. I come from a working-class background. Let me tell you, it's a simple miracle that I'm able to run for Vice President. It is only because it's a new party, a reform party and a billionaire helped create it."
After the speech, a few students lingered to chat. And the Dallas-based ABC affiliate, Channel 8, devoted just a minute that night to Dr. Choate on the 5 o'clock newscast, nothing on the program at 6 and 45 seconds on the 10 o'clock news. The next day The Dallas Morning News carried an 18-line item on the talk.
Dr. Choate spent the next morning in his North Dallas hotel suite. Just before 8:30 A.M. he telephoned his first campaign stop, CNN Radio in Kansas City, Mo. Two and a half hours and a muffin later, after four interviews, he had reached 21 states.
From 11:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M., at Perot '96 headquarters nearby, he tapped out answers on a computer keyboard to questions from high school students, using a CNN on-line chat service.
While the policy planks in Dr. Choate's public remarks are the same as Mr. Perot, his sensibilities at times are not. Mr. Perot's speeches focus on helping the middle class; Dr. Choate often talks about aiding the working class.
Answering the question at the Rosebud about the post-election fate of Reform Party ideas, Dr. Choate said that while he expected Mr. Perot to remain active in the party, he would return to the United Broadcasting Network, a radio network he says he controls along with a partner. But he said that the network would "be very aggressive on these issues over the next four years."
United Broadcasting produces public affairs programming and markets American-made products.
Until his candidacy, Dr. Choate, who has a Ph.D. in economics, was a full-time policy analyst with his own research group, the Manufacturing Policy Project. In the early 1990's, he wrote "Agents of Influence," in which he asserted that Japan's business interests were heavily involved in the affairs of the United States, and, if left unchecked, could turn this country into an economic colony.
But in the campaign Dr. Choate has concentrated on other issues. In an interview, he said that contributions to the major parties by "special interests" had, in effect, erased the differences between the parties.
President Clinton, a Southern Democrat, and Mr. Dole, the Republican nominee, are "corporate Republicans," he said, adding: "They're both financed by corporations. They seek the ratification and endorsement of those corporations."
Between 2008 and 2012, he predicted, the nation will undergo a political realignment: The business-backed elements of the major parties will merge, and working-class, moderate and reform-minded voters will join the Reform Party, which will become a labor party, he said. "What you're moving to in this country is back to a traditional alignment that we saw earlier in the century and that you see in England," he said. "That's capital and labor. That's what is happening here -- a party of workers and the owner class."

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
More Town Houses Rise in Raritan Township, N.J.

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: RARITAN TOWNSHIP, N.J.

 BODY:
Banking on location, architecture and competitive pricing, a New Jersey developer is building a large town house development in this Hunterdon County community, which has seen its countryside blanketed with attached housing in the last decade.
The builder, the Kalian Companies of Red Bank, is putting up a 243-home development called Townsende in the northwest portion of this township about 50 miles from Manhattan, and abutting Main Street in the historic borough of neighboring Flemington. The 69-acre project, off Walter E. Foran Boulevard, is not far from several major roadways, including Routes 31, 22 and 202 and Interstate 287, and the corporations that have sprung up alongside them. Kalian, using its own equity and bank financing, will build the $35 million project in two phases over the next three and a half years. 
 Many of the existing condominiums in the Raritan-Flemington area were built during the mid-80's building boom and have one or two bedrooms, one-car garages and few basements. The market for attached housing, which was hit hardest in the real estate recession, has stabilized, said Nancy Spencer, manager of the Flemington office of Weichert Realtors. The average sales price for existing town homes, she said, is $121,500; for resale single-family homes it is $175,000. Prices for new single-family detached homes are higher, starting in the $250,000 range, although there are a few that are in the low $200,000's.
At Townsende the three-story town homes, designed in Victorian style by Kaplan, Gaunt & DeSantis of Red Bank, have two or three bedrooms, with 1,700 to 2,000 square feet of space, two-car garages and basements. Prices range from $154,900 to $189,900, which is $5,000 to $10,000 higher than when pre-construction sales began in June.
Patrick Kalian, president of the Kalian Companies, said Townsende was designed for people who wanted a large new home but who could not or chose not to pay the cost of a new single-family detached house in the area. It is a segment of the market not now being served adequately, he said.
Ms. Spencer agreed, but added, "The question is how deep is that market?"
Mark S. Bellin, Kalian's senior vice president, said his company also went ahead because a market study it commissioned showed the area's demographics were strong enough to support the project. Its location, within walking distance of an established neighborhood and shops, was also a positive factor. "People will buy if they are getting value," Mr. Bellin said, adding that so far contracts have been signed on 33 homes.
Townsende was conceived at the start of this decade. Kalian bought it early this year from the previous owners, who decided not to proceed. Development of the site required building a new road.
To that end Kalian is extending East Main Street in Flemington 1,000 yards north, through Raritan and past its project, to Route 31. The road will be completed next month. The company also increased the size of the residences by an average of 300 square feet from the original plans and added the basements to make them more attractive to buyers, Mr. Bellin said.
Townsende is one of several projects that will help Raritan comply with the State Supreme Court's Mount Laurel decisions requiring municipalities to offer housing for people with low and moderate incomes. Raritan has an obligation for 426 such units.
Kalian is contributing just over $1 million toward a regional contribution agreement, which allows the township to pay for half of its units to be built in New Brunswick.
Robert Kren, Raritan's planner, said that Townsende not only helped the township satisfy its affordable housing obligation, but created a new road that would direct traffic away from local streets.
Mr. Kren said zoning was in place for the other town house projects, together totaling 1,000 more units. Now, he said, the township is seeking to preserve farmland and open space and to keep future development in check. Since 1980 Raritan's population has gone from 8,200 to 20,000.
The 243 residences at Townsende will be contained in 39 buildings, with four to eight units each, spread over the site, more than 30 percent of which will be left clear. Most of the buildings face woods or open space.
The homes, which take their architecture cues from nearby Flemington, have scalloped siding and gingerbread-trim Victorian touches. Each includes nine-foot ceilings, decks and a two-car garage.
A pool, tennis court, small clubhouse and play areas are also planned. Monthly charges are $109 and taxes on a $165,000 unit will run about $3,600.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Wall Street, usually thrilled by merger deals, shrugs at one.

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim 

 BODY:
DESPITE the general enthusiasm this bull market has offered for many takeover plans, analysts and investors yesterday registered displeasure with both a buyer and seller.
The deal was the proposed $1.7 billion purchase of Ornda Healthcorp by the Tenet Healthcare Corporation that is to create a chain of 126 hospitals. The combination, which must be approved by shareholders and Federal antitrust regulators, would unite Tenet, the second-largest for-profit hospital group, with Ornda, the No. 3 chain. It would add 50 hospitals to Tenet's 76 institutions for a total of 126, still behind the Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corporation. which has more than 320 hospitals. 
 Yet Wall Street didn't reflect any particular gusto for either side of the deal. Tenet Healthcare fell 87.5 cents, to $21.25 a share, as is typical for an acquiring company. But in a market reaction unusual for a takeover candidate, Ornda actually slipped 37.5 cents a share before rebounding to scratch out a gain of 25 cents, to $27.50.
Analysts questioned whether Tenet was paying too much for Ornda, whether the location of Ornda's hospitals in poor areas would become an issue if cuts in Medicare and Medicaid occur and whether Tenet could have done better by spending its money in other places.
Tenet, which is based in Santa Barbara, Calif., and Ornda, of Nashville, said they could save $70 million a year by eliminating overlapping equipment, laboratories and computer systems and add 7 cents to earnings a share on $8.5 billion in revenue. They would have 29 hospitals in the hotly competitive Southern California market, mainly in Los Angeles and Orange counties, outnumbering Columbia, which has 17 there and is acquiring four more. In south Florida, the new company would have 11 hospitals plus one Tenet is already acquiring.
"It strengthens their health care networks in two managed care hotbeds," said Randall S. Huyser, an analyst with Furman Selz.
Jeffrey C. Barbakow, chief executive of Tenet, said, "We can deliver quality at the prices that are demanded today."
But skeptics said that a number of Ornda's hospitals were in poor sections of Los Angeles and heavily dependent on Medicaid and Medicare payments now endangered by the pressure for Federal budget-cutting.
"The quality of the assets they are buying is very poor," said Todd Richter, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds. "It's a bad deal for the Tenet shareholder."
Kenneth S. Abramowitz, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, put a slightly different face on the deal, calling it "one of those good news, bad news stories." He said potential savings could increase earnings by 10 cents a share in 1998.
On the down side, though, "Tenet could have taken the money and theoretically bought more prestigious not-for-profit hospitals in various regions," Mr. Abramowitz said.
Mimi Willard, an analyst with Cowen & Company, said that the added size would improve Tenet's chances of forging new ventures with independent hospitals. "Before, it wasn't clear that they had enough size and clout to be a player for the long term," she said.
Indeed, speculation persisted that Columbia-HCA might step in and make an offer for Tenet. To forestall such a move, both Tenet and Ornda agreed to pay a $50 million penalty if the deal falls through from either side. And shareholders would then have options to buy big minority blocks of each other's stock.
Under the terms announced yesterday, each Ornda share would be exchanged for 1.35 shares of Tenet common stock, and Tenet would assume $1.37 billion of Ornda debt.
Analysts said that the price, including debt, was more than eight times Ornda's cash flow measured in revenues before interest on debt, depreciation and taxes. Mr. Huyser said that the price was "fair," but Mr. Richter said that it was higher than Columbia had paid when it absorbed three other big hospital chains.
Investor-owned hospital chains have been mainly buying nonprofits recently, and increasingly expanding from their bases in the Sun Belt to states like Massachusetts, Michigan and Ohio, where for-profit hospitals were an exotic novelty. "The key to size is to be big enough to get economies of scale and regional or even national managed care contracts," Mr. Huyser said.
Hospital stocks as a group have trailed the market, he said. Columbia-HCA is down 10 percent from its 52-week high, and Tenet was up about 5 percent before yesterday's announcement. Ornda, though, has risen 15 percent this year.
Officials of Tenet would take most of the key management jobs at the new company. Mr. Barbakow of Tenet would continue as chairman and chief executive of the combined company and Michael H. Focht would continue as its president and chief operating officer. Charles N. Martin Jr., the chief executive of Ornda, would become vice chairman of the new company.

HEADLINE: Corner Office Is Still G.O.P. Country;
Executives Back Dole Despite Clinton Record

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
If any class of Americans has reason to be content on the eve of this Presidential election, it is probably the nation's top executives. Nearly 9 of 10 say the condition of the economy is "good," up from the nearly half who said so four years ago. A solid majority believes that inflation has been tamed, and many of the companies that the executives run have bullish plans to invest and hire new employees in the coming year, according to a new New York Times/CBS News Poll.
The next recession? Not before 1999, according to nearly half the executives, and another 27 percent do not see a downturn coming until 1998. 
 Nonetheless, America's executive suites remain die-hard Republican territory. At a time when poll after poll of voters shows President Clinton ahead by double digits, 65 percent of the executives surveyed said that they preferred Bob Dole for President. Twenty-five percent said they would vote for Mr. Clinton -- just about the same level of support he got in 1992.
Like President Clinton, the top managers stress the importance of cutting the Federal budget deficit: 26 percent ranked it as the nation's chief economic problem, versus the 9 percent who said high taxes topped the list.
And a large portion of the executives, 41 percent, said that Mr. Dole's centerpiece plan to cut Federal income taxes by 15 percent was wrong for the country. Fifty-two percent favor the plan, but that figure falls to 19 percent if the tax cut would increase the deficit.
But 71 percent of the executives still said Mr. Dole would do a better job reducing the deficit, versus 18 percent for Mr. Clinton. And 63 percent said Mr. Dole's economic program would result in more growth, versus 26 percent who favored the President's. Executives appear to see no reason to vote for Mr. Clinton, despite the economy's strength.
"A lot of the good things that have happened have occurred despite Clinton, not because of him," declared David Hubers, the chief executive of American Express Financial Advisers in Minneapolis and one of several people who took part in the poll and agreed to be interviewed in depth afterward.
In fact, while 48 percent of the executives polled approved of the way Mr. Clinton was handling the economy, 44 percent disapproved. Executives said the kudos belonged to the Federal Reserve Board, which got the most credit from 42 percent of respondents, and to Congress, which got the nod from 28 percent. Only 16 percent said the White House was most responsible.
These were some of the key findings of a poll conducted by telephone from Sept. 25 to Oct. 11 with 442 top executives across the country. The sample comprised 109 executives from companies with revenues of more than $500 million, 119 from companies with revenues between $100 million and $500 million and 214 from companies with revenues between $5 million and $100 million.
The responses were weighted to reflect the actual distribution in the economy of companies of different sizes, and the poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus six percentage points.
Only 10 days ago, Mr. Clinton was trumpeting his support among the nation's business leaders. Surrounded by 300 executives at a campaign stop in Stamford, Conn., on Oct. 7, he boasted about the state of the economy; his campaign released the names of more than 2,500 executives across the country who had endorsed him.
The poll does show that executive appreciation for Mr. Clinton's economic stewardship nearly doubled the last two years. In April 1994, only 27 percent of business executives approved of the President's handling of the economy, while 67 percent disapproved.
But the new poll shows that Mr. Clinton is likely to get no more support from business leaders this year than he did in 1992, when 21 percent of executives said they voted for him -- a statistical dead heat with his current showing.
In a December 1992 poll, 53 percent of executives said they had voted for then-President George Bush, lower than Mr. Dole's current level of support, while Ross Perot, with 14 percent, had more support than his 4 percent showing now.
The premier campaign issue four years ago was the seemingly lackluster economy, which cost Mr. Bush votes among both executives and the public -- even though, as statistics later showed, the economy was growing at a robust 4.3 percent annual rate in the final months of the Bush Presidency.
But while Mr. Clinton has presided over most of this longest of postwar economic expansions, executives are not satisfied.
"The economy has to expand more quickly than it has," said Dan Akerson, the chief executive of Nextel Communications, a wireless telecommunications company based in McLean, Va. "Historically, it has grown at 3.5 percent a year, and during Clinton's tenure it has grown at 2.5 percent."
By a huge margin, 63 percent versus 26 percent, the executives believe that Mr. Dole's economic program will result in more economic growth than Mr. Clinton's economic plans.
Some of the executives' support for Mr. Dole, the poll demonstrated, is rooted in their preference for a minimalist government.
Nearly 9 of 10 said that government was doing too many things to solve problems that were better left to businesses and individuals. A mere 8 percent said that government should do more.
Forty-six percent of the executives said that government should do less to regulate the environmental and safety practices of the business community; just 14 percent said it should do more.
Such sentiments are not mirrored among the general public. In a New York Times/CBS News poll taken earlier in September, 27 percent of voters said government should do more to solve the country's problems, while 62 percent said it was doing too much. A majority of voters -- 53 percent -- want more environmental and safety regulation.
The executives were also tougher than the public on Mr. Clinton's overall performance.
Only 39 percent of the executives approved of the way Mr. Clinton has handled his job as President, while 54 percent disapproved. Among the general public, 58 percent approved and 32 percent disapproved, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll.
Beyond their philosophical differences with Mr. Clinton, some of the executives said in interviews that they were troubled by Mr. Clinton's character.
"I believe that the way President Clinton has conducted himself in office is wanting," said Irvine O. Hockaday, the chief executive of Hallmark Cards, who said he was not thrilled by the choice but planned to vote for Mr. Dole.
"We're at a stage in the evolution of our democracy where the power of example has become disproportionately important," Mr. Hockaday said. "The inconsistencies in delivering on his word and the way the White House has handled Whitewater and Filegate issues all add up to a counterproductive behavioral example."
It comes as little surprise, then, that nearly two-thirds of the executives believe that if Mr. Clinton wins a second term, he will reverse his stated course and seek to substantially increase spending on government programs.
Still, the executives expressed strong optimism about the business scene.
Forty-nine percent said that they would add workers in the next 12 months, up sharply from the 36 percent that expressed such plans two years ago. Only 6 percent said they expected staffing levels to fall, while 45 percent said staffing would remain steady.
Capital spending plans are even more robust, and few executives expressed worries about inflation. Completing the picture, executives said profits, which have been buoyant, would largely remain so. Just 13 percent of those polled predicted a downturn in their companies' earnings, while 34 percent expected profits to rise.
And how are the executives themselves doing? Fifty-one percent said that many chief executives were overpaid nowadays, although only 32 percent of executives at the biggest companies felt that way; over all, 33 percent said that chief executives were paid appropriately.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The New York Times/CBS News Poll of American business executives is based on telephone interviews, conducted from Sept. 25 to Oct. 11, with 442 senior executives at companies throughout the United States.
The sample of companies and executives called was randomly drawn by Survey Sampling Inc. of Fairfield, Conn., using the nationwide data base of both publicly owned and privately held companies maintained by Dun & Bradstreet Information Services.
Companies with $5 million or more in annual revenues were eligible for the survey. Within each company one executive at a senior level was interviewed. Titles eligible for the poll included owner, partner, chief executive, president, chairman, executive vice president, senior vice president, with first opportunity for an interview given to the most senior official.
The completed sample comprised 109 interviews in companies with annual revenues of $500 million or more, 119 interviews in companies with $100 million to $499 million and 214 interviews in companies with $5 million to $99 million in annual revenue. The combined total sample of 442 was then weighted by revenue size to reflect the actual distribution of all listed companies in the country because smaller companies predominate.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, results based on such samples will differ by no more than six percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out senior executives at all listed companies in the country with annual revenues of $5 million or more.
The potential sampling error for groups with fewer cases is larger. For example, for the biggest companies, those with $500 million or more in annual revenue, it is plus or minus nine percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey can introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.
