HEADLINE: Peso Strengthens and Mexican Stocks Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Mexican stocks rose for a second day after the peso strengthened and the Bank of Mexico cut borrowing costs, raising hopes that company earnings would benefit.
The bolsa index rose 25.46 points, or 0.78 percent, to 3288.47, after the peso rebounded to 13 cents each from 12.7 cents Wednesday and the central bank cut the cost of an overnight loan to 29.54 percent from 31.69 percent. 
 The Mexican currency, which had been relatively stable at about 13.3 American cents since midsummer, had fallen 3.3 percent since the beginning of last week.
Lower borrowing cost can boost economic growth, company earnings and the size of dividends paid shareholders. A stronger peso makes Mexican stocks worth more.
Even with the currency see-sawing in recent days, "Mexico is looking good, perhaps one the best markets in Latin America," said Francois Gour of Credit Lyonnais S. A. in New York. "At the end of the day, money will gravitate toward it."
With the currency near its weakest point in the last 11 months, sales and earnings at exporting companies should rise, as well as those of companies that depend on higher numbers of foreign tourists to profit.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Blue Chips Set Records, But Nasdaq Retreats 9.03
Blue-chip stocks set their third record of the week. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 38.39 points, to 6,059.20, and the S.& P. 500 stock index rose 2.58 points, to 706.99, as investors focused on consumer-product companies like Merck, P.& G. and Philip Morris.
In contrast, the Nasdaq composite retreated 9.03 points to 1,241.96, as traders took profits in computer and technology stocks. [Page D8.]
 
Buyers bid up Treasury prices, as a host of economic data showed growth slowing with little chance that inflation will pick up. The 30-year bond yield slipped to 6.80 percent. [D18.]
 
Silicon Graphics Reports Loss
Silicon Graphics reported a loss for its first quarter, surprising analysts who had expected a profit even after the company warned last month that its results would not meet their estimates. The loss marked the fifth consecutive quarter in which Silicon Graphics has underperformed expectations. [D4.]

Stronger Profits at Baby Bells
Bell Atlantic, BellSouth, Pacific Telesis and SBC Communications each posted stronger profits, as a result of rising demand for local phone services. [D4.]

Few Cracks in the Glass Ceiling
A study of America's 500 largest companies found that 10 percent of their officers were women, but only 2 percent of the companies' top five earners were women. [D4.]
 
American Woman for British Post
Marjorie M. Scardino, chief executive of the Economist Group, was named chief executive of Pearson, the media conglomerate. Ms. Scardino will be the first American to head Pearson and the only woman heading one of Britain's 100 largest publicly traded companies. [D7.]

Chrysler Penalized on Lemon Law
A California regulator ordered Chrysler to halt new car and truck shipments to the state for 45 days as punishment for selling 116 used vehicles without disclosing that they had been repurchased under the "lemon law." [D9.]

New York Sues Tobacco Companies
New York City sued tobacco companies to recoup the cost of caring for people with illnesses caused by smoking. The suit angered Philip Morris, one of the city's largest and most influential corporations. [B17.]

McDonnell Profit Tops Forecasts
McDonnell Douglas reported a rise in earnings on improved performance by its military and commercial aircraft businesses. [D2.]
 
An Unpopular $1.7 Billion Deal
Analysts and investors did not think much of the $1.7 billion purchase of Ornda Healthcorp by Tenet Healthcare. Market Place. [D8.]

A Rare Look Back for MTV
MTV is taking a rare look back in a retrospective of 15 years of its advertising and promotional efforts, including promotions for spring break beach parties and a "Choose or Lose" voter registration drive.Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]

What Dole Leaves Unsaid on Taxes
Bob Dole calls for a new tax system. But, knowing that any change would produce losers as well as winners, he has offered no specific alternative to the current system. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Dow and S.& P. 500 Hit 3d Highs This Week; Nasdaq Is Off

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks marched to record highs yesterday for the third time this week as interest rates fell.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 38.39 points, to 6,059.20, down slightly from a 45-point gain that briefly put the Dow within 35 points of 6,100 just three days after its first close above 6,000. 
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks also notched its third new high this week, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index, also dominated by blue chips and other larger companies, closed at record levels after a 10-day drought.
The Nasdaq market, dominated by technology issues, retreated, however, pressured by more profit taking in computer stocks, whose shares had rallied in advance of this week's strong earnings reports.
With few eye-catching earnings reports like those that dominated the last two sessions, many investors focused on consumer product concerns like Merck, Procter & Gamble and Philip Morris, whose fairly reliable revenues are looking increasingly attractive with each new hint of a moderating economy.
The Government offered several such suggestions yesterday morning, reporting that construction of new homes and apartments fell 6 percent last month to the lowest level of 1996, while industrial production inched up just two-tenths of 1 percent.
Bonds rallied on the news, which reinforced other recent indications that robust demand was easing enough to contain inflationary pressures without an interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve.
As bond prices rose, the yield on the 30-year Treasury -- a key determinant of corporate and consumer borrowing costs -- fell to 6.80 percent, from 6.85 percent Wednesday.
"The overall picture indicates that we are in an extended period of rest and recuperation after a pretty fast sprint earlier this year," Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said.
But he also cautioned that "this R & R will probably end fairly soon," noting other recent indications that consumers have jobs, income and confidence -- all the right ingredients for a healthy holiday season.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by nearly a 7-to-5 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume was heavy at 478.6 million shares.
The Standard & Poor's 500 rose 2.58, to 706.99, and the New York Stock Exchange index rose 1.88, to 376.41, leaping past the Oct. 7 record close of 374.74.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 9.03 points, to 1,241.96.
As expected, AT&T reported a drop in third-quarter profits, while Apple Computer joined the stream of good results from the technology sector with late Wednesday's report of an unexpected profit for the June-September period. AT&T, a component of the Dow, was unchanged, at 39 7/8, while Apple was up 5/8, at 26 3/8. It was among the most-active issues on Nasdaq.
Merck, up 2 7/8, at 74 7/8, was the Dow's biggest gainer, benefiting from a brokerage upgrade prompted by the drug maker's better-than-expected earnings report on Wednesday. Procter & Gamble up 1 1/2, to 97 1/2, and Philip Morris, up 1 1/2, at 97 3/8, also lifted the Dow.
Coca-Cola rose 3/4, to 49 1/4, after the company announced plans to buy back up to another 10 percent of its shares over the next 10 years.
Cirrus Logic fell 2 3/4, to 21 1/4. The chip maker reported a profit of about $3 million, or 5 cents a share, for its second quarter ended Sept. 28. Some analysts had predicted a loss for the quarter, but the results were well below a profit of $33 million, or 47 cents a share, in the similar period a year earlier.
Northwest Airlines gained 1 1/2, to 32, after the company said its third-quarter profits rose 9.9 percent. But Northwest cautioned that fuel costs, a weak Japanese yen and reinstatement of a 10 percent Federal ticket tax would continue to affect fourth-quarter results.
Among initial public offerings, Metro Networks, a provider of traffic reports, local news, sports and weather to television and radio broadcasters, surged to 20 1/2 from its share pricing of 16.

SECTION: Section A; Page 27; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: POLITICS: CAMPAIGN FINANCE;
Business Is Biggest Political Donor, Dwarfing Labor's Contribution, Study Says

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
In one of the most comprehensive studies to date, a private research group projected today that this year's Presidential race would cost $800 million, three times as much as the 1992 campaign, and that another $800 million would be spent on Congressional races.
Although Republicans have complained about spending by organized labor, the largest source of money for all candidates is business, said the study, by the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonprofit group that studies campaign finance. 
 In this election cycle, business has raised $242.4 million, most of which has gone to Republicans, while organized labor has raised $35 million, most of it for Democrats.
"Money is not coming from ordinary Americans," said Ellen Miller, the research group's executive director. "American elections are paid for, overwhelmingly by economically interested industries and a small handful of individuals."
Ms. Miller added, "We have a political system paid for by Wall Street, not Main Street -- and also paid for by Tobacco Road."
The big force behind this surge in financing for Federal campaigns has been a new activism by business political action committees, as well as a growth in "soft dollar" contributions -- money given to national political parties, which spend it on Presidential and Congressional races. The biggest business donor and soft-dollar contributor is Wall Street, which has given nearly $60 million, mostly to Republicans.
A loophole allows donors to avoid Federal campaign finance restrictions if they give to the national parties rather than to individual candidates. Direct contributions to Federal candidates are capped at $1,000 from individuals and $5,000 from businesses.
The $800 million for the Presidential race is composed of Federal matching funds to the candidates, soft dollars to the Republican and Democratic Party Committees, money to political action committees and direct individual donations to candidates. Soft dollars and business donations have swelled contributions to the Presidential race, but spending on Congressional races is only slightly above the 1994 level.
In this year's elections, one of the biggest turnarounds in fund-raising techniques is in the use of political action committees by business to funnel money to Congressional candidates. Long considered a financing tool of organized labor and used mainly for Democratic candidates, PAC money goes mostly to Republican candidates, who now get $3 for every $1 received by Democrats. The change occurred right after the Republicans won control of both houses of Congress in the 1994 elections.
"When the Republicans took over all these chairmanships and subcommittees, they reaped a whirlwind of money," said Larry Makinson, the research group's deputy director. "Even some of the labor PAC's were giving more to Republicans than Democrats."
Donations to Republicans from political action committees, mostly organized by business, has increased by 87 percent in this election cycle to $71.3 million, from $38.2 million in the 1994 races. The financial services industry, Wall Street and insurance, has by itself contributed $21.5 million, up from $18.1 million in 1994. Republicans are getting 90 percent more and Democrats 36 percent less from this industry than in 1994.
Political action committee contributions to Democrats have fallen by more than 20 percent; Democrats received $71.8 million in 1994 but have received only $55.4 million in this election cycle.
Organized labor's political action committee donations have remained almost constant. Labor, which supports Democrats almost exclusively, is giving about the same in the 1996 Congressional races, $26.6 million, as it did in the 1994 races, when it gave $24.2 million.
This imbalance may be somewhat offset by labor's plans to spend $35 million more on advertisements independent of the candidates and in support of Democratic candidates. This $35 million is not included in the tabulations by the Center for Responsive Politics. Business groups have also vowed to spend about $20 million on such independent ads, which are also not included in the data from the research group.
The financial services industry, which includes Wall Street, insurance and real estate, is the biggest industry giver of soft money: $59.8 million, 64 percent of it for Republicans. The largest corporate donor is Philip Morris, which has given $2.7 million, 78 percent of it to Republicans, followed by AT&T, which has given $2.2 million, 60 percent to Republicans.
Both major parties have vowed to raise about $120 million in soft-dollar donations for their Presidential campaigns. Most of it is coming from business, provoking criticism that political fund raising has turned into a game of selling access.
"Our campaign finance system is a quid pro quo to all manner of interests," said Ms. Miller of the research group. "When candidates for political office solicit and receive big bucks for their political campaigns, big favors are incurred. Both parties know it. Both parties do it."
The next largest donor is "miscellaneous business," which has given $37 million, nearly two-thirds of it to Republicans, followed by organized labor, which has raised more than $35 million, almost all of it for Democratic candidates. Agricultural companies have given $24 million, mostly to Republicans, while the telecommunications and electronics industry has given $24 million, almost divided evenly between the two parties.
The Association of Trial Lawyers of America is the biggest contributor to the Democrats, which has received more than 80 percent of the association's $2.1 million in contributions. Trial lawyers have long opposed Republican efforts to restrict lawsuits against business.
Other big soft-dollar donors are Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, the Canadian distiller's American subsidiary, which has given about $1 million (over half to Democrats); Atlantic Richfield, the oil company, which has given about $1 million (two-thirds to Republicans), and MCI Communications, the long-distance carrier, which has given $767,000 (over half to Democrats).

HEADLINE: A Cable Monopoly

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Providing an outlet in New York City for a diversity of television news channels and live cable coverage of the City Council, as proposed by Gene Russianoff (Op-Ed, Oct. 16), would strengthen the life and and the economy of the city.
New Yorkers would not allow a main thoroughfare like Madison Avenue to be controlled by a single retailer. Yet, the allocation of cable channels raises concerns when we allow one company, Time Warner, to control the system and many of the sources of cable programming. 
 This city is the nation's center for production of news and nonfiction entertainment. We should consider how its cable television systems can serve the interests of the city as a whole.
 
MITCHELL L. MOSS
New York, Oct. 16, 1996
 
The writer is director, Taub Urban Research Center, New York Univ.

HEADLINE: Expand Javits Center

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Jacob K. Javits Convention Center has indeed been turned around under the administration of Gov. George E. Pataki ("Progress of the Javits Center," editorial, Oct. 12). Crime has been virtually eliminated, and the work force is being motivated by the most powerful incentive to provide customer satisfaction -- keeping their jobs.
There is a problem, however: a severe and growing lack of available dates. The center is in the middle of the pack in terms of square footage and is falling behind every day as our major convention city competitors -- Las Vegas, Chicago and Los Angeles -- all continue to expand. Shows that wish to come here are being turned away. 
 By the end of the decade, New York will become the equivalent of a third world city, convention wise.
A trade show producer myself, I have three fashion industry trade shows at the center this month that will contribute 10,000 hotel night stays to the city's economy, as well as innumerable taxi rides, restaurant meals and theater tickets. My shows are typical.
Much coverage of the center focuses on whether it makes a profit. The $600 million or so that the state spent building the center would be a poor investment indeed if its goal was simply to make $1 million or $2 million.
We need to plan an expansion of the center, so that two of the city's brightest industries, tourism and conventions, can continue to power our economy into the next millennium.
 
DAVID LARKIN
New York, Oct. 15, 1996

HEADLINE: Dollar Up vs. Yen in New York and Tokyo

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar surged against the Japanese yen yesterday, bolstered by Japanese investors seeking higher returns abroad, and by reports showing a narrowing trade gap between the United States and Japan.
With Japan's interest rates at record lows, investors there are looking to the United States and other countries for higher-yielding investments. 
 "There is still a lot of investment interest out of Japan in the U.S. markets," which is helping the dollar, Seth Garrett, a director of foreign exchange at CS First Boston, said.
The dollar received a lift in Tokyo trading, climbing to 112.63 yen, after Japan said its trade surplus shrank more than 30 percent in September.
In New York trading, the dollar briefly slumped, then recovered, after the United States said its trade deficit fell almost 7 percent in August, a smaller drop than many analysts had expected. The dollar settled at 112.47 yen, up from 112.22 yen on Thursday. It was little changed at 1.5422 marks, down slightly from 1.5429 marks. The British pound rose to $1.5885, from $1.5860.

LENGTH: 562 words

HEADLINE: An Ivy-Covered Shell Game

BYLINE: By William D. Hansen; William D. Hansen, Assistant Secretary of Education in the Bush Administration, is executive director of the Education Finance Council.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When it comes to paying for college, are Americans better off today than they were four years ago? Will they be better off four years from now, if President Clinton is re-elected? The answers, unfortunately, are no and no.
Mr. Clinton has tried to alleviate anxiety over college costs, but so far his education programs have done little to help middle-class or poor families pay for college. 
 If re-elected, the President promises to create the Hope Scholarship program, which would allow families to deduct up to $10,000 in tuition from their annual taxable income or take a tax credit of $1,500 for the first two years of college.
Sounds good. But Robert Reischauer, former director of the Congressional Budget Office, wrote that the proposal, which could cost $43 billion over six years, is "bad tax policy and worse education policy."
Why is the tax credit bad policy? First, it would give families no real purchasing power, because colleges would have little incentive to hold down their prices. They could simply work this tax break into their annual tuition calculations.
Second, the tax credit would do nothing for the nearly four million low-income students who receive Pell grants. Under the Clinton plan, they would not qualify for the tax credit.
This proposal builds upon other misguided Clinton education policies. During the 1992 campaign, Mr. Clinton proudly touted his direct student loan proposal. He claimed college would be more affordable because direct loans would offer students lower monthly payments.
In actuality, the private sector usually offers lower interest rates and lower fees than does his direct loan program. And in many cases, monthly direct-loan repayments amount to less than the accruing interest, so the outstanding balance can grow dramatically. The Government forgives any unpaid balance after 25 years, but the Internal Revenue Service will treat the forgiven amount as taxable income.
So a student who borrows $50,000, for example, could have an unpaid- loan balance of $79,000 after 25 years. This borrower would then have to pay $22,000 in Federal income taxes on that unpaid balance, and the taxpayers would get stuck with the remaining $57,000.
Similarly, President Clinton's Americorps national service program has turned out to be incredibly expensive and inefficient. Taxpayers pay $400 million to help only 25,000 students. That means Federal aid goes to only one out of every 750 college students -- who receive something like $30,000 each.
The President deserves some credit for securing the most generous Pell grants ever in the 1997 budget. But in his first three years of office, Mr. Clinton reduced these grants twice, and recommended sharply cutting other forms of financial aid, such as the work-study program.
The Department of Education delivers basically the same number of grants, college loans and campus awards that it did four years ago -- only now it spends hundreds of millions more a year to do the same thing. President Clinton seriously thinks that the department should become America's third-largest bank, displacing private loan providers.
Helping families pay for a quality college education can best be achieved by improving, enhancing and simplifying existing programs and eliminating those that don't work -- not by creating inefficient new programs or tax credits.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); 

COMPANY: CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET OFFICE (56%); CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET OFFICE (56%);

HEADLINE: A Good Law Yields More Voters

 BODY:
An encouraging new study finds that an impressive 12 million potential voters have been added to registration rolls because of the National Voter Registration Act -- popularly known as the motor-voter law. The new law, which went into effect last year, required states to allow people to register by mail. Citizens now can easily register when they obtain a driver's license or visit other government agencies like unemployment and public assistance offices.
While a party breakdown for motor-voter registration is not yet available, overall registration numbers do not show the surge of new Democratic voters that some Republicans feared. Continuing a 30-year trend, Democratic registration fell about 1 percent over the past year, from 50 to 49 percent, while Republican registration remained steady at 34 percent. The number of new voters registering as Independents showed a small increase, from 16 to 17 percent. 
 There is no telling what impact the increase in registration will have on next month's elections. Much depends on which, and how many, of the new registrants actually cast ballots. But over the long term, the nation is enhanced when more Americans are eligible to participate in the core ritual of democracy. On this score, the motor-voter law is proving its worth.

HEADLINE: Slow Changes in Japan

 BODY:
After four Prime Ministers in three years, Japanese voters had hoped that their next parliamentary election might bring a measure of political stability. Instead, balloting tomorrow seems likely to produce a new period of confusion and jockeying among familiar players. All the major candidates say they favor a Japan that is more open and free of regulations, with a foreign policy more independent of the United States. But voters remain conservative and skeptical about the possibilities of reform.
Japan is slowly emerging from one of its worst recessions in modern history, and economic issues are a major factor in a campaign that sometimes sounds similar to the American election debate. One challenger for prime minister, Ichiro Ozawa, has gone the route of Bob Dole, advocating a sharp reduction in business and personal taxes. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, the front-runner, argues that the deficit is too high and Japan will have to increase taxes to support its increasingly aged population with health and social benefits. 
 Mr. Hashimoto, the head of the long-running Liberal Democratic Party, is way ahead in the polls. Mr. Ozawa, who broke from the Liberal Democrats several years ago, is foundering, in part because Japanese voters do not believe he can carry out his promises.
The opinion polls may be less reliable than usual this year because Japan has revamped its electoral system. The changes, which call for each district to be represented by only one member of Parliament, were designed to eliminate smaller parties and allow for the emergence of one strong centrist party to challenge the Liberal Democrats. That has not yet happened. The Liberal Democrats remain the favorite to win as they face a challenge from several smaller parties, all of them fighting each other.
The new system was also supposed to cut back on the money pouring into politics from business and special interests, which has had such a corrupting effect in the last decade. The flow of money has diminished a bit, but mostly because falling profits have left many corporations unable to make large contributions.
For the United States, the apparent strength of Mr. Hashimoto's Liberal Democrats poses the same dilemma that Washington has faced for years. The party is the most resistant to reforms that Americans believe could open Japan to American exports and services. But the party has such strong roots in the bureaucracy and other elites that it can usually deliver on the promises it does make to Washington. Mr. Hashimoto is further prized in Washington because of the skillful way he has defused anger in Okinawa over the behavior of American troops there and renewed the strategic alliance with the United States.
Japanese voters have grown increasingly impatient with the Government's insensitivity to their needs. Their views have been reinforced by a recent scandal in which the Government invited the spread of AIDS by callously barring imports of safe blood products in order to give Japanese drug companies time to develop their own versions. No matter who wins these elections, the voters are likely to remain cynical if their leaders continue allowing business interests to keep the economy closed.

HEADLINE: Drinking Leads to Dismissal Of 1 of 2 Black Simpson Jurors

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 18

 BODY:
The only black man on the jury in the civil case against O. J. Simpson was removed today because of a drinking problem and replaced with a white man.
The move to dismiss the man -- who believed Mr. Simpson might have been framed by the police -- came less than a day after the jury was seated. 
 His removal required a brief reopening of jury selection, during which a white aspiring firefighter and a white woman who once met Simpson in a shoe store, were also removed from the panel under the defense and prosecution lawyers' peremptory challenges. They were replaced by two white jurors.
By the end of the day, the jury had one fewer black member than it did a day before. It had nine whites, one black, one person of mixed race and one Hispanic. The only black member is a woman in her 60's.
Superior Court Judge Hiroshi Fujisaki sent the new jury home with a warning to avoid information about the case. "There are numerous experts out there that have their fingers in the past case or this case," he said. "They are flooding the media. I don't want you to be affected by any of that."
He told the jurors to return for opening statements on Wednesday. Eight alternates remain to be chosen.
The families of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman are suing Mr. Simpson for unspecified damages, contending that he is responsible for their slayings.
The only black man on the jury sworn in Thursday, Edgar Allen, was removed after four others in the jury pool told the judge they smelled alcohol on his breath. The judge found him "incapable of and unsuitable for jury service in this case."
"Because of his use of alcohol he is excused from this case," the judge said.
Mr. Allen, a black postal worker retired from the Air Force, acknowledged to reporters, "I'm an alcoholic." But he denied he had been drinking while on jury duty.
He said he had gone home on Wednesday night and drank gin and beer, which left a smell on his breath the next day.
Mr. Allen told lawyers during the questioning phase that he had been married several times and he was now in an interracial marriage. He said he thought Mr. Simpson might have been framed by the police.
The white man who replaced him is an unemployed cement finisher in his 40's or 50's who said he had doubts about the evidence presented in the Simpson case.
Nine blacks were on the jury that acquitted Mr. Simpson last October in the 1994 slayings. In that trial, two jurors were removed before testimony began and a total of 10 were replaced by the end of the trial. That jury was mostly black from start to finish.
At his criminal trial, Mr. Simpson's lawyers argued he was the victim of a racist police frame-up. They are expected to use the same defense this time. Polls have shown that blacks are far more likely than whites to believe Mr. Simpson is innocent.

HEADLINE: Bosnian Serbs Said to Hide Big Supplies of Heavy Arms

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The Bosnian Serbs have far more heavy weapons than they formally declared and have resorted to subterfuge to avoid destroying their excessive stock, said Western officials who have been meeting here for the last two days.
The violations of the Balkans arms reduction agreement were determined by the officials who have been exchanging intelligence information in closed meetings here. 
 The greatest discrepancy is in the number of artillery pieces, the weapons that terrorized Sarajevo and laid waste to villages throughout Bosnia, according to American and European intelligence agencies.
The Serbs say they have some 1,350 artillery pieces, while the average of the assessments of intelligence agencies from five countries puts the number at 2,500, said a senior European military officer.
The Serbs are also trying to save more than half their tanks from the scrap heap by designating 300 of them for export or use in research and development, a proposition Western officials find preposterous.
"This is dangerous, this is provocative," a senior official with the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said of the Serbs' conduct. "It can lead to the whole arms control agreement falling apart." The organization, based in Vienna, oversees the agreement.
The officials meeting here to discuss the matter included representatives from the so-called contact group on Bosnia: Germany, Britain, France, Italy and the United States, as well as the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. Russia, a contact group member, did not attend.
The arms control agreement, concluded earlier this year, sets limits on the number of tanks, armored personnel carriers, artillery pieces, combat jets and helicopters that Yugoslavia, Croatia, the Muslim-Croat Federation and the Bosnian Serb Republic can have. It requires the various Governments to destroy stocks in order to achieve those levels. Exempt from destruction are particular weapons intended for export or for use in research and development programs.
Officials said that all the parties had skirted the edges of full and honest disclosure under the treaty, or, as one NATO official put it, they have been "economical with the truth."
The Croatian Government, for example, has some 500 more artillery pieces than reported, a NATO military officer said. But American and European officials said that the Bosnian Serb violations were the most egregious.
"Cheating and abusing" is how an official of the European security organization with access to the intelligence information described the Serbs' actions. While American and European diplomats are alarmed, it is not clear how far they are willing to go to confront the Serbs. The NATO Secretary General, Javier Solano, and John Kornblum, Assistant Secretary of State, plan to raise the matter with Bosnian Serb leaders within the next week, a NATO official said. But officials acknowledge that talk alone is not likely to persuade the Serbs to make changes.
The most decisive and effective way to bring the Serbs into compliance with the treaty would be for the NATO forces in Bosnia to destroy the weapons. But no one thinks that NATO, which has continually sought to restrict its mission, is going to undertake such a task.
Another option, said a senior American diplomat involved in Bosnian policy, would be for the Americans to provide more weapons to the Muslim-Croat Federation army under an "equip and train" program, which is already in progress.
While trying to come up with a common policy on confronting the Serbs, Western intelligence agencies are still skirmishing over the exact numbers.
At the low end, French intelligence puts the number of Serbian artillery pieces at 1,374, while British intelligence says the Serbs have 2,584 pieces, which is close to the number the Italians have come up with; the C.I.A.'s number is even higher.
Under the arms control agreement, the Serbs are entitled to only 500 artillery pieces.
Officials of the Bosnian Serb Republic declared that its army had 1,355 artillery pieces. But that does not mean it intends to destroy 855 of them. Indeed, the Serbs say they have to destroy only 79 artillery pieces because, they say, 776 are to be used in research and development or exported.
On the matter of tanks, the Serbs have declared that 168 out of the 493 in their inventory are intended for export. But NATO officers note that many of these tanks are of World War II vintage, and it is hard to imagine who would buy them.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Turning Hopes Into Reality In the Bronx

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
ASTIN JACOBO sat in the bleachers of his favorite Bronx ball park, the Yankees logo on his cap positively glowing in the dusky shadows that descended on this patch of earth. He was in a special place, as hallowed to him as another ball park, where the World Series is to open tonight.
Yankee Stadium is a few miles to the south. This one is in the center of the Bronx, and his heart. It's the Mapes Athletic Field, a place for Little Leaguers with big dreams. It's on a block in Crotona that emerged in the 1980's from the charred buildings and soggy lots left by the fires that once flashed through the borough, like the one broadcast to the country by Howard Cosell during the 1977 Series. 
 Jacob -- nobody, from mayors to mothers, calls him Mr. Jacobo -- grimaces at that remembrance.
"In the 1970's there were fires, I know that," he said impatiently. "But people should know that one fire is extinguished with another fire. Sometimes you have to be careful and see that when a community is going down, instead of adding more firewood they should help put it out."
He did. Since coming to this neighborhood 27 years ago, Jacob has been on a mission to rebuild Crotona with renovated and new housing, corner gardens and a stray ball field or two. He jokes that the fires and chaos used to be so bad in the 1970's that you could dance to the musical mayhem of fire alarms, bells and sirens. Not anymore.
UNFORTUNATELY, this neighborhood isn't where you'd find George M. Steinbrenner 3d or any of the other Bronx bashers who would like to move the Yankees someplace else.
"Yes, Steinbrenner has the money put into the team," he said. "But we have our pride and future and spirit."
There once was a time that the only fire Jacob knew was the kind hurled by the young Dominican ballplayers he scouted for the Houston Astros. Bad times at home forced him to move to the United States, where he settled into a job as the custodian of St. Martin of Tours Elementary School. He knew sports and he knew young people, so he nudged them into teams. Through the children he got to the parents, persuading them to band together and fight for rebuilt apartment buildings, safe streets and better schools.
"From nothing, we started playing ball," he said. "And when the buildings burned, we put the kids into them so people wouldn't strip them of the pipes. The kids would stay with the family until the city or the landlord would come and fix it."
When slash-and-burn was the rule of the day in Bronx housing, Jacob dreamed up some new plays to prevent the wrecking ball from finishing what the arsonist had started. Only one family was living at 785 East 181st Street when the city decided to demolish it. Jacob cajoled officials to visit the building before they razed it.
HE raced back to the neighborhood and rounded up a half-dozen people to move into the almost-empty building, asking them to stay only until the housing officials had visited. It worked. Today the yellow-brick building is a low-income co-op, spotless and quiet as it rises behind the Mapes Athletic Field.
"This has been out of this world," Jacob said with a smile and gaze that lock on you. "The changes we've seen."
It might as well be another world for the thousands of baseball fans who will descend on the Bronx today with hardly a glance to the rest of the place. If a village arises from the ruins and no one comes to see it, does it really exist?
Mayor Edward I. Koch used to visit often, ever since Jacob challenged him to do so at a 1983 Town Hall meeting. Jacob credits the former Mayor and the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, with providing the encouragement and money to embark on the rebuilding of Crotona.
Before he took to wearing his Yankees cap late this season, Jacob usually sported a green cap in honor of Mr. Koch. The green, to him, symbolized the new life found in the gardens, houses and ball fields that were reclaimed from the rubble. He has yet to find a hat for the current Mayor, who he says has yet to visit.
"It doesn't take nothing for a leader to come to the people," Jacob said. "If we don't see your face, how can we trust you? You don't have to talk a lot to change a community. It's the people who devote themselves to the job."
That's good advice for a certain team owner too. It comes from a man whose eye for talent and potential is equally keen on the diamond or on the street. A man who, with no regrets, gave up the big leagues for the Bronx.

HEADLINE: FUTUTES MARKETS;
U.S. Energy Chief Rejects Action To Push Heating Oil Price Down

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Hazel R. O'Leary, the Secretary of Energy, said today that the Goverment would not intervene to ease a sharp rise in heating oil prices.
After meeting with oil company executives and some industry experts for about an hour today, Mrs. O'Leary said that it would make no sense for the Government or "Big Brother to go and buy heating oil and put it in storage," when homeowners and truckers needed it to meet the demand for the season. 
 Speaking to reporters at the Energy Department, she said that the department would look at a proposal to stockpile such products when they are in short supply but that no action would be taken during the current heating season.
"I don't see an impending crisis," she said. "I see a tight market. My job is to watch this."
Expectations that no change in policy would come from Mrs. O'Leary bolstered heating oil futures prices today on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Heating oil for November delivery jumped 1.77 cents, to 74.06 cents a gallon.
Other energy prices were also higher today. The November crude oil contract climbed 37 cents, to $25.79 a barrel, the highest price since Jan. 16, 1991, and November gasoline rose 1.41 cents, to 67.94 cents a gallon.
Representatives and senators from the Northeast and some consumer groups have urged Mrs. O'Leary to intervene and sell off part of the crude oil in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve and to stockpile heating oil.
Prices to consumers have gone up in recent weeks for heating oil and diesel even as the industry is stepping up production. Despite the pickup in production, inventories continue to fall and are far below last year's levels. On Thursday, the Energy Department reported that stocks of heating oil and other distillate fuels fell 900,000 barrels last week to 111.4 million barrels.
Heating oil stocks are particularly lean on the East Coast, which uses two-thirds of all heating oil in the United States.
Prices have also begun to rise on the retail level, with some distributors reporting that consumers are already paying 10 to 15 cents more a gallon for heating oil compared with last year.
The reason that refiners find themselves with low inventories resembles the pattern of last spring, when gasoline prices surged.
Refiners sought to keep inventories low late last summer, believing that the price of crude oil would fall when Iraq, under an agreement with the United Nations, re-entered the world oil market. But that planned limited sale of oil has since been suspended.
Even with refiners now operating at almost full capacity, they have been unable to rebuild the stockpiles for distillates. Strong demand for diesel fuel by the trucking industry as a result of brisk economic growth and an incentive to export low-sulfur diesel fuel to Europe has helped to keep down the stockpiles of heating oil.
Since diesel and heating oil are refined from the same part of crude oil, strong demand for diesel has had an effect on heating oil production.
Of the 20 companies invited to today's meeting with Mrs. O'Leary, 16 sent representatives, including officials from Amerada Hess, Exxon, Mobil, Texaco and Shell Oil, a subsidiary of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group.
Two refiners at the meeting pledged to take steps to stave off a potential heating oil shortage. The Tosco Corporation said it would increase output from its refinery in Linden, N.J., earlier than planned.
And the Citgo Petroleum Corporation, which is owned by Petroleos de Venezuela, offered to delay planned maintenance at a refinery in Lake Charles, La.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: Campaign Trail;
THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

 BODY:

Movie Money
In mid-September, when President Clinton was in Beverly Hills at the sumptuous estate of the supermarket magnate Ron Burkle, he broke bread with some of Hollywood's biggest names and raising $4 million for the Democratic cause.
The President was back in California on Thursday. He was at the sumptuous estate of the supermarket magnate Ron Burkle, breaking bread, etc., etc. 
 Lunch for 200 at the 10-acre, three-Monet Burkle spread, built in the 1920's by the silent-film star Harold Lloyd, was a mere appetizer in a day-long menu of political money-collecting. Mr. Clinton also led a fund-raiser for Dick Swett, the New Hampshire Democrat running neck and neck for a Senate seat now held by a Republican, Robert C. Smith.
That night, he also attended a fund-raiser on the Universal Studios lot with Michael Douglas, Mr. Clinton's alter-ego in the 1995 film "The American President," as master of ceremonies. ("I sort of thought I should be up here introducing him tonight," the President joked.)
All told, campaign officials said, the events took in about $5 million. Two other fund-raising sprees scheduled in the next week or so are expected to raise another $10 million for the Democratic National Committee and the party's House and Senate political arms.
The timing might have seemed unfortunate, given the developing furor over potentially illegal Democratic Party contributions solicited in part by an Indonesian colleague of the President. Mr. Clinton's strategists were said to be unfazed. Republicans, too, have "all fed at this trough," said the campaign's spokesman, Joe Lockhart.
 
Dole in Junior High
Meanwhile, Bob Dole appeared before a Denver audience on Friday to unleash a biting attack on President Clinton's trustworthiness and offer detailed explanations of the Dole-Kemp platform on taxes, Medicare and Social Security. The crowd went absolutely wild.
Unfortunately, they couldn't vote: Mr. Dole was addressing the sixth-, seventh- and eighth-grade classes of the Place Middle School.
Standing before a banner reading "Bob Dole: choice of the next generation" and accompanied by the disco-style beat of the group Black Box, Mr. Dole gave the 12- to 14-year-olds much of the same stump speech he gives baby boomers and retirees out in the workaday world.
It was one of the stolid campaign's odder moments, enhanced by the fact that Mr. Dole's audience had the fervor of a Republican rally in Orange County, Calif.
"Maybe some of the young people may not fully comprehend all of this," Mr. Dole began. Demonstrating why this might be so, he explained the percentage differences in the growth of Federal spending under his economic plan and that of the Clinton Administration, adding, "For the family earning $30,000, that $1,261 -- that's about an 86 percent tax cut."
Mr. Dole promised them that he would cut the capital-gains tax in half. (Squeals of delight.) He led the crowd in a cheerleader-style chant of his campaign's slogan, "It's your money!" (Pandemonium.) He denounced teachers' unions. He denounced the flow of foreign political money into Democratic coffers.
He accused Mr. Clinton of attempting to scare America's elderly into believing that he would cut their Medicare benefits.
"I haven't seen any seniors in here," he told the youths. "But in case any senior citizens show up: We're not going to cut day care. We're not going to cut Social Security. We're going to increase Medicare spending by 39 percent under our plan. And Social Security is going to be increased by 34 percent."
For some reason, Mr. Dole left out one part of the platform: he did not discuss his plan to reduce the estate tax. MICHAEL WINES

HEADLINE: Money Does Grow On Trees;
Turning Fall's Many Colors Into Basic Green

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
In towns and villages from Maine to New York's Catskills, a sure sign of fall has long been the throngs of visitors who come to admire the annual color spectacular put on by dying leaves.
Now, though, autumn's splendor has also become big business in higher elevations and cooler climes from coast to coast. 
 In many locales, leaves are the basis of a whole new tourism season, as growing numbers of visitors travel long distances -- even from overseas -- to join day-tripping leaf watchers in creating traffic jams along the back roads of America year after year. New England still draws the largest crowds, most tourist dollars and biggest traffic snarls,but unlikely states like Georgia and Arizona are also luring spectators to the southward-marching fireworks.
The peak season is blazingly brief -- a week or two at best in any one area -- so local merchants have only a small window of opportunity to rake in tourists' dollars. The timing can vary, at the whim of the crisp nights needed to turn the leaves red and gold. Visitors who fail to time things just right can wind up looking at green, or bare, trees.
And the competition to promote one locality's display over every other's has grown sharp. Frustrated tourists have found, for example, that some states' foliage hot lines have been known to put the most colorful spin on nature's wonders.
Still, foliage fans are traveling in droves, many arriving in their own cars on weekends or mini-vacations, but tens of thousands come on bus tours that last up to 10 days and can easily cost $1,500.
"It was like seeing what God can do with His paintbrush," said Philip Kent, a retired civil servant from South Pasadena, Calif., who with his wife, Gloria, recently returned from a weeklong foliage bus tour of four New England states. "It's more than indescribably beautiful, it's a spiritual experience."
Last October alone, more than 600 tour buses visited Newport, R.I., a popular way station on foliage tours, as well as a reminder of America's gilded age. This year even more buses are expected to make their way to Newport, and 10 ships on foliage cruises have docked there in recent weeks, including Cunard's venerable QE2. The cost of a five-day cruise? From $1,100 to $4,400 a person.
While fall foliage has long been inseparable from spirituality, esthetics and love of nature, it is economics that is transforming it into big business. States and communities that only recently took the changing leaves for granted have come to realize their economic potential, especially as they have seen leaf watchers fill hotels, restaurants and bed and breakfasts that in the past were shuttered soon after Labor Day.
"Many people who have seen the foliage in New England now want to see it in West Virginia, Pennsylvania Dutch country or on Mackinac Island" in Michigan, said Carol Snyder, a spokeswoman for Maupintour in Lawrence, Kan., a tour company that offers dozens of foliage trips.
States and communities are also successfully marketing autumn to foreign tourists.
"International tourists are our fastest-growing group, especially tourists from the United Kingdom and Germany," said David C. DePetrillo, director of tourism in Rhode Island. Britain does have its own fall foliage, "but it's nowhere near as spectacular as in New England," acknowledged Robin Prestage, press relations executive for the British Tourist Authority in New York.
With that in mind, many states, including all six in New England, have sent delegations abroad to woo tour operators and travel agents, and they have invited foreign journalists to see autumn's grandeur for themselves, which has usually resulted in favorable articles back home.
Perhaps less predictably, Sedona, Ariz., a popular winter tourist town between Phoenix and the Grand Canyon, spent about $50,000 last year underwriting such trips, and this foliage season the town has been rewarded with a big increase in British visitors.
"Leaf-changing visitors have made September and October our best two months," said Frank R. Miller, executive director of the Sedona-Oak Creek Canyon Chamber of Commerce.
Because of all the marketing abroad, tour officials say many first-time foreign visitors come with a reasonable understanding that leaves change at different times, depending on the elevation and the weather -- which is more than can be said of some Americans.
Right now, the foliage season is past in Colorado and the higher elevations in the East, but the peak color is making its way from southern Vermont to the New York area. In North Carolina, the leaves around Asheville in the Blue Ridge Mountains won't peak before this weekend; the high point in the state's coastal areas will follow in a couple of weeks.
"Every year we get calls asking what day the leaves are going to change," said Dan Tomlinson, manager of the Quality Inn Biltmore in Asheville, N.C. "And because Kimberly Avenue is particularly beautiful, with lovely old houses and lined with maple trees on both sides, we sometimes even get calls asking what time of day the leaves are going to change on Kimberly."
Many communities have established fairs, festivals and craft shows to tie in with the foliage, in the belief that visitors want to do more than look at leaves.
Fort Fairfield, Me., only a stone's throw from the New Brunswick border, promoted this year's brief foliage season -- which began in mid-September -- as an opportunity for visitors to see potato harvests. That is when many schools in the area close for three weeks so pupils can help bring in the crop.
Wisconsin, where foliage tourism is up 14 percent since 1993, published its first separate fall catalogue this year, a 16-page booklet listing a dozen fall festivals and nine scenic drives. Other states tie foliage visits to trips to outlet malls and shopping centers.
"New England has done such a great job of packaging foliage tours that it has created a demand for that kind of thing in many other states," said Kelly Ladyga, spokeswoman for the Colorado Travel and Tourism Authority.
Among the more unusual tie-ins in Colorado are a cowboy poetry gathering in Durango, sightseeing tours to Rocky Mountain National Park, tied to the elk mating season, and a "Roadkill Supper" in Kremmling that includes elk chili, moose and antelope. ("But we don't actually scrape it up off the road," said Carol Jarbo, director of the Kremmling Chamber of Commerce.)
Andy Dawson, executive director of the Shenandoah Valley Travel Association -- whose promotional efforts within the 150-mile-long corridor in northern Virginia include the scenic Blue Ridge Parkway and Skyline Drive -- said his association used to compete for foliage tourists with Williamsburg and other Virginia destinations.
"Now," he said, "we're competing with everybody up and down the East Coast."
While that might sound grandiose to many New Englanders, it is not regarded as boastful by Bobbe Maynes, commissioner of the Vermont Department of Tourism and Marketing.
"Vermont's and New England's foliage is still unique," she said, "but because Virginia, Ohio, Illinois and lots of other states are pumping big money into their foliage promotions, we've had to struggle to maintain market share." The popularity of Branson, Mo., and the Foxwood Resorts Casino on the Mashantucket Pequots' reservation in Ledyard, Conn., has also cut into Vermont's foliage tourism, she said.
Vermont spends about $1 million a year promoting tourism and derives about $400 million of its $2 billion total tourist revenues from leaf watchers. Neighboring New Hampshire earns about $700 million from fall tourism, or 23 percent of its total.
To encourage tourist visits, especially outside the crowded fall weekends, nearly 100 Vermont hotels, motels and bed and breakfasts have offered discount midweek packages this year.
For the first time, also, Vermont has created a toll-free foliage hot line, and for the second consecutive year, it has financed local leaf hot lines in 10 cities, including New York, Boston and Philadelphia.
The foliage hot lines in many states, regions and cities are based on reports from volunteers, forest rangers or visitors' bureaus. Such hot lines often include the current color and quality of the leaves, the projected number of days or weeks until color peaks, plus recommended scenic drives and festivals.
Georgia, whose native son Johnny Mercer wrote the lyrics to "Autumn Leaves," probably the best-known paean to the season, invites leaf watchers to dial a toll-free United States Forest Leaf Watch Hot Line to check foliage conditions in the northern part of the state.
Critics say that with so many tourist dollars at stake, some leaf hot lines tend to gild the lily -- or the maples, oaks and aspens at any rate.
"Last fall's leaves were the worst in years because of the prolonged drought, and some states' foliage season this year suffered from storms and tropical winds," said one Midwest tourist official. "But I can't think of a single hot line in either year that so much as hinted that anything was less than perfect."
After record rainfalls in many parts of the country in the last year, in many states this autumn's peak leaf days are about a week later than usual. But visitors who have already witnessed the foliage season in higher elevations agree with tourism officials that this is one of the most spectacular change-overs in years.
Yet given the fickleness of Mother Nature, even veteran leaf watchers sometimes guess wrong.
"You take your chances," said Jean Walker, a retired secretary in Fort Collins, Colo., who has taken foliage trips to New England, the Ozarks, the Carolinas, Arizona and the Great Lakes. "My last trip to New England, in 1990, turned out to be a twig tour," she said. "All the leaves were gone."

HEADLINE: Julian H. Levi, 87, Influential Advocate of Urban Renewal

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Prof. Julian H. Levi, a Chicago lawyer, educator, city planner and an influential advocate of urban renewal, died on Wednesday at his home in San Francisco.
He was 87 and had formerly lived in the Hyde Park neighborhood of Chicago, where he helped stem the tide of urban blight that threatened to swamp the University of Chicago community in the 1950's. 
 Professor Levi was one of the country's foremost experts in stabilizing racially changing neighborhoods and helped shape national urban policies.
He retired in 1980 as professor of urban studies at the University of Chicago. At his death he was a professor at the Hastings College of Law, part of the University of California at San Francisco.
Professor Levi (pronounced lee-vee) argued that vibrant urban environments should reflect the nation's diversity. He saw this as people naturally living, working and shopping together, places where white homeowners could sell to blacks and blacks to whites without ado.
From 1952 to 1980 he was the executive director of the South East Chicago Commission, which was created save Hyde Park-Kenwood, the country's first large urban community to undergo such planned redemption at its own request.
Hyde Park-Kenwood was the only truly integrated section of Chicago. But whites, including members of the university faculty and staff, were fleeing en masse as mostly poor black Southerners moved in. Housing was falling apart, crime and drugs stalked streets, and what had been a desirable city environment was turning into a slum.
"The very life of the university is at stake," Lawrence A. Kimpton, the chancellor, warned the City Council at a time when the University of Chicago was seriously considering a new lease on life in the suburbs.
The response to the community's plight, with its implications for Chicago's future as a whole, was a "total wallop," in Professor Levi's phrase. It ranged from a Quaker group training dogs to patrol the campus against muggers to a huge influx of Federal construction aid.
With the community, civic and religious groups, Chicago, Illinois and Washington all pulling together, and with Mayor Richard J. Daley's lending powerful political support, the effort became one of the country's great urban success stories.
The project involved an area of about 900 acres and some $200 million in city, Federal, university and private money. Large tracts near the university were cleared as unredeemable, but the emphasis was strongly on preservation and rehabilitation.
Eighty percent of existing structures and gabled architecture lived to see a new day. And Hyde Park-Kenwood survived as the same highly articulate, highly organized and racially integrated community it was before.
In 1974, Mayor Daley named Professor Levi the chairman of the Planning Commission, giving him a hand in stabilization and development throughout Chicago. Professor Levi also helped draft amendments to the Federal Housing Act on behalf of the cities and state legislation directed at landlords of blighted buildings.
Julian Hirsch Levi was born in Hyde Park, the son and grandson of rabbis. He graduated from the University of Chicago College in 1929 and received a degree from its law school in 1931. He spent 15 years in private practice and then worked for the Reynolds Pen and Reynolds Printasign companies before turning his attention to urban renewal.
He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Marjorie Reynolds Levi; a son, William G., of Kansas City, Mo., and a daughter, Kay L. Pick, of Winnetka, Ill.; two brothers, Edward H., of Chicago, a former president of the university who served as Attorney General in the Ford Administration, and Harry, of Highland Park, Ill., and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Narrows, but Just Slightly

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit edged down only slightly in August from its near-record level in July, the Commerce Department reported today, as improvements in trade with Western Europe and Japan were largely offset by growing gaps with other nations, especially China.
The decline was far less than most forecasters had predicted. 
 The report brought a withering attack on President Clinton's trade policies from Bob Dole, his Republican challenger. In a statement, Mr. Dole linked the nation's continuing trade deficits to the loss of manufacturing jobs, and called the latest numbers "proof perfect why economic anxiety is endemic among American workers."
Administration officials said the focus should be on the continuing growth in exports, which they said were supporting high-paying jobs in industries across the nation.
The overall trade deficit -- the amount by which imports of goods and services exceeded exports -- declined to $10.8 billion in August from $11.6 billion in July, a drop of 6.9 percent. August imports were $80.1 billion, up 1.5 percent, and exports were $69.3 billion, up 3 percent.
For just the second time, the largest deficit in the month was with China. The gap between imports and exports rose to $4.7 billion in August from $3.8 billion in July, exceeding that of the longtime leader, Japan, which was $3.8 billion, down from $4.3 billion in July. The deficit with Western Europe narrowed sharply, to $1.6 billion from an unusually high level of $4.2 billion in July.
The deficit with China -- one of a host of politically sensitive issues in the relationship between Beijing and Washington -- has bounced up and down on a month-to-month basis. It appears to have grown in August as the United States imported more toys and Christmas decorations to build inventories for the holidays.
The deficit with China for the first eight months of the year was $24.2 billion, an increase of $2.4 billion, or 11.2 percent, from the comparable period last year. But China's deficit has not been the fastest growing this year among the nation's biggest trading partners.
That honor belongs to Canada, the largest single trading partner of the United States. So far this year, the United States deficit with Canada has grown $4.8 billion, or 44 percent, compared with the period a year earlier. Demand in Canada for United States imports has declined in the last year largely because of fiscal and monetary policies that have slowed growth there. Demand in the United States for raw materials and automobile parts from Canada has remained strong.
The deficit with Japan, long the bane of American trade policy, has dropped 28.5 percent this year, compared with the first eight months of 1995.
The overall August deficit was the second largest, behind that in July, since 1992, when the Government began to gauge trade figures in a new way that is not comparable with earlier reports. Under a different system that derived roughly comparable monthly figures from quarterly data, the deficit last topped the levels of July and August in the last three months of 1987, when the average monthly deficit was $12.9 billion.
The American economy has been showing clear signs of slowing over the last several months, and economists said the surprisingly large size of the August trade deficit might mean that third-quarter growth was even lower than the 2 percent or so that many forecasters had expected.
The economy grew at a 4.7 percent pace in the second quarter, and third-quarter growth of less than 2 percent could be low enough to give Mr. Dole's attacks on the Clinton Administration's economic record more credibility in the Presidential campaign's closing days. The Government's first report on growth in third-quarter gross domestic product will be issued on Oct. 30.
To mainstream economists, the persistent American trade deficit mainly reflects the inability or unwillingness of the United States to finance its investment fully out of domestic savings. The gap has been filled by foreign capital, which must be matched by a comparable deficit in goods and services.
While the swelling of the deficit in the summer months probably contributed to a slowdown in growth, the trade deficit's stubbornly high level reflected in part the underlying strength of the American economy relative to those of the nation's big trading partners, most of which are just recovering from recession or muddling along with anemic growth. Because the United States has been growing faster than other nations, its demand for imports has been higher.
Administration officials were also quick to point to the healthy growth in exports, especially in capital goods like aircraft and computers, as evidence that the nation's competitiveness was undiminished.
"Exports are on track to a new record high this year," said Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor, crediting the gains in part to the Administration's new fair trade agreements, especially with Japan and China.
But whatever credit the Administration deserves -- and the Dole campaign asserts that it deserves none -- a combination of protectionist trade policies among other nations, low savings in the United States and lackluster economic growth in industrial nations elsewhere have made it difficult to bring the deficits down.
For the first eight months of the year, the trade deficit stood at $74.7 billion, 5.2 percent lower than for the similar period last year. But economists said the deficit for the full year was likely to be as high as for last year if not higher, as 1995 ended with a string of unusually low deficits.
And that has led to a critique of the standard economic explanation for the high trade deficit. "Six or eight months ago most economists and forecasters were saying that the trade deficit would be lower this year," said Larry Chimerine, the chief economist at the Economic Strategy Institute, a research group in Washington.
"Now it's more than likely that it will be higher this year than last year. No matter what happens -- the dollar goes up, the dollar goes down, the economy grows, the economy doesn't grow -- it's the same old story.
"It's about time people started realizing that this is not a macroeconomic problem or an exchange rate problem. It's a structural problem."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Further Japan Drop
 TOKYO, Oct. 18 (Reuters) -- Japan's trade surplus fell 30 percent in September and the surplus with the United States declined, the Government said today.
The drop means the surplus has fallen more than 40 percent in the first half of Japan's fiscal year. The overall surplus fell 30.3 percent, to $6.96 billion in September, from September 1995, while the surplus with the United States fell 8.5 percent from a year earlier to $3.56 billion.
 The figures "are very good for everyone," said Chris Pavlou, treasurer of global markets at the Midland Bank in Tokyo. "The balance with the United States is coming down nicely."

HEADLINE: Nicaragua Sour and Unsure As Nation Prepares to Vote

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MASAYA, Nicaragua, Oct. 18

 BODY:
This town was known as "the cradle of the insurrection" for its role in the Sandinista revolution against the Somoza family dictatorship. Then in 1990, after a decade of Sandinista rule, Masaya helped drive the leftists from power by voting decisively for their opponent, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro.
Today the 133,000 residents of Masaya, a commercial center south of Managua, are disillusioned and deeply divided. With their country voting on Sunday to elect a successor to Mrs. Chamorro, about the only point of agreement is that the last six years have been a disappointment, with one lost opportunity after another. 
 Her years in office have been marked, as she described it at a news conference this week, by "complete respect for civil liberties," as well as the demilitarization of Nicaraguan society. The astronomical inflation and huge deficits of the Sandinista years have also been brought under control. But the cost has been high: incomes have stagnated and half the population lack regular employment, making Nicaragua the second-poorest nation in the hemisphere.
"With Dona Violeta, we did not get what we wanted, which was for our country to be stable and prosperous," said Roberto Garcia Acuna, a 43-year-old teacher, as he sat with colleagues outside a pharmacy here. "We are not at war anymore, that is true, but there is a lot of unemployment, and so there is much discontent in every sector."
But in contrast with 1990, in this election voters here and elsewhere in Nicaragua seem unsure of which direction to turn. Both Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the former President who is again the candidate of the Sandinista National Liberation Front, and his main right-wing rival, Arnoldo Aleman of the Liberal Alliance, are campaigning against the status quo Mrs. Chamorro represents, which they characterize as one of widening poverty and a leadership vacuum.
Mr. Aleman and Mr. Ortega offer markedly different visions of this country's future and radically different interpretations of its recent violent past. As a result, supporters of both men say, Nicaraguans remain profoundly polarized, with the unresolved questions of the 1980's still very much on their minds.
Most polls here show Mr. Aleman slightly ahead, with the support of more than 40 percent of voters, although his double-digit lead has shrunk to less than five points over the last two months. But as in 1990, Mr. Ortega retains the support of about 40 percent of the people, and he and his supporters hope to force a runoff by denying Mr. Aleman the 45 percent of the vote he needs to win in the first round.
Mr. Ortega has been aided by a makeover of his image and program that makes him appear, as Mrs. Chamorro put it, to be "disguised as a saint." Dressed in white, as opposed to the fatigues he favored in the past, he preaches conciliation with the United States and the ruling class, promising that "the blood of Nicaraguans will never again be shed" even as he continues to adhere to the Sandinistas' traditional gospel of economic and social justice.
"For the poor, the Front is the only alternative, and around here there are lots more poor than rich," said Maria Auxiliadora Flores, 36, who runs a small bakery here with her husband, Efrain. "During the time of the Sandinistas, everyone had work, they gave the poor people houses to live in, and they made sure doctors came to keep children healthy. Now all of that has been lost."
But Jose Donaldo Gutierrez Soza, a 45-year-old teacher, argues that "to vote for Daniel Ortega would be like putting a gun to your own head." A Sandinista victory, he said, would mean a return to repression and rationing, while Mr. Aleman's pledge to take a purely capitalist path is a guarantee of prosperity.
"As Mayor of Managua, Aleman has given everyone work, cleaned up the streets, and built schools and roads," Mr. Gutierrez said. "That's what we need, not a weak government like Dona Violeta's, manipulated by the Sandinistas."
Among the thousands of former combatants in the civil war, both Sandinistas and the contras who were supported by the Reagan Administration, their disillusionment with the last few years of peace has led them to set aside many of their differences. In the northern town of Quilali, for instance, the two camps now operate separate veterans associations out of the same set of offices.
"We have an interest in common," said Jose Endrique Mejia Cruz, a former contra. "All of us have screwed-up arms and legs, and all of us get a miserable pension."
Former combatants on both sides describe themselves as soured by the lack of leadership they see.
"For 10 years I had a cause and a future," said Luis Fley, a former farmer and contra leader. "Now all that has been cut short, and I am a Government employee, a tax collector, just trying to survive, like everyone else."
For that loss of optimism, many blame Mrs. Chamorro. In the last couple of years in particular, the country has seemed adrift, with the President hobbled by health problems and ceding most day-to-day duties to her son-in-law and chief adviser, Antonio Lacayo, and a Cabinet widely regarded as corrupt.
"If Dona Violeta had surrounded herself with honest advisers, we would have been fine," said Guillermo Ramirez Ayala, a 58-year-old jeweler here. "But that Government has become a nest of vipers, penetrated by corruption and full of people getting loans they never pay back. All kinds of donations come from Europe and Japan, but not even a pencil reaches the classroom."
At her news conference, Mrs. Chamorro defended her performance, saying she has faced "enormous obstacles" in her effort to turn a dictatorship into a democracy and a socialist economy into a free market. While the problem of poverty "cannot be solved overnight," she said, she takes pride in having been able to guarantee personal liberties and protect human rights.
But even on that front she has come under criticism. Unlike neighboring El Salvador, which lived through its civil war in the 1980's, Nicaragua has never tried, through a Truth Commission or other official body, to hold accountable those from both the contras and the Sandinistas who were responsible for killings and other human rights violations.
"If the Sandinista era was characterized by repression, the period of Dona Violeta has been one of impunity," said Lino Hernando Trigueros, executive director of the Permanent Commission for Human Rights. "She promised, and had the obligation, to see the worst cases of the past brought to justice, but has preferred to sacrifice justice in order to avoid problems, and so there has been no true reconciliation."
Almost against their wills, though, Nicaraguans are hoping that Sunday's moment of decision will deliver them from the impasse. No matter who wins, they say, the electorate will continue to demand that certain basic demands be met, and will be harsh with the rulers if they are not.
"This country is still quite divided," said Francisco Gaitan Lopez, a 30-year-old laborer here who supports Mr. Ortega. "But we hope that with a new government we can finally get what we really want. To live better and to live in peace, that is everyone's objective."
