SECTION: Section 2; Page 30; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1023 words

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY VIEW;
On CD, Orchestras Fall Victim to Their Glorious Pasts

BYLINE: By Lawrence B. Johnson 

 BODY:
THE STRIKING MUSICIANS OF the Philadelphia Orchestra are aggrieved that they have lost their recording contract with EMI Classics. Citing the orchestra's incontestably great recording tradition, that bountiful library begun and cultivated in the epochs of Leopold Stokowski and Eugene Ormandy, the suddenly disenfranchised Philadelphians are asking, in essence, "Is nothing sacred?"
"Why, yes," replies a happy chorus of collectors, "all those wonderful recordings by Stokie and Ormandy." 
 What makes the chorus so happy is the new and improved sound of those beloved older recordings by the Philadelphians -- as well as the Cleveland Orchestra under George Szell, the Chicago Symphony under Fritz Reiner, the Boston Symphony under Charles Munch and the New York Philharmonic under Leonard Bernstein -- in digital remasterings on CD's.
For many classical-music lovers such a list bespeaks a golden age of orchestral recording. Digital technology has retrieved that era and brought it to a new level of sonic splendor. These days, after digital transfiguration, it is often hard to tell the difference between a recording made three or four decades ago and one produced last year.
In a way that was never possible before, the recording traditions of America's great orchestras are coming back to haunt them; or perhaps more accurately, to bite them. The constant stream of reissues that floods the CD bins is qualitatively different from the recyclings of the LP era.
Back in my student days -- when a computer still took up most of a large room -- I prowled the record shops for the latest "budget" reissues on RCA Victrola, Angel Seraphim, Columbia Odyssey, London Stereo Treasury and others. Gems mined from those bins allowed me to own many fine recordings; or I should say, fine performances. The sound of those cheaply remade LP's was typically not great, and the pressings were often blighted by pops and clicks. If you could afford it, you were better off investing in the high-priced spread.
Moreover, 30 or 40 years ago, even as recently as the 1970's, the classical-record industry seemed to have room to expand -- indeed, a driving need to do so. In the early, exciting days of stereo sound, I used to curl up in bed at night with the latest issue of the Schwann catalog and painstakingly map out lists of recordings I wanted to acquire. I watched my favorite record shop for the new releases.
It seemed then that every new recording was momentous; it was a time of musical expansion and revelation. And not merely for the classical sponge I had become but also for a generation of music consumers whose imaginations had been sparked, if not detonated, by stereo and the rapid improvements in hi-fi sound systems.
Today, in place of the simple guide that the Schwann catalog once was, the wide-eyed wanderer in music's enchanted realm holds a tome of options. The current Schwann rivals the Manhattan White Pages in sheer bulk and density. It is still a useful guide, even desperately necessary, given the 60 recordings of this and the 75 of that from which one must choose.
But I cannot imagine curling up with those daunting pages on an autumn night. In its teeming columns of Beethoven, Tchaikovsky and Mahler, Schwann today recalls the scene in "Moscow on the Hudson" in which Robin Williams's Russian character, having been steered to the "coffee line" in an American supermarket, takes one look at the staggering array of choices and faints dead away.
Purveyors of classical recordings in the United States say the market has gone flat. Maybe it has simply fainted. In any case, the current scene is not very good for the big American orchestras. The beleaguered Philadelphians have plenty of company. Decca/London has pared its commitment to the Cleveland Orchestra. Neither the Chicago Symphony nor the New York Philharmonic is recording with anything like the frequency of the glory days. And the Boston Symphony is in the same sail-less, if not sinking, boat.
Yet this bleak picture could brighten for all parties when and if the digital video disk makes its grand entrance. The much-touted (though perpetually pending) new disk holds the potential for a spectacular era of sound recording.
Even apart from the video factor, the tremendous data capacity of this high-density format has sound-recording engineers drooling with anticipation. The new disk, able to store up to 12 times as much information as the present music CD, should raise the ante for sonic realism in terms of both accuracy of timbre and the sense of spaciousness achieved through multichannel effects.
CURIOUSLY, THE MAJOR classical record labels have shown no particular interest in the digital video disk. Across the board, the attitude seems to be: "Consumers are perfectly content with the CD, so why confuse them with a new format?" America's phonographically challenged orchestras might suggest an answer: Never having heard the ripping sound that the "Pathetique" Symphony could have on a high-density disk, record collectors have never heard Tchaikovsky at all.
Fifteen years ago, the classical-record industry was complaining about flat sales. Consumers were not really grousing about the LP; they just weren't buying as many as they once had. Came the CD, and the game began all over again. Sales surged. The industry was "saved." From every perspective, the future looked secure. What is different now? With the high-density desk on the horizon, why no hallelujahs from record moguls? The answer seems to lie in economics.
Not only are American orchestras expensive to record, but the industry already has a sizable investment on the line, represented by the glutted pages of Schwann. This time, technology may not bring the familiar solution. For orchestras enmeshed in losing struggles with their own pasts, the only workable answer may be to stop fighting and strike out in a new direction unique to the digital age: high-definition, multi channel satellite music broadcasts on demand.
One can't help thinking that given the chance, Stokie would have been the first to put his ethereal sound into orbit.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1309 words

HEADLINE: Vintage Glimpses of a Lost Theatrical World

BYLINE: By MARGO JEFFERSON 

 BODY:
MAYBE IT'S THE FACT THAT the century is ending, but everyone I know is desperate for a performing-arts renaissance. New material, new techniques? Sure, I'll take them. But any renaissance worth its name has to be as much about approaching the past as assessing the present and anticipating the future. After all, the word does mean rebirth.
For a renaissance to be real and healthy, we have to look again at what we think we already know and be willing to uncover what we might have overlooked. Our tools are psychic and cultural, instinctive and analytical: the artist's equivalent of the instruments scientists use to gather information about solar systems they can't see clearly but know exist. 
 When it comes to art, a solid chunk of what we'll call the elemental material does not change. But the settings change, the tones and rhythms change, the arrangements of elements change and our responses change.
I was struck by all this recently when I made my way through just a portion of Jean-Claude Baker's quite ravishing collection of black theater material from the teens and 1920's. Playbills, posters, scores, letters, detailed descriptions of performances, interviews and photographs -- lustrous, surprising photographs from the early years of the century, when American art and entertainment first shook the world, producing ragtime, blues, jazz, a new kind of streamlined popular song, a dizzying number of new dances and enough new expressions and grammatical constructions to permanently alter the English language. There they were, in black, white and every shade of sepia: legends, historical footnotes, innovators and hard-working minor players.
Mr. Baker became acquainted with this world through Josephine Baker, one of its most celebrated performers and expatriates. He toured with her, worked for her, and joined her tribe of adopted children. (Though he was not officially adopted, he later took her name.) He is the author, with Chris Chase, of the definitive 1994 biography of Baker; it was after I had reviewed his book that I met Mr. Baker and got my first glimpse of what is surely one of the best collections of black theater memorabilia in the world.
But what exactly is black theater, I thought, studying images of pantomimists, ventriloquists, blues singers, jazz musicians, languid ballroom dancers, cakewalkers and natty tappers, loud-talking vaudevillians and high-minded thespians. Does it mean the pioneers in forms black Americans were crucial to creating and developing, like jazz, blues, tap, modern vernacular dance and certain styles of verbal and physical comedy? There is ample evidence of them here: delectable photographs of Bert Williams and Florence Mills, Bessie Smith and Louis Armstrong, Ethel Waters (parodying Josephine Baker), the Berry Brothers, Peg Leg Bates and those comic prototypes of Amos and Andy: Flournoy Miller and Aubrey Lyles.
What was I supposed to do, though, with the pictures of black practitioners and masters of forms mostly created and developed by Europeans and European-Americans -- ballroom dancers, pantomimists, operetta stars and lines of chorus dancers in tulle and feathers or black tie and tails? There are plenty of these in the collection too. Are they part of "Black Theater"? Or are they to be categorized and patronized as interlopers -- dutiful imitators of something called "White Theater"?
The richness and the range of a collection like this expose the limits of these terms. In theater, styles and traditions spill past the boundaries of those who first made them up. One people's tradition becomes another's innovation. What one group deems high art becomes grist for pop art somewhere else.
And yet sifting through this collection brings one face to face with a stark fact about the way theater worked for black performers in decades past. If they stayed on their side of the color line, playing to all-black audiences on the all-black theater circuit, they got much less money and much less exposure than on mainstream circuits, but they got to work in many more genres. Not just minstrel shows with their plantation plots, but original musicals in a range of styles (ragtime to waltz), Shakespeare, Dumas, opera selections and Americanized versions of fencing routines, tangos and Russian folk dances. (Bessie Smith hired Ida Forsyne, a black dancer who learned to strut her Russian stuff while touring that country before World War I: "Go on, Ida, show 'em!" Bessie used to shout from the wings before swaggering on to do her blues.)
If these performers were making forays into white vaudeville, they were generally -- though not invariably -- expected to highlight their more obstreperously "Negroid" mannerisms and skills. This is an especially bleak version of the trap every aspiring mass-appeal performer in America, black or white, has encountered: keep doing what the public and the producers know you for. And it's especially bleak -- even lethal -- when applied to an entire race and bound up with offstage opinions of that race's worth and place in society.
I don't want to make martyrs of these performers; they didn't see themselves that way. They knew they were good, and some of them knew they were great. Every performer takes certain risks: Will I make it to the top of my profession? Will I get the recognition and the kind of material I want? Will I get to use my talents to the fullest? But it is doubly hard to take all these risks knowing that the social, economic and artistic arrangements of the world you work in have already decreed that the answer will be "probably not."
In the years these performers were working, as reviews and histories make clear, white audiences liked best to see black singers, dancers, comics and actors playing in styles that were recognizably black. At the same time, black audiences liked to see them doing "white styles," say, opera selections, often right alongside the buck-dancing, raucous comic sketches and ragtime songs.
In general, white audiences rarely saw the kind of stylistic intermingling that took place in a variety of black theaters for a variety of black audiences. But small privileged groups were exposed to it and went looking for it in certain highly specialized, sophisticated spaces: designated "colored clubs" (some with all-white patrons, some with mostly black), like the Cotton Club or Connie's Inn or the Club Alabam' in 1920's New York; an occasional Broadway theater or vaudeville house; nightclubs in Paris, Germany or England, where there was much less paranoia about how a black performer might presume to act on stage or off.
The pictures in Mr. Baker's archive (he has started his own foundation to support research and writing in this field) suggest that free spaces could be found inside the performers too -- that they could play with, against and beyond restrictive racial codes. And countercodes, imposed by black audiences, for in the name of striking back at white prejudice they could be unkind and unfair. When Mr. Baker began interviewing these 1910's and 1920's veterans in the 1970's, they felt that on top of being exploited or ignored by whites, they were now being dismissed as toadies and sellouts by blacks.
But of course free space exists inside audiences too -- consciously and unconsciously, whether they're inside a theater or listening to a radio or phonograph.
What follows are some of the thoughts that struck me as I looked at these pictures. They offer images of delight, dissent and complexity. They ask us to take more risks, think more clearly and imagine more boldly when it comes to race, ethnicity, class, style, sex, esthetics and American theater.
We can't have a renaissance unless we have access to a range of performance styles and impulses that have gone unacknowledged or been oversimplified.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Chorus members of the Cotton Club, a hot spot in 1920's New York-- Playing with, against and beyond restrictive racial codes. (Jean-Claude Baker Foundation) (pg. 1)
 
CHILD DANCERS IN PARIS (1903) AND FREDI WASHINGTON AND AL MOORE (1927)
Here are two young performers dancing the cakewalk -- that plantation-derived black dance that became a national and worldwide rage at the turn of the century. Actually, they are doing "Le Cakewalk" at Le Nouveau Cirque in Paris in 1903. They probably began their careers in a medicine show, circus or all-black troupe. Or perhaps as "pics" (short for pickaninnies), youngsters of color hired to sing and dance behind a white vaudeville star. They are typical "pics" in certain ways: the dark brown skin, meant to contrast ostentatiously with the costume or skin color of the leading lady they backed.
But here, in Paris, the color contrasts work for, not against the little dancers: he has the look of a small dashing fencer or gymnast, and she of a garden-party soubrette. You can't miss the erotic touches: the exposed midriffs, his revealing pants, her short skirt waiting to fly up as soon as she kicks her legs. But they are playful, not degrading. There is delicacy here, and innocence, in their faces and in the way they hold their well-trained little bodies. (The Cinematheque de la Danse in Paris has them on film, and they are enchanting.) They embody all of the mixed impulses and motives that first gave rise to the cakewalk. It was said to be a parody by black slaves of their masters' showy party manners, but it read as enough of a tribute (mimicry so often is) to delight the masters and mistresses when they watched it, and to please the slaves as well.
Now, compare these child-troupers to that suave and soigne pair, Fredi Washington and Al Moore, actors and dancers who trudged along from engagement to engagement in the States (musical revues one season, straight dramas or nightclub spots the next), but had great success in Europe in the late 1920's as Vernon and Irene Castle-esque ballroom dancers. They were too lyrical and too light-skinned to be big hits on the American scene, unless they had chosen to cross the color line and pass themselves off as white dancers.
Fredi Washington acted out a version of this career dilemma in the 1934 movie "Imitation of Life," in which she played Pecola, the ambitious, rebellious and fair-skinned daughter of a humble brown-skinned housekeeper, who passes for white because she craves the privileges of being white, and suffers torments of guilt when her mother dies alone. Washington's performance is riveting -- as was her dancing, by all accounts.
I admire her for returning to the United States and helping to found the Negro Actors' Guild, which employed many a struggling performer in the decades that followed. But I wish for her sake that she had stayed abroad. When Mr. Baker interviewed her years later, Washington still recalled the sweetness of her Paris success, and her hotel on the Riviera overlooking the sea. She told him that, at night, "it was as if someone had thrown a handful of diamonds into the water, it was so beautiful; and here I was, thinking of home, the boardinghouses with no hot water, the bedbugs, the life we Negroes had to live, and how much had to be changed; and here I was crying in front of so much beauty." What was your reaction after coming back home, Mr. Baker asked. And the response came back flatly: "Well, I didn't have any reaction, because I knew, after all, what I was facing; I had lived in this all my life."
 
CLAUDE HOPKINS (1928)
America was lucky enough to generate three forms that rearranged the landscape of modern music: blues, jazz and the popular theatrical song. As founders and key participants in all three, black performers tended to have more freedom whenever music dominated and plots could be minimized or dispensed with. Self-contained vaudeville acts or revue numbers often allowed performers like Florence Mills, Bill Robinson or John Bubbles more range than an elaborately plotted musical comedy. And the club, cabaret and dance hall have been at least as important to black theater as any Broadway or repertory playhouse.
What black man was allowed to display as much dash, drama, wit or glamour as the black man who led and performed with his band? James Reese Europe, with his ragtime-era Clef Club Orchestra; Fletcher Henderson, helping set the tempo for the Jazz Age; Duke Ellington; Count Basie; Jimmie Lunceford and so many others, all keeping their musicians in tune and in line, spurring then stilling the eager dancers and gauging -- or manipulating -- the audience's mood every night. The bandleader did for the orchestra what the director does for the play. But when he wrote his own music he took on the role of playwright as well. And since he was on stage constantly, he was expected to conduct himself like a leading man.
Look at dapper Claude Hopkins, who played a lithe stride piano, was the musical director for "La Revue Negre," the show that introduced Josephine Baker to Europe in 1925, let Edward, Prince of Wales, sit in on drums whenever the band appeared in Paris, and had his biggest hit in 1934 with a sleek, airy version of "Three Little Words." He is said to have been admired offstage by both Josephine Baker and the Prince. The mirror in this photograph suggests that he admired himself as well.
The potent and erotic figure of the bandleader can still be found in concert halls and in jazz clubs. But when big bands lost their mass audiences, the bandleader lost his star status. Today, you will find his descendant on various late-night television talk shows. He supplies the guests with backup music; he supplies the host with a theme song and some second-banana chitchat.
 
BUTTERBEANS AND SUSIE (c. 1928)
 Battles of wills and wits between the sexes aren't as much fun as they used to be. Butterbeans and Susie were part of a couples continuum that in the 1910's, 20's and 30's included Burns and Allen; Astaire, first with his sister, Adele, then with Rogers; Noel Coward and Gertrude Lawrence, and the various sparring pairs that peopled romantic and screwball comedies.
But Butterbeans and Susie were lowbrows (television descendants include Ralph and Alice Kramden and Roseanne and Dan Conner). They had a lot of the old minstrel show about them, but the best minstrel-show performers were great clowns who had mastered every trick of physical and verbal comedy.
Susie and Butter, as she called him, were magisterial roustabouts who were always reminding each other of their inauspicious beginnings in some Southern town where one or the other of them sold fish from the back of a wagon. They would trade insults punctuated by refrains like "I ain't scared of you," then see who could come up with the smartest retort, now that they were both settled up North. They delivered their tunes and their wisecracks in rich, artfully laconic Southern accents, perfectly pitched between speech and song.
You can't imitate them, but there isn't a comic duo or musical theater performer around who couldn't learn something about delivery and timing from listening to them.

BESSIE SMITH (early 1920's)
We tend to think of Bessie Smith as an elemental force, a creature of epic proportions who became an emblem of imperiled but mighty black womanhood. What you see in this photograph, taken in the early 1920's, is a slightly shy, vulnerable but thoroughly modern young flapper. This is the Bessie Smith who learned all aspects of her craft, who could Charleston and do comic turns, then send her audience into a trance with her spare but voluptuous blues. And in the 1930's, when slow blues were being supplanted by jazz swing, she got ready to adapt once more.
She died in 1937, but her last, 1933, recordings of tunes like "Do Your Duty," "Gimme a Pigfoot" and "Down in the Dumps" show that she would have been sensational with a big driving band like Count Basie's. Some artists do manage to seem larger than life. But whether they're Bessie Smith or Pablo Picasso, it's because their work was larger -- richer, braver, more willing to take on pain and pleasure -- than life, the way we live it most days of the week.

JOHNNIE WOODS WITH LITTLE HENRY (1917)
When black performers were alone with black audiences, what did they say about race? They joked, they lectured, they commiserated and criticized one another. They mocked social pretensions and snobbery, but they also mocked lowlife manners and attitudes.
Take the ventriloquist Johnnie Woods, a top draw on the black vaudeville circuit in the World War I years. You can see that Johnnie is a prosperous and respectable fellow; there's a touch of Theodore Roosevelt's heft and heartiness about him. But the dummy, Little Henry, is something else again, with his shiny black skin and loud checked suit. Little Henry has turned his back to Mr. Woods -- he's paying his master's voice no mind. And Mr. Woods watches, his hand extended with an air of reproachful, teacherly concern. He is the responsible Negro citizen who is uplifting the race; Little Henry is his dybbuk hand, his racial alter ego -- a rowdy Negro who does what he wants when he wants and race propriety be damned. But Johnnie Woods produced both voices and characters. Who did he give the last laugh to?
 
CHORUS GIRLS: AT THE COTTON CLUB (1925) AND IN THE BROWN SKIN MODELS REVUE (c. 1925)
Now, let's contrast the tastefully languid chorus girls of the Cotton Club with the jauntier chorines who made up the Brown Skin Models revue. The Cotton Club, Harlem's toniest hot spot and tourist attraction in the 1920's and 30's, featured only top black entertainers and admitted only well-heeled white patrons. The chorines were billed as "tall, tan and terrific," and they were beige and cream-colored as well: Jazz Age descendants of those octoroons, quadroons and mulattoes who drift prettily and lasciviously through 19th- and early-20th-century race fantasies.
The Brown Skin Models were meant to satisfy less rarefied tastes. The show's black producer, Irvin C. Miller, claimed that the idea came to him one day as he stood before a Broadway marquee that advertised the Ziegfeld Follies and its glorification of the American (the white American) girl. Just at that moment, a lovely brown-skinned woman walked down the street and into his line of vision. "Why not glorify the brown-skinned girl?" he cried -- and a show was born.
Updated yearly, the Brown Skin Models revue toured the country from 1925 to the start of World War II. Black and brown and beige audiences were clearly delighted to see fantasy versions of their all-American girl next door.
 
JOHNNY HUDGINS ON STAGE (1926) AND IN HIS PARIS DRESSING ROOM (1928)
Johnny Hudgins was a legendary pantomimist and dancer whose imitators included the young Josephine Baker and whose admirers included the young Edmund Wilson. He was equally popular with white and black, American and European audiences. He was filmed by Jean Renoir in a short entitled "Charleston," and he left behind a brief but wonderfully detailed book that described his act in great detail. The Ballroom Dancer with the imaginary girl partner, the Ice Skater, the Charleston specialty in a lady's straw hat with feather plumes and veil, the Pullman Porter, "burdened with bags, suffering under an intense weight and then finally receiving a miserly tip," which provokes a dance called the Porter's Twist. The repertory of steps: the Snake Shuffle, the Baltimore Todloe, the Desert Glide and the Peacock Strut.
In the picture at left he is doing his "Mwa Mwa" routine, turning himself into a human trumpet while alternately bullying and flattering the audience. There is a short film clip of this number, made at the Club Alabam' in New York in 1926. Hudgins's body and face are so fluid and witty, his charm so palpable that the burned-cork makeup, which we have come to read as intrinsically degrading, seems as incidental as the white makeup circus clowns have worn for centuries.
Nevertheless, I do love seeing Hudgins in the picture at right. He is in his own skin, dapper as can be in his dressing room at the Moulin Rouge in Paris, surrounded by celebrity dolls.
Josephine Baker smiles at his right and he cradles Maurice Chevalier in one arm. He holds a Little Black Sambo doll in his other hand, at a slight distance, pointing a finger and arch1ing an eyebrow. Behind Sambo sits a Hudgins doll in blackface, looking a bit abashed. "Don't forget who's in charge here," Hudgins seems to be telling them. (All photographs from the Jean-Claude Baker Foundation, except that of Bessie Smith, which is on loan from Arthur Reagan-Herr, and the Brown Skin Models revue, on loan from Olivette Miller.)

HEADLINE: L.I. Appealing to Floridians to 'Come On Up'

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
REMEMBER the airline that encouraged Long Islanders to "come on down" to Florida?
Now Carnival Airlines is telling Flordians to "come on up." 
 In an advertising campaign Carnival, in conjunction with the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau, is promoting fall foliage on the Island in Florida cities that the line serves, Fort Lauderdale, Orlando, Tampa and West Palm Beach.
"We have literally hundreds of events going on at this time of year, everything from a pickle festival in Greenlawn to the Oyster Festival in Oyster Bay that could draw 100,000 people," said the president of the tourism bureau, Michael Davidson.
East End wineries are promoting wagon rides, tours and wine tastings, and the Long Island Fair is in Bethpage this weekend,, and it expects more than 70,000 peple.
"Tourism isn't just a 90-day season on Long Island, but year-round," Mr. Davidson said. "East End resorts are weather dependent. But the rest of the Island depends on meetings, conventions, group tours and business travelers. They are part of what we are all about."
The cool and rainy weather in July and the lack of a heat spell in August hurt tourism, Mr. Davidson added.
"It could have been better," the owner of the 50-room Daunt's Albtross Inn in Montauk, Frances Daunt, said. "The weather and the plane crash did not help at all. Our business was off at least 20 percent from last year, and restaurants were down, too."
The crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 on July 17 kept away tourists, Miss Daunt said, even though it occurred off East Moriches. "People perceive the Island as being the Island, whether it's the beginning or the end," she added.
The president of the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau, Michael Davidson, said small East End hotels had been particularly hard hit because they generally did not have the advance bookings of larger hotels.
Although the total of tourists for this year is not available, Mr. Davidson said, the proportion from outside the New York metropolitan region rose, from 20 percent in 1994 to 31 last year.
"We have traditionally attracted people from the New York metropolitan area," Mr. Davidson said. "These figures show that we are drawing more people from greater distances. The greater people travel, the longer they stay, the more they spend, and the more economic development activity you stimulate. Otherwise you are just recirculating money that is already here."
He added that the tourist industry on Long Island employed 92,000 people last year, with a payroll of $1.4 billion. Hotel occupancy last year was slightly less than 80 percent, he added, and it fell "2 or 3 percent" in July at East End hotels.
As the weather improved in August, so did hotel bookings, he said, and East End hotels not on the water fared somewhat better than waterfront establishments.
The general manager of the 140-unit Montauk Manor, Janice Nessel, said: "We usually get browbeaten because we're not beachfront. But this year it helped."
She said the hotel, which features an indoor pool, sauna and squash courts, was even with last year. "It was not a good season for anybody, because it rained nearly every weekend through most of July," Ms. Nessel said.
Mr. Davidson said Islandwide occupancy was flat, because the larger hotels on Nassau and western Suffolk depended less on weather. "Their business was from conventions, business travelers and motorcoach groups," he said. "That was very strong this summer."
But weather-dependent attractions like Splish Splash by Adventureland in Riverhead did suffer. "May, June and July were underwhelming, and August was overwhelming," the president of the amusement area, Chip A. Cleary, said. "The weather during May, June and July did not send out signals that summer was here, and so attendance at most area attractions lagged.
"In August people realized time was running out before school started. That, combined with slightly improved weather, brought the crowds out in force."
Overall, Mr. Cleary said, Splish Splash, the largest water park in the state, fell 5 percent from 1995. Last year, he noted, was the best season in the six that the park has been open.
The weather also held down attendance at state beaches, said the director of recreation services for State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, George A. Gorman.
"Attendance was off at our beachfront parks by about 15 percent," Mr. Gorman said. "Last year was one of our best. So it looks worse this year than it really was."
Crowds at Jones Beach State Park in Wantagh fell 20 percent. The latest figures show attendance from January to Aug. 20 dropped, from 5.6 million last year to 4.4 million this year.
Golf parks, campgrounds, arboretums and preserves and picnic areas reported levels similar to last year, he said. Belmont Lake State Park had 208,000 visitors through Aug. 20 last year and 210,000 this year.
Cool weather may have hurt beach revenues, but they helped retailers. The general manager of the Tanger Outlet Center in Riverhead, Janine H. Nebons, said customer traffic was up 10 percent from Memorial to Labor Day.
Mr. Davidson said his office, in conjunction with Carnival Airlines, started advertising two weeks ago to attract Floridians to new fall foliage trips. He said the ads had appeared in cities served by the airline, which flies to Islip.
Other states, too, advertise on Long Island. Television, newspaper and magazine ads promote attractions like Colonial Williamsburg, which is buying commercials and 30-minute infomercials on cable, New York television stations and News 12.
Mr. Davidson said his bureau was working with Mystic and More, a promotion to attract visitors to the Mystic, Conn., region. In the spring, he added, the two groups mounted an effort to convince bus operators that the region was attractive for group tours. "We did joint advertising in their trade publications, as well as direct mail, and then we knocked on their doors together," said Mr. Davidson.
In April the two organizations took 43 motorcoach operators from 13 states and Canada on a familiarization tour. They spent a day and a half on Long Island and then went to Mystic on ferry from Orient Point to New London, Conn.
The executive director of Mystic and More, Vivian C. Stanley, said the joint venture included meetings with travel agents in Florida that Carnival Airlines had helped arrange.
In February, representatives of both tourist groups spent five days visiting travel agents and tour operators in Clearwater, Fort Lauderdale, Fort Myers, Orlando and Palm Beach.
The partnership is trying to sell international travelers on seeing New York City and Long Island, taking the ferry to Mystic and going to Newport and returning home from Boston. "It's a very easy and pleasant trip," Ms. Stanley said. "The ferry carries cars and motorcoaches, and it's a nice way to get from one lovely area to another. Long Island Sound is a lovely alternative to struggling into and out of New York City."
Her organization, she said, has a $1.2 million-a-year budget and promotes Mystic and More primarily through New York magazines.
Connecticut has a campaign that promotes the state as a whole and with an annual budget of $3 million to $4 million, Ms. Stanley said. "Our visitors come primarily from New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania," she noted.
Mr. Davidson said the visitors' bureau was expanding its advertising as far as Rhode Island and Washington. "This was our most organized effort to broaden the market into Long Island," he said. "Last year we had no calls from Rhode Island. this year we got 160 after running one ad there."
The year-old North Shore Promotion Alliance, founded by Gloria D. Rocchio, has 85 chambers of commerce, museums, restaurants, arts organizations, hotels and shopping centers between Great Neck and Port Jefferson.
In the past, Ms. Rocchio said, vistors "would come thinking they could see things in Kings Point and Montauk the same day, and that's absurd."
With the help of a grant from American Express, the group printed 75,000 copies of a pamphlet, "The Long Island Heritage Trail," which has 11 self-guiding tours. Another booklet listed special events.
Other groups cover the North Fork, the South Fork, Riverhead and Southold. The president of the Fire Island Lighthouse Preservation Society, Gayle E. Haines, said she was involved in helping to form a group for the South Shore that would include Nassau County and parts of Suffolk.
Miss Haines and Mike K. Eagan have started a business to show off another not-so-appreciated attraction, the 23 lighthouses surrounding the Island. Eighteen are accessible, and the new business, Long Island Lighthouse Safaris, includes tours that include historical explanations.
Mr. Davidson said his bureau was operating this year on a budget of $880,000 generated from a 0.75 percent tax on all hotel rooms on Long Island. This was the third summer the tax had been in effect in Suffolk, and the second in Nassau. Both County Legislatures have voted to extend the tax to the year 2000.

HEADLINE: What Bond Act Might Mean for L.I.

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
WHEN Long Islanders enter their polling booths on Nov. 5, supporters of a $1.75 billion environmental bond act hope that they look upward.
Only by looking at the top of the ballot, the supporters say, will voters see Proposal 1, the Clean Water and Clean Air Bond Act of 1996, an environmental initiative by Gov. George E. Pataki. 
 In 1990, a $2 billion environmental bond act proposed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo failed, despite winning in Nassau and Suffolk. This year support from Long Island voters will be crucial for the bond to win statewide.
A coalition of environmental groups has been campaigning since the summer to build awareness of the plan. "People across the state are looking at this in a very positive way," said Sarah J. Meyland, executive director of the Citizens Campaign for the Environment.
But some people are worried about the sideshow setting of the proposal far above the names of President Clinton and Bob Dole and candidates in other races.
"People are going to have to look way to the top of the ballot, and that could be a problem," said Assemblyman Michael Balboni, Republican of Westbury.
The defeat of the bond act would be a stinging rebuke for Mr. Pataki.
A poll released last month by Quinnipiac College found that more than 65 percent of voters favored the bond referendum. The survey also showed, for the first time, that a majority of voters approved Mr. Pataki's policies.
Yet supporters said they were worried about voters who search ballots for measures to vote against. The supporters said such voters were more apt than others to notice and vote on Proposal 1, opposing it.
Opponents said voters should reject the bond act because it called for more borrowing by the debt-ridden state.
The $1.75 billion that would be raised by selling bonds would provide $200 million to help clean up Long Island Sound, the largest item for the region. The work would involve limiting nitrogen discharges from sewage plants, which a Federal, New York and Connecticut study identified as a major cause of water degradation.
An additional $30 million would be divided between the Peconic and South Shore estuaries for planning and cleanup. Part of $150 million for statewide land purchases would be available for the pine barrens and East End farmlands.
Long Island would also receive shares of $100 million for parks and historic preservation, $355 million in grants and loans to upgrade water supplies, $230 million for clean air that would include $125 million for work like replacing coal-fired boilers in schools and $50 million for recycling programs.
A $200 million allocation for so-called brownfields projects that would recycle abandoned industrial sites could also benefit Long Island.
The program director for the Citizens Campaign for the Environment, Jeffrey D. Fullmer, said approval of the act could mean the infusion of up to $2 billion in Federal matching funds.
"Some say bonding is expensive," Mr. Fullmer said. "But one point that's very important to make is that raising money through bonding is going to leverage Federal money."
Mr. Fullmer is also the chairman of the citizens' advisory council for the South Shore estuary program.
The Long Island Association has urged support for the bond issue. "Improving Long Island's environment ultimately benefits our economy," its president, Matthew T. Crosson, said in a press release. "Quality of life is one of the most, if not the most, important economic development factors on Long Island."
Supporters say the bond would assure long-term financing for environmental projects, averting the uncertainties of annual legislative votes.
Opponents said the bond, although well intentioned, would increase the staggering state debt. "New York already has significantly more debt than any other state," the majority leader of the Assembly, Michael J. Bragman, Democrat of Syracuse, wrote in a letter. "It is near or at the top in every other debt category."
Mr. Bragman said interest on the bond would total more than $1.3 billion over 40 years, putting the total cost at more than $3 billion. He suggested a pay-as-you-go approach in which the $100 million-a-year real-property-transfer tax would be dedicated to environmental projects.
Peter Quinn of the Long Island Progressive Coalition said borrowing for environmental projects was fiscally irresponsible for a state with a $36 billion debt. "This proposed bond is simply irresponsible leadership under the guise of environmentalism in order to boost the image of the Governor," said Mr. Quinn.
He suggested that cuts in the State Environmental Conservation Department showed that Mr. Pataki "speaks with a forked tongue on the environment." State spending of $300 million a year for six years would finance environmental projects without saddling taxpayers with $1 billion in interest costs, Mr. Quinn added.
The bond act is the lone state or county proposal on the Nassau ballot.
In Suffolk voters face a choice between two proposals to spend surplus money in a drinking water program that is financed by 0.25 percent of county sales taxes.
In a twist, the Long Island Pine Barrens Society and other groups that mounted a petition drive to place one of the three proposals, No. 3, on the ballot now support Proposal 2, which the County Legislature approved.
The counsel to the Legislature, Paul Sabatino, said the two proposals involved a $55 million surplus that the county expects when the water program ends on Nov. 30, 2000.
Mr. Sabatino said Proposal 2 would allocate $34.1 million to buy land in the pine barrens. About $17 million, would buy land in Babylon, Huntington, Islip, Shelter Island and Smithtown.
The remaining $3.9 million would be for security and maintenance in county parks.
The pine barrens, protected in a state forest preserve, are atop the largest supply of drinking water in the region. The pine barrens society and other groups strongly objected when the legislature voted in November to transfer $25 million from the water surplus to the county's general fund.
The groups gathered voters' signatures for a ballot proposal to prevent future "raids" on the surplus.
According to Mr. Sabatino, that proposal would not take effect until the last two years of the water program, meaning that no more than $29 million of the $55 million would be available for land purchases.
The executive director of the pine barrens society, Richard L. Amper Jr., said the groups agreed that Proposition 2 would provide more money to buy land. He added that the Legislature acted only after pressure from the groups. "The citizens forced the issue, and the legislators finally cleaned up their act," he said.
Voters who do not know the history of the two proposals may have trouble differentiating between them. Each calls for amending the County Charter.
In four of the five East End towns, residents will decide whether to finance town-level programs to preserve farmland and other open space. Proposals in Southampton and East Hampton, where residential development is surging, call for issuing $5 million in bonds. Proposals in Southold and Shelter Island call for $2 million and $600,000 in bonds, respectively.
In Riverhead the Town Board approved a $2 million bond issue for farms and open space. The action does not require voter approval, but is subject to a referendum if voters petition for one.
Residents in the five East End towns will also vote on whether they support the creation of Peconic County. A "yes" vote requests the State Legislature to permit a binding referendum on the question.
Sentiment for secession from Suffolk County, whose 1.3 million residents live predominantly in the Towns of Babylon, Brookhaven, Huntington, Islip and Smithtown, has been strong on the East End years.
Proponents say the county would give the 110,000 residents of the East End greater control over the farming and resort region that is half of Suffolk.
"It's not about home rule just for the sake of home rule, but to protect our quality of life out here, to keep our rural character and open spaces," said Assemblyman Fred W. Thiele Jr., Republican of Sag Harbor, a leader of the Peconic County movement.
He added that a feasibility study showed that the taxes in a new county would be half the current rate.
A question remains, he said, about whether the Suffolk Legislature would need to ask the State Legislature to approve a binding referendum. The answer could come from a court case in which Staten Island is contending that no home rule message for the New York City Council is needed for the State Legislature to schedule a binding referendum that would let Staten Island secede from the city.
"Obviously that case has great precedential value for us," said Mr. Thiele.
The Suffolk County Comptroller, Joseph R. Caputo, said a new county would cost East End residents more taxes, not less. "They are overlooking a lot of things like the costs of setting up a new government," Mr. Caputo said. "Unfortunately some elected officials are playing with the emotions of people out there, and it isn't quite fair."
"Joe Caputo is 100 percent wrong," Mr. Thiele said. "We have had western Suffolk politicians trying to break the spears of the East End before by saying this would be very expensive, and it just isn't true."

HEADLINE: Environmental Bill: The Pros and Cons

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THERE are those who extol it, those who support it with reservations and others who downright oppose it. But the bottom line is that voters will decide the merits of Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed $1.75 billion Clean Water-Clean Air Bond Act when they go to the polls on Nov. 5.
Mr. Pataki is calling it a fiscally sound measure aimed at addressing a host of environmental ills from the banks of the Hudson River to the shores of Long Island Sound. 
 "This is a campaign to vote yes for our future, to vote yes for our children, to vote yes for New York State leading the nation in environmental protection, quality of life and economic opportunities," the Governor said recently.
But critics of the bill, like members of Change-N.Y., the state's largest taxpayer organization, take an opposing view. They make a point of the $1.3 billion in interest charges that would be paid out over the life of the bond issue.
"There are far cheaper ways to invest in the environment," said Brian D. Backstrom, vice president of the group. "We advocate a pay-as-you-go approach."
So does State Assemblyman Michael J. Bragman, the majority leader from Cicero, who said New York already has more debt that any other state and its credit rating is tied with Louisiana's for lowest in the country. He has proposed instead that revenue set aside by the Governor for debt service payments be dedicated to the state's Environmental Protection Fund.
While Mr. Pataki has proposed using half of the Real Estate Transfer Tax for debt service, Mr. Bragman's proposal would dedicate all of it -- about $200 million a year -- to the fund for environmental remediation projects. Many, though, like Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Democrat from Scarsdale, support the measure, albeit with some restraint. "It was orginally a bad bill," he said. "We had a big fight."
Mr. Brodsky is chairman of the Assembly's Environmental Committee and sponsored the measure in that house. He said he objected to the omission of money for Superfund cleanups, along with the additional debt the state was incurring.
"Programmatically, however, it's a good bill, even with the problems," Mr. Brodsky said. "When you sit down to make your decision, I say it's worth supporting."
There are five categories:
*The Clean Water Program, which calls for $790 million for municipal-treatment improvements, nonpoint-source-control projects, aquatic-habitat restoration and implementation of management plans for the Sound, Lake Champlain, Onondaga Lake, the Finger Lakes, the Great Lakes, Peconic Bay, the South Shore Estuary, New York Harbor and the Hudson River. (The program also includes $150 million for open-space acquisiton to protect water resources, $100 million for state and municipal parks, $50 million for waste water and flood control for communities with fewer than 75,000 residents, $30 million to retain and create jobs in communities with fewer than a million residents and $15 million for dam-safety projects.)
*The Safe Drinking Water Program, which allocates $265 million to start a revolving loan fund and $90 million in grants for municipalities to upgrade drinking-water systems so they meet safe-drinking-water standards and assure safe supplies.
*Solid Waste Initiatives, which provide $75 million for closing the Fresh Kills Landfil on Staten Island, the largest unlined landfill in the world; $50 million for projects at rural and Adirondack landfills and $50 million for capital investments in recycling centers.
*Municipal Environmental Restoration Projects, which call for $200 million in grants to municipalities to clean up so-called brownfields, which are abandoned sites, for re-use according to Superfund standards. (The program would provide municipalities not responsible for polluting a site with 75 percent of the cleanup costs. Municipalities that sell the property back to responsible parties would have to repay to the state all funds received for the cleanup, and that money would then be used to replenish the program account. The restoration program is expected to clean up and put hundreds of sites back on the tax rolls and provide jobs in urban areas.)
*Air Quality Projects, which would allot $230 million for state investments in clean technologies, including $75 million for low-emission buses and electric vehicles, $125 million to help schools switch from coal-fired furnaces and boilers to equipment using cleaner fuel and $30 million to help municipalities retain jobs at businesses that need to improve air emissions.
The Governor said, "With this bold and fiscally sound plan, we will attack the problems that threaten our water and foul our air in a way that helps local taxpayers, protects our schoolchildren and promotes economic growth."
In Westchester, the proposal would provide $200 million to implement the Long Island Sound Study's management plan, which calls for upgrading four sewage-treatment plants to reduce the amount of nitrogen entering the Sound. Nitrogen acts as a fertilizer for algae blooms, which eventually sink to the floor of the 1,300-square-mile estuary, decompose and consume oxygen -- harming fish and other creatures.
"Whether it is the Long Island Sound, the Hudson River or the Great Lakes, these water bodies are our life lines," said David J. Miller, executive director of the National Audubon Society of New York State. "The Governor's environmental proposal will create tens of thousands of jobs, clean up water quality and improve the quality of life for its residents. To us it's a no-brainer."
The proposal also includes $25 million for Hudson River estuaries. In general, the health of the river has improved in recent years, and many environmentalists view it as one of the greatest environmental comeback stories of the century. Much of its current health is attributable to a state bond act passed in the 1960's.
Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a lawyer for the Hudson Riverkeeper Fund, a private environmental group, said his organization sued New York City's 14 treatment plants in 1987 and won a suit requiring the city to install nitrogen-removal devices at the plants. The city was also ordered to remove flotables in the water and to control toxic matter.
"We identified the problem; we identified the solution," said Mr. Kennedy, who is also a professor at the Pace University Environmental Law Clinic. "The only thing that was missing was the money. This bond act provides that."
In other parts of the county, municipal leaders praised the proposal. Neil P. Hess, Village Manager of Hastings-on-Hudson, said passage would allow the village to foreclose on contaminated properties in cases where owners owed back taxes.
In Irvington, the Village Board of Trustees has unanimously approved the proposed bond act and has urged that New York voters follow suit. Stephen A. McCabe, the Village Administrator, said the proposal would allow his municipality and others to clean up old industrial areas, build parks and acquire open space.
Environmental organizations are also endorsing the bill, some with reservations. "It represents a deal struck in an early-morning negotiation," said Anne Rabe, executive director of Citizens' Environmental Coalition, which represents 9,000 people and 90 community environmental groups and civic organizations. "It doesn't address the problem of toxic waste dumps in New York or the ailing Superfund program, which is about to go bankrupt. The bond act should not be seen as the be-all and end-all in terms of dealing with the environment."
In Westchester alone there are nine hazardous-waste-disposal sites: the Caldor Shopping Center in Pelham Manor, the Harmon Railroad Yard in Croton-on-Hudson, the Dobbs Ferry Riverfront Park in Dobbs Ferry, Port Chester Harbor, Peekskill Plaza, Reiter Drum and Barrel Company in Yonkers, Gedney Way Landfill in White Plains, Electronics for Medicine in Pleasantville and Bedford Ponds in Bedford Hills.
Ms. Raver said that although the proposal has problems, her organization supports it.
"Our concern," she said, "is that the Governor has still not seen the light, because he is ignoring so many other environmental problems. So we support the proposal, but with reservations."
Business groups, however, have given it their full approval. "It's critical for the state's economy," said Robert B. Ward, director of research for the Business Council of New York State, a group representing 5,000 companies. "These projects can't be kept waiting."
Research organizations say about 50,000 jobs are created for every billion dollars invested through these types of bond issues.
While Mr. Pataki, a Republican, strongly supports the candidacy of Bob Dole for President, the Governor's political advisers have said they are counting on President Clinton's popularity in the state to draw a wave of Democratic -- that is, pro-bond act -- voters on Nov. 5.
Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute of Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, recently said he felt the bond act would appeal to a liberal constituency and that by seeking its passage in a year when Mr. Clinton is expected to do well, Mr. Pataki would benefit.

PUB-DATE: October 20, 1996

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1786 words

HEADLINE: County Attracts Interest for Using Managed Care

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
A YEAR ago, Westchester County embarked on a radically changed method to provide health care to its poor. In a prototype program that operated under a waiver from the Federal Government, the county became the first in the state to mandate that Medicaid recipients receive care through health maintenance organizations and prepaid service plans.
The county had two goals -- to save money and improve the health care of the poor. Managed care emphasizes preventive care, which proponents say will reduce high costs from acute medical interventions, eliminate the inappropriate and often excessive use of emergency rooms and decrease the number of hospital admissions. 
 Earlier this month, Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation requiring the state's Medicaid population to use managed care -- a sea change in policy, which will put millions of dollars into private hands. As New York prepares to begin this huge transformation in the delivery of its health care services to the needy, many eyes are on Westchester's experience. Has the new system worked here? Has the health care of the poor improved? Has the county reaped the savings it expected?
The answers to those questions so far have proved to be elusive. Through managed care, Medicaid recipients have access to doctors who were once unavailable to them. While people who are privately insured balk at the limits that managed care puts on their choice of doctors, Medicaid recipients were already used to barriers. Although in the old system they were technically free to see the doctor of their choice, that freedom extended only to doctors willing to accept Medicaid rates that ran as low $7 a visit, meaning a limited selection.
While the availability of doctors has increased, health experts agree that it is premature to measure the long-term medical benefits of preventive care for the recipients in the program. The payoff on timely immunizations, pap smears and similar services may not be seen for many years. And with state and Federal pressure to move recipients off welfare rolls sooner, some health care providers say that such benefits based on continuity of care may be difficult to achieve, let alone to document.
"You cannot achieve meaningful long-term improvements in people's health when you have membership tied to a system that is continually churning," said Georgeann Chapin, executive director of Healthsource, one of the plans the county contracts with to provide services. "I can't take someone who is assigned to my plan, have their immunizations up to date, control their asthma, screen their families for T.B., and get their mental health needs met by June when they are dumped off the rolls. Positive health outcomes can only be achieved if there is long-term care."
As for saving money, the county has budget projections on cost savings, but the actual amount spent on Medicaid for the year will not be known until the budget is adopted, which will probably be in March of next year. The Department of Social Services anticipates that when they are available, the numbers will reflect a saving of $8 million. It estimates that the county will spend $58 million this year on managed care for welfare recipients, while a strict Medicaid program would have cost $66.5 million.
Though the data are not yet available, there has been sufficient experience among county officials, health care providers and advocates for the poor to evaluate informally how well the new program is working.
The consensus seems to be that although there have been some rough spots -- particularly in getting Medicaid recipients to choose from among the six plans the county offers -- the transition into managed care seems to have been fairly smooth.
Part of the success of the program can be attributed to the decision by the Department of Social Services to phase in enrollment. At the time of the mandate, the county already had a voluntary Medicaid managed-care program, which had 10,000 enrollees, so there was a degree of preparedness, as well as a structure in place.
The county does not have a shortage of primary-care doctors -- though some areas are better served than others -- so the Department of Social Services was able to make sure that the health plans with whom they contracted had sufficient capacity to serve its Medicaid population.
Over the last year, only the children of families on Home Relief and recipients of Aid to Families with Dependent Children -- roughly 32,000 people -- were mandated into managed care. Those Medicaid recipients are generally younger and healthier and less likely to tax the system.
Next June, the biggest users of the Medicaid system, those who receive Supplemental Security Income, will begin to be enrolled. This group, which includes the elderly and disabled, represents 28 percent of recipients but spends 78 percent of all Medicaid dollars.
The biggest difficulty the county has faced so far is in getting Medicaid recipients voluntarily to choose one of the six managed-care plans being offered. Under the current system, if a recipient does not choose a plan, one is automatically assigned. Department of Social Services officials say that about 27 percent of those involved has been assigned a plan. Advocates for the poor counter that the actual figure is closer to 42 percent, because the county included those voluntarily enrolled in the program as choosing a plan instead of solely using the group that was mandated into the program.
Linda Samuels, Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Social Services, said that trying to get responses from those receiving public assistance -- either by mail or phone -- was an arduous proposition.
"It is a tremendously difficult process," Ms. Samuels said. "No matter what you mail out, you don't get a response. If you call, you don't get a response."
The information on choosing a plan can be daunting. The requirements include a description of the six organizations and the services they offer, where they offer them and which doctors are available. To someone already overwhelmed by difficulty with housing, education, job searches and the like, the choice may simply be too much.
Earlier this month, Ms. Samuels spoke at a meeting of the Westchester Work Group on Medicaid Managed Care here, which is a committee of the Westchester Women's Agenda, a feminist group that works for women's issues. She said the department ran into the same difficulties when it tried to conduct a satisfaction survey to measure how the people receiving Medicaid liked managed care.
The results of the survey were very positive, she said, but was based on a relatively small sample of several hundred people. Of those who responded, 97 percent said they had received their health plan's orientation, and 86 percent rated that orientation excellent or good. Eighty-seven percent said they understood how to use the plan, and 97 percent said it was usually easy to make a doctor's appointment.
On the down side, 27 percent of recipients said they did not know what to do in an emergency. The county has not tracked whether emergency room use is down since the new program was installed. Calls to county emergency rooms revealed little change in use over the last year, except for a significant drop at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers, where emergency room visits dropped from 21,000 to 19,000 over a one-year period that ended last month. "We're seeing less of the common cold, the child who has a slight fever, and uses from the person who doesn't have a personal physician and was using the emergency room as a medical office," said Steve Lucas, a spokesman for the hospital. "We feel that the managed care guidelines have had an effect."
Ms. Samuels also expressed concern about the number of people in the survey who said they had not attended any health education programs and about the number who said they had not used family planning services.
Also speaking at the meeting was Deborah Bachrach, a lawyer who represents managed health maintenance organizations and who helped draft the new state legislation. Ms. Bachrach said that one of the biggest effects of the new law on Westchester would be a provision allowing H.M.O.'s to have a role in marketing their plans to Medicaid recipients. Under the county's current system, health care providers are prohibited from directly enrolling clients.
The reason for the prohibition was that the county wanted to prevent the kind of marketing abuses seen elsewhere in the country, Ms. Samuels said. In some cases, overzealous sales representatives were signing up clients to plans they did not understand and sometimes had too few providers where they lived. She said she feared the marketing representatives would harass people at home or at the county's Social Services office.
Representatives of the health plans, though, say that they are in a better position than anyone to explain their services. "We feel it's much more appropriate to enroll clients within our walls," said Lindsay Farrell, director of operations for the Open Door Family Health Center in Ossining. "We feel that the marketing representatives understand how our system works; they know our providers, they know if this particular pediatrician is good with asthmatic patients or if this family practitioner has an emphasis on education. That's far better than a worker just reading about us in a book."
The state law will also change the formula by which the county divides its automatic assignments, giving some preference to provider-sponsored plans, which are nonprofit.
Some health care advocates worry that shifting huge numbers of people into managed care will drive down reimbursement rates too quickly, putting those who have traditionally taken care of the indigent -- community health centers and hospitals -- at risk for survival. Such institutions are the only ones left that will be able to care for the growing ranks of the uninsured.
Ms. Chapin said, "The minute someone gets off home relief, they're not going to have anywhere to go if the community-organized clinics and hospitals aren't there. As rates fall, you're going to see everybody get squeezed very tightly."
She added that it was also unreasonable to look at managed health care as a panacea for solving the ills of the county's poor. "Managed care is not going to solve the social, economic, educational and housing problems of the poor anymore than Medicaid did," Ms. Chapin said. "People's lives are very complicated, and it's inappropriate to expect a health care organization to solve these problems. There's a lot of current hope for managed care -- and it's well meaning. But it's not realistic."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (92%); 

COMPANY: SOCIAL SERVICES DEPARTMENT (NYS) MEDICAID (94%); 

ORGANIZATION: SOCIAL SERVICES DEPARTMENT (NYS) MEDICAID (94%);

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

ONE-MAN SHOW
The new exhibition at the Silvermine Guild Arts Center in New Canaan features a solo display of oils and watercolors by Charles Reid, artist, author and holder of bi-annual painting workshops. 
 In addition, a group exhibition of Guild members' drawings and sculptures is on view, plus solo shows of paintings by Kirill Doron and the sculpture and mixed media works of Lisa Daugherty.
All three shows will remain through Nov. 10. The guild is at 1037 Silvermine Road, and the galleries are open Tuesday through Saturday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M. Admission is free but donations are welcome (203-966-5617).

DOGS' WEEKEND
Dog owners, lovers, walkers, prospective dog owners, wannabe breeders and trainers will find something of interest during the Ridgefield Library's "Going to the Dogs Weekend" next Saturday and Sunday.
Mary Ellen Duby, a breeder, will talk about buying a puppy on Saturday at 1:30 P.M., focusing on the character traits of various breeds.
Dog obedience will be the subject at 3 P.M. when Posey Armistead, a dog trainer, will discuss basic training techniques and methods of dealing with bad habits.
On Sunday at 1:30, Alexis Dorf, who raises guide dogs for blind people, will talk about how the dogs are trained and describe the characteristics of working dogs. The final session at 3 P.M. will be a talk by Mike McCarren on training his own dog for therapy work at nursing homes. The library address is 472 Main Street and the phone number for more information is 203-438-2282.

ETHICS, POLITICS, MONEY
A series of four free, public lectures on ethics, politics and economics will be delivered at Yale by Sissela Bok, a distinguished fellow at the Harvard Center for Population and Development Studies.
"Truthfulness and Deceit in Public Life" is the title of the first program scheduled for tomorrow at 4 P.M. at Luce Hall, 34 Hillhouse Avenue on the New Haven campus, followed by a public reception at 5:30.
The second talk (to be held on Oct. 28 in Room 102, Linsly-Chittenden Hall, 63 High Street) is entitled "Easeful Death: From Keats to Kevorkian." The third lecture, "Lifeboat Ethics: Human Rights, Population Growth and Scarce Resources," will be on Feb. 24, and "The Philosoper's Stone" will wind up the series on March 3.
Ms. Bok is chairwoman of the Pulitzer Prize board. She has taught philosophy at Brandeis University, and has written extensively on moral choices and human values. (More information: 203-432-0964).

WHIMSY AND MORE
Three artists will appear at the Big Horn Galleries in Fairfield today from 3 to 5 P.M., at an exhibition of their paintings and prints that will run through Nov. 10.
Charles Wysocki and Ed Parker paint sophisticated, whimsical primitives, creating genre scenes of American life. Bill Duffy has a more ethereal approach, painting nature in its infinite variety.
Originals in oil sell for up to $45,000, limited edition prints range from $150 to $3,000.
The gallery, at 1657 Post Road, is open Tuesday through Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., Sunday from noon to 5. More information: 203-255-4613.

IDEAS FROM FARMERS . . .
The first Connecticut Food and Agriculture Exposition takes place today at the State Armory in Hartford from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.
Organized by the state's Department of Agriculture, it will contain 120 exhibits, demonstrations and programs designed to showcase the diversity and technological advances in farming.
On hand to answer questions will be representatives from the Agricultural Experiment Station, the Extension Service, the Farm Bureau, and dozens of nurseries, greenhouses, florists and agricultural associations.
Cooking demonstrations will be performed by members of the Connecticut Chefs Association and several specialty food companies. Children's entertainment includes hands-on exhibits, animals and audience-participation performances on farming at 1 and 3 P.M.
Tickets at the door are $3, free for children under 12. The armory is at 360 Broad Street and parking is free.

. . . AND ARCHITECTS
The Connecticut chapter of the American Institute of Architects will hold its annual Architects Convention and Design Exposition on Thursday from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. at the Hartford Civic Center. Those involved in the design or construction industry might find it a source of new ideas and contacts while ordinary householders or people planning a home may also leave with useful information.
Admission to the exposition and a 6 P.M. reception is free.
Seminars will be conducted by architects, engineers, building officials and contractors on masonry construction from 8:30 to 11:30 A.M.; on emerging architects from 1 to 2 P.M., and on pricing and fee development from 2:30 to 4:30 P.M. They cost $25, $10 and $25 respectively, or $50 for all three.
Tickets are available in advance or at the convention. The number to call for more information is 203-865-2195.

THE HOLOCAUST
A symposium entitled "Work in Progress: The Unfinished Study of the Holocaust" will take place this evening at 7:30 in the Greenwich Reform Synagogue, 257 Stanwich Road. Speaking are Daniel Jonah Goldhagen and Geoffrey Hartman.
Mr. Goldhagen, an associate professor of governnment and social studies at Harvard, is the author of "Hitler's Willing Executioners." Geoffrey Hartman, who has taught literature at Yale for 30 years, established a Judaic studies program and a Holocaust video project. His latest book is "The Longest Shadow: In the Aftermath of the Holocaust," a series of essays. More information: 203-629-0018. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: Sunday October 20, 1996: TRAVEL;
Remembrance of Corn Pone Past

 BODY:
Lots of people dismiss small-town Southern festivals as hokum, but according to "Ghost Dancing on the Cracker Circuit," a forthcoming book from the University Press of Mississippi, these events also constitute serious "nativistic revitalization movements." The book's title is a nod to the poignant "ghost dance" phenomenon that gripped 19th-century American Indians, who danced to bring back the buffalo. In the modern analogue, vanished cultural symbols are similarly ritualized, usually by white Southern Smallvillians who hope, in part, to keep their towns alive by "selling" extinct traditions. Of course, neither hosts nor fans intellectualize matters this much -- they just like pigs and hillbillies -- but for you brainy folkways buffs, here are highlights from the 1996-97 season.

Swine Time
Thirty-one years ago, tiny Salley, S.C., found itself in a pinch: Christmas was coming and there was no money for decorations. Solution? Chitlin' Strut, a festival held right after Thanksgiving, honoring the dish made from minced hog intestines. Besides feeding 60,000 visitors with 10,000 pounds of guts, the event raises $25,000 for civic coffers. "The Strut is definitely the most important thing in town," says Peggy Yon, Salley's treasurer. "Without it, we'd probably fold."
 
Hillbilly Days
In Pikeville, Ky., best known as the site of the Hatfield-McCoy feud and in the heart of the cash-poor Appalachian coal country, Hillbilly Days occurs every April. Created about 20 years back, the event features rambunctious Shriners, dressed as mountain rednecks, who drive beat-up trucks decorated with toilet seats. "It's kind of like historical," says a spokeswoman. Don't laugh too hard, however. Hillbilly Days draws 150,000 people, pumping needed green into the local economy.
 
Scopes Trial Play and Festival
For decades, residents of Dayton, Tenn. -- home of the Scopes Trial -- tried to shake the monkey off their back. Now they're putting the critter to work. Every July, Bryan College stages a festival and a trial re-enactment called "Destiny in Dayton." One goal is to show that the college, a Christian school that was named for William Jennings Bryan, John Scopes's grumpy, Bible-beating antagonist, is still proud of their man. "We're not trying to do a hatchet job," says a college spokesman, "but this is not 'Inherit the Wind.' "

Tobacco Festival
In 1939 there were 2,900 tobacco farms in Bladen County, N.C. By 1980 there were only 340. That doesn't stop the small town of Clarkton from holding an annual October homage to the crop that built it. Only problem: These days, the festival's theme is politically loaded, and the tobacco companies want no part of it. Clarktonians keep pressing on, says Madeleine Clark, the town's unofficial historian, because "history is all we have left."
 
Mayberry Days
The apotheosis of post-modern ghost dancing could be this event, staged every fall by members of "The Andy Griffith Show" Rerun Watchers Club. For a weekend, members gather in Griffith's hometown of Mount Airy, N.C. There they pretend they are visiting Mayberry, the sitcom town that exists only in syndication. "It's like you'd like your family to be," says a recent visitor to Mayberry Days, putting it hauntingly. "It's not like your own family. Nobody's snide to you. Everybody's friendly. Or at least . . . they pretend to be."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Pan Am Announces A Novel Fare Method

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
Pan Am World Airways plans to adopt an unusual fare structure when it ends its introductory fares on Nov. 24.
Unlike many airlines that offer a variety of fares for travelers who book 21 days or 7 days before a flight, Pan Am's fares for each flight will rise as its planes fill up. 
 For example, fares between New York's Kennedy Airport and Miami will start at $99 one way. After a certain number of seats are sold, the fares will rise to $110, then to $132 and finally to $165. First-class fares are $231 one way.
Between New York and Los Angeles, one-way fares will start at $253, then rise to $319 and top out at $385. First-class fares are $495.
The fares are nonrefundable, but Pan Am, unlike many other airlines, does not charge a fee to change a flight. The airline also offers refundable tickets at significantly higher prices.
The introductory fares, which are in effect until Nov. 24, are $99 one way between New York and Miami, and $198 for first class. Between New York and Los Angeles, one-way fares are $199 for economy and $398 for first class.
Pan Am, (800) 359-7262, is using wide-body Airbus A-300 aircraft and will serve meals on its flights. The airline intends to expand its route network to include other major cities. ADAM BRYANT
