LENGTH: 2446 words

HEADLINE: Never Enough Good Jobs To Go Around;
Testimony From the Weary On the Welfare Treadmill

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

 BODY:
THEY are the poor, the jobless, sometimes the lazy, often the diligent. Welfare has kept many of them alive and their families intact.
But the system that has been a poor man's bootstrap since Kennedy's time is in crisis. While it has kept a portion of America clothed, fed and away from crime since its inception more than three decades ago, it has also done little to push people back into the work force. 
 Unable to produce gainful employment and social acceptance for the poor, the welfare program has become a political pariah in an election year, based as much on the American myth of self-reliance as on the real need to educate people and train them for work. In New Jersey, as throughout the country, tough new welfare rules are challenging both its philosophy of help and those who depend on it to stay alive.
Governor Whitman outlined her plan to overhaul the state welfare program earlier this year. It would limit benefits to five years for both families and individuals. But unlike proposals in many other states, Mrs. Whitman promises to provide incentives to help welfare recipients move more quickly into the workplace by investment in child care, transportation and job training.
The Whitman proposal, which is similar to the new Federal program enacted in August, is being drafted for consideration by the Legislature, where approval is expected.
Many recipients in the state are already required to work or go to school for 20 hours a week to receive benefits. But teachers and trainers complain that with the new rules will also come cutbacks on the very programs intended to develop skills.
They say the changes will most likely lead more people to a trough with less to offer, particularly in the cities, where good jobs are already hard to come by and unemployment is epidemic.
Interviews with present and former welfare recipients in the state show a group that by and large does not know what to make of the changes.
Tying benefits to work, cutting Aid to Families With Dependent Children and enforcing an end to aid after five years: none of this will fix the system, say many of those interviewed, adding that some people would be sure to fail even if enough jobs were there to be filled.
Among their ranks are the people on society's margins: the homeless and unskilled housed by a government check, the unwed mother with a baby and no job skills, the man with a criminal record whose only experience is dealing drugs on the street, the abused wife clawing her way out of violence, and the families where welfare has come to seem the dividend of being a poor American.
 
THE BASICS
'It's All Backwards'
It is lunchtime at St. Paul's Community Development Corporation in Paterson, and dozens of welfare mothers have just been let out of class after hours of learning how to multiply and read. Some are legal immigrants desperate to improve their English so they can get a job and stay in the United States. Others are United States citizens who never learned the basics, their school careers cut short by a series of births and failed marriages.
They pass by a board used to teach English as a second language, their simple dream clearly laid out in one example: "I want to be a taxicab driver. They make a lot of money. I need a lot of money. I want to pass my test."
Some have been on welfare for nearly a decade, and few have ever been able to keep a job. They hope to gain what they have lacked for a lifetime in a few short months of cramming but say there is a pall cast by welfare reform.
"It's all backwards," said Donna Turner, who has spent the last eight years taking care of her four children on a welfare ration. "Right now at least they are letting us get training, but there are still no jobs. They should be making sure there are jobs out there for us. Instead we're basically educating ourselves for nothing, because we still can't get work once we're graduated.
"Even if we get a job, we can't hold on to them because of layoffs," she added. "It's just a merry-go-round, and people ain't getting nowhere."
At 37, and skilled only as a worker in a dry-cleaning shop, Mrs. Turner has plenty of company among those trying to get ahead but seeing little reward for their efforts. And these are the lucky ones, women with children who qualify for special training that the most unschooled and the single are often not offered.
"You can't get a job without experience and you have to get a job to get experience," said Xiomara Martinez, echoing a common refrain. A Dominican immigrant with three young children, she has spent five years on welfare. "There is no opportunity for us."
Frank Geier, a 30-year-old teacher at the school, calls this "the reality of the marketplace." Paterson, like many of New Jersey's urban centers, has lost its industry, the silk mills and other major factories having long since shut or moved away.
The poor have no transportation to get to jobs in the suburbs, and unions are tightening the market in the city. Meanwhile, teachers at St. Paul's are forced to train double the number of applicants with about half the welfare aid they received two years ago. Next year, they worry that the aid -- which now only barely covers teaching salaries but nothing else -- will be further cut.
"It's a bad situation," Mr. Geier said, "one that is being made worse by politicians who want to get up on front of their constituents and show they are cleaning the rolls but have no idea what the reality is in the streets."
To the question "Who, then, gets off welfare?" the answer seems, not surprisingly, to be "Those with a great deal of outside support and assistance." Strong family or church connections seem to play a part, while an inner resiliency and a lack of time on welfare all appear to give the agency's success stories the extra advantage they need.
Few of them credit the agency itself with much of a helping hand, saying it did little more than offer busy work, a warning to hurry up, and a check every month.

A WAY OUT
'I Did It All Myself'
Jacqueline Wright, 31, a mother of two in Orange, was placed in a hospital stamping mail when she asked her caseworker for training; two other recipients joined her putting files in a cabinet for four hours, five days a week.
Ms. Wright says she would still be there had she not gone one day with a friend taking a typing test at the Urban League. Not wanting to just sit around, she also took the test. Passing it gave her a spot in the organization's internship program, where after working well beyond the 20 hours prescribed by her welfare office, she was later hired as a secretary.
"I went into these programs voluntarily," she said. "Even though it's mandatory, no one at the welfare office called and told me it was time, and I only heard from my caseworker when I called her. I got this job because I treated it as a job, but I did it all by myself."
While Ms. Wright was dealing with joblessness, her fellow recipient, Lea Zayachek, 28, had a multitude of ills to combat while trying to get off the system in Bloomfield. Fleeing an abusive husband and with two young children, no child support, little work experience and no home, she was finally forced to declare bankruptcy to get welfare payments. Even then, caseworkers misplaced her file for three months, she said.
But after taking an eight-week computer training course financed by the agency's Family Development Program and existing on welfare for a year, she found a job as a receptionist at a fertilizer company after a friend there recommended her. It pays about $18,000 a year, much of that eaten up by rent, the rest by medical care, school supplies and clothes for her two children.
"Right now we're getting by," she said, sitting with the children in their new one-bedroom apartment as they prepared for Halloween. "But in a year, welfare won't help me with child care anymore, and I will have to come up with at least $150 a week to pay for that. And if I don't get child support, or a big raise, I don't know if I will make it."

SELF-ESTEEM
'I'm Getting Ahead'
For those who squeeze through the system into gainful employment, there is no better feeling. Former welfare recipients talk glowingly about what it's like to have somewhere to go when they get up in the morning, and the pride they have in being able to pay their own way.
They talk about having an appointment to get their hair done -- like normal people -- and how they finally see a line toward the future. Most are part time, struggling for security and worried about being laid off. But often for the first time, they feel they have some control over the outcome.
"I'm an adult and I'm getting ahead," said Lucille Walker, 41, of East Orange, a welfare recipient who recently got a job with New Jersey Transit in Elizabeth and is hoping someday to be full time. "I'm just beginning to understand that I can make a difference in my life, that there will be ups and downs but that I have control over what I do."
But the training programs are mainly geared toward women with children, and few have spots for men, particularly those -- part of a growing segment in society -- with criminal records for drug-related offenses. James E. Murphy, 32, of East Orange recalls that when he went into the welfare office after serving jail time on a robbery charge and a series of odd jobs dried up, "they just looked at me like another one for the state, told me to fill out the form and sit over there."
Mr. Murphy said he might still be sitting around waiting for his check and doing community service if his godmother had not seen a flier for a private program that helped people train for commercial drivers' licenses in Newark. He passed the course and now has a job driving for Goodwill Industries, but few other such training or internship programs are out there for men in his city.
Because of this, the feeling of making it that now energizes people like Ms. Walker and Mr. Murphy has escaped many of the haggard men who file nightly into the foyer of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, looking for a bed and a warm meal. On the wall, a sign reads, "Never let any mistake cause you to stop believing in yourself," but it's a hard mantra to follow.
Some of these men, blankets and toiletries in hand, are the working poor, seasonal laborers or those who eke out a living in jobs with no benefits and too little money to afford a rent. Others have revolved in and out of the welfare system for years, their work history cut short by layoffs or prison terms.
Jobs are what many want. But these are not forthcoming to the unskilled and under-educated. And while New Jersey's welfare system already pushes these men into unpaid labor, few feel they are learning the skills necessary to get a job that will keep them off the dole.
After a string of jobs from bookbinding to construction, Salvador Brito, 36, finally found himself without an option three months ago and applied for welfare. Before that, he had always found a way to get by on short jobs at minimum wage or below, jobs from which he was laid off just before he was eligible to collect unemployment, and then rehired.
With a seventh-grade education, he was hoping that welfare would help him get training while he received its benefits. So far, training has consisted of sweeping up streets and taking out garbage, he said.
"When I applied for welfare, I told them I wanted to go to school to improve myself and get a job I can count on," he said. "I've been to that office three times, and every time I requested some help getting skills. But my social worker just looked at me and told me to go to the city and sweep."
He works for the city three days a week. Every other day is spent looking for a job, sometimes filling out applications two and three times a month at restaurants, factories or laundries, and often lying about his skills in desperation. But his choices are few and ill-paying, offering up the same subsistence work he has lived since a teen-ager.
"When you got nothing but a sixth- or seventh-grade education it's tough," he said. "Guys that don't have skills can't get any of the jobs. Education is what we need."
Alex Bush, 40, sat nearby. He has sold cars and vacuum cleaners, been a construction worker, welder and machine operator. "I'm a jack of many trades, a master to none," he said with a laugh, adding that he had not stayed long enough in any one job to become an expert or advance.
Part of the problem was a term in prison. Convicted more than a decade ago for possessing drugs, he has twice violated his parole, he said, adding that a few days in jail always leaves him jobless once he's out.
While he is confident that something will turn up soon, he is not so certain about the future of many others in his position. For one thing, those who haven't been to prison haven't learned much of a trade, he said.
"With this workfare stuff, you don't learn anything, except for maybe how to clean your house or take out the garbage," he said. "When I was in prison, we could get training in everything from paralegal work to machine operating. But our here, they have you sweeping the streets.
"These guys in here got no skills and the welfare system isn't interested in giving them any. They just want them off welfare. But if they don't learn anything that gets them ahead, they'll be right back on it in a couple of years."
Some of his bunkmates have been coming to St. Paul's for years, whether they have had a job or not. Many are drug abusers, alcoholics or mentally unclear. Others have just got old, finding it harder and harder to fabricate a living in the marketplace of the unskilled. Some have slept in the shelter every day since it was opened yearround last September, and were frequent visitors before, when it took people in only for the coldest six months.
Fastino Rodriguez, a 51-year-old Puerto Rican, has been bedding there for nearly four years, except for short periods when he spent $50 a week for a nearby room in a rundown hotel. Before this year, he needed the shelter even though he had worked for two decades packing cakes for a bakery; now he was unemployed, and things had changed little.
Mr. Rodriguez can't drive, knows nothing about carpentry and has no other skills besides packing cakes. But he is confident that if he must find work, he will. "I can do anything," he said from bunk No. 6, one ear to a Mexican radio station. "I'm just very depressed right now and I don't know what kind of job I can get. I don't know why I'm here, so I pray, but if I must, I can work again. I just need somebody to give me a job."

GRAPHIC: Photos: STILL TRYING Donna Turner has spent eight years trying to get off welfare. SECTION: Section 9; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1452 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Manhattan Lodging;
If Room Prices Keep Rising, So May New Hotels

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THE hospitality business in New York is booming," said Ambrose Cheung, a director of the Lai Sun Development Company of Hong Kong, which led a group that bought the luxury Four Seasons Hotel earlier this year. "For overseas investors, New York is the prime city of the East Coast of the United States."
And he expects the good times to continue. "The last two years have been very strong and we expect a 3 to 4 percent increase in occupancy rates and 4 to 5 percent increase in room rates over the next two years," Mr. Cheung said. 
 This is, indeed, a happy period for New York's hotel industry, which was laying off workers in the early part of the decade. With the pace of business increasing, which means more business travel, and with a weak dollar attracting hordes of foreign tourists, hotel occupancy rates are at the highest levels since the early 1980's and expected to go higher. The cost of a hotel room in the city is climbing as well, although it has not yet gotten high enough that developers are prepared to start new construction.
According to Coopers & Lybrand's hospitality consulting practice, 78.8 percent of the city's hotel rooms were occupied in the first six months of the year, compared with 74.8 percent in the first half of 1995. Since the fall is a heavy travel period, the occupancy rate is expected to go over 80 percent in the second half of the year. When hotels sell out or get close to it, managers gain the flexibility to raise room rates. And they have. Coopers & Lybrand reports that the average room rate in New York in the first half of the year was $157.96 a night, up 7.7 percent from $146.61 in the previous year.
"You have to look at this from a historical perspective," said Arthur Adler, director of Coopers & Lybrand's hospitality consulting practice in New York. "The industry bottomed out in 1991. It was overbuilt, overleveraged and there was a recession on. Occupancy rates fell below 70 percent and average room rates stagnated."
As a result of the slump, many owners lost control of their properties, which reverted to banks and other lenders after the owners defaulted on loans. Among those that wound up in the hands of lenders was Donald Trump's Plaza Hotel, taken over by a consortium of lenders, and the Hotel Macklowe, taken over by the then Chemical Bank.
"Hotel was a four-letter word for banks in the early 1990's," said Douglas P. Hercher, director of investment sales and finance for Jones Lang Wootton U.S.A. "Those properties went into workout in 1991 and 1992 and the last of them were not disposed of until last year."
"In the 1980's a lot of people built because of the availability of capital," Mr. Cheung said. "But the economics and finances did not work out." The Lai Sun group bought the Four Seasons, where the average daily room rate is $480, for about $200 million, or about half the approximately $400 million cost of building. Still, at about $500,000 a room, it was a record price for the acquisition of a New York hotel.
As a result, lenders remain skittish about backing new construction, but are increasingly willing to finance hotel purchases and the conversion of office buildings at least partly to hotel use. Donald J. Trump's conversion of the old Paramount Communications building facing Columbus Circle is to include hotel rooms as well as condominiums. And Bernard Goldberg's Gotham Hospitality Group is planning to convert an office building at 141 East 44th Street into a 162-room hotel to be called the Hotel Grand Central, in recognition of its proximity to the railroad station. At the northwest corner of 52d Street and Third Avenue, the 250,000 square feet in the tower section of the old Macmillan Building is expected to be converted to a hotel while the much larger lower floors will probably still be used for offices. "The lower floors are too deep and dark, but the tower, where the floors are about 12,000 square feet each, is more easily converted," said Ron Cohen, a broker with Edward S. Gordon, who was involved in the recent sale of the building. "There will probably be two entrances to the building, one for the hotel and one for the offices." The building was purchased by Stellar Management, which has not designated an operator for the hotel part of the project.
EVEN the little construction that is under way represents hedged bets, pairing hotel rooms with other uses. The Renaissance Plaza project in downtown Brooklyn, being developed by Joshua L. Muss, will combine a Marriott hotel with office space, and the Embassy Suites Hotel to be built in Battery Park City will combine a hotel and 10-screen movie theater. Industry executives say other conversions are under active study, with an office-building-to-hotel project likely in the Downtown area and a limited-service hotel possible on 46th Street in the Times Square area. Because they use existing buildings, conversions are less costly than all-new construction.
The vacancy rates demonstrate that the demand for rooms exists and industry analysts say the market could easily absorb more rooms. "There are approximately 60,000 hotel rooms in New York," said John A. Fox, senior vice president of PKF Consulting, which specializes in the hotel industry. "You can make an argument that the market could absorb 5,000 to 10,000 more, but you cannot finance new construction."
But with room rates rising, it may just be a matter of time before new hotels are built. "We are projecting an average room rate of $169 for calendar 1996, which is getting pretty close," Mr. Fox said. "We are probably just a few years away from justifying new construction in Midtown."
Time is very much on the mind of the executives directing the biggest announced hotel project in the city, the Tishman Realty and Construction Company's E Walk project on Eighth Avenue between 42d and 43d Streets. The project includes a 200,000-square-foot entertainment and retail complex along 42d Street and an 860-room, 45-story, 650,000-square-foot hotel that will be entered from 43d Street.
"We will start demolition for the retail part of the project soon, but the timing of the hotel depends on the state of the transformation of Midtown West and the state of financial markets," said Thomas Arasi, president of the Tishman Hotel Group.
He said that as new projects like Madame Tussaud's wax museum, the Disney Store and the refurbished New Amsterdam Theater replace the dingy buildings that sell pornographic tapes and movies, the bright, friendly neighborhood "will eliminate the landscape as an item in due diligence." And he said the lukewarm willingness of lenders to finance new construction "will go to hot and red-hot over the next 12 to 24 months."
"We think we can build a better hotel for ourselves and the city if we wait 12 to 18 months," before beginning to build, Mr. Arasi said. "We think by then the market will support a hotel that is a little fancier, with higher room rates, than we could now." In all, the E Walk project, whose name is meant to suggest entertainment and a collection of restaurants and shops, is expected to cost $300 million and will be built entirely by Tishman.
HOTEL industry analysts say the current conversion and mixed-use hotel projects are a precursor to new construction. "Conversion is the first step," said Angelo Stambules, vice president for the hospitality services group of Landauer Associates. "It minimizes the cost of construction because you have the existing skeleton of a building to work with."
"There is plenty of money available now for acquisitions, renovation and conversions," said Daniel H. Lesser, director of the hospitality group at Cushman & Wakefield. "This is going to cause values to rise and approach replacement-cost levels."
He said foreign investors, like Mr. Cheung's group, were an important factor in the market. "We are seeing tremendous interest from overseas investors, who want to buy hotels in New York," Mr. Lesser said. "You cannot be a worldwide hotel company unless you have representation in London, Tokyo and New York."
Recent sales indicate prices are beginning to approach replacement costs, industry participants say. "The Vista sold for $140 million, which is $200,000 a room," said Mr. Hercher of Jones Lang Wootton. "Replacement cost is probably $240,000 to $250,000 a room, so we are getting there."
He said the reluctance of lenders to go first might delay the start of hotel projects in New York, but once the ice is broken, a rash of projects may follow. "It will take someone with courage to do the first one," he said. "The numbers almost work today and they are getting better. There is just a psychological hurdle to overcome."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Adult Communities Are Spreading Across the State

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
HAVING rebounded from its recessionary slump, the market for active adult communities in the state is edging forward, stoking developer interest in starting new projects.
Such communities cater to people 55 and over in their pre-retirement or retirement years. They offer recreation, socializing and someone else to do the outside maintenance. 
 The interest is coming from long-term players like the Kokes Organization, of Manchester; U.S. Home, based in Dallas with offices in Freehold, and H. Hovnanian Industries, of Tinton Falls. They continue to build, and are being joined by newcomers that want to increase their market presence, like K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, the state's largest developer. Other new arrivals include Calton Homes and SGS Communities Inc., both of Manalapan, and the Mignatti Companies, of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. Toll Brothers, also in Huntingdon Valley, said it also would enter the field.
There are about 100 active adult communities in the state, with 80,000 units, according to state and industry sources. Some 12,000 more units are approved, under way or planned.
Many of the new homes are planned for Ocean County, long a locus of such housing, and for nearby Monmouth County. But they are creeping into other parts of the state like Mercer and Burlington Counties and to a lesser degree into Morris and Somerset Counties, industry experts said. They are also going up near employment centers, underscoring the trend that many buyers still work.
The activity is being fueled by several factors. One is the improvement in the state's overall housing market, enabling buyers over 55 to sell their homes to buy the new ones. In the last three years, sales prices for adult housing have risen 3 to 7 percent, said James Robbins, president of RAD Consultants, a real estate consulting concern in Fairfield. Most units are selling for $160,000 to $175,000, he said.
Another factor is the trend of such buyers to stay near their families rather than relocate to retirement areas in the South and Southwest.
That, Mr. Robbins said, is also pushing development to areas where adult housing is not now available.
The shape of new communities is also changing, with many smaller than the giant developments of the past, said William Becker, a Teaneck housing consultant who specializes in retirement communities. The size is being dictated both by what developers say is a demand for more intimate communities with modest recreational amenities to keep monthly fees down and by the state's shrinking supply of huge sites.
Yet the houses are getting bigger. The average house is 1,700 square feet, with some over 2,000 square feet, compared with 1,100 square feet a decade ago, Mr. Robbins said. Most are single-family detached homes.
DEVELOPERS also say many municipal officials welcome adult housing. Among the reasons are that it offers people 55 and over an alternative to maintaining their old one-family homes and a way to keep them from moving away.
Such communities also add to the tax base but do not overburden local services like schools.
The main force, however, is demographics. State data show the number of people 55 to 74 will rise modestly through the end of the century and then build through 2010, when 19.3 percent of the state's 8.5 million residents will be in that group.
After that it is expected to rise further as baby boomers enter the retirement housing market, said James W. Hughes, Dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University in New Brunswick.
Still, developers and analysts say there is a sizable wave of people to support new communities. Though they say state regulations and the cost of building such communities, which require more initial capital for amenities like clubhouses, will temper the activity, there are concerns of overbuilding.
"Developers are following the same snake dance," Dr. Hughes said. "It will work for a while, but the person at the end of the line may well lose out."
Among the largest projects is Renaissance, which Calton Homes, a subsidiary of Calton Inc., is developing as its first project. Renaissance will have 2,000 units around an 18-hole golf course on Route 571 in Manchester Township in Ocean County.
"This is a carefully planned reaction to a market that is growing, not shrinking," said Rick Griffith, senior vice president of the company's adult housing operation. It will be built in phases over 14 years. He said the existing supply had been absorbed "and there is good demand for a large development" offering a variety of housing and amenities.
The first 307-unit phase will comprise single-family detached homes with 1,500 to 2,200 square feet and one- or two-car garages, priced from the $140,000's to $220,000's. Amenities include a 25,000-square-foot clubhouse, tennis courts and a health spa. The monthly maintenance fee is expected to be $95. Sales open later this year. At the same time a few miles away on School House Road, the Kokes Organization will start sales on its new community of 250 homes. And early next year it will open a project near Route 70 in Toms River, a hub for such housing. It will have 1,100 detached and attached homes edging a golf course. Homes at both will range from 1,308 to 2,277 square feet and be priced at $115,000 to $250,000.
Aware of the competition, some developers are moving south in the county to Barnegat. There, the Mignatti Companies is building its first New Jersey project. Stephen McKenna, its president, said the reason was simple: "The demographics are right, and we saw Barnegat as an alternative to Toms River."
The project, Heritage Bay, near Routes 9 and 72, will have 293 detached homes, each with 1,200 to 1,800 square feet of space and one- or two-car garages. Prices are $104,900 to $136,000.
THERE will be a 4,000-square-foot clubhouse with billiards and card rooms as well as an outdoor pool. But more costly amenities like a golf course and tennis courts have been omitted to keep monthly maintenance charges low, said Mr. McKenna, who put such charges at $40.
"We are hitting a niche in the market," he said, adding that 60 homes had been sold since sales opened in June.
Developers are also moving to what they say are untapped markets in other counties.
One is K. Hovnanian Enterprises, which returned to the adult housing market in 1994 after a decade's absence with the opening of a 1,500-unit project in Lakewood in Ocean County. With half of the one-family detached homes at that project sold, Hovnanian is moving ahead with five more projects totaling 3,500 units. All will be outside Ocean County, and some will be smaller, with fewer recreational amenities.
"We continue to follow the baby boomers," said Ara Hovnanian, the company's president. "Now we are expanding our product line in, and focus on, adult housing."
A case in point is its latest project, Four Seasons at Wall, with 400 homes and a 12,000-square-foot clubhouse in Wall Township in Monmouth County. During the first weekend of sales last month, contracts were signed on 100 of the 1,618-to-2,318-square-foot homes. Prices are $192,950 to $226,950.
And SGS Communities is entering the market with two projects. One, with 528 homes and a 15,000-square-foot clubhouse, is in West Windsor in Mercer County; the other, with 115 homes and a smaller clubhouse, is in Holmdel in Monmouth County.
Explaining the company's strategy, Fred B. Rothman, its president, said, "We saw an opportunity and need for more adult housing and are taking it into new areas." Earlier this month, the company also merged with D.R. Horton, a large builder in Dallas, which "gives us the security of a capital base to properly develop adult housing," Mr. Rothman said.
Prices for the 1,500-to-2,250-square-foot homes will range from the mid-$150,000's to the low $200,000's. Construction on each project will start this spring, Mr. Rothman said.

HEADLINE: Never Enough Good Jobs To Go Around;
Go From Welfare to Work? Somebody Has to Be Hiring

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
WE don't want to spend all our time and energy answering questions about whether there will be enough jobs," said Eileen McGinnis, chief of Governor Whitman's Office of Policy and Planning. "We want to spend our time making the program a success."
But jobs -- that is, enough jobs with enough employers willing to hire welfare recipients -- are the key to the success of the state's ambitious welfare overhaul. The state is planning to move most of its 125,000 welfare recipients entirely off the dole within five years. The only exceptions will be people who are too mentally or physically disabled to work, and the number of people in these categories is not expected to exceed 20 percent of all people now on welfare. 
 Obviously, getting people working requires job openings -- and these must be entry-level jobs with employers willing to hire inexperienced workers.
"We're expecting enough jobs," said Kathy Krepcio, director of policy and planning for the State Department of Health and Human Services . She cited State Department of Labor reports predicting 65,000 new low-skilled jobs over the next 10 years. (The newest figures have lowered that prediction to 45,430 low-skilled jobs.) Also, she said,30,000 jobs are expected to be created at six new Atlantic City casinos, and ripples from those jobs could generate 10,000 more positions in the area.
But local economists and social-service workers are less confident.
"Will there be enough jobs?" asked Don Linky, president of the New Jersey Public Affairs Institute, a nonprofit economics research center. "The answer is no, on the basis of the job-creation performance of state over the past few years." Anne Miller Christensen, a caseworker at St. Joseph's Home for homeless families in Jersey City, said: "The jobs they're imagining aren't there. The jobs that are there don't begin to generate the income necessary to pay rent, child care, medical and put food on the table."
A report by Mercer Street Friends, a Quaker-founded social services agency in Trenton, details New Jersey's unemployment picture, making it clear that things would have to change markedly to absorb tens of thousands of new, unskilled workers with little education. At present there are three people for every job opening in the state. And the jobs are frequently many miles from the people who need them -- people who are often too poor to afford a car.
In a few counties, especially relatively affluent ones, like Somerset and Hunterdon, the number of people hunting for jobs is about equal to the number of jobs available.
But unemployment, not surprisingly, is highest in the counties of New Jersey's economically troubled cities, where the bulk of welfare recipients live: Essex, Passaic, Camden and Hudson. Essex County, for instance, has more than 6 people for each job opening. In Hudson and Passaic Counties, more than 5 people are vying for each open slot.
And these are jobs available at all levels, including ones demanding college or graduate degrees. The recent heavy job loss in corporate downsizing mean that skilled and managerial workers are often willing to take lower-level work
"New Jersey is lagging behind the nation in overall job creation," Mr. Linky said. "Job growth is strongest in suburban corridors. Most people coming off the welfare rolls are living in cities. There are gaps between where jobs are being created and where people are living, and there are gaps between education levels required by jobs and education levels of people on welfare."
The state's plan is to address the latter gap with pointed job-training, its philosophy being, as Commissioner William Waldman of the Department of Human Services said, "The best training for a job is a job."
That means no general schooling except for teen-agers who haven't graduated from high school. Instead, the state will emphasize basic workplace job skills, like promptness, phone manners and getting along with bosses and co-workers. For the least able, there will be workfare. The state will also pay employers to give welfare recipients six months of on-the-job training, a program Joan Verplanck, president of the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce, called "a great return on the investment."
And to address the former gap, the miles between jobs and those who need them, there are planned innovations in transportation. The state is trying to persuade New Jersey Transit to add more buses on new routes from cities to suburbs. There is talk of hiring a transportation broker -- a kind of managed care for the roads -- to coordinate car pools and send vans back and forth.
Still, what happens to welfare recipients who, after five years of trying, still don't have jobs that pay enough to support their children? The state's old and obscure but still valid Poor Law says they may turn to their municipality, which is obligated to help them, supplying emergency food, shelter, and clothing. But it's unlikely many mayors will be prepared to step in.
Mr. Waldman, however, has another solution if in five years it's needed: change the law. "I really think the jobs will be there," he said, "and with the right mix of job training and workplace training we can hook people up with them. But the people of this state are moderate."
If welfare reform doesn't work, he said, "they'll change it."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "KEEPING TRACK: Where the Work Will Be" shows the projected job growth in New Jersey, 1994-2005. (Source: Mercer Street Friends) (pg. 10)

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
The Whitman Approach To Welfare Reform

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Governor Whitman has joined with other Republicans to warn voters that President Clinton, if re-elected, would weaken the new Federal welfare law. But Mrs. Whitman herself proposes softening some of the new law's harshest provisions as part of her plan to overhaul New Jersey's welfare program.
In comparison with her fellow Republican governors in New York, Connecticut and Pennsylvania, Mrs. Whitman's approach toward moving welfare recipients more quickly into the workplace is decidedly more compassionate, as well as pragmatic. It takes into consideration some of the obstacles that the poor face finding jobs, and seeks to remove them. 
 While emphasizing "personal responsibility," Mrs. Whitman promises to give welfare recipients some of the tools they need to break their cycle of dependency, such as access to affordable child care and help with transportation, along with job placement and job training programs. She also says that health care benefits would be made available through Medicaid up to two years after a welfare recipient finds a steady job.
In many ways, Governor Whitman's plan is strikingly similar to the new Federal welfare law. When she first outlined her ideas for changing the state's approach toward welfare earlier this year, she also proposed a five-year time limit on cash benefits. And like the Federal law, she wanted unmarried teen-age mothers to stay in school and live with their parents or under adult supervision and she wanted parents to cooperate with child-support enforcement efforts.
Yet, Mrs. Whitman proposes to use state dollars to continue providing cash benefits to noncitizens in families eligible for Aid to Families with Dependent Children under the old program, even though the new Federal law will no longer make Federal dollars available for public assistance to legal immigrants. Mrs. Whitman is also looking to continue Medicaid coverage for elderly legal immigrants now in nursing homes, and extending food stamp benefits to legal immigrants as long as possible this fiscal year.
She also offers two loopholes to the poor that are not contained in the new Federal law. If a woman with a child under 6 does not have child care, and therefore cannot work, the Federal law protects herfrom losing benefits, but the clock on the woman's five-year time limit continues to tick. Mrs. Whitman proposes stopping the clock until adequate child care is found.
In addition, Mrs. Whitman has included another provision for working parents who abruptly lose their job through no fault of their own, such as a layoff. After unemployment benefits expired, they would be able to receive public assistance for up to 12 months, without its being counting toward their five-year limit. Those who have already surpassed the five-year time limit would be eligible for benefits up to 12 months. Both the Federal and state plans provide hardship exemptions from the time limit for up to 20 percent of the welfare case load.
Mrs. Whitman, who submitted an abbreviated version of her plan to the Federal Government last week so the state could begin qualifying for Federal funds, said that all of her ideas would be outlined in state legislation that she expects to be completed and introduced next week.
There is strong support among Republicans in the Republican-controlled Legislature for Mrs. Whitman's proposal. And since President Clinton signed the Federal welfare bill into law, it is doubtful that Democrats will make too much of a fuss, particularly since Mrs. Whitman's proposal contains many of the same changes that leading Democrats have suggested the President consider after the election.
"We have been reaching out to both sides of the aisle," Mrs. Whitman said last week. "We want to make this is a program that is going to work for New Jersey and for people who need the support."
But the biggest test for Governor Whitman and for the Legislature is not legislative approval of a new state welfare program. It will be making sure that enough dollars are available to cover the enormous cost of providing the tools that will help welfare recipients find the jobs to support their families.
Take the issue of transportation, as an example. If you are poor and live in Camden, or even rural Salem County, you are unlikely to find a job down the block. Economists warn that there are not enough jobs. But most of the jobs that are available are outside the areas where there is the biggest need. Getting to work anywhere within New Jersey is almost impossible without a car.
The Governor acknowledges the problem and she said state human service officials were working closely with state transportation officials to find solutions. Although the state will initially receive about $40 million from the new Federal block grant this year, providing transportation assistance, affordable child care, job placement and job training programs are expensive.
Tackling welfare is a huge task, but so far New Jersey looks as if it is taking the best possible approach under the circumstances. New Jerseyans, while fiscal conservatives, are also known for their moderate stance on social issues. The Governor's plan mixes compassion with good politics.
But again, it will not be clear until after Governor Whitman presents her fourth state budget in January how strong her commitment is to changing welfare, as we know it, in New Jersey.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 2340 words

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN '96;
Talking About New Jersey With the Candidates for the Senate

 BODY:

New Jersey, A State of Mind
 
TORRICELLI
 
Q. Talk about New Jersey. You've represented a slice of the state for quite a few terms, and now you want to represent the entire state in the Senate. How does New Jersey as a whole differ from the Ninth District?
 
A. You know, there have really been two halves to my service in the Congress. I was born and lived all my life in small suburban communities in Bergen County. I am a product of the postwar suburban environment. And from the issues of quality education to controlling taxes, I represented the views of those constituents for a long time. 
 But my district changed in 1990, which was good for me and my education [and] very important for my service in the United States Senate. . . . I learned a lot. People asked about why did I vote for the Clinton deficit reduction plan. You know, 20,000 families in my district, the vast majority of them living in Jersey City, had their taxes cut under the deficit reduction plan. We had 20,000 families getting their income tax credit; the Clinton plan reduced their taxes by $2,200. . . .
When Jersey City came into my district, the home heating assistance for low-income families was being eliminated under the Clinton budget . . . 25,000 families who every winter get help meeting their utility bills so that they can maintain their mortgage payments and not lose their homes.
I've learned a lot about different sides of life in New Jersey in the last five years. That is why as United States Senator some of my highest priorities are keeping the light rail systems going into Hudson County and mass-transit improvements in Newark and Elizabeth, because those systems are vital to economic revitalization and attracting jobs. . . .
We're going to do more to improve the infrastructure in the next five years, if we can keep the appropriations approved in the Federal Government, than we've done in a generation. This is very exciting. This light rail system in Hudson County for Jersey City is an economic revitalization. And it will extend into Newark [and] Elizabeth, with our rail link. We can make a real difference here. . . .
I know how people are skeptical of New Jersey's cities. . . . I walked with Sharpe James through Newark last weekend. Fifteen thousand new town houses through tax credits. Giving corporations tax credits, and private companies are building new attractive town houses in which people take real pride and they own their own homes.
You know, 15,000 housing units is not going to change urban America. But it is the old story of "better to light a single candle than curse the darkness." Gingrich's Congress voted to repeal the tax credits. . . . Mr. Zimmer voted against the light rail system in Hudson County and the Newark-Elizabeth rail link and airport extension. . . . He voted against our own appropriation for the most important mass transportation improvements in a generation.

ZIMMER
 
Q. You've represented one district, and now you're seeking a statewide office. What have you learned about the state as you make that transition?
 
A. It's bigger than I thought it was. It's been a remarkably diverse state, and I've met people from all sorts of economic and ethnic backgrounds, had the opportunity to meet people I never would have been able to meet if I weren't running for this office.
So the diversity of the state has been something that I knew about intellectually but I really hadn't experienced personally, and it's a remarkable, remarkable place. To be able to speak in a Hindu temple before 5,000 Indian Americans or to be able to meet with Coptic Egyptians, to be able to talk to some folks in areas that are even more rural than my own . . . it's been a personally enriching experience for me.
And I've been able to meet with people like Monsignor Linder [founder of the New Community Corporation in Newark] and see in some depth the kinds of things they've been able to do in the City of Newark. What I've read about but never been able to actually see for myself. Go behind the scenes at the casinos in Atlantic City and look through the one-way mirrors or two-way mirrors and see how they actually operate. I've really come to understand the state a lot better and appreciate its people and its diversity and its economy and in its population.
 
Q. What do you think New Jerseyans want from their senator?
 
A. I think they want a senator who will make government less, more affordable and less intrusive. Who will address their needs but will reduce the burdens that government imposes on them. I think they're looking for somebody like Christie Whitman, who is a sensible fiscal conservative who is pro-choice and pro-environment. . . .
 
Q. Could you assess Senator Bradley's term? Would you be like him in some ways and different in others?
 
A. Yeah, I hope so. One of my constituents said that Bill Bradley plays politics the way that he played basketball -- he may not be fast on his feet, but he's a straight shooter. And that's, I think, a good compliment. He's honest. He's high-minded. He has the courage to talk about issues that other people may not want to talk about.
I would differ with him on his proposed solutions . . . because I think that they're generally standard liberal solutions that have not proved very effective in the past. But I think that he has won the trust of his constituents the way I believe I won the trust of my constituents in the 12th District. And that's an important starting point. . . .
 
Q. In the latter part of his term, he began talking a great deal about diversity and the need for people to live together more harmoniously. Is there something that you and Mr. Torricelli need to be talking about, as far as New Jersey is concerned?
 
A. Well, I've been asked by reporters why I've been spending so much time campaigning in the cities and amongst minorities who historically haven't voted for Republicans. And the reason I'm doing so is not because I think there's a very good chance that I'll get a lot of votes out of these areas and from these groups, but rather because it's the right thing to do. We are a single state, and we will not move forward if any geographic or ethnic element is allowed to be left behind.
So as somebody whose family came from the cities of New Jersey and who grew up in the shadow of Newark, I believe that our cities have got to be once again the places that they used to be, which is the launching pad for people's aspirations and potential. And I think we have an obligation as a society to make sure that any progress we have as a country is progress for everyone. And this is going to be a greater and greater challenge as we enter the global economy.

Schools, and How To Pay for Them

TORRICELLI
 
Q. Senator Bradley was nearly defeated six years ago, partly because he avoided the question of Governor Florio's tax increase. What are your views on that tax and on Governor Whitman's tax cuts?
 
A. I campaigned on [Mr. Florio's] behalf because I thought he should be re-elected Governor. There's a little revisionist history here. You know, I supported Jim Florio, but I did not support his tax increases in 1990. In fact, the two state legislators from Bergen County who voted against the Florio increase, didn't they say that they sought my counsel at the time and I urged them not to vote for it? And I did that because I thought Bergen County, the suburban communities, were disproportionately paying the tax -- defending a local interest.
[As for] Mrs. Whitman, I supported the income tax cuts. My concerns were and continue to be the impact on real estate taxes. My real estate taxes in Englewood have continued to climb, and I'm very concerned that the state is only engaged in a tax shift off income taxes and onto property taxes, which hurt senior citizens and people on fixed incomes disproportionately. But income taxes in New Jersey are too high, and I did support the lowering of them.
My other criticism of her program was this issue of suburban schools. I think she's simply putting a ceiling on the quality of suburban schools, which is not the answer to dealing with the question of urban education. . . .
 
Q. So what do you think of Governor Whitman's proposed school finance plan?
 
A. Well, I have a disproportionately Bergen County view of this, as you might imagine, having lived there all my life. . . . I think the goal is to raise the floor to insure that every child is reaching some minimally accepted standard of education. Somehow that has been reinterpreted to put a ceiling on the quality of education that school districts want to meet in some of our suburban areas.
The government should never be in the role of telling parents or teachers in a suburban school district that they can't do something extra to improve that quality of education. So the common denominator is being lowered rather than simply lifting those who are not getting the quality of education.
 
Q. So how do you propose that the State of New Jersey deal with this very difficult problem?
 
A. They're solving a problem that I don't concede to be a problem. The problem is insuring that every student is able to reach a minimally acceptable level of education. That standard should be high, and it should continue to rise. We should do this by equalizing or insuring that there is sufficient spending in each of these districts and then seize the districts where they're not properly administered and test them to high standards. That's the problem.
The more serious national problem is that people who live in these other suburban school districts believe their children are getting a good enough education because they're being compared to schools that are not performing. The comparison is not whether the schools in Ridgewood or Cherry Hill or Morristown compare favorably with the schools of Jersey City or Newark. The comparison is whether they compare favorably with the schools in Paris, Milan and Tokyo. And they are not.
 
Q. On what basis do you say that?
 
A. Our average American high school student spends 40 percent amount of time as a Japanese or German student studying math or science. Of the 18 industrialized nations, we rank 16th in performance on basic mathematics or science tests. Our students are in school 180 days and their German counterparts 210 and their Japanese counterparts 220. We are not meeting world standards.

ZIMMER
 
Q. Can I ask your views on the Whitman school finance plan?
 
A. I think in concept it's a good idea. It's probably the most sensible way to comply with the Supreme Court mandate.
 
Q. There must be a number of school districts in your Congressional District that are unhappy with the prospect of having to cut spending.
 
A. But you see, they get to spend more if their voters want them to spend more. And as somebody who has always believed in the sovereignty of the people, I think that if they can make the sale to the communities they serve, they'll have no problem. And if the public doesn't want to foot the bill for services beyond those that are constitutionally required, I don't see why the state should either force them to or should subsidize those activities.
 
Q. Do you fault the plan in any way?
 
A. Well, I'm not familiar with the details. And if I were a legislator, I'd try to massage it to get the best deal for my constituents and my school districts. But I don't see structurally that there's any other way to go, in the basic outlines of the program. Any other approach would just bust the budget and put us even further ahead of all the other states in the per capita expenditures per student without necessarily resulting in a concomitant increase in the quality of the education, or else would be very punitive in some districts. So it seems to me like it's a reasonable approach. But it's something that I have not given a lot of detailed attention to.
 
Q. How good a job do you think New Jersey's public schools are doing? And again, is there a role for the Federal Government in helping them do more?
 
A. Well, I am a product of K-through-12 New Jersey public schools [in] Hillside, Bloomfield and Glen Ridge. And I did well enough to get a National Merit Scholarship, a full scholarship to Yale, go on to Yale Law School. Both my kids went to public school K through 12 in South Orange and later Delaware Township School and then Hunterdon Central. And they both got into Yale and graduated with honors, and one is gainfully employed and the other is in graduate school. So public schools have done well by me and my family.
But there are areas in New Jersey where the public schools have betrayed the children they're supposed to serve, and we cannot afford to waste another generation while we talk about improving the quality of public schools. That's why I support a pilot program for school vouchers so that poor people will have the same kind of options that my wife and I have to pick the school that's best for their kids. I think the Federal Government, which provides about 6 cents out of the national education dollar and less for New Jersey because our schools are more expensive and we get less aid per capita, has a limited but important role to play in education. . . .
 
Q. Bob Dole said that the teachers' unions are getting in the way of improving the schools. Do you agree with that?
 
A. That's sometimes true. But the New Jersey Education Association is a very good union, in the sense that it has effectively advocated the interests of its members. And sometimes the interests of its members are not consistent with the interests of a good quality and cost-effective education.
It's not my desire to get into a fight with the N.J.E.A. They actually endorsed me once or twice. In 1990 they had buttons that said, "Vote for Bradley and Zimmer." They're up in my attic someplace. Maybe I ought to pull them out.

HEADLINE: Q & A;
Rallying to Stake Their Claim on a Better Future

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
Two rallies, two causes and thousands of individual reasons for joining in: here's a look at two New Jersey residents who decided to stand up and be counted. One traveled to Washington on Oct. 12 for a march to promote Hispanic issues; the other went to the United Nations on Wednesday for a rally observing the first anniversary of the Million Man March.
 
Finding a Common Voice
 
WHO Jaime Vazquez, Jersey City Councilman.
WHAT Participant and speaker at Hispanic march in Washington.
OUTSTANDING IMPRESSION "I think it is significant that there were a lot of college students there. It is important for young people to get involved in these issues."
BACKGROUND A City Councilman for more than 11 years, Mr. Vazquez is a native of Puerto Rico who came to the mainland and Jersey City in 1952, when he was 3. He is a United States Marine veteran who served in the Vietnam War and earned a Purple Heart. He has a degree in urban studies from St. Peter's College in Jersey City.
SUBJECT OF HIS TWO-MINUTE SPEECH "I told them of the things Jersey City has done to help Hispanics and all minority groups. I sponsored a resolution adopted by the City Council that makes Jersey City a safe haven for all people, no matter what their immigration status. We are not going to use city resources to identify or inform on or prosecute any immigrants. Jersey City claims the Statue of Liberty, and it has always been an immigrant city with a long history of tolerance and acceptance."
DEMOGRAPHICS One-fourth of Jersey City's 228,000 residents are Hispanic. A majority are Puerto Rican, but the number of immigrants from the Dominican Republic is growing. Ten percent of New Jersey's more than 7 million people are of Hispanic origin. many of them refugees from Cuba who settled in Hudson County.
WHAT THE MARCH ACCOMPLISHED "It brought together Hispanics from different nationalities. Puerto Ricans are United States citizens and some think the attacks on immigrants does not affect them, but that is not true. All Hispanics have a commonality. The march helped us organize politically so we can have a common agenda for better education and better economic opportunity." KAREN DeMASTERS

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Holders of Savings Bonds Get That Sinking Feeling

BYLINE: By MARCIA VICKERS 

 BODY:
FRAN REYNOLDS is not happy with the United States savings bonds that she bought in the mid-1980's. A few weeks ago, the bonds' 7.5 percent minimum interest rate became a thing of the past. And while there is a new floor, it is a lot lower: 4 percent.
"I'm disgusted," said Ms. Reynolds, a retired schoolteacher in Forest Hills, Queens. "I was under the impression that the minimum guaranteed rate would be there ad infinitum." 
 Not so. On Oct. 1, the last of the tens of thousands of people who bought these Series EE bonds -- they were sold between March 1983 and October 1986 -- saw the 7.5 percent rate vanish. The investments lost their guarantee bond by bond, as each passed the 10-year anniversary of purchase, which, because of the 7.5 percent floor, meant they had reached face value.
The bonds will still earn the higher of the new minimum rate or an average market yield pegged to the five-year Treasury rates. But that is small comfort; it just gives investors a choice between the 4 percent floor and a market yield of 4.06 percent.
The Government is not certain how much is invested in the 7.5 percent bonds, but it is surely many billions of dollars. An estimated $4 billion of them were bought in just the last three days they were sold.
Despite the surprise of Ms. Reynolds, the Treasury Department did not pull a fast one. Under longstanding rules that applied to bonds sold before May 1995, the investments were bought at half of face value, and the rate guarantee evaporated once they reached that value. (To figure the maximum time needed to reach it, use the "rule of 72": Divide 72 by the guaranteed rate, then round off the answer. For 7.5 percent bonds, it is 10 years.) After the bonds mature, meaning they arrive at face value, the original guaranteed minimum is replaced with the prevailing rate, now 4 percent.
Old or not, these savings bond rules are hardly common knowledge. "Most of these investors are unaware of the rate expiration -- even though it was disclosed to them when they bought the bonds -- because they haven't been sent any further notice or received regular statements," said Daniel J. Pederson, founder and president of the Savings Bond Informer, a Detroit company that provides bond information.
The Treasury Department itself acknowledges that the rules are elusive. "If you thought savings bonds were plain-vanilla investments, they're really vanilla fudge, with rocky road mixed in," said Pete Hollenbach, a spokesman for the department's Bureau of Public Debt. Few people may know, for example, that Series EE savings bonds earn interest for 30 years.
These confusions are one reason the Treasury changed the rules last year. Bonds bought on or after May 1, 1995, have variable interest rates based solely on the market, with no minimum rate. Bonds held for less than five years get 85 percent of the average yield that six-month Treasury bills earn during the bonds' life, while longer-term bonds get 85 percent of the average yield of five-year Treasuries.
"With new bonds going forward, we're really trying to simplify matters," Mr. Hollenbach said.
Should investors with the 7.5 percent bonds sell them and put the proceeds into other investments? Not necessarily.
"Savings bonds still may be considered a good deal when compared with other investments in the same conservative class, such as money markets, savings accounts and certificates of deposit," said Joel Isaacson, a financial planner in New York City. For example, the bonds are subject only to Federal tax and the tax is paid only upon redemption, while many other investments are fully taxable as interest accrues.
"When you look at the low yields of the other investments and take the tax implications into consideration, suddenly savings bonds don't look so bad," Mr. Isaacson said.
New savings bonds now yield 4.36 percent if held for less than five years and 4.85 percent if held longer. These rates will change on Nov. 1 -- they are adjusted twice a year under the May 1995 plan -- but they are not expected to move significantly.
Depending on income, taxes and the effect of other savings bond rules, however, investors may still want to cash in their 7.5 percent bonds. But remember that timing can be crucial. "By cashing out just one day too soon, you can lose an entire six months of interest," Mr. Isaacson said. Savings bond earnings are credited in six-month increments from the date of purchase; according to Mr. Pederson, about $100 million is forfeited each year by investors who mistime their bond redemptions.

HEADLINE: Tourism Might Just Destroy New York's Flavor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With regard to your glowing account of the transformation of 42d Street (Arts pages, Oct. 15) and the rising role of tourism in the New York economy, I would like to register this cautionary point: Are we one more step down the road to blandness?
Although tourism can be financially rewarding for those who run the venues, it can also have a chilling effect on local cultural development. Take a look at London, Paris or Rome, all great tourism meccas by design. These cities, while marketed for their cultural treasures of the past, are culturally anemic, or worse, in the present. Somehow, the marketing of location for mass tourism tends to freeze-dry it, as if it were a moving target that needed to be stopped. Need I mention Florida? 
 The new emphasis on tourism comes at a sensitive time in our city's evolution. To many, New York has already seen a decade-long shrinking of its prominence as a cultural innovator. No longer do we set the trends in fashion, music or the fine arts. I can only attribute this to the employment cutbacks that have occurred in many of our most culturally dynamic industries, like network television, fashion and music.
We would do well to emphasize both tourism and rehabilitation of the local forces that helped make this place unique. The day that we all get to ride on a Holden Caulfield Simulator is the day that we are through.
 
FRANK KALAMAJKA
New York, Oct. 15, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Investors Hate Oil, But It Keeps Going Up

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Markets are amazing things. Sometimes they go up because everyone thinks they will. And sometimes they go up even though no one thinks they will.
It is the oil market that provides clear evidence of the latter point. Almost unnoticed by most investors, oil has been a much better investment this year than stocks. The spot price of oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange is up 32 percent in 1996, while the Dow Jones industrial average has risen just 19 percent. 
 Throughout that run-up, there has been widespread disbelief. In the last 15 years, investors and oil company officials alike have learned that any rise in the price of oil is likely to be temporary.
(Over that same period, investors have concluded that any fall in share prices will be temporary, but we'll get to that later.)
A result of the disbelief has been that virtually everyone in the oil business has taken steps to protect themselves from the inevitable fall in prices. Refiners buy only as much crude as they must have immediately, fearful that they will end up with overpriced crude oil. It has been widely assumed that Iraq would be allowed to sell oil, or that Saudi Arabia would bolster production to protect us from high prices.
Neither has happened yet, and inventories are tight as winter approaches. Hazel O'Leary, the Energy Secretary, called oil executives to Washington on Friday in the hope that talk would prevent increases in home heating oil prices.
For now, anyway, it appears the Government will not order sales of crude from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, as it did last April. (That move provided a fine example of how the Government wastes our money. The oil was bought, at prices well above current quotes, supposedly as protection from a supply cutoff, of which there was and is no threat. Buy high, sell low.)
Even with Government sales last spring, oil prices soon resumed their rise. Someday soon the suspicion may grow that worldwide demand now matches supply, creating the possibility of a new bull market in oil.
You don't believe that? It is hard to accept -- at least as difficult as it once was to believe that oil prices could ever fall. In 1981, I attended an energy conference that featured academics and oil industry executives. The debate centered on how fast oil prices would rise. The possibility of a decline was not even considered.
In those days, stocks were cheap and unloved. In the autumn of 1981, the Dow Jones industrial average was trading in the 800's, well under the level it had reached in 1966. It was generally agreed that stocks should be bought, if at all, for quick trades, not as long-term investments.
Now, the Dow is above 6,000. And a poll of mutual fund investors, conducted for Liberty Financial by Louis Harris & Associates, finds a consensus that prices will only rise. Only 14 percent think the stock market will fail to do at least as well in the next decade as it did in the last one. Four out of 10 think the market will not have a 10 percent fall in any year of the next 10.
Such complacency does not prove that prices are set to fall. Stocks, unlike oil, cannot be consumed, and prices can keep climbing if money continues to pour in.
Still, it is interesting to wonder why oil prices are rising when almost everyone thinks they shouldn't. And one might recall that when the Dow plunged 45 percent in less than two years in 1973-74, it was soaring oil prices that got much of the blame.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Ready to Go In Vietnam: Alas, There's No Market

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON 

 BODY:
INVESTING in Vietnam is so hard that even J. Mark Mobius is struggling.
Two years ago, Mr. Mobius started the Templeton Vietnam Opportunities fund in expectation of a stock market in Vietnam -- but no such market has developed. And so earlier this month the Securities and Exchange Commission and shareholders approved changes in the policies of the $100 million closed-end fund. 
 "When we launched, a stock market was going to come in 1994, and then '95, and then '96, and '97, and now they're talking about the year 2000," said Mr. Mobius, a well-regarded emerging-markets expert who manages several funds from Hong Kong. "The bottom line is the whole intent of the fund has had to change."
Vietnam's allures for business are many, including low wages and enormous tourism potential. But as in many other rapidly developing countries, its economic reach is exceeding its political grasp. As eager as the nation's leaders are to attract Western money, they are as unschooled in capitalism's legal and market underpinnings as they are suspicious of the country's colonial past.
The Templeton fund has thus been marking time. About half its assets are in United States Treasury bills, with most of the rest in shares of Asian companies doing some business in Vietnam, like Jardine Matheson of Hong Kong, which has construction and development deals in Hanoi. From the fund's start-up through September, its net asset value is up 0.32 percent, annualized, while its market price is off 11.6 percent.
Mr. Mobius's latest tack is to invest directly in joint ventures operating in Vietnam, a switch that required approval of both the S.E.C. and shareholders.
Since receiving those approvals, Mr. Mobius said he had invested about 2 percent of the fund's assets in a minority stake in Phuben Tea, a plantation and processing center in north Vietnam. The operating partner is Sipef East Asia, a Belgian concern. He said he was in talks with Indotel, a Singapore company that holds a majority stake in hotels managed by the Accor Group of France, but a venture has not been completed. In all such ventures, he said, the fund would take a minority position and rely on its partner to manage the business.
IN a telephone interview from Turkey, Mr. Mobius said that he had been offered 150 deals but that few met his investment criteria, which include an experienced and successful venture partner, complete government licenses in advance and a defined mechanism to get his investors' capital out.
The S.E.C. has given the Vietnam fund until October 1997 to have at least 65 percent of assets invested in Vietnam. If it does not, it will have to liquidate or change its name. Mr. Mobius rates his chances of meeting this goal as 60-40. "I've bought some of the fund so I think there's a chance," he said, "but I'm not putting out any guarantees."
A name change and a formal switch in focus may be likelier than liquidation. Thomas J. Herzfeld, publisher of The Investor's Guide to Closed-End Funds, a newsletter published in Miami, noted that a closed-end fund he runs, the Herzfeld Caribbean Basin Fund, changed its name from the Cuba Fund when it saw no end to the United States-led trade embargo of Cuba.
Calling Mr. Mobius "one of our heroes," Mr. Herzfeld said that he and his money-management clients were investors in the Vietnam fund and that he planned to stay with it. "It has really turned out to be an Asian regional fund," he said, "with a Vietnam punch should the market develop there."

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Job Uncertainty Makes Offers Easier to Refuse

BYLINE: By ROY FURCHGOTT 

 BODY:
AS an advertising executive, Paul Cappelli knows an enticing pitch when he hears one, and over the last five years he's heard a few -- like the one the Leo Burnett Company used to try to lure him from his New York agency to Burnett's Chicago headquarters. He said he was offered a raise and signing bonus that was too good to pass up.
But he did pass it up, choosing instead to stay in his lower-paying job in New York, where he felt more secure. "If something should go wrong here, it would be easier to find another job," Mr. Cappelli said. "In Chicago, I'm a fish out of water." 
 Workers around the country have been doing the same thing, saying job uncertainty has made them less willing to transfer to a different city for their current company or to relocate for a new employer. According to a survey this summer by the New York recruiters Battalia Winston International, 54 percent of the executives polled said job insecurity would encourage them to remain in their current positions instead of moving for a job elsewhere. One byproduct of this insecurity: executives are more willing to move to New York, perceiving that it offers a lot of job opportunities.
The most recent biennial survey of relocation and human resource executives by Runzheimer International, industry consultants based in Rochester, Wis., showed that relocations fell to an average of 155 at each company in 1994, the last time the survey was done, from a peak of 245 in 1990. In its 1996 survey, due out next year, the firm expects to see little change from 1994. Relocations have been falling, the firm said, for several reasons: with increased layoffs, there are fewer employees to move, companies have been reducing the number of relocations to cut costs and stability-minded executives are less eager to move.
"Contracts with employers aren't what they used to be," said Dale Winston of Battalia Winston. "People are afraid it won't work out, and not because they think they won't do a good job."
It's not just the employees who suffer, said Beverly Berberich, a corporate relocation manager at S. C. Johnson Wax in Racine, Wis. "It's really hindering corporate America from having the right person in the right place at the right time."
All of this concern over job security is, surprisingly, benefiting New York. Suddenly, the city seems more attractive: crime is down, and although New York's job growth has lagged that of most of the country, executives perceive that if they lose their jobs here they will have a better chance of finding new ones.
"Right now the economy is good, and New York is a hub for business," said Karen Russo, a recruiter in Greenwich, Conn., specializing in middle management.
New York, which Ms. Winston said had been among the toughest locations for recruiters to sell to prospects for more than 20 years, has become the third-most-popular city for executives, behind Boston and San Francisco, according to her firm's survey. "Popularity of a geographic area has a lot to do with the press, and New York is getting great press," she said.
While New York's reputation as a livable city has grown, some executives who left found that the better life they sought outside the city never materialized.
"I have seen three of four clients go down to Atlanta and they don't like it," Ms. Russo said. "They think they will have this great life style, and they don't."
"A lot of people are coming to me saying, 'I want to come back to New York.' The crime rate has dropped and people are comfortable being in the city now," she said.
Employees who do move are negotiating larger signing bonuses and severance packages, industry experts say.
"People will go to the moon for opportunity, but they want insurance," said Michael Palma, a recruiter based in Atlanta.
The increasing number of two-income families are also changing the equation.
"If you are concerned about job security and you uproot a working spouse, you are jeopardizing two salaries," said James Simon of PHH Relocation in Danbury, Conn. "If your spouse has a job, you have the opportunity to pass up a transfer."
According to the Runzheimer study, the top requests by transferees are for help in selecting schools for their children and in finding a job for a spouse. But most of the relocation executives polled said they expected big increases in requests for help in finding a job for a trailing spouse and nearly half expected an increase in requests for help with schools and assistance in finding care facilities for elderly parents.
The growing reluctance to move has raised the bids for desirable executives. While those transferring within a company can do some bargaining for perks, it is the relocated new hires that are getting the richest deals.
"I rarely move an executive without a sign-on bonus," Ms. Winston, the recruiter, said.
Most new hires also look for a hefty severance package in case they get downsized in an unfamiliar new city. "It's security and enticement," said Maria Capano, a recruiter in Westport, Conn. Ms. Capano says she now sees severance of up to two years' base salary.
Of course, while executives can bargain the terms, they can not always afford to refuse the offer to move.
"Maybe you are the fair-haired boy and your company wants you to transfer, and you say, 'No thanks,' " said Roger Aylward of PHH Relocation. "You just went from the fast track to the slow track, which often leads to the exit ramp."
