HEADLINE: A Political Fight Marks a Coming of Age for a Silicon Valley Titan

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: MENLO PARK, Calif., Oct. 18

 BODY:
Think of it as the end of innocence for Silicon Valley.
At 7:30 on a recent Monday morning some 30 chief executives and venture capitalists crowded into the boardroom of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the Valley's most prestigious venture capital firm. The understated corporate decorum was marred only by a huge red and white "No on Prop. 211" banner hanging against the far wall. 
 Under the room's lofty cathedral ceiling all eyes were on a wiry figure with tousled blond hair, a button-down blue shirt and a rep tie. With an unexpectedly deep voice and a laser-like intensity, L. John Doerr, a Kleiner partner, is one of the Valley's most visible figures.
For Silicon Valley's best and brightest, and Mr. Doerr in particular, the battle over California's Proposition 211 -- which would lower the barrier to class-action lawsuits in cases where stock fraud is charged and would leave corporate directors and officers personally liable when juries award damages -- has been an epiphany of sorts. They see the measure as a direct attack on the region of the nation that has created a vast number of new jobs and immense new wealth since World War II.
Where they had once been oblivious to politics, the Valley's top executives have suddenly become impassioned activists, driven by what they see as a threat they believe will cripple the nation's technology heartland.
The lawyers who are pushing the proposition are selling it as a way to defend the savings of retirees from those who, with the help of misinformation or inadequate disclosures of risk, would lure them into the high-flying, hard-crashing world of technology stocks. Both sides are spending freely to make their cases: the executives' group expects to spend up to $35 million, its members say; observers expect the measure's proponents will match that.
Personally for Mr. Doerr, who had been a registered Republican and largely apolitical until earlier this year, Proposition 211 has been a political coming of age. He already had one of the highest profiles in Silicon Valley, a figure whose opinion on the viability of new technologies was crucial to the creation of companies.
As a venture capitalist, Mr. Doerr has been the financial architect of a breath-taking array of high-technology companies, ranging from Sun Microsystems Inc. to the Netscape Communications Corporation. But since last spring, he has taken on a new avocation as a principal organizer of the campaign to stop the measure.
A one-time engineer for the Intel Corporation, Mr. Doerr has made his reputation since 1980 by nurturing technology start-ups that developed into entire new industries. He still frets over details -- but this time, the things that concern him are not about balance sheets or universal resource locators, but political allies.
"I have the backing of the Protestant church," Mr. Doerr told the group with the slightest hint of a smile. "I'm working on the Catholic church.
"In a way this has been a gift," he added. "It has caused the technology community to come together in a way that has never happened before. Andy Grove has taken to this with a religious zeal; everyone is aligned on this issue. The only one missing is Mother Teresa."
Indeed, Mr. Grove, the chairman of giant Intel and a Silicon Valley pioneer, said this weekend that "Proposition 211 has mobilized this industry to an extent that nothing else has since the Japanese threat of the mid-1980s."
Those who have worked with Mr. Doerr in business said that even as a novice political organizer he has been remarkably effective, translating the skills he has long used to build networks of Silicon Valley companies.
"John is the ultimate in networking and he really loves doing this," said Judy Estrin, the president and chief executive of Precept Software Inc. in Palo Alto, Calif., and a board member of Sun Microsystems, Federal Express and Rockwell International.
"Our jobs are so intense that unless it has a direct impact on us we usually don't get involved," Ms. Estrin added. "What Proposition 211 has done is make people realize that our part of the world is not sheltered from everything else in the world."
Proposition 211 was introduced after a new Federal law imposed restrictions on securities lawsuits in U.S. courts that gave companies more legal protection in making financial projections that may later fall short. However, opponents say Proposition 211 was designed so that even if there is only a single California owner of a share of stock in a company it would be possible to file a securities fraud lawsuit against that company in California.
In fact, Proposition 211 is the second round of the battle; the executives' fervor in this campaign can be traced in part to their defeat in the last one. In March, during the California primary election, the Valley's executives spent $11 million, only to see their efforts for a trio of anti-lawyer initiatives go down to defeat.
In the wake of that earlier defeat, a new political consciousness began to take root among the community of computer nerds and M.B.A.'s who have traditionally been more passionate about bits and bytes than banners and ballots. But they are not only working to defeat the measure, they are threatening to move their headquarters out of the state and stop giving financial information to the public if the measure passes.
And Mr. Doerr, like other venture capitalists, is planning to resign his seat on six corporate boards if the campaign against the measure fails.
Trained as an electrical engineer at Rice University, Mr. Doerr, who came to Kleiner Perkins in 1980, bridles at the suggestion that the ballot measure is often seen as a squabble between wealthy lawyers and Silicon Valley moguls. "I don't think this is an argument between the greedy and the wealthy," he said. "This is about jobs and opportunity and information for investors."
Mr. Doerr, who is 45 years old, has taken to his new role with his legendary hyperkinetic style. Last month, he helped persuade President Clinton to oppose the ballot measure, even though it had been drafted by a San Diego lawyer, William S. Lerach, who has been a major financial backer of the President.
A month earlier he had worked his remarkable network of contacts and helped build a stellar list of high-technology executives' endorsements for the President, including Steven Jobs, co-founder of Apple Computer, and such Republicans as Carol Bartz of Autodesk, Ed McCracken of Silicon Graphics and John Young, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard. Both Mr. McCracken and Mr. Young had also backed Mr. Clinton in 1992.
Moreover, Mr. Doerr was willing to cross class lines and build a bridge to Silicon Valley's labor unions, overcoming an enmity that has led to bitter divisions in the area.
He approached John Neese the head of the Santa Clara County Building and Trades Council. Mr. Neese has, in turn, had good luck in prying away other union leaders who have traditionally been Mr. Lerach's political allies.
For the union leader, opposing Proposition 211 became a simple economic proposition. "If business isn't doing well, then we hurt," Mr. Neese said.
Not only did Mr. Doerr shift party allegiances and back Mr. Clinton in exchange for the President's opposition to the proposition, but with other Silicon Valley executives, including Mr. Young, Tom Proulx, the co-founder of Intuit, and John Chambers, the chief executive of Cisco Systems, he has created an organization, California Technology Alliance, in a step toward building a bipartisan coalition that Mr. Doerr insists will be both pro-growth and development and pro-education.
The group has already given $500,000 to candidates in this election and Mr. Doerr envisions it as a catalyst for a variety of future issues, including lobbying to make needed investments in local infrastructure.
Mr. Doerr stops short, though, of the idea of forming a new party, or of going any more deeply into politics himself. What he does best, he said, is to start new companies. He is anxious to return to what he refers to as his "day job."
Last Friday, at the end of a grueling week of campaigning Mr. Doerr was clearly worried by a California Field Poll that showed Proposition 211 still ahead, though it had begun losing ground.
Win or lose, he insisted the Valley will never be the same. "Even if it does win, the institutional memory we're creating is significant," he said.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
City Economy Shows Strength
The economy of New York City, which has foundered since the recession of the early 1990's, has begun to crawl back toward prosperity, largely because of rising profits on Wall Street. In the first half of this year, the city's production of goods and services grew at an annual rate of 2.2 percent, which is below the national average of 3.3 percent but still higher than the rate for the first six months of any year since 1988. [Page A1.]
 
A surge in tourism, business travel and demand for hotel rooms in New York City that began in 1993 has shown few signs of slowing. [B6.]
 
So, What About That Stadium?
It has become, at a time of baseball mania in New York, the issue that dare not speak its name: will the Yankees leave the Bronx? Politicians who a few months ago were tripping over themselves to guess now recoil into no-comment mode. But the stadium question has become profoundly different from what it was six months ago when it dominated headlines, because the Yankees have become a different team in the hearts of New Yorkers. [B1.]
 
The Yankees lost the opening game of the World Series against the Atlanta Braves. [A1.]
 
Inmates Denied Treatment
When it opened last fall, New York State's new drug program for prisoners was supposed to represent a leap in thinking about criminal justice. The center would be the state's first attempt to divert about 3,400 addicted felons a year away from teeming prisons and into treatment. But a year after the center opened, hundreds of beds remain empty. That is because the power to decide which defendants can be sentenced to the center rests with prosecutors, not judges. And prosecutors have overwhelmingly refused to allow prisoners to participate. [B1.]
 
Schools Get a Second Shift
Just before noon at Richmond Hill High School, seniors and juniors, ending their school day, stream out of one side of the Queens school and freshmen and sophomores arrive through another entrance to start theirs. The Board of Education has staggered daily schedules at many crowded schools, with some students arriving and leaving earlier than others. But only a few high schools have Richmond Hill's schedule, known as split sessions, which separate underclassmen and upperclassmen. [B1.]
 
Campaigns and Consequences
Do those candidates who are campaigning against immigrants know what they are doing? More to the point, are they looking ahead, past, say, Nov. 5? Maybe. Maybe they figure the votes are with them in electoral perpetuity. Or maybe what is happening now in this country will someday stand out as the most remarkable demonstration ever of the principle of unintended consequences. At least that is how it looks in California, where the immigrant wars are red hot. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [B1.]
 
Excavation Brings Debate
A team of archeologists stumbled across a trove of ancient artifacts during the excavation of a lot at Broadway and Maiden Lane, possibly the remnants the long-sought Dutch outpost that Peter Stuyvesant established here more than three centuries ago. But the State of New York has begun moving ahead with its own plans for the property: a $24 million office building. [B5.]
 
Teen-Ager Charged in Slaying
As his mother sobbed in the courtroom, a 16-year-old was ordered held without bail on charges that he strangled a Long Island high school student. [B6.]
 
REGION
 
Clinton Campaigns in Region
In a drive for a Democratic Congress, President Clinton campaigned in New Jersey to support the Senate campaign of Representative Robert G. Torricelli and then pushed on to fund-raisers in Tarrytown and Manhattan intended primarily to help House and Senate candidates. [A1.]
 
In the race for United States Senate from New Jersey, Representative Robert G. Torricelli and Representative Richard A. Zimmer each picked up endorsements. [B6.]
 
Rain Leaves Wide Damage
The sun peeked out, floodwaters receded, transit and travel resumed and the World Series finally got under way as the metropolitan area's worst rainstorm in years churned off, leaving 90,000 homes without power and four storm-related deaths. [B5.]
 
CONNECTICUT
 
Zeroing In on a Glass
In the courtroom where Alex Kelly is on trial for rape, both the prosecution and the defense have focused on a teen-age drinking game called Quarters. Reporter's Notebook. [B4.]
 
A Casino Even for Nongamblers
Mohegan Sun, the spectacular, Indian-theme gambling casino that opened on Oct. 12 in Uncasville, Conn., is a dense, exhilarating forest of symbols. Trees right beside slot machines. Immense paintings of flowers over card tables. To those unfamiliar with either the customs of the Mohegan Indians or the rites of American gamblers, much of this sign language is incomprehensible. But it's a pleasure to feel bewildered here. Mohegan Sun is a place that even nongamblers can enjoy. Architecture Review, the Arts. [C13.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CONDUIT;
Fund-Raiser for Democrats Now Faces Harsh Spotlight

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and JAMES STERNGOLD 

 BODY:
In 1986, when John Huang arrived in Los Angeles as the chief representative of one of Indonesia's wealthiest families, he brought Asian-American business leaders some advice: with skillful organization and well-targeted campaign contributions, they could gain influence to match their new wealth.
Early this year, after an undistinguished career in banking and a brief, frustrating stint as a Commerce Department official, Mr. Huang returned to California and heeded his own counsel. He became one of the most successful fund-raisers for the Democratic National Committee, tapping Asian-American sources neither party had called on. 
 And now Mr. Huang, 51, has found himself, and his cause, at the focal point of far more attention than he ever imagined. He is at the center of Republican attacks over foreign contributions to the Democrats -- including an illegal $250,000 donation from a South Korean company that was later returned -- and his own party has suspended him from any further fund raising until an investigation is completed.
Interviews with Mr. Huang's colleagues and competitors in recent days suggest that in each phase of his career he has been a man with two missions: to increase the political influence of Asian-Americans and to aid his patrons, the Riady family of Indonesia, which controls the Lippo Group, a major financial powerhouse in Southeast Asia. What is being questioned now is where the one role ended and the other began, and who this highly regarded member of the Chinese-American community has really been serving by cultivating influence in Washington. Republicans have called loudly for an independent counsel. Some Asian-Americans have been quietly asking whether Mr. Huang's activities, no different in many respects from those of any other political fund-raiser, are being regarded suspiciously because he is Asian-American.
The Republican Presidential candidate, Bob Dole, is arguing that Mr. Huang -- who was naturalized as an American citizen 20 years ago -- was an agent of foreign influence. "We cannot allow the political influence of any American to be outweighed by foreign money," Mr. Dole said. But the picture of Mr. Huang's career that emerges from the interviews is more complex. At the Commerce Department he sat in on none of the important strategy meetings about Asia -- but he did show up in the Oval Office for private meetings between President Clinton and James Riady. So far there is little sign that any Government policy -- affecting Indonesia or the Riadys' far-flung business interests -- was changed because of Mr. Huang. But there is evidence that in his drive for donations, Mr. Huang at a minimum skirted the legal limitations on fund raising and ignored the cardinal rule of campaign finance: Know the real source of your contributions.
Mr. Huang himself has remained out of view and the Democratic National Committee has deflected all requests for interviews with him. Appearing on CBS' "Face the Nation" yesterday, the chairman of the D.N.C., Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, was pressed on when Mr. Huang would answer questions in public. "I'm certain that it will be done," Mr. Dodd said, but later seemed to hedge a bit, saying, "We'll try and make him available to you."
Mr. Huang was born in China, but raised in Taiwan, where he served in the air force before attending the University of Connecticut in 1969. In 1972 he started working in banking, first in Washington, then in Louisville, Ky., and Memphis. He moved to Hong Kong, and soon jumped to the banking operations run there by the Lippo Group, the Riadys' business empire. Then he joined the Worthen Bank of Little Rock, Ark., in which the Riady family held a large stake, before he was moved to Los Angeles in 1986 to help run the Lippo Bank, a small institution owned by James Riady, who had worked in Little Rock, where he became friendly with Bill Clinton. Mr. Huang quickly established himself in Los Angeles -- in part by using the Lippo Group's name and money -- as a prominent member of the Asian-American community and a member of numerous civic organizations.
"He always had this vision that the Chinese-American community had not been active enough in politics and that our interests were being ignored," said Charles Woo, the chief executive of P. C. Woo, which produces Megatoys. "He always said that with donations of money the political establishment would pay attention to us. I admire him a lot for that, and so did a lot of other people."
Among the issues Mr. Huang concentrated on were immigrants' rights and helping Asian-American businessmen build networks that would increase their influence.
Mr. Huang's career at Lippo Bank, which has four branches in California, was conspicuously less successful than his efforts in politics. The bank has had run-ins with regulators for poor management, bad loans and discriminatory lending practices. And its performance has been desultory at best. Lippo Bank lost $3 million last year, and in its best year, 1993, it earned just $1 million.
"If James were here they would have grown substantially," said Len Rushfield, the executive vice president of a consulting company in Los Angeles and a friend of James Riady, the son of the Lippo Group's chairman and its No. 2 official. "John's focus was different. It was not so much on making the bank a bank, it was representing the Lippo Group here."
 
At Commerce: Quiet and Frustrated
In its early days, the Clinton Administration, already critical of Indonesia's treatment of dissidents in East Timor, threatened to terminate Jakarta's special trade preferences unless it improved its record. The Riadys saw a role for themselves as intermediaries between the Administration and the Indonesian Government. By late 1993, working through Mr. Huang, Administration officials said, James Riady was pressing to meet the key members of the Cabinet who had a voice in the decision, including United States Trade Representative Mickey Kantor and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown. Lower-level trade officials had already seen Mr. Riady in Jakarta; Mr. Kantor said last week that he and his deputy, Charlene Barshefsky, refused, as did Mr. Brown.
Soon thereafter Mr. Huang decided to seek a job at Commerce; some Riady family associates say he was "placed" there, but none of his colleagues can recall who proposed him as deputy assistant secretary for international economic policy.
The one official who does recall pressing senior Commerce officials to hire Mr. Huang is Maria Haley, a friend of President Clinton's and of Mr. Huang's from Arkansas, who helped place several Asian-Americans in the Clinton Administration. "You help the people who bring you to power," Ms. Haley, now a director of the Export-Import Bank, said in an interview last week.
Mr. Huang's handwritten financial disclosure report shows that the pain of taking a pay cut for a Government job was eased by a farewell gift from the Riady family: $788,750 in "salary, bonus and severance" from Hip Hing Holdings, a Riady-family property firm in Los Angeles.
At the Commerce Department Mr. Huang recused himself from issues affecting Indonesia and his former employer. But if he had hoped to delve into the major initiative of the department -- a focus on the "Big Emerging Markets" of China and the rest of Southeast Asia -- he was soon disappointed. His office was not involved.
By all accounts, most of Mr. Huang's tasks were administrative -- personnel issues, budgets, preparing Congressional testimony for senior officials. "He was incredibly quiet," one of his superiors recalled last week. "This is a guy who never asked to go to a meeting, never overtly sought to involve himself in policy." The exception to that rule was dealing with Taiwan: Mr. Huang's office was asked to take up the problems of American companies seeking to get a piece of a major nuclear project there, chiefly because China would react badly if the same officials dealing with Beijing were also visiting Taipei. He visited Taipei twice.
Mr. Huang held a "Top Secret" security clearance, but appears not to have had access to truly sensitive material about China, the role of corruption in major deals, and intelligence analysis of foreign governments and companies.
But at least once during his tenure at Commerce Mr. Huang found himself in the Oval Office -- on Sept. 13, 1995, with James Riady. Bruce Lindsey, the deputy White House counsel, who also attended the meeting, called it a "social visit." Soon thereafter Mr. Huang asked Mr. Lindsey for help getting a job at the Democratic National Committee. By early December he was packing his desk at the Commerce Department.
"The man was frustrated by his lack of involvement in matters he thought were in his purview and the best use of his background," said one senior official, recalling Mr. Huang's comments as he left the department.
 
The Fund-Raiser: Busy in California
By early January, now a vice-chairman of the D.N.C. for finance, Mr. Huang was back in California, holding meetings in San Francisco's Chinatown and telling supporters he wanted to raise more than $3 million in Asian-American contributions for the Presidential campaign. "We have to bring ourselves into the political arena and let the rest of the country as a whole understand the role Asian-American communities are playing and will be playing in the coming century," he said at one meeting on Jan. 8, according to local press reports at the time.
To reach that goal, Mr. Huang appears to have violated election law on at least one occasion. He brought in a $250,000 contribution from the United States' subsidiary of a South Korean company called Cheong Am, a maker of electronic display boards. But its American subsidiary has generated no revenue, and taking money from a foreign company -- even if it is funneled through an American unit -- is illegal. When The Los Angeles Times reported the contribution, it was given back. The company's Los Angeles office has since been cleared out and its chief, John Lee, who met Mr. Clinton briefly at a fund raiser after making his contribution, has not been seen for some time.
Mr. Huang and Maria Hsia, a prominent Los Angeles immigration consultant with whom he had worked on Democratic events in the 1980's, put together other major California projects: a big fund raiser this summer in Century City, attended by Mr. Clinton, and another fund raiser attended by Vice President Al Gore at a large, Chinese Buddhist Temple in Los Angeles on April 29.
The event at the temple has raised a number of questions. The temple is tax-exempt, and that status makes it legally questionable for political fund raisers. After recent press reports the Democratic Party announced that it would reimburse the temple for the $15,000 the event cost.
Moreover, a lawyer for the temple, Peter Kelly, a former chairman of the California Democratic Party, confirmed that a nun from an affiliated temple in Texas reported last week that she had been handed $5,000 in cash and then asked to write a check to the party to conceal the real donor's identity, a clear campaign finance law violation. The temple is investigating, he added.
Officials at the Hsi Lai Temple also confirmed that some monks and nuns made donations, but said they possessed the means to do so from teaching and lecturing. The temple has also been popular with other Democratic politicians, including Representative Patrick J. Kennedy of Rhode Island, the son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy. Representative Kennedy visited twice this year in what the temple says were nonpolitical meetings.
The Riady family has not contributed to the D.N.C. for several years, records show; James Riady is no longer living here, and thus is barred from contributing.
One question facing the Federal Election Commission now is whether the Riadys' acted through proxies. Arief Wiriadinata is often referred to by Republicans as a "gardener" -- he appears to be a landscape architect -- and his wife, Soraya, is the daughter of a now-deceased founder of the Lippo Group with close ties to President Suharto of Indonesia. They contributed more than $400,000, in a series of gifts, earlier this year, including nearly $300,000, that were apparently made after they left Virginia and returned to Jakarta. The legality of that contribution is now one of several under investigation.

HEADLINE: Speaking of the Yankees, What About That Stadium?

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
It has become, at a time of baseball mania in New York, the issue that dare not speak its name: will the Yankees leave the Bronx? Will they get the $1 billion stadium proposed for the West Side of Manhattan? Politicians who only a few months ago were tripping over themselves to guess now recoil into no-comment mode. The focus is on the World Series, they say, and everything else can wait.
"Let's not fight over the stadium during the period of time in which we are having such success," said Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani at a City Hall news conference last week. A spokesman for George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the Yankees' principal owner, said he was similarly focused on the fundamentals. "The Yankees have brought back a spirit to New York that's amazing," said the spokesman, Howard Rubenstein. "That's as far as he'll go in any discussion of the future." 
 But even in quiescence the stadium question has become profoundly different from what it was six months ago when it dominated the headlines, because the Yankees, by winning in a big way in the postseason, have become a different team in the hearts and minds of New Yorkers. In the swirl of politics and passions involved in any major sports stadium decision, fan emotions are always a wild card, often a determining one, sports industry experts say. And in New York, those emotions are now fully engaged and in play.
"You ought not to make 30-year decisions based on a short-term success or failure of a team," said Marc S. Ganis, president of Sportscorp, a Chicago-based consulting company that works with government agencies and teams on arena issues. "Unfortunately it happens all the time."
For the Yankees, the surge in local feeling introduces numerous variables that fans, politicians and sports industry experts like Mr. Ganis said would emerge only when postseason play ends and the stadium question re-emerges. For one thing, thousands of people are being drawn back to the Yankees' 73-year-old stadium in the Bronx and could come away with new feelings about the team and its historic place in New York. Winning teams, especially if they win the World Series, almost always see big jumps in attendance, which could undermine Mr. Steinbrenner's claim that the team's location is a problem.
But there also are tantalizing hints that Mr. Steinbrenner has been studying up on how the emotional-fan card might be played -- as it was in Texas for the Rangers, for example.
The Rangers galvanized fans in 1989 by signing the pitcher Nolan Ryan just before the season began. Attendance shot up as the team went on to have its first winning season in three years. A year later, the voters overwhelmingly approved a new stadium in a referendum and a new tax to pay for it.
"It attracted a lot of attention and made people more conscious of baseball, and then they were more receptive to the discussions of the economic impact on the community," said Richard Greene, the Mayor of Arlington, the Rangers' hometown. "Once you had their attention, you could help them understand why we didn't want them to move."
The Rangers' story caught Mr. Steinbrenner's attention in particular.
"I have discussed our deal very thoroughly with George Steinbrenner," Mr. Greene said. "Last year I sat with him through two games, and most of our conversation was how we did the ball park deal -- he was very complimentary."
People who know Mr. Giuliani also say that the Mayor will almost certainly leap into the postseason Yankees celebrations with his usual gusto. Mr. Giuliani led a ticker tape parade down Broadway in 1994 when the Rangers won the Stanley Cup as National Hockey League champions, and offered to fete the Knicks at City Hall even when they lost in the National Basketball Association championship series the same year. This year, those people say, watch for a bit more.
"If the Yankees win, the Mayor might be more likely to jump in and say, 'We need the Manhattan stadium,' because then the fan is not going to say, 'Why are you giving a billion dollars to them?' " said one government official who has worked closely with Mr. Giuliani and who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Consultants retained by the Yankees, the city and the state said in April that the best alternative for the team was a 70,000-seat domed multipurpose stadium that could be built in Manhattan west of Pennsylvania Station at a cost of $1.06 billion, which would make it by far the most costly sports arena ever built.
But since the Yankees' lease in the Bronx does not expire until 2002, rumors have regularly surfaced about alternatives, from the New Jersey Meadowlands to Tampa, Fla. One plan would link the new stadium to a bid to bring the Olympics to New York City in 2008.
Sports industry experts say the Seattle Mariners probably offer the closest parallel to the Yankees' stadium saga. Last year, at the start of what looked to be another lackluster season in Seattle, local boosters and business officials began a campaign to replace the old Kingdome with a new stadium. The effort looked doomed. A public opinion poll in the spring showed only 33 percent of residents in favor of the idea. The Mariners said they would leave and seemed likely to make good on the threat.
But then, late in the season, the Mariners caught fire. They roared into the playoffs and beat the Yankees. People fell in love again. The measure lost narrowly, but was taken to the Washington State Legislature, which immediately approved a package to build a new stadium and keep the team. Opinion polls suggested by then that the Mariners' fans would have had it no other way.
"Had the team been not so on fire and the region not so completely focused on baseball, I am doubtful that our elected leadership would have found a will to make it happen," said Sue Tupper, a public relations professional who led the campaign for the new stadium.
The Toronto Blue Jays got financing for the Skydome in early 1986, just a few months -- coincidentally or not -- after winning the American League East division championship for the first time in the club's history. In professional football, the San Diego Chargers were able to win approval for a major stadium renovation after their first appearance in the Super Bowl, in 1995.
One major difference between those cases and New York's, however, was that the arguments for new parks or rehabilitations generally grew louder as the teams performed well. In New York, it has been the opposite case, with each new Yankee success serving to stifle talk of a new ball park.
Mr. Steinbrenner, who had been widely expected to announce last spring that the Yankees would leave the Bronx, has repeatedly postponed any announcement since then, and has said most recently that a decision on the team would come no earlier than November. The Giuliani administration, which had similarly been on a fast-track schedule this spring to hire a financial adviser on the stadium issue, let the matter slide until late August.
Fans say the motivations to suppress are clear enough. At a time of boundless hopes for victory, the stadium is a reminder of a potentially devastating loss -- for the Bronx, if the team leaves for Manhattan; for the city, if the team leaves for New Jersey; for the whole region, if the team moves away entirely.
Other fans say they believe that success will serve the status quo and keep the Yankees where they are by proving to New York and the world that the team, and the ball park, still work.
"With them winning, most likely they're going to stay up there -- that's my opinion," said Tommy Bamundo, a 44-year-old postal worker from Brooklyn. "Next year they're going to be in contention, the people are going to go out," he added. "Maybe they're going to have capacity for the games now they see they have a competitive team."
Other fans are fighting back now. A group called the Eternal Vigilance Society filed a lawsuit on Thursday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx against the Yankees' owners and the city arguing that the Yankees name and image are so indelibly wedded to New York as to confer a kind of ownership by residents. The group's attorney, John Nicholas Iannuzzi, said he had no doubt that the team's new success, as wielded by Mr. Steinbrenner, would haunt the city in the months to come.
"Now that he's got the Yankees in the World Series he can really put the fire to the feet of the Mayor and the city," he said.

HEADLINE: WALL ST. PROFITS LEAD A RECOVERY IN NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The economy of New York City, which has foundered since the recession of the early 1990's, has begun to crawl back toward prosperity, largely because of rising profits on Wall Street.
In the first half of this year, the city's production of goods and services grew at an annual rate of 2.2 percent, which is below the national average of 3.3 percent but still higher than the rate for the first six months of any year since 1988. As a result, in the first nine months of 1996 the city government reaped 15 percent more from its personal income tax than it did in that period last year. 
 The city has still not regained the jobs it lost in the recession, but it has made progress. From January to August, 32,000 new private jobs were generated in the city, officials said; in the same period last year, only 9,000 were created.
Also this year, record numbers of tourists are visiting the city, sending the hotel occupancy rate to the highest level in 15 years. Revenues from the city's hotel tax increased 17 percent in the first eight months of the year, even though the tax rate actually dropped.
The improvement is showing up in smaller indicators as well. The Brooklyn Union Gas Company, for example, said that customers were paying their bills 10 percent faster this year than they were last year. And the number of help-wanted advertisements in newspapers has increased 13 percent, city officials said.
Some sections of the local economy, particularly manufacturing, have not rebounded from the recession, which pummeled the city far harder than it did the country as a whole. And economists warned that the city's recovery was tied to the boom on Wall Street, adding that if interest rates were to rise or the stock market stumbled badly for that or other reasons, then financial services might slump, and the city's economy could follow.
Still, the economists said the slow growth was a relief after years of gloom. Besides the surge on Wall Street, which has led to higher profits in banking and securities firms, the city is benefiting from upturns in the communications, entertainment and software industries, they noted.
"It is shaping up as a pretty good year for New York City," said John L. Wieting, regional commissioner for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "You are seeing added strength if we look at the past year. The economy is pushing ahead."
The jump in tax revenues has surprised city officials and might allow Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to scale back proposed budget cuts, a move that could benefit him as he starts campaigning for re-election next year. In the first three months of the city's fiscal year, which began on July 1, the city collected $289 million more in taxes than it had expected, officials said.
The new spate of improved economic figures certainly does not indicate that the city is entering an era of robust expansion. It is a sign of how poorly the city fared in the recession that many economists and fiscal monitors are hailing even this new, sluggish growth.
Economists noted that while new jobs were being created, more people were entering the work force. As a result, the city's unemployment rate has not dropped below 7 percent in years. It was 8.6 percent in August; nationally, the rate was 5.1 percent.
The city lost 361,000 jobs in the recession, a 10 percent drop in its work force. Since the recession officially ended in the city in November 1992, it has recovered only about 81,000 of those. As a whole, the country quickly gained back all the jobs it had lost in the recession. Part of the explanation is the continuing cuts in government budgets. Since the recession, the city has actually added 141,000 private jobs, while the government has shed 60,000 positions.
In an interview, Mr. Giuliani argued that the recent expansion validated his economic policies, though he acknowledged that the city still trails the rest of the country in job creation.
"It is almost all good news for the city, given where it was," he said. "The difference between then and now is that in those days, as America was gaining jobs, New York was losing jobs. We don't gain them at quite the same rate as the rest of America, but at least we are moving in the same direction."
The Mayor's Democratic rivals put the opposite spin on the same numbers.
"Even with this good news, we are way behind the curve in relation to the national growth rate," said the City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, who is a potential mayoral candidate.
The State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, said: "The economy is improving. The risk is that it's coming from one sector, financial services, that is volatile."
In August, the Mayor ordered $500 million in cuts to the city's $33 billion budget to help close projected budget gaps for the rest of the decade, stirring criticism from some City Council members. The news that the city took in an extra $289 million in tax revenues in the first three months of the fiscal year could step up the pressure to increase spending.
The Mayor and his aides played down the importance of the money, saying that a rise in tax revenues would have to continue for many more months before it would alleviate the city's chronic budget problems. They also said that some of the extra revenue had come from one-time audits and programs that encouraged businesses and property owners to pay their taxes in advance.
"This is too early in the year to be overly optimistic or pessimistic about whatever happens with taxes," Mr. Giuliani said.
Councilman Herbert E. Berman, a Democrat of Brooklyn who is chairman of the Finance Committee, said there would be calls from some members to spend more. But he said that the city would have to plug some holes in the budget before the end of the fiscal year, and that the money should be reserved for that.
"The thing to do right now is respect the fact that we adopted a budget that has risks, and see which of these risks become a reality," Mr. Berman said.
Some fiscal monitors who had attacked the Mayor earlier this year for not cutting the budget enough praised him last week for putting the extra revenues aside.
"For the first time in a long time the city is getting a head start on addressing its long-term budget problems," said Robert A. Kurtter, a vice president at Moody's Investors Service, a Wall Street bond-rating firm. "It is positive for the city over all."
Mr. Kurtter questioned whether the city's economy was actually performing better than it appeared, saying that the statistics might miss some activity. "Clearly, New York has a greater disparity of wealth than exists in many places," he said. "But it's more than that. New York has a larger underground economy, so there is more hidden employment here than elsewhere.
"Right now, it is underperforming, but there are strengths in this economy, and there is opportunity."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Whoever Fixed The Field Is Fired!

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
ALL night and all day, the limber-hipped disco-dancing grounds crew struggled to dry off the Yankee Stadium field so the World Series could open.
Today all these worthy laborers are likely to be unemployed, along with assorted advance scouts, pitching coaches and front-office personnel who had anything to do with the Yankees' 12-1 skunking by the Braves last night. 
 For this they dried off the Stadium? Somebody even called in an air strike on the Stadium. No, it was not Donald Fehr of the players' association or Richie Phillips of the umpires' association making a definitive labor statement. It was merely two helicopters brought in to dry off the field with the whir of their rotary blades.
The midday assault by baseball's air force helped blast away some of the water left from Saturday's monsoon that pushed back the opening of the World Series.
"Yesterday at 1 P.M. it was puddling," Bill Murray, the executive director for baseball operations with Major League Baseball, said of Yankee Stadium's field. "Last night it was under water. But the grounds crew did a great job. They put extra tarpaulins in the outfield and steered the water to the open plugs."
A few hours of bright sun in the morning did not hurt. And Bob Wilkinson's grounds crew (those guys do more than dance to the music of "Y.M.C.A." during the fifth-inning sweep) dried off the infield. And then Greg Murphy, the president of Major League Enterprises, authorized paying for two city helicopters to dry off the grass.
Four hours before game time, Bobby Cox, the former Yankee who manages the Braves, came out to check out the field and met up with Joe Torre, the Brooklyn native who manages the Yankees. They greeted each other with the hearty laughs and comfortable body language of two baseball lifers who know enough to enjoy a World Series while they are in it.
"Center field is a little spongy but right field and left field are all right," Torre told Cox.
After Torre departed, Cox sat on the top step of the dugout and promptly felt some left-over rain seep into his uniform pants. He had seen more water than that. Everybody says that if you're going to have a rainout, it's good to have it in San Francisco or New York. But Saturday's rain had been so heavy that Cox had been confined to quarters.
"There weren't any cabs and all the restaurants were jammed up, so we had to eat right in the hotel," he said, sounding a trifle disappointed.
The field was so dry by game time that Darryl Strawberry did not even hydroplane as he made a skidding catch. By then, the Braves had called in their heavy artillery.
Andruw Jones whacked a home run in the second inning to become, at 19, the youngest player ever to hit a home run in the World Series, more than a year younger than Mickey Mantle, who did it in 1952. On the Mick's birthday, no less, Jones promptly whacked another homer one inning later.
"Andruw Jones has just become the second youngest player ever to hit a home run in the World Series," announced Rich Millet, an assistant football coach at Bethpage High on Long Island, sitting directly in front of the auxiliary press seats in left field.
"Jones is a little older than he was when he hit the first one," Millet reasoned.
By that time, the fans had nothing much to do but chant "We want rain!" and indeed some more rain did fall, much too late to change the outcome.
Baseball could avoid some of the potential for foul weather in late October by getting the Series over a week or two early, but the terribly greedy players and the wonderfully generous owners are locked into escalating wages and need elongated playoffs to pay the bills.
The real danger is that the unusually strong storm could be used by the new Sun Belt types in baseball to make a push for a domed World Series or a southern World Series, played in some city that did not earn the World Series.
Don't laugh. A trial balloon was lofted early this year by Jerry Colangelo, the major domo of a team in Phoenix that will not play its first game until 1998. Colangelo, a normally perceptive basketball executive, emphasized that he was only thinking out loud, but the specter remains that he is not alone in his thinking.
Television already calls the shots on starting times. How long do we have until the networks dictate indoor games so they won't have to adjust to rain delays -- or have to take on the sacred Monday Night Football?
Can you imagine what would be happening in New York at the moment if the Yankees were playing in their first World Series in 15 years -- but the games were being held in some hideous dome or outdoors in the Sun Belt? The city would delegate some of its finest zealots to heave some AA batteries in foreign ports. Instead, the Yankees took a bombing on the Mick's birthday.
Another loss like this and George Steinbrenner is going to start riding elevators at random like a latter-day Captain Ahab, seeking the alleged men who allegedly roughed him up after a loss the last time the Yankees played in the Series, 15 years ago. Somebody must pay for this.

New York Economy Starts to Bounce Back
The economy of New York City, which has foundered since the recession of the early 1990's, has begun to crawl back toward prosperity, largely because of rising profits on Wall Street. 
 In the first half of this year, the city's economy grew at an annual rate of 2.2 percent, below the national average of 3.3 percent but the highest for the first six months of any year since 1988. [Page A1.]
 
No Deal in G.M. Strike
Negotiators trying to end a strike by Canadian workers against General Motors reported slow progress but were hopeful that a deal might be reached as the deadline neared. [A12.]
 
Trends in Child Labor
Fewer children appear to be working overseas to make apparel sold in the United States, as companies adopt codes of conduct barring child labor, the Labor Department has found, but many companies fail to enforce the standards adequately. [A10.]
 
A Profit at Apple, but What Next?
The good news of Apple Computer's $25 million profit for its most recent quarter is set against a darker backdrop of much bigger losses and sales declines. The critical question is whether the marketplace will wait while Apple's new chief completes his corporate "transformation." News Analysis. [D5.]
 
The Big Loss At Burnett
By developing ad campaigns featuring memorable characters like the Marlboro cowboys, Tony the Tiger and the Maytag repairman, Leo Burnett has long been the envy of other agencies. But its loss of the United Airlines account was only the most painful of a number of blows. [D8.]
 
The action on Madison Avenue last week was not confined to the skies, friendly or otherwise. As United dismissed Burnett, there were changes among top executives at several other agencies. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D11.]
 
Pulling the Wool Over Their Eyes

Crossing the Digital Divide
A little-known board is charged with recommending ways to give small libraries and schools access to modern telecommunications at discount prices. [D5.]
 
U.S. Robotics's Stock Gyrates
The stock of U.S. Robotics, which has bounced up and down, continued the trend after the company's announcement that a faster modem was on the way. Market Place. [D6.]

A Missing Note on the Web
Imagine calling up a music site on the Web. Then you click a button on your PC screen to copy the title onto a CD. You could pop the CD out of the recorder and play it on your stereo. Unfortunately, such an application -- as well as others that would turn the Web into more of a custom information source -- does not exist. Denise Caruso: Digital Commerce. [D5.]
 
A New Encyclopedia for Russia
Five years after the demise of Communism, the only Russian-language encyclopedia dates to the Brezhnev era. Now Collier's plans to publish the first uncensored Russian encyclopedia since 1917, after the collapse of a partnership between Encyclopedia Britannica and Russian scholars. [D9.]

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Monday with the continuation of an article about the economic rebound in New York City misstated the timing of the most recent recession in the city. It began in 1989 and lasted until 1992; it did not occur in 1988. In some editions the chart also misstated the hotel occupancy rate for 1988. It was 75 percent, not 80.

HEADLINE: Federal Subsidies to States Tell Half the Story

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Several Oct. 12 letters raise questions about our study, "The Federal Budget and the States, Fiscal Year 1995." Gov. George Allen of Virginia in his letter focuses on the 17 percent of the domestic Federal budget that flows to state and local governments. By contrast, we analyzed all domestic Federal spending, including Social Security, defense, income support payments, veterans benefits, Medicare and Medicaid. We also look at all sources of Federal receipts used to finance these programs. 
 All these programs have economic effects on the state -- whether the states administer the programs themselves or the Federal Government provides the service directly. The point is simple. Salaries paid to Federal employees, payments to Federal contractors and Social Security checks to individual recipients all offer economic benefits to the states.
Governor Allen also suggests that the way to evaluate fairness is "to ask whether the funds are in fact flowing back to the users who finance them." We disagree. Some Federal programs, like Medicaid, are designed to be redistributive in nature, while others, like defense, are designed for other purposes -- but nearly all involve some redistribution.
States whose residents are better off should, and do, bear a higher percentage of the Federal tax burden. The policy question is how big the shifts ought to be.
 
MONICA FRIAR
HERMAN LEONARD
JAY WALDER
Cambridge, Mass., Oct. 18, 1996
 
The writers are at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government.

HEADLINE: If a Tree Falls, Should Its Neighbors Too?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: GREENVILLE, Me.

 BODY:
FROM a seaplane, Moosehead Lake sprawled steely gray under a dark, drizzly overcast. But autumn's brilliant hues made it seem as if full sunlight were bathing the trees of the Maine woods: red, orange and yellow hardwoods covering the mid-slopes of the northernmost Appalachians, set off by dark green conifers on the ridges and in the valleys.
The magnificent vista lasted for perhaps five minutes. Then the landscape gave way to a series of open tracts punched out of the woods as if by a cookie cutter. Some looked as bare as a moonscape; others displayed the shades of green, flecked with puffs of red and orange, that signal the early stages of recovery from deforestation. 
 Clear-cutting has long been hotly disputed here, and Maine voters are preparing to decide in a Nov. 5 referendum whether to ban it. The paper industry, which owns 10 million of the state's 17 million acres of forest, fears a decision to ban the practice. It has joined with middle-of-the-road environmentalists to offer a competing proposal that would reduce from 250 acres to 75 acres the greatest permissible size for clear-cutting.
The sharp debate has raised an issue that goes far beyond clear-cutting, that of how to manage the whole landscape to serve both nature and the economy. Some intriguing proposals are now being discussed by the industry, scientists and environmentalists.
One strategy, known as the triad approach, has been advanced by scientists at the University of Maine. It would assign one part of the landscape to be untouchable nature reserves, one to be tree farms and a third part to be lightly logged, in ways that mimic natural losses from fire, windstorms and insect infestations.
A second strategy is about to be tested in an unusual experiment on 100,000 industry-owned acres of mature forest. Known as the shifting mosaic approach, it relies on the ability of forests in the Northeastern United States to regenerate. The idea is to harvest timber in a sequential pattern that produces all stages of the natural recovery, from light-loving trees like white birch in the early years to shade-tolerant kinds like sugar maple, beech and spruce that appear later. Each stage of this mosaic would be host to a different set of plant and animal species, thus preserving the forest's full array of living creatures.
The mosaic idea, which is supported by some industry foresters and environmentalists alike, may or may not include clear-cutting, said Dr. John M. Hagan, the director of the experiment and an ecologist with the Manomet Observatory, an independent research organization in Manomet, Mass. Dr. Hagan has previously touched off debate by arguing that a single large clear-cut area can be healthier for a forest than many smaller but widely dispersed cuts, even partial ones, which degrade a larger area.
Whatever logging methods are used, Dr. Hagan says, the mosaic experiment is the first large-scale test of whether industrial forestry and biological health are compatible. If the answer is no, he says, it might be necessary to turn to remedies like nature preserves.
This leads to a third strategy, proposed by some environmentalists: that of converting more than two million acres into a national park, a prospect sure to be stoutly resisted by industry and unlikely to reach fruition any time soon.
Much depends on how serious the powerful paper industry is about ecological health. While industry foresters have "very definitely learned how to talk the talk, we'll have to see whether they can walk the walk," said Dr. Malcolm L. Hunter Jr., a wildlife ecologist at the University of Maine and an author of the triad strategy. Nevertheless, serious discussions are taking place. "Just five years ago," he said, "we didn't know how to get the conversation off the ground."
(The New York Times Company does not own or manage any forests. The company is a 40 percent owner of Madison Paper Industries in Madison, Me., which makes high-quality paper for magazines, including The New York Times Magazine.)
The issue of forest management here is different from that in the West, especially the Pacific Northwest with its virgin old-growth forests. Humans have been manipulating the Maine woods so long that only tiny remnants of virgin forest remain. The woods, in fact, have never been free of human influence: after the retreat of the glaciers some 10,000 years ago, people moved into this region before trees did.
Henry David Thoreau's account of an "uninterrupted" forest on his trips through Maine from 1846 through 1857, often cited today, also documented widespread logging even then.
The Maine woods' ability to regenerate has allowed them to be cut two, three, even four times. In much of the West, by contrast, aridity and high altitude often inhibit recovery. The smaller Eastern tree species also reach maturity in a century or less, much faster than the giants of the Pacific Northwest, which require up to 400 years.
Scientists say that continual reharvesting in Maine has created a relatively young forest. Still, it is possible to get some idea of what a mature forest is like. In one stand of evergreens near here, for instance, the ground beneath black spruce estimated at 100 to 120 years old is softly carpeted by wet moss. Lichens encrust the old, tightly spaced trunks. Not far away, on a slope dominated by brilliantly colored hardwoods, the trees have been growing back since a catastrophic fire in 1913. Sugar maples, beeches and yellow birches tower overhead, their canopies overlapping. The floor is strewn with herbaceous plants, fallen trunks, branches and leaves, providing a rich and complex habitat for animal life from salamanders to moose.
In the 1970's and 1980's, after a spruce budworm infestation killed large stretches of forest, wide tracts were clear-cut. But after a 1989 law limited clear-cutting to 250 acres, the proportion of timber harvested by this method has steadily declined from almost half to 8 percent, according to data from the Maine Forest Service. From 1990 through last year, the service reports about 16 percent of the Maine woods was cut; about 2 percent was clear-cut.
Scientists say clear-cutting leads to loss of vital soil nutrients, which may take decades to return. Still, a leading ecologist, Dr. Gene E. Likens of the Institute of Ecosystem Studies in Millbrook, N.Y., says on the basis of long-term studies that it may be an ecologically acceptable practice in the Northeast, if the clear-cut area is not too large, on too steep a slope or repeated too soon. An interval of 100 years or more is recommended.
Dr. Hagan says he has discovered that clear-cut areas are not the biological deserts he once thought. In one large, 10,000-acre clear-cut section, for instance, he found some 40 species of birds, many of them migrant songbirds from the tropics. The birds have adopted Maine's clear-cut areas because new forests have closed out their habitat in southern New England.
On the other hand, many other tropical migrants like the ovenbird can exist only in mature forests. It is not clear how logging affects Maine species other than birds, Dr. Hagan said, because the necessary studies have not been done. Some scientists have suggested that herbaceous plants and animals like salamanders that live on the forest floor could be seriously harmed by clear-cutting.
The purpose of next month's vote to ban clear-cutting is to stop the "worst abuses," said Jonathan Carter, a former forester who leads the campaign to ban the practice. What is going on now is "unconscionable," he said, because in time it will "destroy this state's future."
The alternative proposal restricts clear-cutting to 75 acres, sets up a system for grading paper companies' ecological performance and sets aside some 10,000 acres as an ecological reserve, to serve as a benchmark against which to measure the effect of future forest practices. A third choice on the ballot is to maintain the 250-acre clear-cutting limit.
However the vote comes out, the shifting mosaic experiment is set to begin next summer at two sites, one owned byGreat Northern Paper, the state's largest landowner, and the other by the S. D. Warren Company.
Dr. Hunter, one of several members of a broadly representative "stakeholder council" overseeing the project, said he believed that Dr. Hagan was too ready to accept clear-cutting as a tool, and that the practice too often departed from the ideal of mimicking natural disturbance.
Dr. Hunter's triad approach has drawn criticism as well. Some critics doubt that Maine's soils could long sustain intensive tree farming. Economically, it would take 40 years for the plantations to pay off with no compensating source of timber in the interim, said Marcia McKeague, Great Northern's manager of woodlands.
As for the idea of reserves, there is some support for it within the industry, but also "a great deal of caution," said Ms. McKeague. "There have been huge, huge proposals for reserves that would take up half of Maine, for instance, and that's something we couldn't live with."
Even if everyone could agree on some strategy for managing the forest, there remains the question of whether any approach would hold up under increasing demand for timber. Dr. Stephen C. Trombulak, an ecologist at Middlebury College in Vermont and an expert on the forest, put it this way: "If you continue to extract and extract without ever addressing the demand side, then we've lost all hope."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Job for a President

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The contenders have been uninspiring, the "debates" dreary, the intellectual level ranged from vapid to embarrassing -- but the Presidential campaign has brought one important benefit to the country.
It moved President and contender at last to give consistent public attention to a national problem that hugely increases crime, ruins family lives, sickens the brain, drives many Americans out of work forever, afflicts millions with diseases that cost taxpayers billions, makes the U.S. weaker physically, poorer economically, ugly culturally, withered morally and an object of contempt internationally: drug abuse. 
 The question is, will this attention, and follow-through action, last after Inauguration Day? How long?
If he is elected and does not make himself the leader of the movement against drugs, either Bill Clinton or Bob Dole will miss an opportunity that is unlikely to come his way again -- to use the Presidency to put a mark on history as a man who specifically and tangibly brightened the life and future of the nation.
No, not what he could do if only he had complete control of the Congress, or if foreign nations or domestic polls allowed. It seems reasonable to expect a President to set at least one major goal that he could fulfill pretty much by himself, eliminating excuses and rationalizations, and then for Heaven's sake go do it.
Both men have the ability to attain the goal of giving America the anti-drug leadership it needs, if they also have the courage to hold themselves accountable for achievements or failures during their term.
They will have the critical tool as they begin. The most effective weapon against drug abuse can be consistent Presidential emphasis on drug dangers, and how to fight them. Neither the incumbent nor his predecessors made preaching those dangers part of the weave of his Presidency. That is not the single answer, but is the foundation for all answers.
If the President is to be effective he must be painfully candid. He must tell the country it needs a no-tolerance attitude toward drug selling and other drug crimes and a severe attitude toward drug use. He must emphasize repeatedly that winning the drug war means law enforcement. Most drug criminals serving time are heavy sellers, and are either repeaters or have been arrested before for other crimes.
He will say that drug enforcement must be combined with interdiction abroad and therapy at home. None of the three should be slighted or allowed to become so politically chic as to overwhelm the other two and bring the anti-drug structure down.
He would say enforcement will get tougher, not softer, that on interdiction he will ask Mexico to choose between being the largest exporter of cocaine to America and surrendering U.S. aid and respect. He would say that compared with the cost and cruelties of crimes committed by drug users and sellers, enforcement, interdiction and therapy are cheap.
The President would use the Oval Office to bring in and reach out to parents and teachers. Teen-agers, the group showing an increase in use of drugs, mostly marijuana, a gateway to harder drugs, say they are getting less anti-drug attention from parents than they had expected.
Meantime, the lobby for drug legalization is growing more prosperous. It will not win, but the relative handful of prominent Americans involved get attention and funds that drain energy from the anti-drug effort.
No law prevents a George Soros from donating millions of tax-free foundation dollars to organizations preaching direct or backdoor legalization of drugs. Nor is there a law preventing donations to groups preaching the benefits of slavery. Addiction is one more variety. A candid President would say all that.
He would strengthen Mr. Clinton's own proposal that teen-agers pass a drug test to get a driving license. Why not everybody, and at dates unspecified until after the application or renewal?
The President will have a fine drug czar, Gen. Barry McCaffrey. He could also use a small council from politics, business and drug-fighting organizations. Its members would have something in common -- the passion for the struggle against drugs that the President himself will need if he is to brighten America's life and future.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
USAir Profit Surges 57% For Quarter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
USAir Group Inc. said yesterday that its earnings rose 57 percent in the third quarter, reflecting strong demand for international flights.
The company, based in Arlington, Va., earned $67.7 million, or 69 cents a share, compared with $43.1 million, or 35 cents a share, a year earlier. The per-share results reflect payment of preferred stock dividends. Revenue rose nearly 11 percent, to $2.07 billion from $1.87 billion. 
 Wall Street expected the company to earn 61 cents a share, based on a survey of nine analysts by I.B.E.S. International Inc.
The shares of USAir rose 25 cents yesterday, to $16.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The quarterly results reflect a $41.1 million provision in the 1996 quarter and a $15.1 million provision in the 1995 quarter for an employee profit-sharing plan that was initiated four years ago.
USAir's third-quarter financial performance was "good; it's not great," said Susan Donofrio, an analyst with NatWest Securities in New York. "It's good that it's profitable, but costs continue to creep up."
Increases in fuel prices for the most recent quarter reduced the earnings compared with the 1995 quarter, Ms. Donofrio added.
The average weekly cost for jet fuel during the third quarter of 1996 was 67.74 cents a gallon, up from 53.22 cents in the 1995 quarter.
The company said its improved results were largely a result of increased demand for international flights. USAir said its international business increased 57 percent from a year earlier, mainly because of new flights to Europe from Philadelphia.
Over all, demand for USAir flights rose 6.3 percent for the quarter. Planes were flying at 70 percent of capacity, an increase of 3 percentage points from a year earlier.
Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman and chief executive, said airline companies continued to "benefit from positive economic conditions."

HEADLINE: Ruth Farkas, 89, Nixon's Ambassador to Luxembourg, Dies

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Ruth Lewis Farkas, who was appointed Ambassador to Luxembourg in 1973 after she and her husband, the founder of the Alexander's department stores, contributed $300,000 to President Richard M. Nixon's re-election campaign, died on Friday at the Park Avenue home of her son Robin. She was 89.
Mrs. Farkas, who lived in Palm Beach, Fla., had been staying with Mr. Farkas and his wife, Carol, a nurse, in Manhattan since her release two weeks ago from the New York University Medical Center, where she had been treated for a heart ailment. 
 Despite the uproar that surrounded Mrs. Farkas's appointment and a delay in her Senate confirmation, her posting caused little stir in the tiny grand duchy of Luxembourg, which was accustomed to Americans whose path to ambassadorships was paved with political contributions.
Although Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas cast his Foreign Relations committee vote against her and denounced her appointment as demeaning the Foreign Service, Senator Gale W. McGee of Wyoming said he was satisfied that Mrs. Farkas was innocent of any impropriety and laughed about the custom of making envoys of people who make generous campaign contributions.
"The money -- that's par for the course," he said. "It used to be a cheaper price -- but that's Nixon inflation."
In contrast to Ambassador Perle Mesta, the Washington socialite who arrived in Luxembourg in 1949 with flamboyant ways and gala parties that inspired the Broadway musical "Call Me Madam," Mrs. Farkas, who held a doctorate in sociology from Columbia University and a doctorate in education from New York University, maintained a low profile.
Reserved by nature and press-shy because of the uproar that surrounded her appointment, she was more at ease as the sponsor of forums on the drug problems of teen-agers than in being a second coming of a woman known as the hostess with the mostest.
Not until two years after Mrs. Farkas arrived did she make her first splash in the social life of Luxembourg, with a charity gala that featured the singer Sacha Distel and a United States Army orchestra. The event took in $28,000 for a school for handicapped children.
She maintained close ties with the Government, gave quiet and unpretentious parties and, unlike many envoys, avoided making political statements about United States policy. Most diplomatic work was carried out by her six-member staff, and in the Luxembourg diplomatic community, which then included 13 other ambassadors, Mrs. Farkas, though serious, was not considered a heavyweight.
President Gerald R. Ford accepted her resignation in 1976 and replaced her with Rosemary L. Ginn, a longtime Republican national committeewoman from Missouri.
Mrs. Farkas settled in Florida and resumed her many philanthropic and humanitarian activities and research into male and female roles through the Role Foundation, which she established in 1967.
Ruth Lewis, one of five children of Samuel Lewis and the former Jennie Bach, was born in Manhattan in 1906. Both her parents were in the real estate business and each influenced her. "Community living and sharing, that was my mother; intellectual pursuits, that was my father," Mrs. Farkas once said.
Accompanying her mother into tenements taught her about poverty, and Mrs. Farkas never forgot her mother's advice: "No matter what your station in life, no matter what you grow up to be, always try to contribute to those less fortunate than you."
She met George Farkas when she was 10. Their families lived in the same apartment house, at 107th Street and Fifth Avenue, where George, whose father had died, kept a close eye on his little sister, who was Ruth Lewis's best friend.
"I didn't like him at first because he was such a boss," she said.
They were married in 1928, but not until she graduated from New York University. She received a master's degree from Columbia in 1932 and was for many years a member of the executive committee of Alexander's.
Mr. Farkas died in 1980.
In addition to Robin, Mrs. Farkas is survived by three other sons, Alexander of Highland Park, Fla., and Bruce and Jonathan, of Manhattan; 15 grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Jewish Cemetery Is Desecrated in Argentina, the Third This Year

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 21

 BODY:
A major Jewish cemetery was desecrated over the weekend, the third such attack in Argentina this year, raising fear among Jews and anger that the Government seems to be doing little to stop the anti-Semitic assaults.
Jewish leaders expressed outrage over the attack, in which a gang believed to have seven members sneaked past a guard at La Tablada cemetery on the capital's outskirts early Sunday morning and smashed or defaced 100 tombstones and mausoleums, according to police reports. The intruders painted red and black swastikas and "Hitler" on many tombstones before being chased by a guard who heard them, the police said. 
 The attack follows desecrations of tombs in Jewish cemeteries in the provinces of Cordoba and Salta in recent months and the deadly bombings of the Israeli Embassy in Buenos Aires in 1992, which killed 29 people, and of the country's main Jewish cultural center in 1994. That attack killed 90.
Neither the desecrations nor the bombings have been solved, prompting Jewish leaders to raise questions about the Government's commitment to justice in the cases.
"Our major concern is that this attack could develop into something much bigger," said Sergio Wiedder, the Argentine representative for the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles. The center is devoted to bringing Nazis to justice.
"The real problem," Mr. Wiedder said, "is one of security. The Jewish community is vulnerable to these attacks, because the Government does nothing to protect it or to solve the crimes. All we here is a lot of talk and promises of security, but no action."
Television stations broadcast film on Sunday of people who were weeping on visits to the desecrated tombs of family members and friends.
Last week, Domingo Cavallo, who was dismissed as Finance Minister in the summer in a disagreement over his economic changes, said Argentina had dragged its feet in investigating the bombings.
La Tablada, which covers 138 acres and has 70,000 graves, is the largest Jewish cemetery in the country. With Latin America's largest Jewish population, Argentina has 230,000 people who identify themselves as Jews.
Jewish leaders said the extensive damage at La Tablada had led them to conclude that the desecration was the work of a well-organized group and not a "marginal gang," as some Government officials had said.
The Israeli Ambassador to Argentina, who toured the cemetery yesterday, called on the Government to locate and prosecute those responsible for the attack. "There is no room for xenophobia," the Ambassador, Yitzhak Aviran, said. "But I don't know if we will make it to the next century if these horrible acts continue to take place."
The Delegation of Argentine Jewish Associations, a federation of groups, said in a news release: "We are asking for the right to live in peace. We want answers from the courts, and not merely words of comfort."
Calling the desecration a "cowardly attack against Jews," President Carlos Saul Menem promised to add security for Jewish cemeteries to prevent such attacks, and Interior Minister Carlos Corach, who is Jewish, said the Government would start a full investigation.
"How long will our society tolerate the evil symbol of the swastika?" asked Oscar Hansman, president of the Argentine Jewish Mutual Aid Association, the largest Jewish group in Argentina. "How long will the men who committed this violent act continue to enjoy impunity in the country?"

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A notable trend toward the upgrading of corporate credit.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
THE rising stock market is having a very positive effect on American companies: corporate credit quality, as measured by changes in bond ratings, appears to be better than ever.
So far this year, Moody's has upgraded the ratings of 221 companies, compared with 146 companies downgraded. That works into a ratio of 1.51 upgrades for each downgrade, by far the best in at least two decades. 
 Part of that rise in credit quality has come from the ability of many companies to sell stock, either in the form of additional offerings or as initial public offerings, with the money used to bolster the balance sheet and improve credit quality.
"The stock market strength has prompted the substitution of debt capital with equity capital," said John Lonski, a senior economist at Moody's Investors Service.
That does not necessarily mean that corporate America is stronger financially than ever before. From 1985 through 1992, "we went through a very rough period," characterized by a large number of downgrades, Mr. Lonski said, adding, "To a degree, we are merely reversing a good deal of the damage that was done to corporate credit worth" in that turbulent period.
To some extent, the rising volume of upgradings reflects the growing financial strength of corporate America more than five years into an economic expansion, and is what one might expect.
But it also reflects the reality that leverage is not quite as fashionable as it used to be. Companies once chose to leverage up as part of a growth strategy or in some cases as a defensive strategy, since it was sometimes possible for corporate raiders to effectively borrow most of the money needed to take over a company by pledging the target company's borrowing power.
The rise in corporate bond ratings has come at a time when the bond markets have narrowed quality spreads to historically low levels, which is to say that companies with low ratings are penalized much less than they were when it comes time to borrow money.
That provides an incentive for companies not to worry about their ratings, but the general trend toward upgradings may also help explain why investors are less concerned with credit quality than they were, and are thus willing to bid for bonds at prices that narrow the credit spreads.
Some of the strongest upgrade activity in recent years, and continuing in 1996, has been in financial companies, particularly banks. In 1990, Moody's downgraded 145 financial companies, while upgrading only 18; in the first nine months of 1996, the figures show 49 upgrades and just 12 downgrades.
In addition, much of the upgrading has come in the world of junk bonds -- bonds rated below the investment grade of Baa at Moody's and BBB at Standard & Poor's, the other major bond-rating service.
Take away junk bonds and financial issues, and the corporate quality picture is not quite as attractive. Carol Levenson, editor of the Gimme Credit fax newsletter based in Chicago, which follows the corporate bond market, reports that downgradings of investment-grade industrial issues are running 1.3 to 1 ahead of upgradings, using S.& P. ratings.
Most of those downgrades, however, do not reflect deteriorating fundamentals at the companies. They stem from what is called "event risk" in the bond market -- that is, from a decision by the company to make its balance sheet look worse, either by buying back stock or by making a large acquisition for cash.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "A Positive Outlook" tracks the ratio of upgrading to downgradings for companies rated by Moody's. Graph runs from 1975 through 1996. (Source: Moody's Investor Service)
