HEADLINE: City Ethics Panel Rules for Giuliani in Time Warner Cable Case

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The New York City Conflicts of Interest Board dismissed a complaint against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday, saying that the Mayor did not have to recuse himself from decisions involving Time Warner just because his wife works for the company's competitor, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation.
The board's ruling came as the Giuliani administration released copies of depositions from its legal battle with Time Warner that showed that Time Warner's president had made overtures to a deputy mayor to try to iron out the dispute in private. 
 The Mayor and Time Warner are fighting over his plan to put Mr. Murdoch's new 24-hour news channel on one of the city-run cable stations. Mr. Giuliani decided to aid Mr. Murdoch after Time Warner refused to carry the channel on its regular band of stations, saying there was no space.
The Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, had charged that the Mayor might have violated the City Charter by helping Mr. Murdoch, pointing out that he owns WNYW-TV, Channel 5, which employs Mr. Giuliani's wife, Donna Hanover Giuliani, as a part-time newscaster.
The conflicts board ruled that Mrs. Giuliani would be unlikely to benefit from any action that her husband took involving a review by a city panel of Time Warner's cable franchises because she is not at the managerial level of the News Corporation or its subsidiaries. The board also noted that neither the Mayor nor his wife has an ownership stake in the News Corporation.
Jack Deacy, a spokesman for Mr. Giuliani, said the decision "refutes a baseless charge that was clearly raised for political purposes." In a statement, Ms. Messinger, a Democrat who is expected to run for mayor next year, accepted the board's ruling. But she continued to call on the Mayor to recuse himself, insisting that there remained an appearance of a conflict of interest.
In the depositions released yesterday, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, Randy M. Mastro, described in a sworn statement a phone call that he received from Time Warner's president, Richard D. Parsons, earlier this month.
Mr. Mastro said Mr. Parsons asked him whether there was "some way to resolve this, because Time Warner would have to go to war on these issues if they were not resolved amicably." Mr. Mastro added that by the end of the conversation, the two were unable to settle the dispute.
At the time, Mr. Parsons was an economic adviser to Mr. Giuliani, as well as a prominent supporter. But a few days after the phone call, Mr. Parsons angrily stepped down, criticizing the Mayor's economic development policies.

HEADLINE: Pataki Leads Rare Coalition For Bond Act

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
One morning last week, Gov. George E. Pataki strode serenely into the heart of what was, just three months ago, enemy territory: the midtown offices of 1199 National Health and Human Service Employees Union.
The union had spent $3 million over the last two years on a fierce advertising campaign accusing the Governor of abandoning the poor, the disabled and the elderly. But on this sun-dappled day in Manhattan, Mr. Pataki was greeted like a trusted ally, as some of New York State's most powerful labor leaders gathered to endorse the Governor's $1.75 billion environmental bond act and to pledge their potent get-out-the-vote operations to pass the proposition on Nov. 5. 
 "The environment is basic to health," said Dennis Rivera, 1199's president. "And if the Governor becomes a spokesperson for an issue we care about, hallelujah!"
Mr. Pataki's ability to win endorsements from his onetime labor adversaries typifies his success in building a well-financed and surprisingly diverse coalition to support the Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act, which would finance projects from sewage treatment plants to electric cars to landfill closings and, backers say, create 60,000 jobs.
Just how Mr. Pataki, who has often clashed with the very Democrats, environmentalists and labor leaders who are now embracing him in the bond act effort, managed to win such broad backing is a tale of careful planning and blind fortune. The sudden popularity of the environment as a political issue this year, the recoiling of many voters from conservative Republicanism, President Clinton's big lead in polls in the state and the lack of any other statewide races have all contributed to making the bond act a rallying issue for politicians of all stripes.
But the bond act's apparent popularity -- polls show voters back it by 2 to 1 -- also illustrates how Mr. Pataki, a staunch fiscal conservative, has succeeded in wresting environmental issues from the Democrats and how he has devised a plan that offers something for almost everybody, including many groups he has alienated with budget cuts.
Labor unions like the bond act because of the promise of new jobs. Teachers like it because it will provide money to replace dirty coal-burning school furnaces. Staten Islanders like it because it will pay to close the Fresh Kills Landfill. Suburbanites like the money for waste-water plants. City officials like it because it includes money for cleaning up abandoned manufacturing sites and buying natural-gas buses.
And, of course, environmentalists like it because it addresses several of their major concerns, mainly urban air pollution and water quality around the state.
Mr. Pataki's aides -- mainly his counsel, Michael C. Finnegan, who has taken a leave to direct the bond act campaign -- did much groundwork to garner broad support for the bond act.
First, they conducted polls in the spring to see if voters liked the idea. Satisfied that they did, Mr. Finnegan then studied Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's 1990 environmental bond act, which narrowly failed. He decided that it included too much money for land acquisition, which angered property-rights and farmers groups, and too much money for small projects like parking lots and park benches, which critics lustily attacked as trivial pork-barrel spending.
Finally, he met privately with scores of environmentalists, offering them a role in shaping the plan in exchange for their support.
The result was a proposal that would spend most of its money -- $1.1 billion -- on protecting lakes, rivers, seashores and drinking water. The proposition, which is the only statewide question on the ballot this year, does not list in detail how the money will be spent -- an attempt to avoid the pork-barrel criticism. Instead, it authorizes local governments to apply for money for projects in five general areas: clean water, safe drinking water, solid waste, urban cleanups and air quality.
With the Presidential campaign generating little excitement around the state, politicians on the hustings have been drawn to the bond act like bugs to a bulb. Democrats in Manhattan and Republicans in Rochester alike have eagerly stumped for the proposition, using it either to energize their liberal bases or win support from women and moderates.
Republicans, many of whom have been trying to distance themselves from House Speaker Newt Gingrich and the party's conservative wing all year, have used the bond act to guide them toward the center. Even New York's most powerful Republican, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, has spent more than $500,000 on commercials touting his support for the proposition -- even though he is not known for taking strong environmental stands in Congress.
Democrats, who have long viewed the environment as their issue, have found themselves gritting their teeth and linking arms with Mr. Pataki. Only a handful of Democrats, mostly upstate conservatives, have opposed the act, while many more have appeared at local news conferences endorsing it.
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, who is widely viewed as a likely Democratic challenger to Mr. Pataki in 1998 and who has often attacked the Republican Governor's budgets as fiscally irresponsible, has crisscrossed the state praising the plan. "It is something that is good for all New Yorkers," Mr. McCall said at an Albany news conference last week that was attended mostly by Democratic officials.
Mr. Pataki's critics say he has used the bond act as a midterm vehicle to broaden his support among moderates and soften his image among groups he has angered. And his travels around the state promoting it have become an invaluable off-year promotional campaign laying the groundwork for a 1998 re-election effort.
They note, for instance, that Mr. Pataki has spent much time selling the bond act in New York City, where his support is weakest. Last week, the Governor appeared at a public school in Manhattan with Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew to publicize $125 million in the bond act for replacing coal-burning furnaces in 280 city schools.
Some Democrats regard his actions skeptically.
One Democratic labor organizer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said, "There's been talk among some labor people that if you give Pataki the bond act, it will help him win in 1998 because he'll have all that money to spend, and that will help him move to the center."
But Mr. Pataki contends that he did not propose the bond act to burnish his image.
"This is something I've been very out front on since I was a little kid," he said in an interview. "I don't need another issue to give me the excuse to go around the state. This is a unique opportunity to do something I feel is right."
Still, it is clear that the bond act has provided Mr. Pataki a useful tool to mend fences. For much of this year, his administration was at war with the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O., whose leaders were angry with his proposals to revamp the workers' compensation system, cut state spending and change worker training programs. But after a meeting with the Governor last week, in which Mr. Pataki promised that bond act projects would pay prevailing wages, which are usually union scale, labor federation leaders emerged praising Mr. Pataki's leadership skills.
Edward J. Cleary, the president of the 2.3-million-member state A.F.L.-C.I.O., even said that a labor endorsement of Mr. Pataki in 1998, unthinkable three months ago, was now within the realm of possibility. Labor unions have vowed to provide hundreds of workers to run telephone banks and travel door to door across the state promoting the bond act.
At the same time, scores of environmental groups, whose combined membership is well over 100,000, are using their newsletters and mailing lists to reach pro-environment voters. And the Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act Committee, as well as a coalition of environmental groups, will begin running television and radio commercials this week.
Those efforts dwarf the opposition, which remains scattered, muted and poorly financed. The Farm Bureau, an organization representing farmers, and the state's Conservative Party, which helped defeat the last environmental bond act, in 1990, have done almost nothing to oppose this one, largely because they strongly support Mr. Pataki.
Another group, Change-N.Y., a longtime supporter of Mr. Pataki, has been more aggressive in attacking the bond act in editorial board meetings and public debates. But the anti-tax group's wealthy backers have not yet pledged any money for a media campaign.
"The opposition is pretty disorganized," said Thomas W. Carroll, the group's president. "But the fact that the last three bond acts went down suggests it will have trouble."
People on both sides agree, however, that opposition to the new bond act is less visceral than in 1990, when an environmental bond act proposed by Governor Cuomo was narrowly defeated. Supporters of this year's measure say the state was in a recession in 1990, creating economic anxieties that do not exist now.
Given the lack of organized opposition, the bond act's greatest obstacle may be voter indifference. Some supporters worry that because President Clinton is doing so well in the polls, urban Democrats -- the people believed to be the most likely to support the borrowing plan -- may stay home.
They also worry that New York City voters will have trouble finding the proposition on the ballot: nestled in the lower-right-hand corner. In upstate districts, where opposition is keenest, the question is in the upper-left-hand corner of the ballot, making it the first thing many voters will see when they enter the booth. Local election boards draw up the ballots.
"The overwhelming inclination in New York City is to vote for it," said Ben Esner, field director for the Environmental Coalition for the Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act. "The key now is to make people know it's there."

HEADLINE: In Creating Russia's 'Sesame Street,' Letter 'D' Stands for Difficult

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Their parents' idea of American culture usually comes straight from watching Russia's most popular television shows: "Dynasty," "Baywatch" and "Beverly Hills 90210."
Now Russian children are also about to have their chance to participate in the great American intellectual experience. At least they will get something worth watching: on Tuesday a striking Russian version of "Sesame Street," or "Ulitsa Sezam," as it will be called here, will start appearing on television sets across the country. 
 "Sesame Street," which is history's most influential children's television show, is often exported and usually welcome in the country to which it is sent. But nothing is so simple in Russia. It took five years and $6 million to develop an indigenous show that would appeal to Russian children, yet not be so gloomy that the people from Children's Television Workshop refused to produce it.
During that time armed gunmen drove the company from its Moscow work space and nationalist politicians demanded to know why Russia needed television shows from America for its children to watch in the first place.
"It has been a long haul," said Natasha Lance Rogoff, the executive producer and series director of the show. "We had a lot to overcome but also a lot to work with. The talent here is rich and wonderful, the children are curious and there is a place for this show."
That's putting it more than mildly. Russia has a great tradition of brilliant animation and wonderful theater for children. But there is only one educational show for the preschool set, and "Sesame Street," which will appear three times a week at 6:30 P.M. on NTV, the independent television network, is an addition sought desperately by educators and parents alike.
But the goofy cheer of the American show and the obvious mission of preparing children for the joy of learning has been achieved in Russia only with enormous effort.
After seven decades of totalitarian rule, followed by several years of constant economic and political uncertainty, this society is anything but jolly. The birth rate has plummeted for years and young families -- often viewing the future with undisguised dread -- have not been eager to raise families.
Not surprisingly, perhaps, children here are grim. "When we went to audition children," Ms. Rogoff said, "90 percent of them sat back in their chairs and started to sing very sad songs. It was astonishing to see. But joy did not come easily to them. In fact, obedience, solemnity and duty seemed to be all they knew. It was sad, but it reminded me how important it was to bring this show to Russia."
There is nothing dour, or even very American, about "Ulitsa Sezam." New York City's quintessential brownstone has somehow become the building courtyard that is the center of human activity in most villages and cities in Russia. Big Bird is out, replaced by an awkward and adorable doglike character named Zeliboba, who lives in the hollow of a gigantic oak tree. Other characters -- including the imaginative but slightly ditzy Businka and Kubik, the pensive inventor -- manage to come straight from the long tradition of Russian folk tales while seeming distantly related to their American counterparts.
"Ulitsa Sezam" seeks to teach children to be proud of themselves and their country, to respect their parents but to understand that fun is an important part of life. It is a crucial message for Russian children, a surprising number of whom are capable of sitting through a day at a circus and a dinner at McDonald's without cracking a smile.
The show brings to Russia the same inventive word play with the alphabet that has helped teach millions of American youngsters how to read. One minute Zeliboba is prattling on about butterflies (whose Russian name begins with the letter "B," too) and the next butterflies are flying at the screen as children screech, "Bravo!" (another "B" word, even in Russian). But even the alphabet turned out to be tough for some of the screenwriters to handle.
From long experience the producers know that a light touch works best. The writers wanted to use heavy words gleaned from their own depressing childhood. Using the word "depressia" (no joke) to teach a child how to use the letter "D" might make Dostoyevsky smile briefly, but it is not a formula for success with toddlers.
"We are a country that has lived through a revolution in the last decade," said Vladimir Grammatikov, the director of the series, who has a reputation for producing high-quality films here. "So we are, of course, having trouble finding people with a new approach to the world. That is exactly why this show is so timely and valuable."
There is also the traditional "Sesame Street" commitment to ethnic blending and ecological responsibility, which grew out of its roots as a show developed by people with a lingering 60's view of the world. Learning the alphabet is one thing; teaching a Russian child the importance of recycling in a country where that word means nothing -- at least not yet -- may be another.
Still, you have to start somewhere. And Russian educators have finally admitted that television has become as influential here as it is in every other country. Better to have children watch something of value than the usual daytime fare of cheap imitations of American game shows and cartoons poorly dubbed into Russian.
The show was produced with the help of several grants, including one from the United States Agency for International Development and the Soros Foundation. Nobody expects it to earn much money. About 60 percent of the shows -- there are 52 so far -- are made in Russia with Russian children and a Russian world view. The rest are dubbed. Next year if the show is continued, the producers say they hope that every show will be made in Russia.
"We are honestly hoping to have as much of an effect on Russian children as 'Sesame Street' has had on Americans," Mr. Grammatikov said. "We want to make this revolution as important as those we have already had."

HEADLINE: Small-Business Owners Prepare for a Megabattle

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
With the City Planning Commission expected tomorrow to approve the Giuliani administration's plan to allow suburban-style megastores in manufacturing areas, the proposal appears headed for a fierce battle before the City Council.
The Planning Commission is expected to pass the measure with only minor modifications. But opposition from small-business owners, who fear that the superstores would doom their businesses, has been consistent and strong. In recent months, a groundswell of community opposition has developed across the city, especially in Queens, which would receive the largest number of superstores under the plan. 
 That neighborhood resistance resonates loudly for Council members and also puts Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in an awkward position, because it comes from areas that supported him strongly in the last election.
Joan V. DaCorta, president of the Astoria Heights Homeowners and Tenants Association in Queens, exemplifies that opposition.
Mrs. DaCorta said she liked the fact that by about 7 every night, after people get off work and go into their well-kept red-brick homes, the streets of her neighborhood become extremely quiet, even dull.
She gets agitated at the mention of the Mayor's rezoning plan, because it would allow a megastore to open in a manufacturing district in the middle of her neighborhood without having to obtain a special permit or go through community review.
"We don't need 24-hour-a-day, 7-days-a-week businesses in our community," she said. "I love to walk to church on Sundays. So do I want a store that's clamoring when I walk by? No. I want my day of rest. If I wanted all that hustle and bustle, I would have moved to Manhattan years ago."
Mrs. DaCorta and hundreds of other homeowners blocked a large Pathmark supermarket from moving into the area in 1994. She said they were prepared to fight the zoning changes with just as much fervor.
Homeowner groups like Mrs. DaCorta's made their feelings known at community and borough board meetings during the summer, prompting 21 of the 36 community boards that considered the plan to vote against it, as did all five borough boards. Those votes are strictly advisory, since the Council will have final say.
City officials said they always expected a significant amount of resistance to the plan, because it would change a policy that has gone unchallenged for more than two decades. But they also said that once they had explained the plan to Council members and citizens, they thought that opponents would be persuaded that the rezoning would improve the city's retail economy while also creating a more sensible and uniform zoning policy.
"What people seem to be forgetting is that right now manufacturing zones throughout the city can be inundated with many kinds of retail activity in unplanned ways that can have enormous negative effects on neighborhoods," said Joseph B. Rose, the City Planning Commission chairman. "Under this proposal, all areas of the city will be protected and we'll be getting rid of arbitrary restrictions."
The Mayor's plan would allow as many as 57 new superstores to open, without going through a community approval process that can take as long as three years, on wide streets in areas zoned for light and medium manufacturing. The stores could be as large as 200,000 square feet, roughly the size of five football fields.
The rezoning would repeal restrictions that the city imposed in 1974 in a failed attempt to keep industries and lure new ones into manufacturing areas. The city decided to prohibit certain kinds of large stores in manufacturing areas out of a fear that retail outlets would drive up property prices and discourage manufacturers from returning to the city. But the strategy was misguided, Mr. Rose said, because it did not help manufacturing and only served to retard retail development.
The City Planning Department estimates that the rezoning would help the city recapture $1.5 billion a year in retail sales that now flows into the suburbs, where superstores have existed for years. It is estimated that the city would reap $50 million annually in sales tax revenues and the new stores would create about 13,600 new jobs.
Mr. Rose added that the changes also would allow the city to regulate more carefully stores like Home Depot and Toys "R" Us, which have been able to move into manufacturing zones because the 1974 law was written before those kinds of megastores were invented and therefore did not expressly prohibit them.
The success of such stores attest to how much New Yorkers want to shop in superstores, he said. The Home Depot that opened in June 1995 in a manufacturing zone in Flushing, for example, is the only 24-hour store and the highest-volume store in the chain of 476 outlets.
Real estate developers have welcomed the rezoning as a historic change that shows the city's commitment to becoming friendlier to retail businesses.
Bruce Ratner, president of Forest City Ratner, which has developed seven retail centers in the city and plans to build seven more, said that after carefully studying the city's retail market, his company has determined there simply are not enough large parcels of suitable land available in the city to meet the demand for retail variety.
He said that even with the proposed zoning changes, he could only find 15 to 20 sites in manufacturing zones suitable for large retail developments. "All this opposition about the rezoning putting people out of business is a tempest in a teapot, because there aren't enough good sites available for retail to make a meaningful impact on anybody," he said.
Richard Lipsky, a lobbyist who heads the Neighborhood Small Business Association, argued, however, that the very sites that people like Mr. Ratner deem suitable for superstores are the kinds of locations that small businesses and homeowners want to protect. "Where else would you put a big supermarket except where the people and the small businesses already are?" he said.
Mrs. DaCorta said her opposition would not wane even if planning officials found a way to remove her neighborhood's manufacturing site from the rezoning plan.
"The idea that the city is trying to eliminate community input and for them to just tell us they know what's right for us, how dare they?" she said. "When you do something like that, we might as well be in Russia.
"This is an opportunity for Mayor Giuliani to prove that he is for the people, and the people in the community are the ones that should have something to say about this."

HEADLINE: Elections Fail to Clarify Outlook for Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 21

 BODY:
As Japan has wallowed through the last few years of economic stagnation and political turmoil, corporate executives have looked to its Government for two things -- stable and strong leadership, and economic deregulation that would lay the groundwork for Japan Inc. to roar again in the 21st century.
But the national elections that were held on Sunday will probably fall short of either of these outcomes. That prompted investors to send the Nikkei index of 225 issues, the benchmark indicator of the Tokyo stock market, down by 1.4 percent today. 
 In the elections, the Liberal Democratic Party, which has ruled Japan for most of the period since World War II and is considered pro-business, met with only partial success. It strengthened its hand in the lower house of Parliament, but not quite enough to completely avoid the possibility of a repeat of the current unstable coalition Government.
And to the extent that the Liberal Democrats now have more control over the Government, they are likely to proceed cautiously on deregulating business and streamlining Japan's powerful bureaucracy.
"The impact on business? I think very little," said Yotaro Kobayashi, the chairman of the Fuji Xerox Corporation, a joint venture of Xerox and the Fuji Photo Film Company.
American businesses, some of which had been counting on deregulation to open Japan's markets, will also probably be disappointed with the election results.
Washington's efforts to negotiate trade agreements in the last few years have been hindered by Japan's lack of political leadership and frequent changes in government. To the extent the Japanese Government, and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, are now stronger, reaching such agreements might be easier.
But Mr. Hashimoto may not be the strong politician who can bring Japan's powerful bureaucracy to heel and single-handedly deliver trade compromises. He made his reputation by standing up to the Clinton Administration in the 1995 automobile talks and has shown no inclination to be the "fixer" that some American officials seek in Japan.
Tokyo stocks dropped significantly but not violently today because the Liberal Democratic Party did not win a clear victory. The Nikkei average fell 309.35 points to close at 21,302.95, wiping out about half of the 644-point gain the index recorded last week after newspaper polls predicted that the party might gain a majority of the 500 seats in Parliament.
[Stocks continued to slip on Tuesday. At the end of the session, the Nikkei was down 179.27 points, or more than eight-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,123.68.]
On currency markets, the dollar rose to a high for the year of 112.89 yen in Tokyo trading today. Later, the dollar set a 33-month high against the yen for New York trading, reaching 112.77 yen.
The election results and remarks today by Yasuo Matsushita, the governor of the Bank of Japan, suggest that interest rates here will remain near zero for the next few months, which tends to weaken the yen.
Analysts said it was difficult to completely predict the election's implications for the economy until it became clear which parties would take part in the new coalition -- and what conditions they would demand for joining.
The Liberal Democratic Party, which despite its name is conservative, won 239 seats, compared with the 212 it held before the election. That is enough to insure domination of the new coalition, but is still about two dozen seats shy of what is needed for a comfortable majority.
"We would prefer a single-party Government, realistically and particularly the L.D.P.," said Masaya Miyoshi, the president of Keidanren, the most powerful business lobbying organization in Japan.
Japan's economy faces serious problems. At 3.3 percent, unemployment is high by Japanese standards, as companies, forced by the strong yen, have moved factories abroad in recent years. Japan, which once chastised the United States for running huge Federal budget deficits, now has a budget deficit that is among the deepest of developed nations. Banks are laden with bad debt.
But this year the yen has weakened and the economy, propped up by low interest rates and high public-works spending, is growing again at about a 3 percent rate, and unemployment has stabilized.
While the economy is expected to weaken again next year, for now the pressure has lessened for radical deregulation that would produce pain and unemployment in the short run, even if it would lead to long-term efficiencies and promote the formation of new businesses.
Despite the growing power of the Liberal Democratic Party, executives said, it would be too simple to say the clock had been turned back to before 1993, when the party had ruled Japan for nearly four decades in a partnership with the bureaucracy and big business.
While that triangle still exists, large corporations have been globalizing, so their interests are less intertwined with those of Japan's economy. Corporate contributions to the Liberal Democratic Party have fallen, in part because a new election law provides public subsidies to candidates, lowering the influence of business on politics.
Corporate executives also say that the Liberal Democrats will have to deliver some changes.
"Hashimoto is no fool," Mr. Kobayashi of Fuji Xerox said. "He knows which way the wind is blowing and he knows the L.D.P. cannot live without the support of business and the society."
The party has realized that it must appeal more to urban consumers, rather than the shrinking number of farmers in the country.
Another factor hailed by some businessmen was that the Social Democratic Party, which is even more resistant to liberalization than the Liberal Democratic Party, was severely weakened by its poor showing in Sunday's election.
The Social Democrats, who have been in the ruling coalition with the Liberal Democrats, blocked the Government from lifting a restriction against holding companies, which business groups want to help corporate revamping. Opponents fear that holding companies would lead to domination of the economy by large conglomerates.

HEADLINE: Moscow Journal;
Anticolonial U., Now a Hotbed of Business Majors

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 17

 BODY:
In the old days, Fidel Castro and Yasir Arafat walked the halls as guests of Patrice Lumumba University. And in the dormitories, the talk among students was of revolution and of radical plots to shake off colonial and imperial masters.
"We were idealists," said Valery A. Belov, a Russian law professor who graduated from the university in 1973. "We thought we could change the world." 
 Created by the Soviet Communist Party in 1960, Patrice Lumumba University had as its main mission to recruit and train students from developing countries. It was hoped that those young men and women, who studied free of charge, might ultimately carry the Communist revolution across the third world. The school was renamed for Mr. Lumumba, the first Prime Minister of Zaire, after he was killed during a coup backed by the United States in 1961.
But when the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991, so did much of the university's funding. Scholarships dried up, and poor foreign students stopped coming.
Today the university, which once educated Nicaraguan guerrillas, Sri Lankan revolutionaries and the terrorist known as Carlos, now courts those who can pay their own way. Many are the wealthy sons and daughters of the very third-world capitalists the Soviets once dreamed of overthrowing.
"Yeah, they all used to be Communists here and some of the teachers still are," said Olawale Bewaji, a 21-year-old engineering student from Lagos, Nigeria, who listens to American rap music in his spare time.
Mr. Bewaji, the son of a Nigerian doctor, says he is more interested in democracy than Communism. "I just tell them, 'You're old-fashioned,' " he said.
Five years after the collapse of the Communist ideology that created it, Patrice Lumumba University -- now renamed the Russian People's Friendship University -- is still struggling to establish a new identity in a democratic Russia.
Foreigners, who once dominated the university with 65 percent of the enrollment of 7,000, now make up only 30 percent of the student body. Most of its students are Russian now, many of them young people who could not gain entrance into more prestigious universities.
The third-world students who do walk the campus these days carry beepers, wear Levis and rent movies for VCR's they brought from home. Most dream about making money, not revolution.
Confronted with the new reality, the administration added business courses, tossed out Communist texts and dropped classes like Marxist Philosophy.
It is only natural then that business administration is one of the university's most popular courses. The once-required staple, "History of the Communist Party," is now history itself.
Even the remaining Communist students here arrive with capitalist sensibilities.
"When I got to the dormitory there was nothing but a bed in the room -- and an uncomfortable bed at that," complained Xuan Yizeng, 23, an economics major from Beijing. "I had to buy a television and a radio myself. Can you believe that?"
The university still attracts foreign students because its diplomas still carry prestige in parts of the third world and because its tuition is only $2,000 a year -- a bargain when compared with some Western institutions.
But the changes sadden some old timers, who miss the heated political discussions at the university.
"Now there are just a few dances, that's it," said Professor Belov, who heads the university's graduate association.
"The students study business and they think about making money," he said. "In the old days, we thought about the struggle. Now, they study capitalist ideas and forget they're in the birth place of socialism."
The welcome that the young foreigners once received from Russians, who viewed the students as allies in the battle against capitalism, is also strained.
"The Soviet hope was that these students would go back and become spokesmen for the Russian view of the world," said Elizabeth K. Valkenier, an American who is a resident scholar at Columbia University's Harriman Institute of Russian Studies. "Together, they were going to strangle the West."
Now, foreign students say, they encounter hostility and racism on the streets from police officers and average citizens. Several years ago, an African student was killed by the police during a confrontation here with black students who complained that the police harassed them.
And students say they are still tormented by police officers, who stop them, demand to see their visas and then insist on a bribe before letting them go.
"The first Russian word I learned was 'fine,' ' said Mr. Xuan, which he said was the polite word that the police often use when demanding money.
"On the metro, the people, they yell, 'Go home!' " he said.
Such hostility surprised Osahon Egho, an 18-year-old law student from Nigeria. Her father, now an engineer, attended the university as a young man. He still raves about the hearty welcome he received here.
"Foreigners, we were like kings, that's what my father tells me," Ms. Egho said. "But now we're second-class citizens."
She says that she and her friends would have preferred to study in the West. But since Nigerian gangs have been linked to the heroin trade, Nigerians often find it difficult to get student visas, she said.
"America wouldn't let us in," Ms. Egho said. "London wouldn't let us in. So we came here. I think I regret it."
But even students who complain about crumbling dormitories and Communist professors still commend the university's academic rigor.
And the school still takes pride in its history, despite the changed environment. In a glass case, in the Patrice Lumumba Museum, for instance, hangs a metal etching bestowed by Mr. Arafat that depicts a wished-for Palestine.
It is surrounded by gifts from students and politicians from around the world: elephant tusks from Sudan, a glittering dagger from Yemen, an Aztec calendar from Mexico.
For while few of the university's students set off Communist revolutions, many have become respected political and scientific leaders in their countries. They include doctors in Japan, economists in Chile, politicians in Mexico and engineers in Nigeria.
And this year, for the first time since 1992, the Government is once again offering scholarships to foreign students.
Even without the ideological glue that once brought people together, the school still hopes to unite foreign students and to produce well-trained professionals who will play significant roles in their countries, Professor Belov said.
"Everything has changed," he said, "but what remains is the idea of the friendship among peoples."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
With Softer Tone, Dole Turns to Economy

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Oct. 21

 BODY:
After a weeklong assault on President Clinton's ethics, Bob Dole downshifted today and went back to extolling his economic package as his bus caravan rolled through the brilliant fall foliage of southern Michigan.
"The mainstay, the centerpiece, of this campaign is an economic package," the Republican Presidential nominee asserted at a low-key forum in Detroit this morning before setting out on a two-day venture across this important Midwestern state, where he trails President Clinton in public opinion polls by double-digits. 
 Rather than wag his finger in shame at the Clinton Administration, Mr. Dole, who has been fighting a head cold, took on a ruminating tone.
He noted that his televised debate last week with the President had drawn a relatively small audience, and said: "So maybe there's no interest in politics. Maybe nobody cares. Or maybe they're just getting around to focus on it and are beginning to make up their minds, because there's a lot of movement out there."
"We see the polls go up and down, up and down," he continued. "And they can't all be right. And they can't all be wrong. Probably some are in the middle."
Once he was on the road, Mr. Dole, wearing a white baseball jacket, sought to delineate his philosophical differences with Mr. Clinton by mentioning social issues that have not been part of his standard campaign fare. In town after town, Mr. Dole expressed his support for constitutional amendments to protect the flag, allow voluntary school prayer and balance the budget. And he spoke against Mr. Clinton's veto of a bill that would have banned some late-term abortions.
"I'm not certain how he connects to the people in this part of Michigan," Mr. Dole said of Mr. Clinton in Chelsea, where the midday crowd was packed with screaming children who had been let out of school to see him. "I hope he doesn't connect. He says he connects everywhere."
Until his last stop, here at dusk, Mr. Dole confined his criticisms to Mr. Clinton's public policies, although he did not pass up a chance to describe the President, who avoided the draft in the 1960's, as "AWOL," and made reference to his own "sacrifice"in World War II.
"I fought for my country before," the former Senator said repeatedly across the state where he recuperated from his war wounds. "I'm fighting for my country here today."
At a large rally here, Mr. Dole reiterated his allegations of what he said were ethical lapses by the Administration. "I will not sell access to the White House," he vowed.
His remarks included several unexplained references to "foreign aid" from Indonesia, an indirect allusion to contributions to Mr. Clinton from people with ties to an Indonesian business family.
But Mr. Dole was not as lacerating as he was last week. What seemed to be a change in tack came amid considerable discussion as to how effective his challenges to the President's ethics had been.
Representative Fred Upton, a Republican whose district in southwestern Michigan includes Kalamazoo, said in an interview that he had advised Mr. Dole that people here cared more about the economy.
"My reaction to the ethics is, people know it's out there," Mr. Upton said. "It's not a new revelation. He doesn't need to bring it up over and over, but people really do care about the deficit."
Generally, Mr. Dole stuck to his economic message. In Detroit, speaking of his tax cut plan, he said that he and his running mate, Jack Kemp, who was seated nearby, recognize that "to make it work in the right way we have to cut spending -- if we're going to reduce taxes, we need to balance the budget." But Mr. Dole also hinted at displeasure with his running mate.
Mr. Dole's campaign spokesman, Nelson Warfield, denied reports in the current issue of Newsweek magazine about tensions between the two candidates. But throughout the day, not all of Mr. Dole's references to his running mate were harmonious.
In Detroit, as Mr. Dole talked about his economic plan and its 15 percent tax cut, an approach that he once deplored, he pointed to their deep philosophical differences, saying: "People say, 'Oh, Bob Dole had this reputation as a deficit hawk.' And I still do. I'm a deficit hawk. Jack Kemp is a supply-sider."
In perhaps his most direct suggestion of something amiss, Mr. Dole said: "Jack gave me some good advice about a month ago. He said: 'Don't watch the scoreboard. If you watch the scoreboard, somebody's going to fumble.' It might be the quarterback or it might be the running back -- whatever role they're playing these days."
Mr. Kemp, a former quarterback in professional football, periodically calls himself the quarterback of the ticket, but then retreats and calls himself the running back.
Mr. Dole's comment suggested that Mr. Kemp thought he was running the ticket and could make the calls -- as he apparently did on Sunday when he said that legal immigrants should be able to make campaign contributions, disagreeing with part of a campaign finance proposal that was Mr. Dole's central theme of the day.
But Mr. Dole was adamant today that only citizens should be able to give money to candidates.
"If you're not a citizen of the United States, and you can't vote in America, you shouldn't be able to influence elections in America with your money," the former Senator said at a rally in Jackson and repeated throughout the day. "You can't vote, you can't contribute."
Mr. Kemp left Detroit for San Diego to begin a two-day sweep in California, part of a renewed effort by the Dole campaign there.
Mr. Kemp's campaign director, Wayne Berman, said that the shift in strategy had also forced a shift in spending and that the campaign had withdrawn television advertising in several states, including New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices Reject Challenge to Gay Policy

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
The Supreme Court today turned down the first constitutional challenge to reach it under the "don't ask, don't tell" policy that presumes that acknowledged homosexuals are unfit for military service.
The Court's action, taken without comment, left standing the decision of a Federal court that earlier this year refused to reverse the discharge of a highly rated Navy pilot, Lieut. Paul G. Thomasson. In March 1994, the day after the Navy put the new regulations into effect, Lieutenant Thomasson sent letters to four admirals for whom he had worked, announcing that "I am gay." Within weeks, the Navy convened a board of inquiry and eventually gave him an honorable discharge. 
 The Court's action today sets no precedent at the Supreme Court level, and does not foreclose the Justices from hearing another challenge to the policy. Other cases are working their way through Federal courts across the country, and lawyers for lesbian and gay members of the armed services said today that they expected the Supreme Court would confront the issue eventually.
In fact, cases now before the Federal District Court in New York and the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, present broader challenges to the "don't ask, don't tell" policy than did the Thomasson case. These other cases include challenges to the section of the law that makes subject to discharge a service member who "has engaged in, attempted to engage in, or solicited another to engage in a homosexual act or acts."
Mr. Thomasson, who lost his case by a 9-to-4 vote of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, limited his challenge to the adverse consequences that flow from a statement of homosexual identity.
The law makes a presumption that a member of the armed services who makes such a statement has also engaged in homosexual acts or has a "propensity" to engage in such acts, leaving the service member free to offer evidence to counter that presumption, as some have done successfully.
At his hearing, Lieutenant Thomasson refused to offer any evidence on the matter. "I will not go further in degrading myself by disproving a charge about sexual conduct that no one has made," he said.
In his Supreme Court appeal, Thomasson v. Perry, No. 96-1, he said, "At issue is whether the Government may restrict the freedom of an accomplished and dedicated military officer to utter a fundamental statement about who he is."
The former pilot argued that the Government's policy was based not on a determination that homosexuals cannot serve successfully -- since those who remain silent or are not named by others may remain in the military -- but rather on the "expected adverse reaction that some heterosexual listeners may have" to learning that a fellow member of the armed forces is homosexual.
Both the First Amendment and the constitutional guarantee of equal protection prevent the Government from basing a policy on "a desire to accommodate prejudice against homosexuals," he said.
In a brief urging the Justices not to hear an appeal of the Thomasson case, the Clinton Administration said the policy had a rational basis in the "considered professional judgment of military authorities" that openly gay people should not serve in the military. The brief quoted Congressional testimony from Colin L. Powell, the retired Army general who was Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, that "the cohesion and well-being of the force" would suffer if the ban was lifted.
Mr. Thomasson, now 33, served in the Navy for 10 years, receiving special assignments and superior performance ratings. The Navy conceded at his discharge hearing that his military record was "enviable," and his commanding officer supported his retention in the service.
He now manages a restaurant in the Washington area, one of his lawyers, Michelle Benecke of the Servicemembers Legal Defense Network, said today. "This is certainly not his life's ambition, and it is a waste of the taxpayers' dollars that trained him to be a computer whiz and a pilot," she said.
There were also these other developments at the Court today:
 
Vietnamese Visas
Citing a new Federal law limiting legal challenges to immigration decisions, the Court vacated a 1995 ruling by a Federal appellate court that the Government's refusal to process visas in Hong Kong for Vietnamese immigrants in refugee camps there violated Federal immigration law.
The Vietnamese involved in the case are not themselves refugees, but have relatives who are United States citizens or long-term legal residents and who have sponsored them for admission to the United States as immigrants.
For many years, the State Department had processed these visas in Hong Kong. But in December 1994 it changed the policy, requiring the Vietnamese to return home and apply for their documents there.
Arguing that this change would place a substantial hardship on people who had a legal right to enter the United States, a legal assistance organization sued and won a ruling from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit that the new policy violated a provision that barred discrimination against "the issuance of an immigrant visa because of the person's nationality."
A new Federal law, the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act, which took effect this month, gave the Secretary of State complete discretion to determine the procedures and locations for the processing of immigrant visas. Arguing that the new law removed the legal basis for the challenge in this case, the Clinton Administration asked the Court to vacate the appeals court's decision.
The case, U.S. Department of State v. Legal Assistance for Vietnamese Asylum Seekers, No. 95-1521, now goes back to the appellate court for an examination of how and whether the new law should apply.
William R. Stein, a lawyer for the Vietnamese, said today that he would argue that his clients should have the benefit of the policy that was in effect before the 1994 change that the appellate court had found to be illegal. He said the case affected fewer than 50 people, many of whom would face political and economic difficulties if they had to return to Vietnam for their immigration paperwork.
The Hong Kong government, which has been repatriating thousands of Vietnamese in an effort to clear the camps before China takes control of Hong Kong next summer, has told the United States that it will take no action against the group for the next three months to provide time for a legal resolution of their status.
 
Immunity Appeals
Accepting an appeal from four state liquor officials in Idaho, the Court agreed to decide whether state courts must make immediate appeals available to state officials seeking a form of immunity from civil lawsuits that accuse them of violating someone's constitutional rights.
Under the Supreme Court's precedents, Federal courts must provide accelerated appeals of immunity determinations. The type of immunity at issue, known as "qualified immunity," is a shield against liability for officials who can show that their actions were reasonable and did not violate clearly established constitutional rights.
In analyzing the issue for Federal courts, the Supreme Court has concluded that immediate appeals on the immunity question should be permitted so that officials need not go through an entire trial, only to find at the appellate level that their claim of immunity was valid all along.
However, many state courts consider an immunity determination at the trial level to be only a preliminary ruling, and not a final judgment that qualifies for a separate appeal.
A friend of the court brief from 32 states, filed on behalf of the Idaho officials, urged the Justices to apply the Federal rule to the states. "The immunity defense is critical to the effective operation of state government," the brief said, describing the defense as "a protection against attacks on reasonable official acts and decisions."
The case, Johnson v. Fankell, No. 96-292, began as a lawsuit against the officials by an employee whom they had dismissed. The trial court denied the qualified immunity defense; the Idaho Supreme Court, regarding that determination as only preliminary, refused to hear an appeal.

HEADLINE: Japanese Election's Outcome Strengthens Premier's Position

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Flush from his victory in a national election on Sunday, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto began piecing together a coalition today that will enable him to form a new government and rule Japan in the years ahead.
Mr. Hashimoto, looking dapper and more ebullient than usual, met this afternoon with leaders of the two parties that backed him in a governing coalition before the election. He formally asked both parties to help his Liberal Democratic Party form a new government. 
 "We hope we will be able to continue to assume responsibility in politics, together with our coalition partners," Mr. Hashimoto said at a news conference this afternoon.
The election marked a triumph for the Liberal Democrats, who single-handedly governed Japan for most of the postwar era, and it suggested that a three-year-old rebellion against politics as usual has collapsed, at least for now. Most analysts expect a continuation of the cautious policies that have marked the last couple of years.
While some experts say Japan is now at a crossroads on economic, political and security issues, they also fret that it may still be there in a couple of years, reluctant to choose any particular path.
Voters gave the Liberal Democratic Party 239 seats, up from 211, in the 500-member lower house of Parliament, the more important chamber. That is a plurality of seats and just a dozen short of a majority, so the Liberal Democrats may be able to attract enough defectors from other parties to take charge without relying on a coalition.
But at the same time, possible coalition partners apparently will have many fewer seats, so that the overall governing coalition may have a smaller majority and therefore be more fragile.
Ambassador Walter F. Mondale, no political neophyte himself, said today that he thought the election results would help strengthen some aspects of the relationship between America and Japan. While foreign policy played almost no role in the campaign, the Liberal Democrats have traditionally valued warm relations with the United States.
"In terms of strengthening the future of the security relationship, I think it's a good election," Mr. Mondale said. "It's very positive." He noted that there had been very little criticism of American military bases in Japan during the campaign.
He said that it was more difficult to gauge the effect on trade policy toward the United States, but that the Government might emerge more able to make decisions quickly and that such decisiveness would help relations with Washington.
The Government will presumably be more decisive if the Liberal Democrats can lure more people into their fold, and tonight the newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun reported that they were making considerable progress. Yomiuri said the Liberal Democrats had already won the cooperation of a group of independents and of a defecting faction from the main opposition party, the New Frontier.
As a result, the newspaper said, the Liberal Democrats can count on 260 votes, a clear majority, though not as big as they would like.
The Liberal Democrats need at least 265 seats to control the lower house and its committees comfortably, and they would like a broader coalition so as to control the upper house, which is much less powerful but still can block legislation.
Mr. Hashimoto appealed in particular to Takako Doi, one of the few senior women in Japanese politics, who is the head of the Social Democratic Party. The Social Democrats were a member of Mr. Hashimoto's coalition but were devastated in the election on Sunday, dropping from 30 seats to 15, leaving Miss Doi noncommittal about whether her party would join the new government.
A leading Liberal Democrat also sounded out the Democratic Party, which campaigned on a platform of streamlining government. But leaders of the Democratic Party were cool to the idea.
While the Liberal Democrats negotiate to form a government, the opposition parties may also need to get together to discuss cooperation.
The voting on Sunday was the first under a new electoral system, and it made clear the disadvantages of a fractured opposition. There were many races in which the seat was won by a Liberal Democrat over several other parties that split the opposition vote.
"There's a two-party logic in the new electoral system that wasn't there before," said Kent E. Calder, a Japan specialist at Princeton University who is visiting Tokyo. "But the problem is that a two-party system requires a cohesive opposition party, and the tendency in Japan has been for the opposition to be fragmented."
The election set a record for low voter turnout, 59.6 percent, as many voters have concluded that Japanese politics never really produce change and are irrelevant to the real world.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Integrated Health to Buy Coram in $280 Million Deal
Integrated Health Services, a home health care and specialized nursing home company, agreed to buy Coram Healthcare, a troubled, debt-laden home care company, for about $280 million in stock.
The deal, which includes the assumption of $375 million in Coram debt, would create one of the largest companies that provide care for patients whom hospitals no longer find profitable. [Page D2.]
 
Stronger Profits at Oil Companies
Several major oil companies reported higher earnings as surging prices for crude oil and natural gas more than offset rising refining costs. Oil company stocks, which have rallied recently, were flat.
Texaco said net earnings jumped nearly 50 percent, compared with the third quarter of 1995; Chevron reported a 29 percent increase, excluding special items, and Exxon said profits rose 4 percent. The results met or slightly exceeded Wall Street expectations. [Page D4.]
 
Stocks Seesaw, Ending Down
Stocks seesawed, ending slightly lower after a morning rally following I.B.M.'s earnings report gave way to heavy profit-taking. The Dow Jones industrial average ended down 3.36 points, at 6,090.87, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 6.07 points, to 1,236.41. [D14.]
 
Treasury prices fell slightly, weighed down by more than $30 billion of notes to be auctioned today and tomorrow. The yield on the 30-year bond edged up to 6.80 percent. [D21.]
 
Election Disappoints Japan Inc.
Corporate executives in Japan have been looking to the Government for two things -- strong leadership, and economic deregulation that would lay the groundwork for Japan Inc. to roar again. But last weekend's national elections will probably fall short of either of these outcomes. [D9.]

Few Issues Remain in G.M. Strike
Representatives of G.M. and the Canadian Automobile Workers union struggled with a few remaining issues in a 19-day strike, as G.M. temporarily laid off nearly 11,000 more American workers. [D4.]
 
Betting on the Internet's Future
The Frontier Corporation and Qwest Communications announced plans for a $2 billion national network to carry telephone conversations and data. [D4.]

United Airlines' Choice Questioned
United Airlines' surprising selection of Fallon McElligott and Young & Rubicam to share its $120 million account is raising questions about how well those two fiercely independent agencies can cooperate. But they voice optimism. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D13.]
 
RJR Reports Stronger Profits
RJR Nabisco Holdings announced that profits were increasing in its Nabisco food unit and its international tobacco business. But the company's results were marred by erosion in its domestic cigarette business. Net income in the third quarter rose 4 percent to $225 million, or 66 cents a share. Revenue increased 7 percent to $4.35 billion. [D2.]

Corporate Credit Ratings Improve
The rising stock market is having a very positive effect on American companies: corporate credit quality, as measured by changes in bond ratings, appears to be better than ever. So far this year, Moody's has upgraded the ratings of 221 companies, compared with 146 companies downgraded. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D14.]

USAir Earnings Rise 57%
USAir said earnings rose an unexpectedly strong 57 percent, to $67.7 million on robust demand for international flights. [D4.]

LENGTH: 1145 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE POLLS;
AGGRESSIVE TURN BY DOLE APPEARS TO BE BACKFIRING

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Bob Dole's sustained two-week assault on President Clinton's ethics appears to have backfired, with the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll finding that Mr. Dole did not improve his standing and even damaged his image among voters.
The poll, taken over four days at the height of Mr. Dole's offensive, shows that the Republican nominee has aggravated his reputation as the candidate more prone to attack, less concerned about addressing issues and more responsible for unfair commercials against his opponent. 
 Still more discouraging for Mr. Dole is that for the first time, he has lost a crucial advantage: the perception that he is more trustworthy. Forty-nine percent of Americans said Mr. Dole could be trusted to keep his word; in the last Times/ CBS News Poll, taken before the debate last week, the figure was 56 percent. Mr. Clinton's rating on trust is now 45 percent, statistically even with Mr. Dole's.
While Presidential races usually tighten in the final weeks, the new poll of 1,148 registered voters shows Mr. Clinton's lead now at 22 points, compared with 17 points last week.
Nelson Warfield, Mr. Dole's chief spokesman, said the findings were at odds with the campaign's numbers, which were not divulged. "The New York Times's numbers neither track our internal battleground polling nor match the sky-high enthusiasm we're seeing on the road," he said. "Maybe the Times poll oversampled Indonesian billionaires. But the bottom line is that the polls remain highly volatile; we're hardly in the final round and Bill Clinton still has a glass jaw. All we need to do is land the right punch."
The nominees nearly crossed paths in Detroit today, as Mr. Dole began a bus tour across Michigan. In addition to the strikes over ethics, he returned today to another campaign staple, his 15 percent across-the-board tax cut. [Page A22.]
Mr. Clinton, also in Detroit, ignored questions about ethics, preferring to have surrogates attack Mr. Dole's "political deathbed conversion" to campaign finance reform. [Page A23.]
The Dole campaign said today that it was dispatching a team of veteran strategists to California for the rest of the race, in the latest demonstration of its move in recent weeks to contest the state at the expense of other battlegrounds.
With the election two weeks from Tuesday, Mr. Dole's advisers had hoped the ethics offensive would help rescue the campaign. Instead, with the polls showing he is in even worse shape, many leading Republicans are increasingly turning their attention to saving their party from losing the House or Senate.
It is not clear from the poll precisely why Mr. Dole's attacks have not helped his campaign, but the survey indicates that neither the long-running Whitewater controversy nor the recent attack over the Clinton camp's fund-raising tactics has appreciably influenced voters.
Mr. Dole's assault on Mr. Clinton's ethics also may have reinforced a perception of the former Senate Republican leader as mean or overshadowed efforts by Mr. Dole to say what he would do as President.
The poll, conducted Oct. 17-20, found that among the probable electorate, 55 percent favored Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore; 33 percent backed Mr. Dole and running mate Jack Kemp, and 5 percent supported the Reform Party ticket headed by Ross Perot. The survey has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
A major disappointment for Mr. Dole in poll is that the issue that has been the foundation of his attacks recently -- the accusation that the Democratic Party accepted illegal campaign money from an Indonesian businessman -- has not roused the public. Only 42 percent said they had heard "some" or "a lot" about the issue. And among those who had heard or read anything about the controversy, 45 percent agreed that it was "politics as usual," and only 20 percent considered it a "serious issue."
In the second and final Presidential debate last week, Mr. Dole, while assailing Mr. Clinton's ethics, sought to avoid appearing too negative by also displaying his humor. But the weeks that Mr. Dole and his aides openly agonized over just how negative to appear may have fed into a lingering public notion that he is a slash-and-burn artist.
Mr. Clinton, meanwhile, stayed clear of such attacks on Mr. Dole during the debate, even though his campaign for months has run a far more negative televised onslaught against Mr. Dole.
Although both sides have been on the attack, voters do not see it that way. While Mr. Dole's favorability rating remains virtually unchanged at 28 percent compared with 49 percent for Mr. Clinton, on several other questions it appears that Mr. Dole has failed to gain ground -- or has lost support.
The most striking change for Mr. Dole is how many more people view him as on the attack. Sixty-three percent said he spent more time attacking Mr. Clinton than "explaining" what he would do as President, up from 50 percent in the last poll. Twenty-four percent said he was spending more time "explaining" than attacking, down from 40 percent a week ago. .
But Mr. Clinton is now viewed as even more above the fray. Seventy-three percent said he spent more time explaining, up from 68 percent in the last poll, and only 14 percent said he attacks more, down from 19 percent.
Only 43 percent said Mr. Dole was addressing "issues that matter to you," a decrease from 55 percent in the previous poll. In the meantime, 60 percent said that of Mr. Clinton, virtually unchanged from the last poll.
Voters see Mr. Dole as the more negative of the two candidates in his advertising. Of those who have seen commercials for the Presidential campaign, 45 percent said Dole campaign commercials had made unfair accusations against Mr. Clinton; 45 percent said they had not. By contrast, only 38 percent said Clinton campaign commercials had made unfair assertions about Mr. Dole; 58 percent said they had not.
Even as Mr. Dole's numbers are slipping, Mr. Clinton's standing related to ethics matters has changed little. Asked to compare the standards of conduct of people in the Clinton White House with past Administrations, 33 percent said it had lower standards and 58 percent said about the same. Those findings are virtually unchanged from last month.
Rahm Emanuel, a White House aide, said of the findings: "They made a huge mistake making Dole the hatchet man."
Only about half the voters said they watched or listened to the final Presidential debate. Of those who did, 63 percent said Mr. Clinton won, and 22 percent said Mr. Dole.
In another dynamic in the Presidential competition, voters see it as getting less, not more, lively in the closing weeks. Only 39 percent said it was "interesting," down from 44 percent last week. And 58 percent said the campaign was "dull," an increase from 50 percent in the last poll.

HEADLINE: Burden of Welfare Changes Falls to State Case Workers

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 18

 BODY:
When Susan A. Christie teaches state employees about the new Federal welfare law, she clucks her tongue and moves her hand to imitate the action of a metronome.
"You have got to hear that clock ticking," she said in a three-day workshop for 24 case managers. "You must have a sense of urgency. There's a five-year lifetime limit on welfare under the new Federal law, a two-year limit for most families in South Carolina. We can't let them languish. Time is a-wasting." 
 The new law is forcing state officials to change the culture of welfare agencies around the country, shifting the focus from the determination of eligibility and the issuance of checks to employment and jobs. Unless welfare case managers make this change, the new law has no chance of success.
For many case workers, as for many welfare recipients, the change will be traumatic. State employees must now collaborate with welfare recipients and help them find jobs, a goal that may be thwarted if case workers are too paternalistic.
Ms. Christie, the director of professional development at the American Public Welfare Association, an organization of state and local officials and welfare policy experts, hops around the country training employees in different states. She told her class here: "We've been treating clients like children. But children don't get jobs. Children get taken care of by their parents. We must treat clients as adults, not as children. To tell people the new rules is a very adult thing to do."
Social service agencies, once a backwater of state government, have become a testing ground for the biggest experiment in social welfare policy since the New Deal.
Striding round the classroom here with a purposeful, no-nonsense manner, Ms. Christie asked students: "You know who's going to get people jobs under welfare reform? I'm looking at you! You should feel some weight on your shoulders. The President isn't going to get somebody a job. Congress isn't going to get somebody a job. There are folks in this country who don't think states can pull this off. But I do. You can make this piece of legislation come alive."
In state plans filed recently with the Federal Government, Arizona, Kentucky, Nebraska, Oklahoma and Utah all affirmed the need for cultural change.
"Changing the culture of the welfare office to support work and self-sufficiency requires that the philosophy and purpose of the program change," the Utah plan said. "Financial assistance is seen as a support service to enable adults to participate in employment-related activities, not as an entitlement."
James T. Clark, director of South Carolina's Department of Social Services, said: "The biggest challenge for us is to change the culture, the bureaucracy, of welfare. Case workers here and throughout the country are disliked because we have treated clients in a demeaning, dispiriting way. We send clients a message that says, 'You're a loser, you can't make it, but that's all right because the Government will take care of you.' "
The number of people on welfare in South Carolina has declined 15 percent in the last two years, to 115,000. But in a sign of the new emphasis on results, Mr. Clark recently told social service directors in 8 of the state's 46 counties that their performance was unsatisfactory, in part because they had not placed enough welfare recipients in jobs.
Under the old law, Ms. Christie said, case workers could tell poor people, in effect: "I'm the boss. I have the money. I have something you want." And for many case managers, she says, "it's very painful to give up that kind of power."
In Washington, Federal officials are still debating the merits of the new welfare law. Some liberal Democrats still express outrage because they see the law as unjust or immoral, a betrayal of the nation's obligation to the poor. State officials, especially those on the front lines, do not have the luxury of criticizing the new policy. They are supposed to make it work, and their concerns are intensely practical.
Elizabeth E. Miller, a case manager for South Carolina's Department of Social Services in rural Barnwell, is trying to figure out how welfare recipients will get to jobs because "we have no public transportation, no taxis, no buses."
Lawerence Jackson, a case manager in Bishopville, S.C., said: "The paperwork keeps growing and growing. In addition to the old forms for determining eligibility, we now have a whole new set of paperwork for welfare reform -- employment plans, individual self-sufficiency plans, referrals to job clubs and so on."
Indeed, case managers still have all the old duties: interviewing applicants, verifying income and expenses, assessing eligibility, visiting welfare recipients in their homes.
In the past, welfare mothers were entitled to public assistance regardless of whether they worked, but under the new law, they must work within two years of receiving aid.
Charlene D. Garner, a case manager in Charleston, S.C., said, "A lot of people seem to think they're owed that money."
And Ms. Christie asked: "Why shouldn't they think that? We've called it an entitlement. But it's not an entitlement anymore."
Ms. Christie, a former welfare official in Utah and Colorado, tells case workers here that the behavior of welfare recipients is not right or wrong, good or bad, except as it helps or hinders them in getting jobs.
"Think of your clients as unemployed people, not as welfare mommas," she said. "Make work the pre-eminent theme of all your interactions with clients."
Case managers seem to have heard the message. They celebrate each success. "When a client gets a job, we all holler and scream, the whole office," Ms. Miller said.
Although the Federal law sets a lifetime limit of five years on welfare payments to any family, states may set stricter limits. And South Carolina has chosen to do so, with a two-year limit for most families.
Because welfare recipients "go over the cliff in two years," Ms. Christie said, state agencies can no longer be slow in providing the services needed to get jobs. A welfare recipient who needs counseling from a "job coach" or instruction in English as a second language cannot wait six months, she said.
John C. Walker, a welfare worker for 13 years, handles cases in Richland County, which includes Columbia. "A family that's been on welfare for two or three generations will have real trouble finding jobs," he said.
But Mr. Walker added: "The concept behind these reforms should have been in place 20 years ago. The old welfare system fostered dependency. It was dehumanizing. It taught people to be liars and cheats. We've been kidding ourselves to think that people can live in Charleston, S.C., on $159 a month." That amount, the maximum public assistance payment for a two-person family in South Carolina, is less than one-third of the Federal poverty level.
Through case studies and role-playing exercises, state employees learn how to coach welfare recipients who say, for example: "I feel like a real loser. Nobody wants to hire me because of my bad hand."
Ms. Christie cautions case managers not to blame their clients. "You don't get to say, 'I had bad clients, so I couldn't get them jobs,' " she said.
At the same time, she said, case managers must not be too paternalistic. "In the name of protecting our clients," she said, "we have marginalized them. Let's not be too quick to assume that they won't change their behavior in the new world order. If you have written off any of your clients, you can be sure they won't get work."
Under the Federal law, states may exempt 20 percent of welfare recipients from the five-year limit on public assistance. But Ms. Christie said: "You cannot know who should be exempt when they walk in the door. If you work with them for two years, you may find that they don't need to be exempt." Thus, she said, it may be "a self-fulfilling prophecy" to classify anyone as unemployable.
Ms. Christie told the case managers: "You will be a role model for your clients, showing them how to be self-sufficient and deal with change."
When case managers were just issuing checks, they could treat all clients the same, Ms. Christie said. "But under welfare reform," she said, "every client needs a customized employment plan. You get jobs for people as individuals, one by one, not as a group."
