HEADLINE: RIGHTIST IS VICTOR OVER SANDINISTAS IN NICARAGUA VOTE

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Decisively rejecting a bid by the former guerrilla fighters of the Sandinista National Liberation Front to return to power through the ballot box, Nicaraguan voters have instead turned further to the right, electing a candidate who advocates untrammeled free enterprise and a closer relationship with the United States.
Incomplete official returns and informal ballot counts compiled by foreign election observers gave Arnoldo Aleman, a former Mayor of Managua who ran under the banner of the Liberal Alliance, a lead of nearly 10 percentage points over his rival, former President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the Sandinista leader. Though Mr. Ortega has yet to concede defeat, Mr. Aleman was quick today to proclaim himself the winner. 
 "With full confidence, I can confirm our victory," Mr. Aleman, a 50-year-old lawyer and coffee grower, said this afternoon as his supporters gathered at party headquarters to celebrate their triumph over the revolutionaries who ruled this country for more than a decade. "We have consolidated democracy in Nicaragua."
At a news conference this afternoon, however, Mr. Ortega challenged that statement, saying that "at this moment we cannot recognize the results because we have found a series of anomalies" in the vote. With Sandinista supporters chanting "Fraud, fraud!" Mr. Ortega said the "serious irregularities" would require a complete recount, but he provided no evidence to support his complaint.
With just over half of the nearly two million ballots cast on Sunday counted by early tonight, Mr. Aleman had 48.5 percent of the vote, enough to spare him the runoff with Mr. Ortega he had hoped to avoid. In a demonstration of the importance Nicaraguans attach to the vote, more than 80 percent of all eligible voters took part in the election, in which 24 different parties offered candidates for President.
Mr. Aleman's apparent victory completes a stunning transformation of the political landscape in this country. Viewed less than a decade ago as a den of Communist subversion by the Reagan Administration, which sponsored a long and bloody guerrilla insurgency aimed at overthrowing the Sandinistas, Nicaragua will now be led by a man whose economic program would not be out of place in the Republican Party platform.
The outcome is a resounding defeat both for the Sandinistas as a party and for Mr. Ortega personally. Pushing aside the protests of many members of his party, Mr. Ortega had abandoned many planks of his party's leftist platform in an effort to win over voters suspicious of the Sandinistas' past.
"Like 1990, this vote was a referendum on the Sandinistas and their years in power," a Latin American diplomat here said today. "The results make it clear the people voted not so much for Aleman as they did against Ortega."
Mr. Ortega lost the presidency to Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in the 1990 election. She was prohibited from seeking re-election by constitutional reforms enacted during her administration that barred two consecutive terms for a President. She said from the start of her six-year term, however, that she did not intend to seek another.
The Sandinistas came to power in 1979 with broad popular support after overthrowing the 45-year dictatorship of the Somoza family. But they quickly plunged into confrontation with the United States and eventually alienated the middle class and the poor with confiscations of property, restrictions on constitutional rights and a policy of universal military conscription.
The results announced today gave Mr. Ortega, 50, virtually the same share of the vote he received as the losing incumbent in 1990, about 40 percent. Those Sandinistas who doubted his strategy are said by party insiders to be angry at the sacrifice of the party's commitment to socialism and revolution with nothing concrete to show in return.
"For Daniel, this defeat may prove to be even more costly than 1990," a former member of Mr. Ortega's Cabinet predicted. "The orthodox group within the front is going to be handing him the bill for this loss very soon."
Mr. Aleman, in contrast, campaigned against both the recent and more distant past, criticizing Mrs. Chamorro and the Sandinistas for the economic decline that has made this country the second-poorest in the Western Hemisphere, with an average per capita income of only $470 a year. He vowed to resolve outstanding land disputes and to take other steps to attract foreign investment and reactivate the economy.
Sharply critical of what he describes as Government inefficiency and corruption, Mr. Aleman advocates giving private investors, both foreign and Nicaraguan, a freer hand to generate jobs and trade. That puts him on the right of the Latin American political spectrum where the tradition of the state as the main engine of economic development remains strong.
In a television interview this afternoon, Mr. Aleman said he would pursue a policy of "national unity" and called on the Sandinista Front to be "a constructive force" and not "the destabilizing element it has been in the past." He described as "cordial" his relationship with the Nicaraguan Army and the police, which remain controlled by Sandinista officers.
"I invite Comandante Ortega to call on all to close ranks, to put down party flags and raise our blue-and-white national banner to help build Nicaragua," Mr. Aleman said shortly after visiting the graves of his parents and his wife. He also pledged "to work day and night to constantly combat poverty" and "to undertake the reconstruction of Nicaragua."
Mr. Ortega's initial response, however, was cautious and doubtful. In public declarations this afternoon, he urged Sandinista loyalists not to be discouraged by the preliminary results, and complained of "some anomalies and maneuvers designed to perturb the process" of casting and counting the vote.
In Sunday's balloting, many of the country's 9,000 polling places opened hours late, were burdened by incomplete voter lists, had to close early because they ran out of ballots, or simply turned away voters who had not received their registration cards. Foreign election observers were critical of the Supreme Electoral Council for those failings today, but attributed the shortcomings to ineptitude rather than fraud.
Former President Jimmy Carter, here as the leader of a bipartisan delegation of American observers, said today that Mr. Aleman's victory indicated that Nicaraguans "are looking for a fresh face and for what people think would be the best relationship with the United States." Among Nicaraguan voters, Mr. Carter added, there is "a presumption that Aleman will have a more receptive ear in Washington."
The Clinton Administration, which during the campaign expressed doubts about Mr. Ortega's commitment to democracy, was quick to pledge its support for Mr. Aleman. At a news conference here this morning, J. Brian Atwood, head of the American Government's official observer delegation here and administrator of the Agency for International Development, said he had already met with Mr. Aleman and expressed a desire to "work closely with him to spur economic development."
Mr. Aleman may also have been helped by a belated and indirect endorsement from Nicaragua's most important spiritual leader, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo. In a homily delivered at a Thursday evening Mass, the Roman Catholic prelate said that "good Christians should take certain prudent steps" before casting their vote, and then turned to a parable to illustrate his point.
In what was universally interpreted here as a reference to Mr. Ortega's change of image and program after losing power six years ago, the Cardinal warned of a snake that had been cast out into the cold and was rescued by a passerby. The man, explaining that circumstances had changed, put the snake to his chest to warm it and restore it to life. The snake bit him and killed him.
"That is why in these days we should reflect on what is most beneficial for the nation," the Cardinal concluded. Having done that, a near majority of voters evidently decided that Mr. Aleman was their only viable option.
Rosa Maria Martinez, a teacher and Aleman supporter, said: "We want a resounding change for Nicaragua -- economic, political and social -- and that's what he has offered us. Historically, Nicaragua has always been betrayed by its rulers, so we hope that with this one we will find peace and the change of direction that we need."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Agency to Hire Ross Roy Staffers

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
Fitch Inc., a corporate identity and design company, is opening an advertising agency by joining forces with employees who had worked at the Ross Roy Communications unit of the Omnicom Group in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. 
 William Faust, vice president at the Fitch office in Columbus, Ohio, said that Fitch would hire 20 to 25 former employees of Ross Roy who are leaving after that agency decided to focus on its Chrysler Corporation business by resigning all other accounts. Fitch will open an office in the Detroit area in January, Mr. Faust added, with three to five of those non-Chrysler accounts. Janet Muhlrman, 45, an executive vice president at Ross Roy, will become a vice president of Fitch and general manager of the new office.

HEADLINE: Economic Sobriety

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Alan Ehrenhalt ("The Voters Sober Up," Op-Ed, Oct. 20) notes that the public mood is one of sobriety rather than ebullient satisfaction. The economic glass is half-full, and it's mostly the top half. But that's still better than the quarter-full of four years ago. Anxieties remain, particularly among working Americans who haven't gone to college, the poor and middle-aged employees who have lost or are in danger of losing their jobs. 
 There is much left to do, as President Clinton admits. If "sobriety" means realism about the pace at which the prospects of these people can be reversed, and the obstacles lying in the way, I'm all in favor of it. But if, as Mr. Ehrenhalt suggests, "sobriety" means resignation that nothing can be done, I couldn't disagree more.
 
ROBERT B. REICH
Secretary of Labor
Washington, Oct. 21, 1996

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Concern About Overvaluation Leads to Selloff of the Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar dropped sharply late yesterday, hurt by a growing view that its recent surge was exaggerated and an unconfirmed report indicating that Washington wants to reduce the currency's value.
The pullback in the dollar, particularly from its 33-month highs against the Japanese yen, caught some traders off guard. The selling intensified as the dollar fell through some technically important short-term levels. 
 Also contributing to the dollar's weakness was a further rebound in the German mark after its selloff last week on fears of political instability in Russia and optimism about Europe's planned single currency.
"The dollar is kind of swooning here," said Elliott Dix, assistant vice president for foreign exchange at the Signet Banking Corporation in Richmond. "People are selling off yen and going into the mark. They're taking the view that the dollar's overvalued because it's come up so far, so fast."
Some traders said the catalyst might have been a report by Market News Service Inc., a financial news agency, quoting unidentified sources as saying the Administration might begin to "talk down" the dollar if there is no improvement in the trade deficit with Japan, a sensitive political issue.
A lower dollar would make American goods and services more affordable in Japan, and several prominent American exporters have expressed concern over the dollar's rise above 110 yen. The Administration's official position has been that it wants a strong dollar.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 112.20 yen from 112.77 yen on Monday, its highest level since January 1994. The dollar dropped to 1.5245 marks from 1.5347. The British pound rose to $1.5975 from $1.5920, extending its rally against the dollar to levels unseen since August 1995.
The dollar had spent much of the day little changed and was marginally higher against the yen, partly on new evidence of economic weakness in Japan that bolstered the prognosis of continued low Japanese interest rates. Low rates depress the value of yen-denominated assets.
The Japanese Government said its index of leading economic indicators for August fell below the important threshold of 50 for the first time in five months. A reading above 50 indicates expansion and a reading below 50 signals a contraction.

HEADLINE: U.N.'s Urban Agenda

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your series on "Housing's Hidden Crisis" in New York City (Oct. 6-11) and editorial (Oct. 14) draw a moving portrait of a problem to which no country, rich or poor, is immune. More than a billion people in the world live in abject poverty, a large proportion of whom are homeless. 
 A photograph with your Oct. 6 article shows an apartment in Brooklyn where nine Mauritanians live in three rooms. Hanging on their wall is a photograph of the 180 kings, presidents, prime ministers, foreign ministers and other delegates who gathered a year ago to commemorate the United Nations' 50th anniversary.
I do not know what the immigrants think when they look at it, but they have every right to hold the leaders responsible for commitments they made to foster economic growth, social development, environmental protection and social justice. The Secretary General, too, is answerable to the inhabitants of the world's inner cities.
The General Assembly is considering how to carry out a plan adopted at the second Conference on Human Settlements (Habitat II) in June in Istanbul. Member states working with representatives of institutions of civil society shared "best practices" aimed at improving the urban environment. The partnerships made Habitat II the most innovative event in the recent cycle of United Nations conferences. We must sustain this momentum.
 
BOUTROS BOUTROS-GHALI
Secretary General, United Nations
New York, Oct. 21, 1996

HEADLINE: Health Costs Pose Problems For Millions, A Study Finds

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

 BODY:
A new study by researchers at the Harvard School of Public Health says that 31 percent of Americans were without health insurance or had difficulty getting or paying for medical care at some time in the last year.
The study, reported yesterday in The Journal of the American Medical Association, involved telephone interviews with 3,993 Americans selected at random. 
 "Problems in getting needed medical care affect about 17 million uninsured adults and 17 million insured adults in America," the study said. "Problems in paying medical bills are reported by 13 million uninsured and 17 million insured Americans."
The researchers, led by Karen Donelan and Prof. Robert J. Blendon at Harvard, found that 45 percent of the uninsured and 11 percent of those with health insurance said they needed care and could not get it at some time in the year before the survey.
"Seventy percent of the uninsured said that their symptoms were either 'very serious' or 'somewhat serious' at the time they could not get care," the authors said.
The researchers did not recommend specific policies to solve the problems they described, nor did they speculate on possible effects of a new Federal law intended to help people retain insurance coverage when they lose or change jobs.
Other research suggests that the number of uninsured Americans has increased in recent years as employers cut back coverage for employees and hire more part-time workers without health benefits.
In September, the American Hospital Association said that employer-sponsored health insurance coverage had steadily eroded in recent years, even though many employers were able to control health costs through greater use of health maintenance organizations and other forms of managed care.
Jack A. Meyer, president of the Economic and Social Research Institute, a nonprofit research organization in Washington, documented the changes in a recent survey examining 600 businesses of various sizes. "In the name of cost control," Mr. Meyer said, "some employers are dropping coverage altogether."
Other businesses continue to provide health insurance, but are reducing or eliminating their contributions toward the coverage of employees' family members, he said.
Four of 10 employers said they would prefer to pay just 50 percent of the cost of their workers' health insurance premiums, or less, Mr. Meyer found. "If this trend continues," he said, "health coverage could be priced out of range for more and more working families, especially lower-paid workers."
The Harvard study, financed with a grant from the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, said, "It is a commonly held assumption that the uninsured can get free or charity care if they need it."
But the researchers found that "only 37 percent of the uninsured who reported problems in paying medical bills said that they had received medical care for free or for a reduced charge in the previous year."
Ms. Donelan, the principal author of the study, said: "The sickest people surveyed are most likely to have problems getting the medical care they need. The vast majority of uninsured adults in poor health had difficulty getting care. This contradicts the conventional wisdom that truly sick people can always get care when they need it."
Over all, the study said, 37 million adults reported that they were uninsured at the time of the survey in 1995 or at some time in the prior year. "Fifty-three percent of uninsured adults reported problems getting or paying for health care in the previous year, with 17 million adults saying these problems had serious consequences" for their physical or mental health, family relationships, employment or household finances, the authors reported.
"Cost and the lack of employer-provided coverage are the principal reasons for being uninsured," the study said, adding that very few people are uninsured by choice.
"Fewer than 1 in 10 of the uninsured said that they did not want or need health insurance coverage or just did not think about getting it," the report said.
About 70 percent of the uninsured said they had been employed some of the time they were without health insurance. Many said they had worked for employers who provided coverage to at least some employees.

HEADLINE: Journal;
Free Rupert Murdoch!

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
How do New Yorkers pick a dog in this fight?
In one corner is Rupert Murdoch, ranked this week by Entertainment Weekly as the most powerful man in the media industry, whining in court that a big, bad monopoly, Time Warner, is out to destroy his little, helpless Fox network by refusing to offer its new 24-hour news channel to Time Warner's New York cable subscribers. 
 Squaring off against him is CNN's Ted Turner, newly absorbed by merger into Time Warner, who has likened Mr. Murdoch to "the late Fuhrer" and threatened to "squish" him "like a bug." In a sworn deposition last Friday, Mr. Turner went still further, reiterating his Nazi analogies and accusing Mr. Murdoch of buying politicians from Margaret Thatcher to Newt Gingrich to Rudolph Giuliani.
Mayor Giuliani entered the picture by intruding in the dispute. He hoped to force Mr. Murdoch's news network onto Time Warner cable, ostensibly to save New York jobs, by trying to air it on a municipal channel. A Federal judge has at least temporarily scuttled this scheme, but not soon enough to stop a battle of the wives from breaking out. On Monday Jane Fonda, stopping by Barnes & Noble for a book signing, suggested that the Mayor was Fox's puppet because Mr. Murdoch is a G.O.P. campaign contributor and employs Mrs. Giuliani, Donna Hanover, at New York's Fox channel.
Already this squabble is surpassing any programming aired by either Time Warner or Fox. The New York Post, Mr. Murdoch's local print organ, has upped the ante by dropping CNN listings briefly from its TV grid and asking its readers to ponder whether "Terrible Ted" is either "veering dangerously toward insanity" or has merely "come off the medication he takes to fight his manic depression." In a display of reportorial enterprise, The Post also has taken to canvassing Jewish leaders who have "expressed outrage" over Mr. Turner's compulsive allusions to the late Fuhrer. It's only a matter of time, we can hope, before CNN rounds up its own Jewish leaders to condemn Mr. Murdoch for buying up rights to the "Hitler diaries" in the 1980's and then dismissing the subsequent revelation of their fraudulence with the memorable disclaimer, "After all, we are in the entertainment business."
But even as we pray for this delicious battle of titans to end up on Court TV -- which is itself co-owned by none other than Time Warner -- the question remains: Whom do we root for? The answer: No one.
Mr. Murdoch, who is being investigated in Britain for alleged anti-competitive practices by his satellite service and is the only mogul to have wrangled Federal permission to own both a TV station and newspaper in New York, is hardly the man to decry the monopolistic strategies of Time Warner or scream that his First Amendment rights are being violated. Nor can he argue that his news operation has been barred because of its conservative bent; Time Warner already carries the country's most right-wing TV news operation, Pat Robertson's.
As for Mr. Giuliani and his cronies in the Murdoch cause, Alfonse D'Amato and George Pataki, they would be preposterously out of line even if they were not Murdoch-backed politicians. Since when do we live in a country where government officials can dictate what news (or anything else) appears on TV?
As for Time Warner, I wish it would air several free channels that are M.I.A. in New York, including Fox's 24-hour news; Mr. Murdoch is indeed in the entertainment business, and it would be fun to spend 24 hours a day watching breaking Murdoch "news," like the fake Princess Di sex tapes trumpeted to the world as authentic by his London tabloid, The Sun. Though Time Warner pleads it doesn't have enough slots on its dial, why can't it just drop one of its countless, often redundant and always exorbitant pay or pay-per-view channels?
But that's not going to happen. In our new merger-consolidated media universe, where four equally ruthless and arrogant quasi-monopolies (Disney/ABC and Westinghouse/ CBS being the other two) now decree what all Americans watch and often read, Mr. Murdoch and Time Warner will sooner or later strike a deal as best suits their own economic interests -- no matter what anyone else, judges and politicians included, has to say about it. Whoever wins, it will still be the public that is squished like a bug.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: G.M., Union Set Accord In Canada

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation and the Canadian Automobile Workers union tentatively agreed today on a new three-year labor contract, settling a 20-day strike that closed assembly plants and parts factories across Ontario and Quebec and, in a ripple effect, idled nearly 20,000 workers in the United States and Mexico.
The deal represents a compromise for each side, with the union allowing G.M. to sell two auto parts factories while demanding stiff payments to workers in exchange. Auto analysts said the deal would do fairly little to reduce the auto maker's steep labor costs, but that G.M. had sent a message to both the Canadian union and the United Automobile Workers union in Detroit that it would not give in easily. 
 "It sounds like they negotiated the best deal they could realistically hope for" at G.M., said Nicholas Lobaccaro, an auto analyst at Bear Stearns. "A lot of the things they were trying to negotiate were relatively unrealistic."
The Canadian union scheduled a ratification vote on Wednesday, and union officials predicted easy approval by the 26,000 striking G.M. workers. Basil E. Hargrove, the Canadian union's president, said that workers would begin returning to factories as soon as Wednesday evening, which should make it possible for G.M.'s factories in the United States to reopen by this weekend.
The deal here clears the way for G.M. to seek a separate labor contract with the U.A.W. in Detroit. G.M. and the U.A.W. resolved many of their less difficult issues before the Canadian strike began on Oct. 2, and a person close to the union said today that a deal might be reached by the end of this week.
The two sides are still discussing how many blue-collar jobs G.M. will keep in the United States over the next three years. The Ford Motor Company has already committed itself to keep employment at 95 percent of current levels or higher, with the proviso that lower levels will be allowed if the economy goes into a recession or if Ford discovers ways to make its factories more efficient. In exchange, the U.A.W. has agreed to let Ford pay permanently lower wages in any new auto parts businesses that it enters over the next several years.
The U.A.W. wants G.M. to agree to the same terms, although less productive factories may be omitted from the minimum employment requirements. The two sides recessed their talks in Detroit shortly before 5 P.M. today but plan to resume negotiations on Wednesday morning.
Even if G.M. settles soon with the U.A.W., its labor problems may not be over. It faces factory-level negotiations with militant local union leaders at several important assembly plants, including its huge mini-van factory in Doraville, Ga.
Today's deal allows G.M. to go ahead later this year with the sale of a car seat factory in Windsor, Ontario, and a bumpers and seat parts factory in Oshawa, Ontario. The auto maker guaranteed that for nine years the buyer would keep the worker pensions and health care benefits at the same levels G.M. maintained, and would maintain wages at G.M. levels for three years.
G.M. also agreed to offer these workers $42,500 to retire, or up to $80,000 to leave the company if they were not eligible for retirement. And the company promised an immediate bonus of $350 for each worker at all of its factories. All of these payments are in Canadian dollars. At the close of trading today, a Canadian dollar was worth 74 cents in American currency.
Following the example of Chrysler, which reached a contract with the Canadian union on Sept. 17, G.M. also promised 2 percent annual wage increases plus annual raises that cover most of the annual increases in consumer price inflation.
G.M. also agreed to stop requiring workers to work more than eight hours a day at assembly plants in Oshawa that make the Chevrolet Lumina and Buick Regal mid-size sedans. Dean W. Munger, the top labor negotiator for G.M. Canada, had said in an interview on Oct. 4 that it would be difficult to run assembly plants by asking for volunteers to put in overtime, but G.M. agreed to do this.
Ford and Chrysler already rely on voluntary overtime. And all three unionized auto makers are able to require workers to put in six eight-hour days each week here.
G.M. also agreed today to pay same-sex partner benefits for health care and bereavement, something that Chrysler had successfully resisted last month. But G.M. did manage to turn down union demands that the company freeze job descriptions and assembly line speeds. And while G.M. agreed to some limits on its ability to buy more parts from outside vendors, numerous exceptions were allowed, such as when a vendor offers new technology, Mr. Munger said.
While G.M. has refused to identify the buyer of the two auto parts factories because of a confidentiality pact, union officials have said the buyer is Joseph, Littlejohn
& Levy, a New York investment firm, which declined to comment. G.M. executives have said that a new owner will be able to make the factories more profitable by selling parts to rival auto makers that are reluctant to buy from G.M.
Local union officials were convinced that today's labor contract would be approved during the ratification vote on Wednesday.
"Oh yeah, we're not giving anything up, we're gaining," said Paul Goggan, an official at the militant union local in Oshawa. Local union officials unanimously approved the deal today, the first time in the Canadian union's 11-year history that the often fractious G.M. division had approved a contract with the auto maker unanimously.
Analysts put the cost of the current strike at $200 million to $400 million in foregone after-tax profits for G.M. By comparison, a 17-day strike last March at two G.M. brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, produced an after-tax loss of $900 million. Mr. Hargrove warned of a strike here last July, and G.M. responded by stockpiling parts so that this time, the temporary layoffs and foregone profits accumulated less quickly.
G.M. temporarily laid off an additional 1,560 workers today because of the Canadian strike, most of them in Mexico. The strike has now idled a total of 19,931 workers in the United States and Mexico, the company said.

HEADLINE: The Local Flavor Only, Please;
Westchester Hamlet Fears an Invasion by Starbucks

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

DATELINE: KATONAH, N.Y.

 BODY:
While other communities may gird themselves against the arrival of commercial behemoths like Home Depot or Price Club, here the enemy is relatively small, seemingly innocuous and even coveted in many corners of suburbia.
The adversary in Katonah is Starbucks, the java giant that acts like the Gap, spawning new stores faster than customers can request "a grande skim half-regular half-decaf cappuccino." 
 The Seattle-based coffee company, among the unlikeliest of establishments to evoke cries of "not in my backyard," has people fulminating over its plans to put a store in this pocket of the Westchester County town of Bedford, a leafy, prosperous community about 35 miles north of New York City.
An editorial in a weekly newspaper, The Record-Review, said Starbucks threatened the character of Katonah, a century-old planned community created for people who were transplanted to make room for the New York City reservoir system.
Residents have urged one another to express their displeasure to the Bedford Zoning Board of Appeals, which must grant Starbucks a variance before it can open here. The Bedford Planning Board turned down the company in early October because Starbucks does not fall neatly into any of Katonah's food-use categories. It was classified as a deli, but delis in Katonah do not have tables and chairs and Starbucks does. A vote on the variance is scheduled to take place in November.
At a meeting of the Katonah Chamber of Commerce in mid-October, Starbucks, which plans to move into a building under construction on Katonah Avenue, was the topic of conversation. "There were 40 people there, bankers and lawyers, and they all said the most important thing about this town are its family-owned businesses and diversity of stores," said Jonathan F. P. Rose, a developer who lives in nearby North Salem and works in Katonah.
"Starbucks meets tourists' desires over real needs," charged Mr. Rose, who also works as a consultant helping communities retain their character. "When that happens, you lose the essence of the place."
To understand Katonah's opposition to Starbucks, one must understand this hamlet of less than 5,000, which sees itself as special.
Katonah Avenue, the main artery in the commercial district, looks like Main Street, U.S.A., with a soupcon of artsy sophistication. There are no golden arches, no Gap stores, no Blockbuster's video emporiums. Mostly there are mom-and-pop operations -- delis, grocery stores, locally owned galleries, antiques shops and boutiques. The closest thing to chain stores are branches of NatWest, First Fidelity and the Bank of New York, and a Mobil station.
Residents -- a mix of commuters and writers, artists and photographers -- say they like the place just the way it is -- devoid of fast-food restaurants, which are forbidden, and devoid of national retailers, thanks, they say, to landlords who will not rent to them.
To hear residents tell it, Starbucks may be Pandora's box, opening the hamlet to commercial homogenization.
"The pharmacist here knows if the cough I had six months ago hasn't gotten better," said Lloyd Truffleman, a marketing and advertising executive. "If you let in Starbucks, who knows, you'll look around and the drugstore will be a CVS."
Starbucks was not stunned by Katonah's stance. It ran into similar resistance in a small Minneapolis community and was forced to reconsider plans to open in two San Francisco East Bay communities. But opposition nationwide has been negligible considering the company's growth. In 1991, Starbucks had 116 stores; today it has 970. The company plans for 2,000 by the year 2000.
"The demand for our coffee is so great that sometimes we open stores right across the street from one another," said Jeanne McKay, a company spokeswoman.
To Katonah residents, that is part of the problem. There's a Starbucks in Mount Kisco, a less prosperous village about five miles away. That's close enough, Nancy Zink, editor of The Record-Review, said.
"You don't need a Starbucks on every corner," agreed Teddy Wainwright, who operates the Baker's Cafe on Katonah Avenue. "We have merchants who give people specialized service, and we have a vibrant economy as a result. That's not true of every town."
Some merchants fear that the arrival of Starbucks and inevitably other chains would drive up real estate prices, resulting in the displacement of small businesses. "The chains would be the only ones able to pay the rent," said Laura Marks, owner of Fine Lines, a stationery store.
But Ms. McKay argued that Starbucks would most likely jolt the business community, including those shops that sell coffee, "by increasing awareness" of specialty coffees. "In Seattle, other coffee shops have moved right next door to us," she said.
Deborah Marsten, owner of a natural cosmetics store on Katonah Avenue, agreed that her business would probably pick up with people drawn to the area by Starbucks. "But it would ruin the quaintness of Katonah," she added.
Interestingly, when Starbucks was turned down by the Planning Board, the ruination of Katonah never came up. The issues in descending order of importance were how to classify Starbucks, water consumption and sewage, said Jeffrey Osterman, the town's director of planning.
Ms. Zink and others said they were first told by the Helmes Group, a local architectural and engineering firm, that the coffee company would not be a tenant of a 5,000-square-foot red brick building that the group is building. "There were rumors for months," Mr. Truffleman said. "I don't mean to sound like Bob Dole, but this is a character issue."
But they were dismayed when the matter came before the planning board and they learned that Starbucks was being considered as a tenant. Kevin Helmes, an associate of the Helmes Group, said the company planned to rent 1,500 square feet to Starbucks and the remaining space to two retailers, though he said that no contracts had been signed. Community opposition was not unanimous, he stressed.
"There are some that's for it and some that's against it," he said. "Some think it would bring in business."
Even if Starbucks wins a variance, its overall success here is not guaranteed, residents say. Katonah has a history of fidelity to locally owned stores. A year ago, when Gannett Suburban Newspapers placed vending boxes containing The Reporter-Dispatch outside delis that sold the paper, merchants and residents boycotted the newspaper until the boxes were moved away from the stores.
Moreover, Katonah has a history of exclusionary commercial laws.
In 1897, when New York City began building its reservoirs, the village of Whitlock Station was moved a mile south and renamed Katonah, according to Katharine Barrett Kelly, 88, a Katonah native and Bedford's historian. "People moved their houses piece by piece, although some were moved intact by horse and wagon."
The villagers designated Katonah Avenue the downtown business district. They carefully laid out spots for the bakery, drugstore, hardware store, general store, reading room (now the Katonah library) and churches. Many of these businesses are still in the same buildings.
There were prohibitions against slaughterhouses and the manufacturing of gun powder, soap, candles, starch, glue, ink and turpentine. They banned breweries and distilleries and establishments that tanned skins, Ms. Zink wrote in her editorial.
All true, the Bedford historian confirmed. But she said that she is not worried about Starbucks and that she does not think that a coffee shop would destroy Katonah's character. She points to the hamlet's recent history.
Twenty-five, 30 years ago, there was both an A.& P. and a Grand Union on Katonah Avenue, she said.
Still, she added that she would not patronize Starbucks if it were to come to town. "I have my two cups in the morning at home," she said, "and that's it."

HEADLINE: Nicaragua's New President

 BODY:
Nicaragua has suffered through more than its share of abrupt ideological shifts in recent years. In a 1979 revolution it lurched from the right-wing dictatorial dynasty of the Somozas to the leftist Sandinista regime under Daniel Ortega. Then in 1990 the Sandinistas were displaced in the country's first democratic election by Violeta Chamorro, who wore white and made reconciliation her theme. In the latest turn, a man with authoritarian tendencies, Arnoldo Aleman, was elected President on Sunday.
Throughout it all, Nicaragua has been constant in its poverty. It is the second-poorest country in the Americas, ahead of only Haiti. Mr. Aleman hopes to attract jobs and investment through an unfettered free market. 
 Despite efforts during the campaign by Mr. Ortega, who was Mr. Aleman's chief rival for the office, to distance himself from past Sandinista policies, Mr. Aleman's television ads featuring shortages and censorship under the Sandinistas were effective. He was helped by the blessing of Nicaragua's Roman Catholic Cardinal, Miguel Obando y Bravo. Perhaps most important, Mr. Aleman convinced Nicaraguans that his friendliness with the United States and ties to wealthy Cubans and Nicaraguans in Miami would help attract foreign investment.
Mr. Aleman was an energetic manager and salesman as Mayor of Managua from 1990 to 1995. But his style bore worrisome touches of the caudillos who controlled the country for centuries. He would quiet his adversaries by offering them city jobs. Allegations of corruption were constant, but nothing was proved.
He has further polarized an exhausted country where, in rural areas, former Sandinistas and contras are still shooting at each other. Mrs. Chamorro, who could not succeed herself, gave the country a needed break from extremism. Her Government crafted pacts on the most divisive issues, including property the Sandinistas appropriated for themselves and for thousands of the poor before leaving office. She agreed to let all these people keep their property while compensating the old owners. Mr. Aleman has criticized her conciliatory policies and said he wants to undo these agreements.
Mr. Aleman, a coffee grower, counts as his advisers mainly the wealthy landowners and businessmen of the traditional ruling class. The Liberal Party he controls once belonged to the Somozas. But circumstances may force him to reach out to Sandinista supporters. He will probably not command a majority in the Legislative Assembly, and the Sandinistas retain the power to mobilize large demonstrations and protests. It would be useful for Mr. Aleman to temper his free-market, small-government orthodoxy with the concerns of the poor. He should remember that while foreign investment flourished under the Somozas, the vast majority of Nicaraguans did not.
For models, Mr. Aleman can look to the modernizing rightists in his neighborhood. Former President Alfredo Cristiani in El Salvador and President Alvaro Arzu in Guatemala have made peace with guerrillas and worked to reduce the domination of the rural landowners. Mr. Aleman, too, has the chance to make reforms that less conservative leaders might find impossible. To do so, he will have to follow his own advice to Mr. Ortega not to return Nicaragua to the bad old days.

HEADLINE: Adelphi Panel Estimates Severance Payout

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Raising new questions about the compensation Adelphi University has given its president, the head of a state panel said yesterday that the president would get $2.7 million in severance, sabbatical and pension payments if he serves out his contract to the year 2001.
The calculation by J. Edward Meyer, chairman of a New York State Board of Regents panel reviewing Adelphi's management, came at a hearing in Manhattan. The panel is considering a petition from campus critics seeking the removal of Adelphi's trustees for failing to carry out their duties. 
 A central issue has been the compensation for Adelphi's president, Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos, which is among the highest of any university president in the nation. Critics say his compensation is excessive, since Adelphi is a small commuter school and its enrollment has dropped more than a third since he took over in 1985.
Besides his retirement benefits, Dr. Diamandopoulos also stands to make a $750,000 profit on a Manhattan condominium that Adelphi bought for his use, Mr. Meyer said. Adelphi spent $1.35 million in 1993 to buy, renovate and furnish the condominium, which is his to use in addition to the president's residence on the Adelphi campus in Garden City, L.I. The trustees later gave Dr. Diamandopoulos the right to buy the condominium for $905,000. Mr. Meyer projected its future value based on a 5 percent annual appreciation.
Mr. Meyer estimated that the retirement payments and condominium profits would total about $3.5 million. Abraham Krasnoff, an Adelphi trustee whom Mr. Meyer was questioning on the witness stand, did not dispute the figures.
Mr. Meyer asked Mr. Krasnoff, who serves on the board's executive compensation committee, whether the benefits "seem somewhat excessive."
Mr. Krasnoff said, "I don't think that's so bad."
As a former trustee at Long Island University, Mr. Krasnoff recalled that Chancellor Albert Bush-Brown received nearly $1 million in severance when he was forced out in 1985. Allowing for inflation, he said Adelphi's figure was maybe $1 million out of line.
It was while recruiting a new chief for L.I.U. that Mr. Krasnoff said he first met Dr. Diamandopoulos, who was his first choice for that job.
After the hearing, a lawyer for the trustees' critics said that Mr. Meyer underestimated Dr. Diamandopoulos's retirement benefits by omitting the interest and investment yield on his severance fund. The lawyer, Amy Gladstein, represents the Committee to Save Adelphi, a coalition of professors, former trustees, former administrators, alumni, students and parents. She also disputed Mr. Krasnoff's comparisons with Long Island University, which is much larger and has several campuses.
The hearings are now in recess until November, when five more days are scheduled. After the testimony ends, the lawyers for the university and the critics will file final briefs and the panel will make a recommendation to the Regents.
Mr. Krasnoff, whose testimony began on Monday, was called by Adelphi's lawyers to rebut accusations that the trustees, most of them recruited by Dr. Diamandopoulos, have been a rubber stamp.
"This is from my view the most involved board of any organization I've been involved in," said Mr. Krasnoff, who retired four years ago as chairman and president of the Pall Corporation, a $1 billion company that makes high-technology filters for fluids. He has served on the boards of many nonprofit institutions, including the business schools at Hofstra and New York universities.
Mr. Krasnoff confirmed earlier testimony that Adelphi's trustees never voted on the president's compensation, even though that is required by state law and the board's bylaws. Only the compensation committee knew the president's compensation, including the option to buy the condominium at a discount.
But Mr. Krasnoff said "that's typical" of other boards he has served on. In 40 years of serving on the board at North Shore University Hospital, he said, he never knew the chief executive's salary.
But he conceded "we were derelict" in not following proper procedure, and added, "It's going to be necessary to change an awful lot of habits at this university."
Mr. Krasnoff said he makes little distinction between corporate and nonprofit compensation. He said Dr. Diamandopoulos should be rewarded for a 'turnaround" in Adelphi's finances, generating budget surpluses, and for revising its curriculum.
But Adelphi "is suffering mightily under this onslaught" of controversy, he said. Asked why most of the deans' posts at the campus are vacant, he said: "It would be impossible to get a good dean under these circumstances. It would be madness to go out and recruit."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Weak Dollar And Auctions Take a Toll

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities ended substantially lower yesterday as concern over fresh supply weighed on the market for a second consecutive session.
The Treasury's sale of $18.28 billion in two-year notes produced encouraging results, but dealers said there was little follow-through buying after the auction. 
 Weakness in the dollar also took its toll on Treasury securities, which are expected to remain vulnerable until today's auction of five-year notes is out of the way.
"The market traded briefly better after the auction, but when there was no follow-through it came down once again," James Kenney, head of government trading at Prudential Securities, said. "It appears there was strong bidding for the issue but then people tried to sell everything else around it."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 23/32, to 98 19/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.85 percent from 6.80 percent on Monday. The new 5.875 percent two-year note was yielding 5.91 percent at the close.
The Treasury's two-year note sale produced a high yield of 5.93 percent, and 56 percent of bids were awarded at the high rate.
This was down from the 6.08 percent registered at the last auction of two-year notes on Sept. 25.
A total of $47.89 billion of bids was received, $1.01 billion of which were noncompetitive bids. The bid-to-cover ratio, a measure of auction demand, came in at a firm 2.62.
After the auction results were released, Treasuries extended early losses, ultimately sinking to session lows as the dollar deteriorated in late trading.
"A lot of what has been propelling the markets is the sense that the dollar is getting stronger," David Horner, senior financial strategist at Merrill Lynch, said.
When the dollar showed signs of faltering, he added, the bond and stock markets followed suit.
The dollar fell against the Japanese yen and German mark yesterday, hurt in part by a growing view that its recent run-up was exaggerated. The dollar was also hurt by a report by Market News Service Inc., a financial news agency, quoting unidentified sources as saying the Clinton Administration might begin to "talk down" the dollar if there is no improvement in the trade deficit with Japan.
A weaker dollar makes American assets like Treasury securities less attractive to foreign investors.
Ample gains in weekly retail sales reports also weighed down Treasury prices, analysts said. Both the Mitsubishi Bank-Schroder Wertheim and LJR Research Service reports showed sizable gains for the period ended Saturday, suggesting that consumers might be bouncing back from an extremely weak third quarter.
Economists predicted further price erosion ahead as dealers set up for the Treasury's sale of $12.5 billion in five-year notes today. But once this supply is digested, they said, the market should perk up again.
"Once we chip through the five-year and get the supply out of the way we have a chance to do marginally better into the end of the week," Lee Youngdahl, money market economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, said.
In the municipals market, a deluge of new offerings totaling about $2.2 billion drew mixed results.
Among the large primary offerings, California sold $500 million of general obligation bonds. The bonds were priced to yield from 4.35 percent in 2000 to 5.75 percent in 2026.

HEADLINE: It's the Season of Ghosts, Goblins and Green

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: NAVASOTA, Tex., Oct. 21

 BODY:
There is plenty of candy. There are pumpkins painted or plain, real or pre-carved plastic. There are costume kits -- cats and bunnies, Bill Clinton and Bob Dole.
But at Brookshire Brothers, an ordinary supermarket in this small Texas town, there is much more for shoppers: orange and black streamers, Halloween twinkling lights, electric Halloween Candoliers, Cryptkeeper battery-operated doorbells, Pumpkin Patch Kid Carving Tools (also known as knives) and Oreo cookies with special orange-colored filling. 
 Across the store, on Aisle 12, there are the greeting cards: "For baby's first Halloween." "For a special godchild on Halloween." "Just thinking of you . . . and wishing you a wonderful Halloween."
"You've really got to watch yourself," said Susan Allen, a shopper trying to dissuade her 11-year-old son from spending $50 to rent a costume at a mall in nearby College Station. "If you don't, there might not be any money left over for Christmas."
Once upon a time, Halloween was a one-day event for children: trick-or-treat, and that was that. These days, however, it is more like a monthlong extravaganza, celebrated by children and adults alike and eagerly welcomed by merchandisers as one of the high points of their year.
In fact, according to a recent study by the National Retail Federation, Halloween has now officially shot past Mother's Day and Easter to generate more commercial revenue than any other day on the calendar except Christmas.
Just as it has grown in economic significance, the day has become a cultural touchstone, acclaimed as a kind of national Mardi Gras in some quarters but vilified in others.
Some church leaders, citing what they see as the day's glorification of pagan rites or of Satanism, have called for a boycott of Halloween.
Several school districts across the country have placed restrictions on costumes for classroom parties: no cowboys with guns (evokes violence), no hobos (offensive to the homeless) or no monsters (just too plain scary).
Still, as a mercantile event, Halloween has an undeniably huge impact. The retail federation, a trade group, conservatively estimates that Americans spend at least $2.5 billion on Halloween, a figure that does not include the value of promotional tie-ins, like Toyota's current Spooktacular sales event or the promise of "Goosebumps" plastic characters to consumers of Kid's Meals at Taco Bell.
On the pages of "Selling Halloween," an annual trade publication published in February, merchandisers talk about consumers who will seemingly spend any amount on Halloween house decorating "as long as it's creative and looks as good as the house next door." Or they breathe a sigh of relief that no one children's costume seems likely to dominate 1996 the way Power Rangers' costumes did so infamously in 1994, wreaking havoc for other creations in the costume market.
Scholars and salespeople all seem to have their own theories as to why the day -- not even, of course, a holiday by the conventional definition -- has become such a big deal. Some theorize that as Americans' fears of crime have run rampant, the day has increasingly offered a clever way for both young and old to confront the stress.
"It's the whole role reversal of power," said Arthur Goldiner, founder of Scarecrow Inc., a California company that advertises "custom fangs and movie-quality toothcaps." "Children are let out on the street to wander around after dark, soliciting adults and making threats."
Perhaps, but that does not necessarily explain why, in many ways, adults seem to have co-opted Halloween as their own, throwing theme parties without a child in sight.
Eighty percent of all Halloween costume rentals and 65 percent of sales are for adults, says the National Costumers Association, a trade group. Cleopatra is the number one costume for women -- "always has been" -- while "the Dracula thing" remains the biggest seller for men, a spokesman said.
Many experts note that in past generations, Americans' experience with death was different than it is today. Elderly parents were more likely to die in the bedroom next door than at the hospital, and infant mortality rates were higher, so death was perhaps less likely to be the object of cavalier or even humorous treatment in a national day of celebration. But death remains something that people struggle to come to terms with.
"We're all going to die sometime," said Jack Santino, author of a book on Halloween and another on the role of holidays in American culture, who argues that Halloween constitutes a form of "deep play" in which people of all ages are given free rein to think about things like death, pain and evil.
"At Halloween, some of our deepest fears are brought out from under the bed and confronted, but kind of in a playful way," added Dr. Santino, a professor of popular culture at Bowling Green State University in Ohio. "The fact that people enjoy it doesn't mean it's not an important thing."
Another line of reasoning is that Halloween, despite its religious origins, is now viewed as a kind of secular festival that families with spouses of different religious origins can celebrate without some of the tensions that can arise during, say, the Christmas-Hanukkah-Kwanzaa season.
Still, perhaps the simplest and most common explanation for the Halloween bonanza is that it stems from the tendency of the baby-boom generation to indulge their children, themselves or both. Robert Bly, the best-selling author, argues in a recent book, "The Sibling Society" (Addison-Wesley), that Americans live in a state of perpetual adolescence. Could that explain the increased desire to play dress-up?
"Maybe it's the whole inner-child thing -- I don't know," said Pamela Rucker, a spokeswoman for the National Retail Federation. "Many adults do seem to feel this need, though -- 'if my kids can have a party, I can have a party.' "
To be sure, many people here in Navasota, a rural town of about 6,000 people where the local Jaycees advertise "The Best Little Horror House in Texas," say they are suffering from Halloween burnout. And the mention of the December holidays -- which, after all, are just around the corner of the calendar -- almost seems to bring a shudder.
"It's all getting to be too much," said Jackie Woods, clutching her son, 4-year-old Eldridge, and ticking off his -- and her -- Halloween party obligations this month. "Too many things going on."
Ms. Allen said she hoped she had persuaded her son that the $50 rental costume, which she described as "some kind of monster," was a waste of money. "I told him the thing looks like a Ninja turtle, and it's out of his age cycle," she said. "I said, 'Honey, I just don't think it's a good investment for a one-night gig.' "
But for many adults who say they loved Halloween as children and love it now, there are no apologies. "Halloween," said Randall Bridges, a 21-year-old security guard, "is the one day of the year I totally feel comfortable."

HEADLINE: Stocks Finish Lower on Technology Selloff

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Traders continued selling to secure profits on technology shares, pulling stocks lower yesterday, as Digital Equipment reported a bigger-than-expected loss and Microsoft's strong earnings failed to satisfy hopes for a blowout performance.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 29.07 points, to 6,061.80, having recovered somewhat from a 53-point loss during the last hour of trading. 
 Broader measures also fell, with the biggest losses coming in the technology-laden Nasdaq market.
Stocks were also pressured by a weak bond market, where interest rates rose as prices fell on concerns about inflation and a flood of new borrowing through Treasury securities auctioned by the Government this week.
After the close of Monday's trading, Microsoft reported that strong demand for its operating systems and office software produced another strong quarterly profit. The profit for the July-to-September period, Microsoft's first quarter, rose 23 percent, to $614 million, or 95 cents a share, exceeding most forecasts.
But as with I.B.M.'s profit report Monday morning, Microsoft's results failed to exceed expectations by as wide a margin as Intel did last week. Many leading technology shares had rallied sharply in advance of the earnings reporting period as investors used last month's indications of growing chip demand to bet on a strong quarter.
Investors were also disappointed by an unexpected loss of $66 million, or 48 cents a share, in Digital's first quarter.
Digital's shares plunged 5 3/8, to 29, or more than 15 percent, as the New York Stock Exchange's most active issue, while Microsoft shares slipped 1 1/2, to 132 1/2, in Nasdaq trading. And I.B.M.'s shares sank 3 1/8 yesterday, to 127, as the Dow industrial's biggest decliner.
Several analysts said it was natural to see investors take some profits after the market's record-setting run, but some found the situation worrisome.
"They sold I.B.M., they sold Microsoft and they decimated Digital," said Ralph Bloch, chief market analyst at Raymond James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla. "What does that tell you when a strong earnings report sees a stock selloff, and when you get a bad report they take the stock behind the shed and shoot it? This is not a healthy description of a stock market."
Bond prices worsened in the afternoon as the Government started this week's Treasury refunding, auctioning $18.28 billion in new two-year notes. The bond market will need to absorb an additional $12.5 billion in five-year notes today.
As bond prices fell yesterday, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a key determinant of corporate and consumer borrowing costs -- rose to 6.85 percent from Monday's 6.80 percent.
Declining issues outnumbered advancers by a 5-to-3 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 410.8 million shares, down from 414.6 million in the previous session.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.28 points, to 706.57, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.70 points, to 376.22.
The Nasdaq composite index dropped 16.41, or 1.3 percent, to 1,220.00, led by big losses in Intel, down 2 1/4, to 105 1/2, and Sun Microsytems, down 3/16, to 59 1/8.
Several pharmaceutical companies reported earnings yesterday that were either in line with or exceeded expectations by many Wall Street analysts.
Bristol-Myers Squibb rose 2 3/4, to 106 7/8, and Eli Lilly gained 1/2, to 69 1/4. Warner-Lambert lost 7/8, to 65 1/4, and American Home Products slipped 1/2, to 65 7/8.
Ontrack Data International, a data recovery company, advanced 2 1/2, to 14 1/2, in its first day of trading as a public company.

HEADLINE: Whitman Proposes Aid to Help Welfare Recipients Work

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed legislation today to overhaul the state's welfare program by shifting about $150 million in spending to child care, transportation, job placement and other support services to help move welfare recipients into the workplace.
The money would come from a variety of sources, among them reducing county welfare administrative costs, tougher enforcement of child support laws and additional Federal aid, and would not mean increased state spending, senior Whitman administration officials said. 
 In keeping with the moderate Republican course she has set for her administration, Governor Whitman's legislative proposal would soften some of the harshest provisions in the new Federal welfare law. Her plan would continue cash benefits and Medicaid payments for legal immigrants, and the five-year lifetime limit on benefits would be extended for individuals who lose their job through no fault of their own.
Senior Whitman administration officials anticipate an additional $80 million under the new Federal welfare and child care block grants, which replace the old Federal welfare programs. In addition, state officials expect saving $20 million to $30 million by reducing administrative expenses at the county level and another $20 million to $30 million on increased child support enforcement efforts. State officials also anticipate the welfare caseload will continue to decline in the coming year, saving the state about $14 million next year.
The Whitman administration also proposes turning over some welfare administrative duties, now handled by the state's 567 cities and towns, to county governments, saving localities about $25 million, which state officials said could be used for property tax relief or other municipal services.
Under the proposal, called Work First New Jersey, Mrs. Whitman plans to double the state's commitment to child care over the next two years and provide welfare recipients with job training, job placement and transportation services. The plan would also let beneficiaries keep more of their outside income and guarantee subsidized child care and health care coverage, through the Medicaid program, up to two years after they have found work. There are about 110,000 families and 30,000 individuals who receive welfare benefits in New Jersey.
Governor Whitman's proposal avoids many of the strictest provisions backed in other states, like the 21-month time limit for welfare recipients that was put into effect earlier this year by Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut. Gov. George E. Pataki, who has submitted a state plan with little detail to the Federal Government, has not yet proposed his plan to the State Legislature in New York. Earlier this year, Mr. Pataki proposed reducing cash benefits for welfare recipients and imposing stricter time limits for childless adults.
"I know that there are some critics who believe that giving states the flexibility to design their own welfare system will encourage a race to the bottom that will leave our most vulnerable citizens out in the cold," Mrs. Whitman said at a news conference at the State House. " 'Work First New Jersey' proves the critics wrong. Our program strikes a fair balance between the responsibility of our able-bodied people to find work and our obligation to help them become self-sufficient."
But advocates for the poor expressed skepticism that the state would be able to generate enough jobs for the huge number of welfare recipients seeking employment in the coming five years. All but 20 percent of the adults in the state's welfare caseload will be required to meet work requirements. The only exceptions will be for elderly recipients, mentally and physically disabled individuals and parents taking care of disabled children, Whitman administration officials said.
"There are not enough jobs," said Kimberly Schevtchuk, a policy analyst for Mercer Street Friends, a social services agency in Trenton, which recently completed a study of job creation and unemployment patterns around the state. "Statewide, there would be three job seekers for every one job. There is considerable variation around the state with some counties having as many as 11 job seekers for every job."
Ms. Schevtchuk also expressed concern that Governor Whitman's proposal did not include additional state dollars for the support services to help welfare recipients achieve self-sufficiency. She also said that many of the support services that Mrs. Whitman outlined were not likely to be in place before the program goes into effect early next year.
"The clock will be ticking before many of these services are available," she said. "The child care slots are not there. The one-stop career centers are not there. And people are being asked to do this immediately and no additional state funds are being put in place for this task."
The Human Services Commissioner, William Waldman, said that the state expected to move about 34,000 welfare recipients into jobs within a year after the plan takes effect.
Although State Labor Department officials project 66,000 new jobs next year, job growth in New Jersey has slowed in the last year. According to John L. Wieting, regional administrator for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, New Jersey created 30,000 new jobs in the last year, mostly in the service and retail industries.
In many ways, the Governor's plan is similar to the new Federal welfare law. In addition to requiring welfare recipients to move into the work force within two years, the Governor's proposal would also require unmarried teen-age mothers to continue their education and to live with their parents or under adult supervision. Welfare recipients would also be required to cooperate with child support enforcement efforts or risk losing benefits.
At the same time, there will be major changes for thousands of families and individuals who now depend on welfare.
While Governor Whitman has agreed to continue cash and Medicaid benefits to legal immigrants, there will be an end this year to food stamps and Supplemental Security Income benefits for legal immigrants. As a result, the state's caseload for childless adults is expected to swell, and New Jersey will be forced to pick up the cost because the Federal Government will no longer reimburse states for giving cash benefits to legal immigrants.
In addition, mothers with infants as young as 12 weeks will be required to find a job. Child care advocates worry that there are not enough child care slots for young infants. But mothers with children under age 6 who cannot find appropriate, affordable child care are exempt from the work requirement.
The Governor's proposal, outlined in four separate bills, is expected to be introduced in the Legislature later this week. And Mrs. Whitman said that she was hoping to win bipartisan support. Both Assembly Speaker Jack Collins and Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, who joined Mrs. Whitman at today's press conference, promised that the legislation would be voted on by the end of the year. State officials expect the program to be put into effect within 30 days after it is signed into law.
State Senator Wayne R. Bryant, a Democrat from Camden and a sponsor of the Governor's proposal, said that it built on bipartisan efforts to establish a "solid foundation of welfare reform in New Jersey."
Mr. Bryant said that he was particularly pleased that New Jersey's efforts to revamp the state welfare program would allow welfare recipients to meet work participation requirements if they are are enrolled in a work-study program.

HEADLINE: Plea Is Renewed for Brazilian Devaluation

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Rudiger Dornbusch, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who is known for predicting the devaluation of the Mexican peso, said yesterday that Brazil's currency was seriously overvalued.
"Brazil has had a brutal appreciation in real terms without commensurate growth in productivity," Mr. Dornbusch told an audience at the Commercial Bank of New York. 
 He repeated recent pleas that the Brazilian currency, the real, be weakened before a crisis erupted that could cause investors to bail out of Brazilian securities.
Although generally comfortable worldwide growth and low interest rates provide a favorable environment, he said, Brazil could find itself facing a currency crisis in the event of an unexpected shock. And he added, "If you have cavities, go to the dentist or you'll have root canal during vacation."
Brazil's annual inflation rate has run at roughly 13 percent over the last year, compared with annual inflation of about 3 percent in the United States.
Mr. Dornbusch made his remarks on a day that Latin American debt prices fell significantly, spurred by dealer selling.
In his remarks, the M.I.T. economist listed Brazil's three major maladies as: 15 years without growth per capita in the gross domestic product, the lack of a balanced budget, and a need for administrative changes -- something now held up in the Brazilian Congress.
Mr. Dornbusch did not predict a major devaluation, saying that two more years of the current situation would be "difficult but not impossible, because in Brazil the impossible is routine."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole Shows High Spirits Across Michigan

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: TROY, Mich., Oct. 22

 BODY:
A couple of times today, Bob Dole was suddenly electrified with enthusiasm, all in the spirit of insisting that he would win the election, even though the polls show him falling increasingly behind.
At an outdoor rally here in this Detroit suburb, the Republican Presidential nominee was reciting his plan to end frivolous lawsuits when he spotted a favorable poster and responded to an encouraging comment from someone in the crowd. 
 "I like it!" he exclaimed. "I like it, I like it. I like all these signs."
In an instant, the previously low-key candidate seemed inspired. "Here we go!" he chortled. "This is the kind of spirit that will win the election! Right out here! Right out there!" The crowd cheered.
"I never did meet President Dewey, did you? No!" he declared, referring to the former New York Governor who was expected to win the Presidency from Harry S. Truman in 1948. "I'm like Harry Truman. I'm from the Midwest, and I'm plain-spoken, and I'm going to win whether you like it or not!"
His suddenly spirited exhibition came as he wrapped up a two-day bus tour of Michigan before heading for a rally in Ohio, two states he needs if he is to beat President Clinton but where Mr. Clinton holds solid leads in the polls.
As Mr. Dole soldiers on here in the Midwest, he seems tireless and has generally remained chipper.
But his nine speeches over the last two days have been relatively subdued and free of the harsh, sustained attacks on Mr. Clinton's ethics that preoccupied Mr. Dole last week.
So his bursts of energy today stood out all the more. And while his speeches today featured a mea culpa about the financing of political campaigns, his audiences responded far more enthusiastically to his fighting spirit.
The former Kansas Senator entertained the crowd here with a spirited riff on his familiar theme that Mr. Clinton likes to please everyone.
He told the crowd that if there was "anything you ever wanted in your life, these next two weeks is the time to write the President." He continued: "In fact, if you just give me a note, I'll take it to him. I may want something myself. And I'll get it, these last few weeks."
To the laughter of the crowd, he went on to combine Mr. Clinton's eagerness to please with the current controversy over Democratic fund-raising techniques.
"You want to spend the night in the Lincoln Bedroom for, say, $100,000?" Mr. Dole asked. "We'll get it for you. Whatever you want, we'll do it. You want to visit Indonesia? We'll arrange a trip. You want to go to India to see some of Gandhi's relatives, who gave $300,000 and owe $10,000 in back taxes? We'll work it out for you."
The references to India and Indonesia were to sources of questionable Democratic Party contributions.
Mr. Dole began his day with his bus caravan in the town of Frankenmuth, in east-central Michigan. The town, founded in 1845 by German missionaries, prides itself on its German heritage.
It was there that Mr. Dole repeated his recent theme that foreigners should not be able to make financial contributions to American political campaigns.
He intended to raise questions about foreign contributions to President Clinton and the Democrats, but he acknowledged -- as a new commercial by the Clinton campaign asserts -- that the Republicans had also accepted foreign money.
"Both parties have been involved in this," he said. "Both parties have done things that shouldn't have been done."
His next stop was at the high school football field in Grand Blanc, a pocket of Republicanism in otherwise strongly Democratic Genesee County. The biggest employer is General Motors, which has been enjoying something of a boom.
That was a tricky topic for Mr. Dole to navigate and still make a case for his economic plan. He initially painted a bleak picture nationally, citing stagnant wages, increased bankruptcies and higher credit-card debt. At the same time, he acknowledged a brighter Michigan economy, which he attributed to the policies of the state's Republican Governor, John Engler.
Mr. Dole also talked to the students about campaign finance changes, again including himself in his indictment of the system.
"All of us in politics have been guilty one way or another when it comes to campaign financing," he said.
"I don't mean violating the law," he hastened to add.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Continuing his campaign bus tour in the Midwest, Bob Dole talked with former Secretary of State George P. Shultz before a campaign rally in Grand Blanc, Mich., at the high school football field. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 907 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE SENATE;
In Minnesota Race, Negative Ads Outnumber the Lakes

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 20

 BODY:
On the screen are a faded Capitol on a gray background and a cartoon figure with the distorted face of Senator Paul Wellstone. With clown music playing, a cartoon arm pops out holding a sign reading, "LIBERAL."
The announcer in the 30-second television commercial says: "Since he's been in Washington, Paul Wellstone has cast one liberal vote after another. He voted against the balanced-budget amendment. He voted against the death penalty for murderers, terrorists and drug kingpins. And he's voted against workfare time and again. Paul Wellstone voted for higher taxes 48 times. He even voted to raise taxes on some Social Security benefits. And he's rated the No. 1 spender in the entire Senate. Paul Wellstone: embarrassingly liberal and out of touch." 
 Former Senator Rudy Boschwitz and the National Republican Senatorial Committee have been running advertisements like this incessantly for most of this year as Mr. Boschwitz tries to regain the Senate seat from Minnesota that he lost to Mr. Wellstone in 1990.
But the negative campaign may have boomeranged.
A statewide poll taken two weeks ago by The Minneapolis Star Tribune and WCCO-TV asked voters whether they had seen television advertisements about the Senate race and whether the commercials had generally made them more likely to vote for Mr. Boschwitz or Mr. Wellstone.
Of the 900 voters surveyed, 90 percent said they had watched advertisements about the race, which have been running round the clock on television. Although the number of Boschwitz advertisements this year have far exceeded those for Mr. Wellstone, 44 percent of the voters said the advertisements had made them more likely to vote for the Senator, and only 30 percent said Mr. Boschwitz.
Moreover, in the last month, when the advertising bombardment has been heaviest, voters' opinion of Mr. Wellstone rose and their opinion of Mr. Boschwitz fell, the poll showed.
The Boschwitz advertisements "have had a hard-edged and caustic tone that I would expect irritates people," said Steven Schier, chairman of the political science department at Carleton College in Northfield, Minn. "Negative ads have worked here in the past, but this may be overkill."
While Mr. Boschwitz has been running negative advertisements almost entirely, Mr. Wellstone has broadcast a mix. About half his commercials describe his position on issues. The other half usually begin with his stand on an issue, then take a shot at Mr. Boschwitz and then return to a positive statement about Mr. Wellstone.
The Wellstone seat is one that Democrats believe that they must hold if they are to stand any chance of regaining control of the Senate. Republicans now have a majority in the Senate of 53 to 47. Assuming President Clinton is re-elected, giving Vice President Al Gore the tie-breaking vote, Democrats must have a net gain of three seats to have a majority.
The Minnesota race is close. The same Star Tribune/WCCO poll showed Mr. Wellstone ahead by nine percentage points, but other recent polls have shown a closer race.
The two candidates could hardly be more different in their personalities and ideologies.
There is a touch of Fiorello La Guardia in Senator Wellstone, a hyperactive little man with a high-pitched voice who wants to kiss every baby he sees and shake every hand he can reach. A former college professor, he took his battered green school bus, his rolling campaign headquarters, to the University of Minnesota homecoming parade on Saturday and waved joyously from the rear platform.
Periodically, the 52-year-old Senator jumped off the bus to slap hands with students outside a fraternity house or to get thrown in the air on a hand-held trampoline. He craves attention from reporters and seems to gain nourishment from crowds.
Probably the most liberal Democrat in the Senate, he is the only incumbent running for re-election who voted against the Republican welfare bill that Mr. Clinton signed last month. He advocates universal, Government-run medical insurance and more spending on education and environmental protection.
Mr. Boschwitz -- 65, tall, thin and gray-haired -- is more reserved. He made a fortune in the plywood business and was known around the state before he was first elected to the Senate in 1978 because of his appearances in television commercials promoting his business. He served two terms in the Senate before being ousted by Mr. Wellstone, who won 50 percent of the vote to 48 percent.
Mr. Boschwitz went to the homecoming parade, too, on Saturday. But he spent less time than Mr. Wellstone, marched with more reserve when he was there and drew less notice. He clearly prefers campaigning in small groups and in predictable settings without reporters.
Ideologically, Mr. Boschwitz embraces most of the national Republican economic and social agenda, including deep tax cuts, fewer government regulations and limits on spending for social programs.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Wellstone said he expected the advertising attack against him to backfire. "People have become angry with how disrespectful it is," he said.
But Mr. Boschwitz said he had no reason to apologize. "Our ads have had a sense of purpose and a sense of humor, and I'm happy with them," he said. "We call it defining the opposition."
He also professed no concern about the latest poll showing him trailing.
"I was nine points ahead in the polls in 1990, and I lost," he said.
