HEADLINE: Clinton Troubleshooter Discovers Big Trouble From Allies on Cuba

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Two months ago, President Clinton handed a top Commerce Department official, Stuart E. Eizenstat, the knotty task of placating America's trading partners infuriated by a new law that punishes certain foreign companies doing business in Cuba. On his first diplomatic shuttle abroad, he was pelted with eggs in Mexico.
Things haven't gotten much better since. 
 Since President Clinton signed the law in March, it has provoked a flurry of denunciations and formal protests from some of America's closest allies that has included, as one State Department official put it, "the most undiplomatic language I've ever seen."
Mexico and Canada have passed retaliatory legislation. And the European Union is challenging the law in a new court under the World Trade Organization, although Mr. Clinton suspended its stiffest measures for six months, a period that coincides with the election campaign.
Now, despite Mr. Eizenstat's missions to 12 foreign capitals to meet with political and business leaders, the anger shows little sign of dissipating. And that has raised concerns that the law could provoke a trade war or at least undercut popular support in the United States for the trade agreement that created the World Trade Organization.
At the same time, Mr. Clinton has found himself in the home stretch of his re-election campaign exposed to criticism from Cuban-Americans and Republicans who say he has not acted forcefully enough to punish Cuba.
"If you want to send a signal, you got to send a signal," Bob Dole, the Republican challenger, declared in the first Presidential debate, accusing Mr. Clinton of doing too little even as the trading partners accused him of doing too much.
In the thick of it is Mr. Eizenstat, a veteran lawyer and Democratic adviser, who served as President Carter's chief domestic policy aide and then stayed on in Washington as a lobbyist during the 12 years of Republican control of the White House. He joined President Clinton's Administration in 1993 as representative to the European Union before becoming the Commerce Department's Undersecretary for International Trade earlier this year.
"It is not," Mr. Eizenstat said, "the easiest task I've ever had in government."
The law -- known as the Helms-Burton Act, after its Republican sponsors, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Representative Dan Burton of Indiana -- seeks to punish foreign companies that use factories or other property in Cuba confiscated from Americans after the revolution that brought Fidel Castro to power in 1959.
Among other things, it requires the State Department to deny visas to executives of such companies and their families -- a punishment already imposed on a Mexican telecommunications company, Grupo Domos, and a Canadian mining concern, Sherritt International.
The law also gives American citizens and companies the right to sue the foreign companies that use confiscated property for restitution in American courts.
Mr. Clinton initially opposed the Helms-Burton Act, but he signed it in March amid the public furor that erupted when Cuban jets shot down two planes flown by Cuban-Americans off Cuba's coast last February. In July, he allowed the law to take effect, but suspended the provision allowing the lawsuits against foreign companies, at least until January.
It was, his aides said at the time, an effort to demonstrate resolve to Cuban-Americans in two important electoral states, Florida and New Jersey, while buying time to defuse the angry warnings of retaliation from abroad.
While the law's supporters argue that it does not seek to curb foreign trade with Cuba but simply targets those companies exploiting confiscated resources, its critics in Mexico, Canada and Europe have called it an "extraterritorial" effort by the United States to impose its foreign policy on others. On the eve of Mr. Eizenstat's visit to Mexico, President Ernesto Zedillo said it was "simply a violation of international law."
Given the anger from America's allies, Mr. Eizenstat's mission appears doomed.
Most of his work has involved bearing the brunt of the outrage over the bill -- not just from the allies, but from Cuban-American groups angered that the law's sharpest bite had been postponed. It was a measure of the domestic politics involved that Mr. Eizenstat's mission did not take him abroad, but rather to Florida and New Jersey.
Mr. Eizenstat acknowledged that he was unlikely to persuade the trading partners to accept the law, as well as a similar one that imposes sanctions on foreign companies that invest in Libya and Iran.
Instead, he said his strategy was to rally support for other steps that nations could take to increase pressure on Mr. Castro's Government. On his diplomatic trips, he has touted a series of proposals for nations to use their embassies to promote human rights, for companies that operate in Cuba to adopt "best business practices" like fair wages, and for nongovernment organizations to promote reforms in the Cuba's media, penal system and judiciary.
In an interview in his office at the Commerce Department, Mr. Eizenstat said these "modest steps" could speed a transition to democracy in Cuba and thus preclude the need for the Helms-Burton law. While he insisted that the President would not try to reverse the law, he suggested that America's trading partners could persuade him to suspend the punitive measures a second time.
He preferred not to characterize the strategy as a carrot or a stick. "The issue is whether they can, on their own, develop concrete and specific measures to which the President can point," he said.
Mr. Eizenstat plans to make a second tour of European capitals beginning this week and fully expects to hear more "unadulterated, undiluted anger." But he says the controversy has had an effect.
"The issue of democracy in Cuba," he said, "would not have been put on the radar screen if not for Helms-Burton."
For their part, the trading partners remain determined, warily hopeful that Mr. Clinton will somehow get around the law once Election Day passes and, as one diplomat put it, the "silly season" ends.
Another diplomat for one of America's closest allies said, "Everybody is sort of holding their breath and hoping that after these elections, people will bring this under control."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;
Dole Tax Plan Would Shelter Some Gains

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Bob Dole has added a potentially far-reaching and controversial element to his economic package, promising that he would act immediately to exempt from capital gains taxes any inflation-induced increase in the value of land, homes, businesses, stocks or other assets.
Mr. Dole was acting at the behest of his running mate, Jack Kemp, who has argued that the move will spur economic growth by freeing trillions of dollars of wealth currently locked up in property that people do not want to sell because of the taxes they would have to pay. 
 For several weeks, Mr. Kemp has been talking about the campaign's commitment to such indexing of capital gains to inflation, and Mr. Dole gave it a public, if backhanded, endorsement on Monday.
"Jack's talked about indexing, which is fine with me, of capital gains," Mr. Dole said.
Indexing capital gains to inflation has long been criticized by the Clinton Administration as administratively impossible because it would require taxpayers to make extremely complicated calculations about how much of any increase in asset values derived from inflation. But the idea has been a favorite of conservative economists and the tax-cutting wing of the Republican Party for years.
The move's effect would be primarily felt by people who had held property for long periods or in times of high inflation. Mr. Kemp uses the example of an entrepreneur who paid $100,000 for a business in 1980 and sold it now for $160,000.
Mr. Kemp says that since the inflation during that period alone would account for the increase in the business's value, there would be no capital gains tax on the sale. Any gain above that attributed to inflation would still be taxed, although Mr. Dole has already promised to reduce the top capital gains tax rate by half, to 14 percent.
Mr. Kemp has been arguing that Mr. Dole could enact the change to indexing through an executive order. But it is unclear whether using an executive order to change tax policy is constitutional because the authority for originating tax law rests with the House. Indeed, this issue was debated among Republicans in 1992, when President Bush flirted briefly with a similar proposal.
Proponents say an executive order would change only the regulations defining the costs associated with capital gains, arguing that inflation falls into that category, and not the underlying tax laws. They also say that by using an executive order, Mr. Dole could bypass legislative wrangling over the issue and enact the policy from his first day in office.
Although the idea of indexing capital gains to inflation was not included in the economic plan Mr. Dole introduced in August, he provided Congressional tax analysts with additional details a few weeks later, including a provision for introducing indexing in 2001.
At the urging of Mr. Kemp and other proponents of the idea, including Theodore J. Forstmann, the Wall Street investor, and Wayne D. Angell, a former Federal Reserve governor, Mr. Dole agreed earlier this month to make a public commitment to indexing capital gains starting next year.
Advocates of the plan estimate that Americans are currently holding property with unrealized capital gains of $7 trillion due to inflation. Under current tax law, the tax liability on those assets would be $2 trillion, and Mr. Dole's plan would eliminate that liability altogether.
"It would address one of the biggest issues facing the country today," Mr. Kemp said in a telephone interview, asserting that indexing capital gains would end a "confiscatory and immoral" tax policy that left some taxpayers with less wealth than when they started.
Mr. Forstmann, a close associate of Mr. Kemp who was a member of a committee appointed by Republican Congressional leaders that studied the tax code last year, said relatively few of the assets were held by wealthy investors.
"Ordinary Americans, that mass of people out there, they have one or two main assets, the house and the business," Mr. Forstmann said. "They tend to have these things for a long time. If you had an asset for the last 20 or 30 years, there is a huge inflation component in its value. It looks good, but in terms of purchasing power, you may have less than when you bought the asset. To tax that, it's confiscation."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Netscape Revenue Quadruples in Quarter

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
Declaring it has made significant inroads into the corporate software market, the Netscape Communications Corporation said yesterday that revenue quadrupled in the third quarter as it reported earnings that were slightly higher than estimates.
The young company, best known for its Navigator software used by millions of people to browse the Internet's World Wide Web, earned $7.7 million, or 9 cents a share, up from $175,000 in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose 329 percent, to $23.3 million. 
 The earnings were a penny above Wall Street expectations, according to a survey of analysts by First Call.
Still, shares of Netscape were little changed in after-hours trading. The company announced its results after the market closed. Earlier, shares of Netscape, which went public in August 1995, closed down 25 cents, at $44.50, in Nasdaq trading.
Analysts said that Netscape's growth, while impressive, had to be measured against the size and power of its main competitor, the Microsoft Corporation. On Monday, Microsoft reported stronger-than-expected earnings growth for the latest quarter, and is on track toward $10 billion in revenue for the year.
"Although it scaled dramatically, Netscape is battling with a giant company that is also scaling very dramatically," said Stan Dolberg, an analyst with Forrester Research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass.
In comments yesterday, Netscape officials made it clear that they intended to tap into the rich revenue vein of the corporate intranet market. Based on the same technology that links millions of computers worldwide on the Internet, corporate intranets are private networks used to allow workers to exchange electronic mail and tap easily into company data bases.
James Barksdale, Netscape's president and chief executive, said about 80 percent of the company's revenue now comes from intranet products and services. Among its largest corporate customers are Chrysler, J. C. Penney, GE Information Services, Shell and Federal Express.
Last week, Netscape announced a series of new products for corporate intranets. They will compete not only against Microsoft's products, but also against offerings from the the Oracle Corporation and International Business Machines . Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates, said last December that Netscape was his company's prime competitive target.
"It is definitely intimidating to have the dominant player in the software industry, with $7 billion in cash, coming after you, but we believe Netscape has a defensible position," said Michael L. Speiser, a research associate at the Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Technology Group in New York.
Mr. Speiser said that while the so-called Internet browser war between Netscape and Microsoft had received the most public attention, neither company made much money at it. Microsoft gives away its browser, Internet Explorer.
But the corporate intranet software market, analysts say, could swell to a $10-billion-a-year business by the year 2000.
"What we're seeing is the beginning of what is going to be an explosive marketplace, and Netscape seems to have a pretty significant share," said Daniel H. Rimer, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 24, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the third-quarter results of the Netscape Communications Corporation misstated the company's revenue. It was $100 million; the $23.3 million figure represented the revenue a year earlier.

HEADLINE: An Endangered Species: Rock Clubs in New York

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

 BODY:
New York City may be one of the cultural capitals of the world, but it's not always easy to present culture here. Rock clubs in particular find that, even as competitors like the Academy and Roseland are being converted to other uses, staying in business is a daily challenge.
"It is more difficult to get a club open and to keep it open once it's licensed than it ever used to be," said Robert Bookman of Pesetsky & Bookman, a law firm that represents more than 50 local clubs. "There is no welcome mat in New York City for night life establishments." 
 To start with, many owners say, rock clubs are simply not lucrative. Because bands receive 80 to 90 percent of the take from ticket purchases, clubs must look to drink sales as a chief source of revenue. This can be a problem since the average rock and pop concertgoer is under 21, and national alcohol consumption is on the wane. When Irving Plaza booked the punk band Green Day on St. Patrick's Day two years ago, it sold 1,000 tickets but distributed only 60 of the wristbands that go to those who are old enough to drink alcohol legally.
Then there are the city and state regulations: To operate a rock club, the owner may need as many as 56 permits, ranging from a public assembly license to a carbonic gas permit for the beer taps. And the requirements to obtain those permits are getting constantly tougher.
Two years ago, the State Liquor Authority granted community boards the right to review liquor license applications, and that has kept projected clubs like the Sunshine Theater on Houston Street from opening. With the passage of what's been nicknamed "the rowdy bar bill" last month, renewals of liquor licenses for existing clubs are now subject to community board review as well.
Many club owners applaud this measure, saying that nightspots need to maintain good relations with residential neighbors. On the other hand, they point out, one angry and influential insomniac can destroy a club.
As if all this weren't enough, it is increasingly difficult to find a building in Manhattan with the specifications for a rock club: a flat-floored, column-free space of over 15,000 square feet, several exits and an unobstructed view. Most of them are being sold as sites for high-rise buildings.
When a prospective owner does find one, it is extremely expensive. Regulations revised several years ago make it necessary for new clubs, in the few neighborhoods still zoned for them, to have 12 square feet a person in a concert hall and 4 square feet a person elsewhere for them to gather. Plans for one new concert facility in Manhattan last year were scrapped after construction was estimated at $2 million and the annual rent at over $600,000.
The result is that the rock clubs operating regularly in Manhattan are in spaces that predate the new regulations, like Tramps, Irving Plaza, Wetlands and, for the time being, Roseland. The owners of these clubs say they must scramble to stay afloat.
Irving Plaza, the club on 15th Street and Irving Place, where every rocker from Eric Clapton to Nine Inch Nails has performed in the last few years, is a prime example.
At the average Irving Plaza show, the ticket price is $15 (before the surcharges, which Ticketmaster keeps). If the club, which can hold 1,000 people, sells out, it takes in $15,000. Then it must pay a $5,000 guarantee to the band; $3,000 for advertising; $1,250 for house and technical staff; $850 for security guards (or more for an audience that likes to mosh); $600 for insurance; $620 for catering and meals for the bands; $500 for sound and lights; $250 for ticket-printing fees, and $100 in copyright fees. That leaves little to split, 20 percent for the club and 80 percent for the band.
The club is often in debt, its owners say, especially since 80 percent of its shows don't sell out. For Bob Mould's well-attended two-night stand this month, Irving Plaza lost $6,000.
"There's a misconception that clubs and club owners are rolling in dough, but a crisis expenditure like a new air-conditioning system or flooding repairs could make or break a club," said Andrew Rasiej, who owns Irving Plaza with Bill Brusca, a former manager at the Ritz rock club.
Because the owners of Irving Plaza also promote their own shows, they can make a little more money by charging $500 in rent per concert and taking 15 percent of overall expenses as a promoter's fee. But since the club is essentially paying itself, in order even to earn that money, the show must make a profit equal to that amount.
As for alcohol, sales average one $4 beer for each legal-age concertgoer. If 1,000 people attend a show and 500 are over 21, (a high estimate), the bar takes in $2,000. After buying the beer (about a dollar each), paying 8.25 percent sales tax, paying the bar staff and taking care of other expenses like liquor liability insurance and the soda system lease, Irving Plaza ends up with a $1,000 profit.
But there are still general operating costs to cover. With an average of 12 shows a month, Irving Plaza doesn't even cover its $15,000 a month rent with bar receipts, let alone thousands of dollars for gas, electricity, telephone, building insurance, maintenance and permit fees.
So how do Mr. Rasiej and Mr. Brusca make do?
They find little ways to scrape up extra revenue, like making a few hundred dollars from a coat check concession and another few hundred dollars as a 15 percent commission on merchandise that bands sell in the club. Record labels help by renting the bar for a party before or after a show. The club also has other kinds of events to make money, like swing dances on Sunday nights, trendy dance parties like Sugar Babies after concerts on Monday nights and private corporate parties. And sometimes a club is leased for video and film shoots.
All of this is still relatively small change, however. Almost every large, successful club has found more clever ways to stay in business. Irving Plaza made a deal with Metropolitan Entertainment, the concert promoter, which entitles the club to an equal share of the profits (or losses) if any rising band once booked at Irving Plaza goes on to play for Metropolitan in a larger concert hall in the area, even as big as Madison Square Garden.
Mr. Rasiej is also a part owner of Galaxy Restaurant and operates the 119 Bar, both on 15th Street and Irving Place. In addition, he started an Internet company called the Digital Club Network (with the Knitting Factory owner Michael Dorf) with investment by Apple Computer and MCI. Although Mr. Rasiej has used profits from these ventures to help Irving Plaza, he said this year the club might finally make money on its own.
Mr. Rasiej, Mr. Bookman, Mr. Dorf and other club owners and concert industry executives say clubs need a trade group to represent their interests. So Mr. Rasiej has helped start the New York Nightlife Association, an umbrella group for concert halls, dance clubs and bars, that intends to publicize the cultural and financial value of nightspots to the city and to work on improving community relations and reducing operating costs.
"Why do I go through this?" Mr. Rasiej asked. "Because I believe in the long-term viability of Irving Plaza and the music business in general."
 In addition, the per-ticket share of the promoter's fee was $1.98 (not $1.32), and the per-ticket share of the total expenses was $15.20 (not $14.54).

CORRECTION-DATE: October 26, 1996, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Wednesday with an article about the financial problems of rock clubs in New York City misstated the the total cost of promotion in some editions for a typical capacity concert at one club, Irving Plaza, in Manhattan. Other figures in the chart, based on the incorrect figure, were also in error.
The promoter's fee for the concert was $1,983 (not $1,317). Thus the club's total expenses for the concert were $15,203 (not $14,537), and the club showed a loss of $203 (not a profit of $92.60). Since no revenue remained (rather than $463), the band shared in no profit; it did not make $370.40.

HEADLINE: Singapore Doesn't Claim to Be Model for Anyone

 BODY:
To the Editor:
William Safire (column, Oct. 21) calls Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore "a tinpot tyrant with dynastic pretensions" in a discussion about China, Indonesia and fund-raising in the United States in which Singapore has no part. 
 At the World Economic Forum in Switzerland last February, Mr. Safire put the same accusation to Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, who reminded Mr. Safire that Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong had invited him to debate with him publicly and to educate Singaporeans on the evils of their Government but that Mr. Safire had declined the invitation.
Singapore is a multiparty parliamentary democracy. Nine general elections have been held in five-year intervals since 1959. All ministers are elected members of Parliament. Senior Minister Lee and the deputy prime minister have repeatedly been re-elected.
Singapore society is relatively drug-free, corruption-free and crime-free and, contrary to Mr. Safire, transparent and accountable. The 1995 World Competitiveness Report rated Singapore No. 1 in world competitiveness and in administration of justice in Asia. Singapore does not pretend to be a model for anyone.
 
CHAN HENG CHEE
Ambassador of Singapore
Washington, Oct. 23, 1996

HEADLINE: Economic SceneGood news for Dole in a new study of his tax plan.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
SINCE August, Bob Dole has been trying to sell the virtues of "supply side" tax cuts to a skeptical public. Mr. Dole's call for "a new Independence Day for the American taxpayer," it seems, has effectively been parried by President Clinton's warning that the Dole economic plan "would blow a hole" in the deficit.
Missing from the debate is a nonpartisan assessment of the proposed tax cuts. Check that: missing until now. Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting and consulting firm, has just completed an independent technical analysis of the plan that uses a dynamic computer model to track the likely fiscal and economic consequences. And for the most part, it is good news for the Republicans. "The plan pretty much works the way Dole-Kemp says," concludes John Wilkins, a former number-cruncher for the Treasury who now directs Coopers & Lybrand's Tax Policy Economics Group. 
 The catch is it wouldn't work the way the more zealous supply-siders in Mr. Dole's camp would have you believe.
Supply-side economists have long contended that official estimates of the impact of tax cuts on Government revenues are biased because they neglect the impact of changing incentives to work and save. There is some truth to this. While a few behavioral effects are built into the Government's computerized tax models, they generally assume that interest rates, national output and employment are not affected.
The Coopers & Lybrand model aims to remedy that defect by linking the standard "micro" models that focus on supply and demand to the "macro" models that look at broad economic changes.
No model, of course, is better than its assumptions: garbage in, garbage out. But here, the magnitudes of "dynamic" assumptions so dear to the supply-siders are fairly conservative. Coopers & Lybrand does not claim, for example, that personal savings would rise if marginal tax rates were lowered -- indeed, it assumes the rate would fall if incentives to defer pay are reduced. Moreover, the model assumes that the Federal Reserve would maintain a monetary policy that did not permit unemployment to fall below the point now judged to generate wage inflation.
Nonetheless, the study finds that the $548 billion tax cut over six years would be partly offset by $124 billion in new revenues -- just $20 billion less than the Dole camp estimated.
A bit of the "reflow" is the indirect result of more rapid capital formation. A bit comes from the increased incentive to work, with 1.4 million new jobs being created above the 5.4 million jobs in the status quo scenario. But most of the revenue comes from the reduction in marginal tax rates that would dampen incentives to defer income or take it as fringe benefits.
If the Dole plan passes muster with the green eyeshade types, why has it been treated with disdain by so many mainstream economists? Perhaps because Mr. Dole's spinmeisters have been peddling two different stories.
One is the purely technical tale produced by Mr. Dole's centrist economic advisers. It asserts that the tax cuts are compatible with a balanced budget, provided Washington finds ways to cut spending sufficiently. The plan does not depend on a burst of enterprise and savings that raises economic growth rates. And that's the same lens through which Coopers & Lybrand views it, projecting a modest gain in gross domestic product by 2002 of about 1 percent above and beyond what the economy might achieve without tax cuts.
The other story is latter-day voodoo, an attempt by Republicans who have long been skeptical of Mr. Dole's traditional fiscal conservatism to bathe his candidacy in the uplifting light of supply-side rhetoric. They persuaded Mr. Dole to set a "goal" of 2 percent-plus growth in productivity -- twice the rate of the last two decades. And Mr. Kemp, his running mate, has repeatedly trumpeted the goal of a 5 percent after-inflation growth rate, double the current 2.5 percent trend. So economists' negative reaction has been driven by the apparent disconnect between experience and expectation.
In part, too, the critics have reacted negatively to the Dole contention that he can achieve substantial cuts in the growth of spending while still raising military outlays and not touching Social Security. That is no problem for the Coopers & Lybrand economists, who simply assumed that the cuts would be made. "It's a separate question whether the spending cuts are politically possible or desirable," Mr. Wilkins argues.
The paradox here is that, for all the hostile words from professionals on the desirability of across-the-board tax cuts, there is little disagreement that lower marginal tax rates are a legitimate goal of tax reform. Perhaps after the election when Washington gets back to the business of political compromise the point will seem obvious.

HEADLINE: Caribbean Nations Find Little Profit in Aiding U.S. Drug War

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados

 BODY:
Hoping for American gratitude and assistance, the English-speaking countries of the eastern Caribbean have in recent years devoted larger portions of their meager budgets to fighting drug trafficking. But now, to the dismay of many in the region, the United States is responding with a policy of economic retrenchment.
Legislation to give Caribbean countries the same free-trade benefits as Mexico and Canada has been shelved in Congress, and a little-noticed provision of the minimum-wage bill that President Clinton signed in August eliminates Federal tax incentives to encourage low-interest loans to the region. Also, the two sides are in a bitter dispute over export quotas for bananas, the backbone of most economies in the area. 
 "What is the message being sent?" Keith Mitchell, the Prime Minister of Grenada, asked. "It is that our friends are abandoning us, that the rug is being pulled from under us, that we are being told we must sink or float on our own."
The scaling back of Washington's economic commitment comes with the region's re-emergence as a favorite transit zone for cocaine and heroin traffickers. Caribbean countries are largely cooperating with antidrug efforts, United States officials say, and their leaders are clearly rankled by what they see as a lack of American economic support.
"We've surrendered our sovereignty," James Mitchell, Prime Minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, said at a recent meeting of the Caribbean Americas Business Network in Miami. "We've given the U.S. all the cooperation in the world. What else do they want?"
American officials acknowledge some of the complaints, but they also say that eastern Caribbean nations have passed up opportunities through membership in regional lending institutions to ease their economic dependence on Washington.
For their part, leaders of the 14 nations making up the Caribbean Community, a regional economic association known as Caricom, have been urging the Clinton Administration to grant them trade parity with Mexico and Canada, the United States' partners in the North American Free Trade Agreement.
But Congress adjourned this month without taking action on the measure, which was intended to supplement the largely moribund Caribbean Basin Initiative created by the Reagan Administration.
In a report last month, the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a Washington-based research group, attributed the delay in action to "partisan and special interest opposition" in Congress. The council said American legislators were wary of offending fruit lobbyists.
Caricom leaders say they need access to free trade to help compensate for a drop of nearly 90 percent in American economic assistance to the region over the last decade, from $225 million to $26 million. In August, a provision in the new minimum-wage law ended tax breaks for American corporations doing business in Puerto Rico.
At the same time, Washington is challenging the traditional system of trade preferences that allows many Caricom nations to export their products to European nations either duty free or at vastly reduced tariff rates. One such proposal, which Caribbean leaders say could cripple the region's banana industry, is now before the World Trade Organization.
"It seems shortsighted and baffling," said Frank Alleyne of the Institute for Social and Economic Research at the University of the West Indies. "What about the cost in social unrest? If they succeed, drug cultivation will increase, mark my word. Farmers must find another crop, and that crop is marijuana."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slips vs. the Mark But Climbs Against the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell to the lowest level in a month against the rallying German mark yesterday, but climbed above 113 Japanese yen for the first time since January 1994.
Traders attributed the dollar's behavior largely to strength in the mark, which surged on new indications that Germany would not lower interest rates further and a surprise reduction of interest rates in Italy. The relative attractiveness of German rates raised demand for marks. 
 The dollar's strength against the yen resulted indirectly from a broad retreat by the Japanese currency, particularly against the mark, as investors in Japan continued to funnel money out of the country into higher-yielding opportunities abroad.
"The strength of the mark has been the primary focus of the day," said John McCarthy, foreign exchange manager at ING Capital Markets Inc. in New York.
In late New York trading, the dollar was at 1.5207 marks, down from 1.5245 Tuesday and the lowest level since Sept. 25. The dollar was at 112.93 yen, up from 112.20. Earlier in the trading day the dollar climbed as high as 113.15 yen, a level not seen for 33 months.
A growing sense that German interest rates are unlikely to fall were reinforced by two leading Bundesbank officials.
Otmar Issing, chief economist of Germany's central bank, said in a television interview that there was no need for further reductions. Johann Wilhelm Gaddum, member of the Bundesbank directorate, said the bank wanted to keep rates unchanged "as long as possible."
The mark derived further strength after the Bank of Italy cut its official discount rate by 0.75 percentage point to 7.75 percent effective Thursday. The bank said the reduction was justified by new signs of diminished inflation in Italy, falling below 3 percent for the first time since 1969.
Traders attributed the yen's weakness partly to further indications that interest rates in Japan are likely to remain at postwar lows for the forseeable future.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday: 1.2530 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.1385 French francs, down from 5.1525; 1,527.50 Italian lire, up from 1,524.20; 1.3436 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3450.

HEADLINE: Wave of Strongmen Make West Africa Their Oyster

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Oct. 23

 BODY:
When State Department planners sat down to work out an African itinerary for Secretary of State Warren Christopher's first trip to the continent, seeking to play up news of positive change in each of Africa's regions below the Sahara, West Africa presented a special problem.
If this region saw a wave of transitions toward democratic rule at the start of the decade, more recently it has become the stage of one setback after another as elected governments have been overthrown by soldiers while incumbents have liberally fiddled with the rules governing voting to insure that they win. 
 In the end, Mr. Christopher chose to visit Mali, widely considered to be one of only two unambiguously democratic countries in West Africa; the other is Benin.
But diplomats say the very narrowness of the choices for the itinerary underscored a major looming challenge to Western policy toward this region: the resurgence of military strongmen who seek to remake themselves into civilian leaders.
If the military coup has faded out of fashion in other parts of the continent, it is enjoying a strong resurgence in West Africa, where soldier-politicians all seem to be reading from the same tightly written script.
In the most recent example, in the tiny country of Gambia, a 31-year-old former captain, Yahya Jammeh, who seized power overthrowing an elected Government in 1994, won election to the presidency last month in a vote widely perceived as unfair.
After seizing power, Mr. Jammeh -- following the lead of several other West African countries led by soldier-politicians -- banned established political parties, jailed many of his prominent critics, carried out repeated attacks against the press and then called elections that gave little time for opponents to organize.
Predictably, major donors to Gambia, like the European Union and the United States, denounced the repression and the country's electoral process. But having seen others in the region get away with much the same thing, Mr. Jammeh apparently decided the risks involved in his efforts to stay in power were worth it.
"Each time there is a coup like this, followed by an election, we have grown accustomed to a standard reaction from the West," said a senior African diplomat, who insisted on not being identified. "They denounce the thing and cut off aid at first, but before long we are back to business as usual. We've already seen that in Niger, Chad and now in Gambia this year, and there are certainly more to come."
With Mr. Jammeh's swearing-in last week, 11 of 17 countries in the region are led by military men turned civilian presidents.
In Nigeria, the continent's most populous country, the signs are multiplying that President Sani Abacha, a general who seized power in a coup in November 1993 after the military canceled the most democratic election in that country's history, is planning to seek election in a bid for international legitimacy that critics say would almost certainly not involve a fair competition.
Supporters celebrating General Abacha's 53d birthday recently toasted the publication of a new book on the philosophy of "Abachaism." And in recent weeks the Nigerian press has been filled with the statements from Nigerians promoting the idea of the general's candidacy in elections promised for 1998.
Western diplomats say that any bid for electoral office by General Abacha would probably follow the same pattern as Mr. Jammeh's.
And if the West, the principal source of the lending and tourism that support the Gambian economy, cannot oblige that tiny country to apply even minimal rules of political fair play, this reasoning goes, what can possibly get in the way of giant Nigeria, an oil-producing country of more than 100 million people?

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Rise as Sale Of Notes Ends

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose yesterday for this first time this week, after the market absorbed another large issue of new supply.
Relieved that the Treasury's sale of $12.5 billion in five-year notes was out of the way, prices staged a modest rally in the afternoon and moved into positive territory after two consecutive days of losses. 
 Talk of Federal Reserve buying in the five-year sector was also seen bolstering prices in the aftermath of the auction.
"Supply is out of the way, the auction came pretty much right where it was expected to come and we saw some relief trade," said Michael McClure, head of government bond trading at Zions First National Bank Capital Markets. "People are going back to their bullish ways."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 1/32, to 98 29/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, slipped to 6.83 percent from 6.85 percent on Tuesday.
Without any economic data to focus on, the market relied on supply again yesterday for much of its direction. Market analysts characterized the Treasury's five-year note sale as largely in line with expectations.
They noted, however, that the market appeared better prepared for the supply than it had been on Tuesday, when the Treasury's two-year note sale gave way to widespread selling.
The Treasury sold the five-year notes at a high yield of 6.325 percent, awarding 55 percent of the bids at the high rate. Of the $28.181 billion in bids received, $326 million were noncompetitive offers.
The bid-to-cover ratio, a gauge of demand for the issue, came in at a slightly soft 2.33.
"It was really plain vanilla," said John Canavan, Treasury market analyst at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc. "There was nothing particularly exciting about it one way or the other."
Talk that the Federal Reserve was buying five-year notes on behalf of foreign central banks helped reinforce the price gains, analysts said.
Dealers could not confirm the Fed purchases, but said the behavior of the market and the widespread nature of the reports suggested the central bank might have been active.
With supply out of the way, the bond market is now expected to begin looking ahead to tomorrow's report on September durable goods orders and next week's busy calendar, which includes key October employment figures.
Economists said the market was hoping that the coming numbers would be supportive, but hesitant about betting on further price gains.
"There are still a lot more hurdles ahead," said Kim Rupert, senior economist at MMS International. "Most people are still expecting friendly numbers, but no one is making a strong play yet."
In the corporate market, cable and media debt dominated trading, but the sector was marred by further widening in TCI Communications paper, traders said.
The slide in TCI debt has slowed, but issues still widened in the range of 5 to 10 basis points into the close. TCI debt has widened by more than 40 basis points since the Standard & Poor's rating agency said late Friday that it might downgrade the credit to junk status. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Elsewhere, Viacom Inc. debt was softer for the second consecutive session after news that it might pay MCA $1.45 billion and exchange its 50 percent interest in the Sci Fi Channel for complete control of the USA Network.
Viacom debt due in 2005 closed at 190 basis points bid, 185 basis points offered. Spreads firmed early after an S.& P. ratings affirmation late on Tuesday, one trader said, but the paper soon retreated to wider levels.

HEADLINE: Drawing Lines in the Shore's Sand;
Plan to Let Nature Rule Worries Investors and Homeowners

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: HARVEY CEDARS, N.J.

 BODY:
Picture this scenario of life along the New Jersey coast in 50 years: The Atlantic Ocean is about eight inches higher than it is now and several yards farther inland. The storms that batter the shoreline are far more destructive. And houses now on the most vulnerable parts of the coast are flooded.
That is the scenario that coastal scientists at Rutgers University projected in a report for the state, paid for with $200,000 in Federal money. 
 The scientists draw what some call a radical conclusion, at least for New Jersey: let nature take its course.
The report, which was released this fall, calls for a major shift in policy, from defending and rebuilding coastal beaches and property in high-hazard areas to removing storm-damaged buildings in those places and letting nature reclaim the beach. Although aligned with Federal thinking prompted by the devastating Mississippi River flooding in 1993, that philosophy has been considered heresy along the shore.
The study has touched off angry resolutions in town halls and in the State Legislature. Businessmen and politicians shudder at the thought of eroded beaches exposing billions of dollars in ocean-front investment -- from the gaudiest Atlantic City casinos to the tiniest beach bungalows -- to the wrath of the sea. They denounce the draft as suicidal strategy: abandonment of the shore and a "blueprint for dismantling the great heritage" of shore resorts.
Environmentalists say that with the sea level rising, the impact of coastal storms will worsen by 2050, and oft-damaged buildings and roads should be sacrificed to nature both to improve personal safety and to reduce costs.
In the uproar, the state's Department of Environmental Protection has for now scrapped public meetings on the draft report. It stresses that the draft is only a possible ingredient in their revision of the state's 1981 coastal policy.
To environmentalists, the agency seems to be backpedaling. The findings in the report, by Norbert Psuty, director of the Institute of Marine and Coastal Sciences at Rutgers University, are not too far afield of goals the department outlined months ago. They include encouraging shore towns not to zone vulnerable areas for development and to consider carefully whether to rebuild structures destroyed by storms.
Since the 1993 Mississippi floods, the Federal Government has promoted the idea of abandoning property. In an attempt to save millions in future Federal flood insurance payouts and disaster relief costs, the Federal Emergency Management Agency has spent $192 million, primarily in the Midwest, to buy thousands of homes and build new ones for storm victims on higher, safer ground, among other measures.
Since 1978, 75 percent of the Federal flood insurance paid in New Jersey, $268 million of $360 million, has gone to property owners in the state's four coastal counties -- Monmouth, Ocean, Atlantic and Cape May -- most in towns along the Atlantic or on major bays. In Monmouth County alone, the Army Corps of Engineers is restoring 21 miles of beach at a cost of $226 million.
A year ago, New Jersey created a buyout program like the Federal Government's. With $30 million in voter-approved bonds, the program, Blue Acres, is intended to buy flood-prone property or storm-damaged homes along the coast or in the flood plains of the Passaic River and its tributaries in three northern counties. The land would then be dedicated to conservation or recreation.
Although the start-up money is modest and there have yet to be any transactions, the program is significant because it is the first buyout plan the state's environmental department has endorsed.
Dr. Psuty's report also urges buying out property owners. His report's basic premise is that the sea level is rising about 16 inches a century. He contends that broadening beaches by pumping sand from the ocean bottom and rebuilding dunes will not provide adequate protection against intense storms in high-hazard areas.
Because of the rising sea level, he said, storms like the worst ones of the last half century would produce surges at least a foot higher by 2050. "Water will reach into places it never reached before," he said.
He proposes that planning in high-hazard areas include buying damaged property, moving residents out, banning new development, relocating roads, sewer lines and other components of the infrastructure, and ending beach-rebuilding projects in areas with high rates of erosion.
Although the report does not pinpoint any high-hazard areas, Dr. Psuty noted that the Corps of Engineers found in 1971 that 82 percent of the 127-mile shoreline was experiencing critical erosion, 9 percent was eroding but not critically, and 9 percent was stable. Monmouth and Ocean counties have been particularly prone to storm damage.
North Carolina has already adopted the kinds of regulations Dr. Psuty is proposing for New Jersey, including a 10-year-old regulation limiting reconstruction of storm-damaged coastal homes. Under the regulation, up to 800 beach houses heavily damaged by Hurricane Fran on Sept. 5 may not be able to be rebuilt.
The Jersey Shore Partnership, which includes local government officials, banks and utility companies, is leading the protest against Dr. Psuty. It has condemned the draft as "sky is falling" philosophy and urges rejecting the idea of not rebuilding eroded beaches.
"We just can't walk away," said S. Thomas Gagliano, a former state senator who helped form the partnership and now heads it. "And we can't send out alarms to banks and insurance and investment companies that the shore is a high-hazard area and don't come here. We don't want to frighten people or infringe on property rights or make beachgoers feel unsafe. Rutgers's attitude is we must retreat and having beachfront property is a liability and you ought to move away."
Mr. Gagliano said that the report ignored quality-of-life issues and overemphasized the rising sea level. "I don't know if that's really important to generations of people," he said. "It's only inches in a century."
The partnership, he said, endorses the Blue Acres program, and agrees that owners of repeatedly damaged buildings should have the option of selling to the state. But the partnership, he said, wants individual properties pinpointed for buyouts, while the report sends out signals about a broader "attitude against rebuilding."
In Harvey Cedars, a sliver of a resort on Long Beach Island, squeezed between the ocean and Barnegat Bay, some owners say they are not averse to selling storm-damaged homes if they can recover their investments. But Fred Rice, part owner of the Harvey Cedars Marina, said the Rutgers report was a "little late," given the billions invested in the shore decades ago.
The value of property here far exceeds that in the Mississippi flood plains, with many tiny lots starting at $400,000, Mr. Rice said. "How are they going to pay market value for that?" he said.
Dr. Psuty called talk about "retreat" an overreaction. "I never used the word," he said. He said his critics were thinking only of economics, development and property taxes, and ignoring reality.
"The hazards are going to increase," he said. "I don't know how you can turn your back on that. You have to come up with alternatives."
One shore community, Belmar, has done just that. After repeated poundings by hurricanes over the years, the town has responded by moving public structures out of harm's way: the southern quarter-mile of its frequently damaged 1.25-mile boardwalk can be dismantled as storms approach, and newly built bathhouses can be unhooked from sewer lines and wheeled away.
Mayor Kenneth Pringle of Belmar has parted company with some of his counterparts. He said that nonshore taxpayers were wearying of Federal spending to rebuild beaches and provide disaster relief for owners of damaged shore property.
"If someone wants to throw their money away, that's their prerogative," Mayor Pringle said. "But I don't know if we should subsidize expenditures close to the shore and automatically bail them out if they make a bad bet."

HEADLINE: Vote Yes on the Bond Act

 BODY:
In 1990 New Yorkers narrowly defeated a proposed bond act providing $2 billion in long-term capital to preserve open space and otherwise enhance New York State's environment. The voters will have a chance to rectify that error on Nov. 5. This year's ballot includes a proposal that would allow the state to sell $1.75 billion in bonds for many of the same projects that were left unfunded six years ago. New Yorkers, who have approved nine other environmental bond acts in this century alone, can honor their long tradition of stewardship by voting yes.
The 1990 proposal coincided with a gubernatorial race between Mario Cuomo and a weak Republican opponent. Assuming an easy Cuomo victory, many downstate residents who normally would have voted for the bond issue stayed away from the polls. The act was also heavily weighted toward the purchase of undeveloped land, inspiring exaggerated fears among upstate New Yorkers that Albany would seize their property. The upstaters turned out in droves to vote no. 
 This year's act would spread the money over a range of projects aimed at cleaner air and water. The bulk of it, $1.1 billion, would be spent on protecting lakes, rivers, seashores and drinking water. This sum includes $150 million for land acquisition, less than necessary but more than is now available. The balance would be spent on urgent solid-waste projects, such as closing the Fresh Kills dump on Staten island; on cleaning up polluted industrial sites, and on clean-air programs, including a project to replace coal-fired boilers in New York City schools.
The most important difference this time around is Gov. George Pataki's involvement. The bond act is an obvious way to burnish his credentials on environmental issues. But whatever his motives, he has traveled tirelessly across the state in behalf of the proposal and has won over many adversaries, including the unions, to his cause.
The act faces only two real dangers. One is voter indifference, which the Governor and his allies are working hard to prevent. The other is the argument -- forcefully advanced by Michael Bragman, the State Assembly's majority leader -- that the state cannot afford any more debt. Mr. Bragman notes that New York has a terrible credit rating and says that pay-as-you-go financing is a more responsible course.
These are serious but incomplete arguments. A lot of important projects -- Fresh Kills, for example, or the dozen or so sewage treatment plants necessary to help rescue Long Island Sound -- simply cannot await piecemeal funding. Second, there is no guarantee that future legislatures will approve annual appropriations for environmental purposes. Finally, problems ignored now are sure to become more complicated and costly later on. New York City's Independent Budget Office says that when inflation is taken into account, pay-as-you-go financing of the same projects covered by the bond act would not be any cheaper.
For these and other reasons, the Clean Water/ Clean Air Bond Act is a sound economic investment. It is also a wise investment in the state's environment, one that future generations will surely applaud.

HEADLINE: The New Face of Europe's Far Right

 BODY:
Austria's far-right Freedom Party continued its troubling electoral climb in voting earlier this month. Confounding predictions that it had reached the natural limits of its support, the Freedom Party pulled within striking distance of the country's two mainstream parties in elections for the European Parliament and did almost as well in Vienna's municipal elections. If it makes further gains in the next parliamentary election, the party may get a chance to form a government.
The far right's resurgence is scarcely limited to Austria, though nowhere else has it come quite so far. In France, Jean-Marie Le Pen's anti-immigrant National Front has been a major political factor for well over a decade and has recently gained strength. In Italy a leader of the old neo-Fascist movement, Gianfranco Fini, has become a major national figure after cleansing his party of some of its most objectionable elements. 
 In Austria the Freedom Party's leader, Jorg Haider, has expressed admiration for veterans of the Nazi SS. His father was an active Nazi. Since World War II a party with such a benign view of Nazism has not come so close to power in Europe.
The 15 countries of the European Union, already coping with high unemployment and immigration, have begun to prune the benefits of the postwar welfare state to meet budget targets for a single European currency. France has sought economies in health-care benefits, Germany has adopted a law allowing reductions in sick pay, and Italy's austere new budget includes pension and health-care cuts. That has fueled a backlash, particularly among anxious working-class voters, with the far right reaping most of the protest votes.
But backlash is not the whole story. Unemployment, in fact, is scarcely a factor in Austria. While most countries are reluctant to acknowledge it, Fascist ideology is a deep-rooted historical strain in European politics.
The wellsprings of Fascist support are typically anxiety about crime, social strife and foreigners and a feeling that liberal democracy is corrosive of national identity. In Austria, Mr. Haider has combined the appeal of youthful athleticism, populist immigrant-bashing and symbolic gestures toward Austria's past Nazi sympathies.
European parties of the center-left and center-right need to sharpen their own appeals to the voters who used to support them but are now streaming to the parties of the far right. In particular, they should reconsider their rush to create a single currency by the end of this decade. That goal, which has little appeal to voters, has forced parties to raise taxes and cut benefits without regard to economic cycles and political consequences.
A far-right triumph in Austria would have few direct consequences for the United States. But it would threaten the European Union's plans for closer economic integration and expansion eastward. It could also legitimize extreme-right-wing parties in neighboring countries like Germany, Italy and Hungary and set a negative example for the countries of the former Yugoslavia, where democratic traditions barely exist.
Far-right parties, as long as they play by the democratic rules, should be free to contest for votes and power. Mainstream parties need to meet their growing challenge by addressing the voters' anxieties that are fueling the rightist surge.

HEADLINE: Lenasia Township Journal;
Learning to Rebuild South Africa, Brick by Brick

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: LENASIA TOWNSHIP, South Africa, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Isaac Makoko is building a brick wall. If it isn't straight, he will have to tear it down and begin again. If he gets it right, he has the pleasure of watching the next trainee dismantle it. It's easy -- his mortar is actually mud.
In this impoverished township south of Johannesburg, next to a squatter camp and housed in what used to be the workers' dormitories of a brickyard, is the Union Building Trades Project, a trade school founded with a $4.2 million grant from the United States Agency for International Development and run by a bricklayer from Ogden, Utah, who works for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. 
 If South Africa is ever to make good on its promise to build millions of new houses, schools like this are going to have to pour out new carpenters, masons, electricians and welders.
"The Clay Brick Association told me the country's going to need 10,000 bricklayers a year if the Reconstruction and Development Program is ever going to take off," said Bill Smith, the school's director. "We train 200 a year. It's a drop in the bucket."
There are about 80 other trade schools, of varying quality, in South Africa, he said. But this is the only one that specializes in taking unemployed men from black and mixed-race townships. It gives them 12 weeks of training in a trade -- enough to get them started up the ladder from minimum-wage apprentice to top-wage artisan.
For example, "there are about 40 skills on the bricklayer's test, from laying a straight line up to building an arch," Mr. Smith said. "By the time they graduate from here, they should be able to build a wall and a column, use a plumb, maybe read a blueprint." An illiterate worker will at least learn to read a tape measure and a "Danger" sign and to total his weekly pay to be sure he was not cheated.
The school emphasizes real-world discipline. Be late three times and you're out. No sitting down. No hard hats off. Lose a tool and you buy its replacement. One locker in the tile classroom has a scrawled warning: "You steal my tools, I steal yours. Just be yourself, brother."
Before trainees graduate, they also get a quick course in running a contracting business. For some the leap is enormous and confusing. They are taught about submitting bids and managing cash flow. But they also get talks on dressing for success and on being ready to look white businessmen in the eye -- in many African cultures, meeting a gaze directly is a sign of disrespect, not honesty.
Mr. Makoko, 28, said he had a 12th-grade education, but had never had a job. "I knew nothing about how to lay bricks and mortar," he said. "Since I'm here, I've got an advantage when I look for a job."
Isaac Manda, 41, said he was once a quality inspector in a cough drop factory, but it moved to Cape Town. "I lost my home ... I lost quite a lot of things," he said quietly, his eyes fixed on the tile he was sanding smooth. "But now I hope to recover it."
Although his family is in Soweto, a 10-minute drive away, he lives in the school's dormitories all week. "We have transport problems in Soweto," he said. "I don't want to disappoint. If I am late, I'll have a fight, and I don't want to fight because they treat me well."
He dreams of having his own business, but the immensity of the obstacles becomes clear as he describes going to a trade fair and seeing a spirit level he coveted -- just one of about 20 tools a tile-and-plaster worker needs. "It could measure degrees," he said admiringly. "If you wanted to make a floor slope five degrees so water would flow down, it would make your job easier. But the problem was, it cost 1,260 rand."
When he graduates, he said, he hopes to make 3,000 rand a month -- about $670. He's optimistic. The average employed graduate makes about $250. About half the trainees find work, usually at large construction comoanies like Grinaker or Stocks & Stocks.
The big success story is Chandler Naick of Lenasia. He spoke when Vice President Al Gore visited the school last December and, with the salesmanship of a recruiting brochure, reported: "Two years ago, I was unemployed. I came here and learned plumbing. I'm working at the moment. I have 200 people under me. I drive a Mercedes."
Why you? he was asked afterward. "I think I was one of the lucky ones," he replied. "And maybe I was more determined."
The school is scheduled to be turned over to South African leadership in December. But it is running into difficulties related to union politics here, which are often militant, messy and parochial.
In another legacy of apartheid, there are several unions in each industry, usually one for skilled white workers and several for unskilled black workers, each affiliated with a different political party. That is the case in the building trades, and the competing black unions affiliated with the school have not been able to agree on a replacement for Mr. Smith.
They also picked the school's last crop of instructors, some of whom were better connected than they were skilled, Mr. Smith said, and five of the eight teachers flunked their accreditation exams in January.
Meanwhile, the industry, more tied to the white unions, suddenly imposed a $22 fee on all new, previously unemployed apprentices. The school is paying the fee for its graduates, but it is another bite in an already tight budget. "I'd rather spend the money on bricks," Mr. Smith said.
He seems confident the problems can be solved. He last did this kind of work in El Salvador. There, "the unions and the contractors were literally killing each other," he said. "But after five years, we got them to sit down at a table and agree that training was a good thing for everybody."

HEADLINE: Discrimination May Affect Risk of High Blood Pressure in Blacks

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The risk of high blood pressure among blacks appears to be affected by experiences with racial discrimination and whether people challenge unfair treatment, researchers said today.
The researchers, from the Harvard School of Public Health in Boston and the Kaiser Foundation Research Institute of Oakland, Calif., said a study of more than 4,000 men and women indicated that racial discrimination and reactions to it made a substantial contribution to the differences in blood pressure between blacks and whites. 
 In general, black professionals who are conscious of instances of discrimination and who challenge unjust or unequal treatment appear to be at lower risk of elevated blood pressure than black working class men and women who may be less aware of discriminatory acts and less likely to challenge them, the researchers said.
The scientists said their study, published in the October issue of The American Journal of Public Health, was the first to examine the relationship between higher blood pressure and experiences with racial discrimination as they relate to the social class and sex of blacks.
Blacks suffer from high blood pressure, or hypertension, at about twice the rate of whites. Several smaller studies have linked stress and the reaction to racism as an apparent added risk factor of hypertension, along with other environmental reasons like diet, excess salt intake, lack of exercise and being overweight.
Blacks also have a genetic predisposition to the condition, which can lead to stroke, heart disease, organ damage and other problems.
Dr. Nancy Krieger of Harvard, the principal researcher for the study, said scientists examining health issues typically treated race as only a biological attribute and did not examine the health consequences of racial experiences and reactions.
"These results, which are preliminary, say that race and discrimination have a bearing on blood pressure," Dr. Krieger said in an interview. "Now we have to find out what it is."
The study involved 831 black men, 1,143 black women, 1,006 white men and 1,106 white women aged 25 to 37 years old. In this relatively young group, part of a larger heart disease study, few had developed overt, treatable high blood pressure.
Generally, the study found that working class blacks who reported experiencing two or more discriminatory instances -- when looking for a job or housing, for example -- had higher normal blood pressure than their white counterparts or professional blacks. The report speculated that the greater social and economic resources of black professionals might contribute to a willingness to point out discrimination and challenge it.
Among working class participants, the study suggested, higher blood pressure may be attributable to suppressed or internalized responses to racial discrimination.
The study noted, however, that the data were not uniform for every group of blacks. For example, groups of black men who reported that they had not experienced racial discrimination in the situations outlined in the study differed from the general trend. Working class black men reporting no discrimination, and who said they accepted unfair treatment unrelated to race, had higher blood pressure than working class black men who challenged unfair treatment and had experienced one or two instances of discrimination.
In addition, professional black men who said they had not been discriminated against, but who said they typically challenged any unfair situations, had blood pressure levels at or below levels seen in white professionals, the study said.
Dr. Krieger said these seemingly atypical results could not be easily explained. Some research suggests, she said, that some people who have experienced discrimination find it hard to admit, even to themselves. A study conducted in England among blacks, she said, found that individuals who initially reported no experience with racial discrimination acknowledged the experiences when asked more probing questions.
"We can't answer all of the questions with this study, but what we can say is that racial prejudice and discrimination does affect the blood pressure of blacks in different ways and should be studied in more detail," Dr. Krieger said.
Dr. Michael J. Klag, a hypertension expert at Johns Hopkins University Medical School who did an earlier study showing that stress among blacks contributed to higher blood pressure, said the new study was important because it spotlighted issues that have gotten too little attention.
"This study is well done and has produced a lot of data that needs to be discussed," Dr. Klag said in an interview. "There are very few studies like this and that's been a problem."
He said some of the results, like those involving black participants who claimed not to have suffered discrimination, were puzzling. "This study doesn't give clear-cut answers to every question, which is why we need more work like this," he said.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;
Clinton Praises Welfare Bill In a Conservative Region

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Oct. 23

 BODY:
In the continuing battle for the nation's fourth-largest state, President Clinton touted his welfare policies in this conservative region of Florida today, a morning after wooing Cuban-Americans at a late-night visit to Miami's Little Havana.
On a glorious sunny day, with American flags and palm trees whipping in a breeze and a green and orange sign behind him proclaiming "Welfare to work, a new beginning," Mr. Clinton promoted his signing of a Republican-originated bill that sets stringent time limits on welfare benefits. 
 "I ran for office in 1992," Mr. Clinton said, "and I told you here in Daytona that I would work to end welfare as we know it and to convert it to a system that promotes independence, good parenting, and successful work. And that's exactly what we're doing."
When he announced this past summer that he would sign the welfare measure, Mr. Clinton called the bill flawed and said he particularly objected to provisions limiting assistance to legal immigrants and to restrictions on food stamps.
But at the rally today the President mentioned none of his reservations. He described the law as one that "says the national Government will continue to guarantee to poor families health care and food for the children and if they go to work more for child care than ever."
The President also pointed to a report released today by the Health and Human Services Department showing that more than $1 billion in delinquent child support payments was withheld from Federal income tax refunds in 1995.
"We're going to keep going until we raise child support more and more and more," he said, noting that this money was coming from "parents, not from the taxpayers."
Mr. Clinton narrowly lost Florida in 1992 and, according to public opinion polls, he and Bob Dole are in a dead heat. The state has been saturated with millions of dollars in campaign advertisements, and Douglas Sosnik, the White House political director, said he expected the Clinton television advertising to continue. He said the President would probably return to Florida before the election.
Florida last supported a Democratic Presidential candidate in 1976, and Mr. Clinton's presence here so close to Election Day illustrates how far he is reaching into states normally considered a secure part of the Republican base. In fact, Mr. Clinton will finish out this week not in the normal battleground states of the industrial Midwest but in Alabama, Louisiana and Georgia.
Mr. Clinton's aides believe several factors have made the President competitive here. The Democrats have been able to make inroads into Florida's large population of retirees by capitalizing on the Republican budget plan last year to slow the growth of Medicare spending by $270 billion over seven years.
In addition, the Democrats say Republican positions on immigration and in favor of English as the nation's official language have hurt in the traditionally Republican Cuban-American community. A recent Miami Herald poll found that 41 percent of Florida's Cuban-Americans plan to vote for Mr. Clinton, compared with 58 percent for Mr. Dole. That is double what Mr. Clinton won in 1992, and Mr. Sosnik said it was generally believed that Mr. Clinton could win the state if he held on to 30 percent of the Cuban vote.
Late Tuesday night -- after appearing at fund-raising events that collected $2 million for Florida Democrats -- Mr. Clinton turned up at the Versailles, a Cuban restaurant in the heart of Little Havana, to eat dessert with 20 prominent Cuban-Americans. Outside the restaurant Clinton and Dole supporters waged a shouting match, one group shouting "Viva Dole" and the other countering "Dole no, Clinton si."
Earlier that day, the Treasury Department announced that it was granting special licenses to allow direct flights to Cuba to bring aid to victims of Hurricane Lili.
Tonight, Mr. Clinton returned to Washington for the third major fund-raising event in a week, bringing the total to an expected $15 million, primarily for Democratic Congressional candidates.

Mr. Gore blamed the Republicans for past economic problems and said the Clinton Administration was "making progress." (James Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Republican Candidate Woos Business as Democrat Speaks on Drunken Driving;
Torricelli Addresses Cuban-Americans On Union City Visit

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Representative Robert G. Torricelli criticized his Republican opponent in the United States Senate race today for failing to back a Federal law against drunken driving by teen-agers and also campaigned in New Jersey's large Cuban-American community, making an appearance with an influential Miami-based exile leader who has drawn criticism for intimidating opponents.
In a brief news conference at the Union Township Police Station, Mr. Torricelli accused Representative Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican candidate, of being an extremist for voting against a 1995 law that cut Federal highway subsidies for states that did not completely prohibit teen-agers from driving after drinking alcohol. 
 "In the state of New Jersey last year, 112 teen-agers lost their lives driving after consuming alcohol," Mr. Torricelli said.
Polls show that the two candidates are running even in the ferocious, mud-slinging contest to succeed Senator Bill Bradley, a Democrat.
Mr. Torricelli appeared with Representative Nita M. Lowey, the Democrat from Westchester who was the author of the legislation. "Anyone who would vote against stronger drunk driving laws is just too extreme for New Jersey," she said. "We just have to get tougher on drunk driving. It is a matter of life and death."
The Zimmer campaign said that the Congressman voted against the Federal law because New Jersey had already passed a 1992 state law banning teen-agers from driving if their blood alcohol level was greater than 0.01 percent. (Although the legal age for purchasing alcohol in New Jersey is 21, it is not illegal to drink liquor at home.)
"Dick Zimmer thinks New Jersey is capable of making its own decisions and does not need the Federal Government telling it what to do," said David Karvelas, communications director of the Zimmer campaign.
Mr. Torricelli said one difference between him and his opponent is their views of the role of the Federal Government in creating policies for all the states.
"The Federal Government having these uniform mandatory zero tolerance standards is an appropriate role of the Government," Mr. Torricelli said.
Earlier in Union City, Mr. Torricelli attended a lunch at Mi Bandera Restaurant with Jorge Mas Canosa, a Florida construction magnate considered one of the most prominent leaders in the Cuban exile community. In a little over a decade, Mr. Mas, a Republican, has used his personal fortune and a political action committee to donate more than $1 million to Congressional and Presidential candidates who support his hostile, uncompromising approach toward Fidel Castro.
"The fight is not over until there is an election in Cuba, Fidel Castro is a bad memory and the people in Cuba are free," a campaign statement quoted Mr Torricelli as saying at the lunch for 75 people.
New Jersey's Cuban-American population of 87,000 is one of the largest in the United States outside Florida. Mr. Torricelli sponsored the 1992 Cuban Democracy Act, which extended the United States economic embargo and imposed penalties on foreign subsidiaries of American companies trading with Cuba. He also helped write this year's Helms-Burton Act, which seeks to punish foreign companies that use factories or other property confiscated from Americans after the Cuban revolution.
"As you were there when we needed you, we are here for you in your time of need," Mr. Mas said, according to a statement released by the Torricelli campaign. "Every Cuban-American would be fulfilling their ideals and their values by casting their vote for Bob Torricelli."
The Zimmer campaign played down the endorsement from the influential Cuban, saying Mr. Zimmer was a strong supporter of strengthening the embargo, of preventing Cuba from getting aid funds from institutions like the World Bank and of reversing the Clinton administration policy of returning Cuban boat people.
"The Cubans in New Jersey don't need to be told who to vote for, they know who to vote for by virtue of Dick's stronger record, not just on Cuban issues but on mainstream matters like lower taxes," Mr. Karvelas said.
Early campaign records show $2,000 in donations from the Mas family to Mr. Torricelli's campaign.
Mr. Mas, often seen as seeking to make himself Cuba's leader, has attracted criticism from the human rights group Human Rights Watch/ Americas for attempting to silence and intimidate opponents. A study published in 1993 by the Strategic Studies Institute of the Army War College also called Mr. Mas intolerant and given to delivering "speeches exuding hatred and intransigence."
The Torricelli campaign rejected any criticism of Mr. Mas. "Mr. Mas Canosa is a leader in the Cuban community and shares Mr. Torricelli's commitment to a free and democratic Cuba," said Josh Isay, a campaign spokesman.
