HEADLINE: Destitute Ex-Contras Demand U.S. Aid

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: QUILALI, Nicaragua

 BODY:
After the leftist Sandinista Government was voted out of office in 1990, more of the American-backed anti-Sandinista fighters known as contras settled here than in any other place in Nicaragua. Most are destitute, and many are crippled -- their limbs, sight or overall health destroyed by a decade of civil war.
Now, however, these peasant soldiers, who fought the Sandinistas with the backing of the Reagan Administration, think they have found a way to ease their hardship. Encouraged by Washington's recent payment of $20 million to Vietnamese commandos who worked as American agents three decades ago, the Nicaraguans are seeking an indemnity from the United States. 
 "They gave us millions to fight, but once we were disarmed and demobilized, we were abandoned and forgotten," said Alex Talavera, a leader of the hundreds of former contras in this isolated mountain community near the Honduran border. "Our wounded, crippled, hungry and orphaned are many, and we believe the United States has a moral obligation to help them."
The idea has been received coolly by the Clinton Administration.
According to a recent study conducted for the International Society for Human Rights, a German group that has spoken out on behalf of former combatants in Russia and Bosnia, "over 20,000 former members of the Nicaraguan resistance and their families live in abject poverty" in northern Nicaragua.
Those who work with the former contras have expressed special concern about the 2,000 crippled by their combat injuries.
"This is such a poor country that regardless of political affiliations, this situation can only be regarded as a tragedy," said Sergio Caramagna, director of the Organization of American States mission here. "To be blind, an amputee or in a wheelchair is difficult enough in Managua, but out in the countryside it is nearly impossible."
Felipe Lumbi Garcia joined the contras in 1982. Just before the war's end in 1990 he stepped on a mine, which left him blind, deaf in his left ear and with severe injuries to his limbs. He lives on a disabled veteran's pension of about $29 a month, larger than normal because he has three children, but he argues that he and his comrades deserve more.
"The United States had a hand in all of the destruction that went on around here," he said. "So it would be ideal if they helped us in the reconstruction."
[Nicaragua's President-elect, Arnoldo Aleman, who defeated Daniel Ortega Saavedra of the Sandinista Front in the election on Sunday, has praised the contras for "helping deliver us from the dark night" of Sandinista rule. But he has also said his top economic priority is "to buy peace" by resolving land disputes from the 1980's, and has not promised any special aid to the contras.]
Former contras plan to take their cause to Congress, which they regard as more sympathetic now.
In June Congress approved a bill authorizing a $20 million payment to 500 former South Vietnamese commandoes trained by the Central Intelligence Agency, many of whom had been captured and jailed after infiltrating into North Vietnam in the 1960's. President Clinton signed the bill into law.
"We are very optimistic," said Uriel Rodriguez, a leader of a veterans' organization here. "Our demand is just and legal, and many Congressmen were our friends and sympathized with our movement."
The Clinton Administration, however, has dismissed the contra demand as lacking merit. "The Department of State is not aware of any basis for such claims for compensation," the United States Embassy in Managua said this summer.
One Government official in Washington said that agreeing to any compensation would set a dangerous precedent. Other groups that have collaborated with the C.I.A., ranging from veterans of the Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba in 1961 to Iraqi Kurds, might also be tempted to seek restitution if the contras' case were successful, he argued.
The contras' demand has also been greeted with reservations by many who championed their cause in the 1980's. Elliott Abrams, who was Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs at the height of the war, noted that the Nicaraguan Government has already received more than $2 billion from the United States, some of it intended to aid the former guerrillas.
"I think we owe a debt to these former allies, and I don't think we have discharged that debt," Mr. Abrams, president of the Nicaraguan Resistance Education Foundation, a charitable group that aids former Contras, said in a telephone interview from Washington. "But there are ways of doing it that I think are sensible and morally persuasive, and others that are not."
Contra leaders here say little of the American aid has reached them. Only a lump sum paid directly to former contras and administered by them can make the situation right, they argue.
"We agree that the United States does have a special responsibility to help the ex-resistance, but I can't tell you that's going to lead to writing them a check," said Dan Fisk, an aide to Senator Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. "Their focus should be on Managua in obtaining compensation.
"In our view the United States did not create the contras. They were indigenous groups that came together and proceeded to take up arms against Sandinista policies, not mercenaries of the United States. It seems to me that as part of their legacy, they do not want to be known as that."
But Stephanie Murphy, a Miami immigration lawyer who has represented many former contras seeking legal residence in the United States, rejected those arguments, saying Washington bears "more than a moral responsibility for the devastation that has been left behind." Should Congress fail to approve compensation, she added, she is prepared to take the issue to court.
"The arguments are the same as Vietnam," Ms. Murphy said in a telephone interview from Miami. "It was an overt war, the C.I.A. was involved, and when it got what it wanted out of these people, they were left in the lurch, to their great hardship and detriment."
Some former contra commanders are now American citizens and live in the United States, which former combatants still living here believe could help strengthen their case. "If they have to, they could file a class action suit in the name of all the combatants," said Mr. Rodriguez, of the veterans' association.
In the meantime, many former contras here continue to wait, hoping for the best but growing more and more bitter. Talk of programs to teach them a new livelihood, like ceramics or carpentry, has amounted to little, and promises that they will receive their own houses and plots of land to cultivate have been slow to materialize.
"The only support we get comes from our own families," said Mr. Lumbi, the crippled veteran. "The big shots, including many of the commanders, are living in big mansions. But we are just peasants, and we have been forgotten."

HEADLINE: Two Sides List Views in Fight Over Cable TV

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Continuing a fight over whether Rupert Murdoch's news channel will be seen in much of New York City, the Giuliani administration and Time Warner issued dueling legal briefs yesterday to bolster their stances on the legality of the Mayor's plan to show the channel on a cable station run by the city.
Each side cited past practice at the five city-run cable stations, highlighting a point that legal experts have been making since the dispute over Mr. Murdoch's new Fox News Channel began last month: there are few precedents to offer guidance on who may be right. 
 At the center of the dispute is the role of the city-run stations, which are known as Crosswalks. The Mayor decided to place the new Fox channel on one of the Crosswalks channels after Time Warner, which serves 1.1 million customers in New York, rejected it, saying there was no room left on the cable system.
Federal law and the city's franchise agreement with Time Warner say that the administration can transmit governmental or educational programming on the stations, but it is not clear whether commercial programming is allowed.
A Federal judge, Denise Cote, is to weigh the legal papers before a hearing on the dispute that she is to conduct on Monday. Judge Cote temporarily blocked the city from transmitting the Murdoch channel on Crosswalks earlier this month after Time Warner went to court.
In their affidavits, administration officials emphasized that they had often transmitted commercial programming that was educational on the city-run stations, proving that there was nothing unusual about their proposal to help Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation. Among the commercial programs the officials cited were weekly spots on computers produced by Microsoft and featuring the company's products, they said.
"Time Warner has never challenged Crosswalks' carriage of these programs," said Elaine S. Reiss, general counsel for the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications, which oversees Crosswalks.
The city's legal papers also referred to contacts between the city and the News Corporation. For example, Fran Reiter, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, said that Roger Ailes, a former Republican political consultant who is now chairman of the Murdoch channel, called Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani late last month, asking for help.
Time Warner said in its affidavits that on at least two occasions, the city had turned down programming for Crosswalks because it was commercial in nature. The company said that those rejections showed that Mr. Giuliani was breaking past practice to help Mr. Murdoch.
Time Warner executives have maintained that the Mayor is helping Mr. Murdoch because he wants the political support of the powerful media magnate, who owns The New York Post and WNYW, Channel 5.
The two companies that Time Warner referred to were the Kaleidoscope Network, which produces shows for disabled people, and Gems International Television, a Hispanic programmer. In interviews, officials of both companies supported the Time Warner contentions.
"They told me that they liked the service, but that because we were commercial, they could not put it on," Dr. Bill Nichols, the president of Kaleidoscope, said of the Crosswalks officials.
Sunny Mindel, a spokeswoman for the telecommunications department, declined to comment on the accusation, saying the agency did not discuss pending legal matters.

HEADLINE: Zoning Plan for Warehouse-Style Stores Is Approved and Sent to Council in Close Vote

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
A divided City Planning Commission approved Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal to allow sprawling warehouse-style stores in manufacturing areas around the city yesterday. It rejected pleas that neighborhoods should have a larger voice in whether an individual store is appropriate for their area.
Acknowledging the concerns of many community groups about increased traffic near residential areas, the commission did agree to change the original proposal to allow local officials to review the traffic plan for a store. Residents could help to determine which street would be the best entrance for a 500-car parking lot, for example. 
 But the proposal would allow developers to build many stores in designated manufacturing areas "as of right," which means that the public hearing process would not be required and neighborhood views not solicited.
The unusually close 8-to-5 vote on the commission, which has a majority of Giuliani appointees, presages an intense fight ahead in the City Council, which must approve or reject the proposal within 65 days. Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the Council, said he had not yet decided how he will vote, but many Council members have expressed opposition.
All seven of the Mayor's appointees to the Planning Commission voted in favor of the megastores yesterday, as did the appointee of Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island Borough President.
But hinting at the political battle ahead, the appointees of all of the other borough presidents and that of the Public Advocate voted no, reflecting the opposition to the stores that has grown in neighborhoods around the city.
Of the city's 36 community boards, 21 have recommended a no vote, as have all 5 borough boards.
Commission members on both sides of the issue said that yesterday's vote was one of the most important they would cast. The chairman, Joseph B. Rose, called it "a historic moment in the city's planning."
Proponents said the rezoning would keep shoppers in the city and out of the suburbs, improving the city's economy and lowering prices. Opponents said the huge stores were bad neighbors and needed stricter controls to limit their impact.
The proposal would permit up to 57 of the stores to be built around the city in light and medium manufacturing zones, many of which are now vacant. In areas where streets are wide, developers would not need special permits to build stores as large as 200,000 square feet, which is a bit more than the size of four football fields. Areas with narrow streets could have stores with 20,000 square feet and would require a special permit and a land-use hearing.
Most of the new developments would probably be food, clothing and department stores, because large hardware and toy stores are already allowed.
The issue of superstores has already become politicized, with several of Mr. Giuliani's expected opponents in next year's mayoral race taking firm stands alongside the small businesses and neighborhood organizations that are against the administration's plan. Several City Council members said they expected the final plan to be a compromise that permits more public involvement and Council regulation of individual stores than the Giuliani administration favors.
Mr. Rose said he thought Council members would come to understand the merits of the proposal if they cast aside political considerations. He said the rezoning plan would allow greater review of large hardware stores like Home Depot than is now permitted, and would impose stricter design requirements to screen stores from nearby homes. Other proponents on the commission cast the decision in economic terms.
"We have a job crisis in this city, and I think the big-box stores can bring jobs to this city," said Victor G. Alicea, the vice chairman of the panel. Alexander Garvin, another mayoral appointee, said many poor residents had complained in public hearings that they were forced to shop in small groceries with small selections and high prices.
"The poor pay more in New York, because they can't go to these stores, which are outside the city of New York, by and large," said Mr. Garvin, an architect and longtime urban planner who served as deputy housing commissioner in the Beame administration. "And who's responsible for this discrimination? The zoning ordinance, because there are not enough sites in New York for big-box retailers."
Opponents of the plan generally agreed that the city needs more large stores to keep shoppers from traveling to the suburbs, but said they could not vote for a plan that excludes residents from the review process.
"While I agree that the current process must be reformed, I do not believe that the total exclusion of the community from the process is right," said Irwin G. Cantor, the appointee of the Queens Borough President, Claire Shulman. "The community knows its neighborhoods, its streets, its storekeepers, its needs.
"It is my view that the community has a right to be heard. It should know more about which specific sites are candidates for large retail, and it should have the right to comment upon such critical impositions in its neighborhood."

LENGTH: 752 words

HEADLINE: Pataki Vetoes Bill That Would Let Solar Panels Earn Credits on Energy Bills

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Siding with the state's electricity industry, Gov. George E. Pataki has vetoed legislation that would have allowed homeowners with solar panels on their roofs to send power back to their utility company and get credit on their electric bills.
In a statement today, the Governor said he supported the intent of the bill but was concerned about what he called inadequate safety standards in the measure. 
 But the veto, done on Friday and announced today, angered environmentalists, who regarded the bill as a key step toward encouraging New Yorkers to use a safer and cleaner form of energy. They dismissed Mr. Pataki's questions about safety as simply an excuse to kill a measure that utility companies had opposed for financial reasons.
Mr. Pataki ordered his staff to submit a new bill, saying that he would attempt to build consensus on the issue between the utility industry and the environmental community.
"This veto should not be viewed by solar advocates as an unfavorable commentary on the solar industry," the Governor said. "I believe solar power should be an important and larger component of our energy supply."
The veto illustrates the quandary the Governor faces as he tries to bolster his image as a friend of the environment without alienating powerful business organizations and his other traditional Republican supporters.
He has already angered conservative anti-tax groups over his decision to add to the state's debt by lobbying on behalf of a $1.75 billion bond act to pay for environmental cleanup projects across the state.
The bill vetoed by the Governor today would have allowed owners of single-family homes to install solar cells on their rooftops and run their electric meters backward to send spare electricity back to their utility companies. Thus the homeowners could have seen their electric bills drop to zero or even register a credit with their utility company.
Only 30,000 homeowners would have been allowed to take advantage of the measure, which would have limited the amount of power produced by households to no more than one-tenth of one percent of New York's total power supply. Still, energy experts argued that the measure could lure a solar-cell manufacturer to the state, cut pollution and help avert blackouts during peak hours of power use.
But the state's electric industry had been pressuring the Governor not to sign the bill. They argued that it would unfairly benefit wealthier homeowners who are able to invest the $10,000 to $30,000 it costs to install such a system, which typically is used to supplement power bought from a utility company.
They also said it would in effect force utilities to buy solar-generated power at the same retail price that they charge their customers. As a result, they said, other customers would have to absorb the cost of buying the premium-priced power.
Today, industry executives praised the Mr. Pataki's veto. "That bill was a mistake," said Howard Shapiro, president of the Energy Association of New York, a lobbying group for the state's power producers. "It would have been a Government imposed burden on ratepayer."
Still, the Governor said his main problem with the bill was that it did not provide adequate guidelines for the installation, testing and monitoring of the solar-energy systems -- an argument that was also made by the utility industry but rejected by environmentalists and other experts.
Mr. Pataki said that this posed a grave threat to utility workers who could, for example, be injured while repairing downed power lines that suddenly receive a burst of electricity from a solar cell mounted on someone's home.
"I am not convinced that this bill completely addresses the paramount issue of safety for those who would be required to repair these systems after a power outage," he said. "Despite this bill's admirable purpose and my support generally for renewable energy sources, I cannot sign this legislation in light of the safety concerns."
But environmentalists said the Governor had seized on this issue as a pretext to veto the legislation. They noted that the safety standards in the bill are nationally recognized and are in fact established by the National Electrical Code and the Underwriters Laboratories.
"I think there was a lot of pressure from the utility industry and he bowed to that pressure," said Larry Shapiro, an environmental specialist with the New York Public Interest Research Group. "The safety argument was bogus."
Still, environmentalists and one of the bill's sponsors, Steven Englebright, a Democrat from Long Island, said they would work to address the Governor's concerns and resubmit the legislation.
"There's no safety issue," said Ashok Gupta, a Manhattan-based economist with the Natural Resources Defense Council and an author of the legislation. "But to the extent that there is the perception of a safety issue, we will address it and get this bill passed and signed."

HEADLINE: History Puts a Sharp Focus on Afghans' Plight

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your reporting from remote areas of Afghanistan has been outstanding. An Oct. 22 news article notes that Ahmad Shah Massoud, the leader of a force seeking to regain control of the country from the Muslim force known as the Taliban, was "one of the better educated of the guerrilla commanders who drove Soviet forces from Afghanistan." While accurate, this is an understatement. 
 Mr. Massoud is an engineer. When I visited Pakistan in 1989, I met with several teams of Afghan engineers engaged in rebuilding areas of their country that had been liberated from the Soviet forces. I reviewed their plans in an effort to advise the United States Agency for International Development on assistance for reconstruction in Afghanistan.
As I examined the drawings for repair and replacement of roads, bridges, hospitals, schools and mosques, I noted that each drawing had received final approval from Mr. Massoud. While engaged as a battlefield commander and military strategist, Mr. Massoud was also a leader in establishing priorities and programs for his country's rebirth.
In addition, your reporting on the oppression of women by the Taliban has brought this tyranny to the attention of the American public.
In 1965 Afghanistan shared the values of the United Nations on women's rights. Kabul University not only welcomed women students but also built a women's dormitory so that women could obtain higher education in all fields, including law and medicine.
It was five years later that women students appeared in my classroom in New Jersey. Seen in this historical perspective, oppression of women by the Taliban is even more poignant.
 
EDWARD A. FRIEDMAN
Hoboken, N.J., Oct. 22, 1996
 
The writer, a professor of management at Stevens Institute of Technology, was a visiting professor at Kabul University from 1965 to 1967.

HEADLINE: Woodstock: Old-Time New-Age Karma

BYLINE: By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
BACK in the 1980's, I was walking down a street in Woodstock when a Volkswagen microbus pulled over and the scraggly haired driver asked, "Can you tell me where the rock festival was?"
At the time, I was in Woodstock, England. 
 The Woodstock festival of 1969, and its 25th-anniversary sequel in 1994, didn't happen in Woodstock, N.Y., either. The first one was in White Lake, N.Y., 60 miles away in Sullivan County; the second one was closer to Woodstock, in the neighboring Ulster County town of Saugerties. Yet a hippie mythos still clings to Woodstock itself, where my wife and I recently spent a long weekend.
Tucked among bucolic and sometimes spectacular Catskill scenery, with a full-time population of 6,290 (as of the 1990 census), Woodstock is the counterculture's country retreat, where the upstate woodlands meet the New Age. It's a haven of hearth-baked bread, folk-rock on the local radio station (WDST, at 100.1 and 96.9 FM), art galleries, artisans and spiritual seekers. Under houses of worship, a Chamber of Commerce brochure lists not only the Dutch Reformed Church but also a Tibetan Buddhist monastery. Among the various "Welcome to Woodstock" stickers at local stores, one reads, "If you lived here, you'd be Om now."
Yet despite its legendary name and a century of experience as a tourist magnet, Woodstock remains a friendly, close-knit small town. There is no traffic light at Woodstock's main intersection, where Tinker Street meets Rock City Road, and the cluster of stores stretches just a few blocks.
On a recent Friday afternoon, before the weekend influx from New York City, Tinker Street was populated by women without makeup and men with ponytails. People in their 20's and people in their 50's all wore the ponchos and fringed buckskin, patched jeans and embroidered shirts of the international peasant-wear economy. Running shoes were the only sign of the 1990's. Still, the shoe store in the center of town featured Birkenstocks.
Woodstock drew utopian free thinkers long before the 1960's. During the 19th century, according to Alf Evers's comprehensive "Woodstock: History of an American Town" (Overlook Press, 1987; $39.50), it was an industrious (and none too environmentally conscious) hamlet, logging hemlock trees from the Catskill mountainsides and using the bark to tan leather.
In 1902, a wealthy Englishman, Ralph Radcliffe Whitehead, started an arts colony, Byrdcliffe. To realize the ideals of the Arts and Crafts movement, it would produce old-fashioned handmade goods and run a summer arts school. Handicrafts couldn't support Byrdcliffe, but painters, potters, musicians, weavers and actors had discovered Woodstock.
The Art Students League, based in Manhattan, opened a Woodstock summer school in 1906, and other groups of artists soon followed. The Maverick colony, just across the town line, drew social reformers, visual artists and performers and presented summer festivals from 1915 to 1931, the real Woodstock festivals. In 1921, factions of the Communist Party convened at the Overlook Mountain House hotel and united as the Communist Party of America. Through the 1920's, artists, theater people and the tourists who arrived to gawk at them kept Woodstock thriving.
Rockers arrived later, when Bob Dylan and the Band settled upstate in the late 1960's and recorded "Music From Big Pink" and "The Basement Tapes." Other musicians, including a jazz contingent, are still in the hills, descending to play rock at the Tinker Street Cafe or the Joyous Lake, the town's two rock clubs, or jazz at the intimate auditorium of the Kleinert/James Arts Center. Well-known bands like Phish record albums in the wooded privacy of Bearsville Studios.
We visited the Woodstock Historical Society, which displayed a newspaper clipping from 1929, headlined "Nude Bathing Parties Offend." An exhibition of paintings by Woodstock artists included a striking self-portrait from the early 1930's by Petra Cabot: a young woman with a modish black hat and a confident gaze. A woman with long white hair walked in and told the caretaker, "I must have that painting, so I can photograph it." It was Ms. Cabot, who smiled as she looked at her self-assured 21-year-old self. "Oh, we had some great times," she said.
Woodstock, we kept realizing, is a place unto itself. It is a town where the biggest, pushiest crowd we saw was the one that mobbed the biweekly Saturday-morning used-book sale at the library. We had been told about it by the proprietor of Readers' Quarry, a small but well-organized used bookstore. "If I see you there," she said, "I won't be able to talk. I'll be too busy."

Peace and Apples
One attraction during our weekend visit was the town's "harvest festival." Like other town fairs, it had a local apple farmer demonstrating an antique cider press. But being Woodstock, it also started with a "peace ceremony," a parade of schoolchildren with assorted national flags. A man walked by wearing a crystal the size of a dill pickle around his neck; a teen-ager had a saucepan for a hat. On the outdoor stage, the group Women Who Drum followed a Hebrew blessing with a Seneca peace prayer.
We picked up The Woodstock Journal, a weekly paper run by Ed Sanders that prints the local police blotter (with regular marijuana-possession arrests) and poetry along with muckraking. Mr. Sanders, now an author and historian, was a prime mover in the zoning laws that keep Woodstock green; in the 1960's, he founded the folk-rock provocateurs the Fugs, whose song title "Refuse to Be Burnt Out" provides the paper's watchwords.
The paper announced that it would celebrate a move to new offices with an exhibition of paintings by Alf Evers, whose book we had been consulting. The paintings are Depression-era scenes of a rural Woodstock and of Mr. Evers's travels; a label on a Bermuda landscape read, "Notice the pink sand." Mr. Evers, now in his 90's, and Mr. Sanders were surrounded by well-wishers at the opening. On the doorstep, a woman was exclaiming: "He's not just a writer! Everyone has multiple personalities!"
At Bread Alone, the Woodstock outlet for a bakery in nearby Boiceville, we could easily distinguish unhurried Woodstockers from the jostling weekenders who mobbed the place on Saturday morning. We tried the organic breakfast tea and substantial currant scones; on a return visit, we picked up a flourless chocolate torte, rich but not overly sweet. A sign in the bathroom read: "This note is sincerely addressed to the person stealing the posters off the bathroom walls. Please stop! If you have any regrets, you're forgiven. Enjoy the art and please don't take any more posters."
Down the block is Pieces of Mine, which sells stones and crystals; its advertisement promised consultations.
"What are you drawn to?" asked the woman at the counter. "What you are drawn to is what you need." We picked red tiger eye, jade, amethyst and turquoise. The woman smiled. "You've covered almost all seven chakras," she said. "You just need something yellow."
"I was just looking at the amber," my wife said.
"It looks like a higher power has directed you," the woman said. Quickly, she added: "I don't mean to say that you're not responsible for your decisions. It's your own higher power from within that has guided you."

All for the Spirit
Mirabai Books, one of the five bookstores in town, concentrates on spiritual and New Age books. One bookcase covers a full cycle: "Death and Dying," "Reincarnation" and "Channeling." We looked into Dharmaware, which sells Buddhist items. An employee with his dreadlocks looped into a topknot was busy moving merchandise between storefronts. "We're in a state of transformation," he said. Nearby was the Tibetan Emporium; as we walked in, the proprietor was chanting along with a CD of monks.
The emporium is run by the director of Karma Triyana Dharmachakra monastery, a traditional Tibetan Buddhist temple built in the 1980's. We drove up Meads Mountain Road to see the impressive white-and-red temple, with its multicolored floral ornaments, and happened onto the daily tour.
"Nothing here is for decorative purposes," the guide said, taking us through the main temple, with its bright banners, golden statues and embroidered pictures of saints, all of them sewn by the temple's abbot. "Everything here has a spiritual meaning behind it."
We wished we had worn thick socks; we took off our shoes before entering the temple, and the floors grew cold during the tour. The guide invited people to come back for the regular prayers at 5 A.M. and 5 and 7 P.M. Forgoing materialism, she didn't mention the center's bookstore and gift shop.
Across the street was the path up Overlook Mountain, renowned for the view from 3,140 feet. The trail ascends about two miles on a steady upward grade to the hulk of the Overlook Mountain House, the third hotel on the same site. Affixed to the concrete walls, eroding photographs and documents (all biodegradable, a sign said) describe the three attempts to maintain a luxury hotel on the slope, all commercial failures; all three burned down.
Past the hotel site, the main trail leads to a former fire-observatory tower; the stairway to the second story has been removed, but intrepid types still climb the scaffolding for the view above the trees. A narrower path, to the right after the hotel ruins, heads along a ridge and offers a clearer view, with a silvery ribbon of the Hudson River, forested hillsides and the gleaming Ashokan Reservoir below.
James Fenimore Cooper, writing before the reservoir was created, declared, "It is a spot to make a man solemnize."
Up Meads Mountain Road from the monastery is the Magic Meadow, a Woodstock landmark now mired in small-town controversy. Some Woodstockers had made a ritual of going to the meadow to greet the full moon. But the meadow is on private property, and to discourage moonstruck trespassers, the town put up "No Parking" signs. Claiming an infringement of religious freedom, people who received parking tickets took the case to court, where it remains. We looked at the meadow by daylight; it is a neatly mowed clearing with a peaceful pond.
There was more mountain scenery to explore. Cold Brook Road, from Woodstock to Boiceville, snaked through a valley with fields and mountains on one side. And when we picked up "Hiking the Catskills" (New York-New Jersey Trail Conference, 1989; $14.95) at the Bookmart, the thoughtful owner was ready to suggest her favorite walks.
As we were tired from our Overlook climb, she suggested a spectacular drive, climbing Platte Clove Road through Saugerties to Tannersville, and back via Main Street in Tannersville and Route 214 to Route 28. The road's hairpin curves keep it closed from November to April.
We spent nights at two different bed-and-breakfasts. The Woodstock Country Inn -- on a secluded road in Bearsville, part of Woodstock Township -- is in a house built by an artist, Jo Cantine, whose luminous portraits and tropical landscapes still decorate the walls. Our room was whitewashed and uncluttered, with wicker furniture and a firm, comfortable bed; it had a view of the surrounding hills.
The innkeeper, Carol Wandrey, has lived in Woodstock for 27 years; she was a fount of information on everything from visiting rockers to good places to stroll. And she introduced us to the web of small-town connections. Jo Cantine's grandson owns the Bear Cafe, generally considered the best restaurant in town.
Like so much else in Woodstock, the Bear has touches of the home-grown and the internationalist. It's a high-ceilinged place with one windowed wall looking out over the Sawkill Brook. Its bread, baked by someone named Heather, is like the ideal grandmother: crusty on the outside, tender within. The mixed green salad was organic and very fresh, and we followed it with noodle dishes from disparate cultures: udon noodles with shredded vegetables in a complex, spicy broth, and penne with grilled vegetables in a portobello broth. Dinner for two was about $55. The Bear eclipsed the other local restaurants we visited.
For our last night in Ulster County, we moved to the Onteora Mountain House in Boiceville. Richard Hellmann, the mayonnaise mogul, retired to the mountainside lodge at the age of 50 on a doctor's advice and lived for 44 more years. Built on Mount Ticetonyk, it faces a panorama of mountains stretching into the distance, with the sunset framed by distant hills.
Its owners have filled its Arts and Crafts interior with Korean antiques, making it more formal than the Woodstock Country Inn; a painting of the Buddha and his disciples was at the head of our bed. The lodge's original pool table, with Mission-style legs, is in a downstairs game room. Breakfast was eggs Hellmann, a high-cholesterol construction of an English muffin, spinach, poached eggs and, of course, mayonnaise. "Our sponsor," the innkeeper said.
For dinner, we tried a place where it seemed as if the 1960's had never happened. La Duchesse Anne, a French restaurant in the former Mount Tremper Inn, has a player piano by the bar, stocked with James P. Johnson and Fats Waller classics. For dinner, we enjoyed a cotriade, a Breton fish soup with tomato and a hint of cream, and a grilled trout in sorrel sauce, neither in the least multicultural and both satisfying. We declined the foot-high napoleons on the pastry cart. Dinner for two was about $50.
On the way home, we made two stops. One was the Sunfrost Farms in Woodstock for local apples (at $2.99 a peck) and Bosc pears (99 cents a pound); it also runs a juice bar and stocks foods like olive spread (black and green) and maitake (hen of the woods) mushrooms.
 
Sampling Ice Cream
And in Kingston, we visited the headquarters of Jane's Homemade Ice Cream. We had sampled Jane's at Bread Alone and concluded that her Killer Chocolate surpasses any other chocolate ice cream in our experience. At the main store, we asked if it was sold anywhere in New York City; only, we were told, at the restaurant at Saks Fifth Avenue.
Our disappointment was tempered by the availability of two dozen other flavors; at $2.55 for two hefty scoops, we chose pumpkin and pralines and cream, both worthwhile, and the remarkable cappuccino Kahlua calypso, with deep espresso flavor and a crunch. The ice cream would speed us back to Manhattan; the apples and pears, over the days to come, would continue to remind us of pastoral surroundings and small-town hospitality.
 
Finding Treats for the Body, Mind and Soul
Here is a listing of places mentioned in the article on the Woodstock, N.Y., area, along with travel information.

Getting There

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slumps Against Mark On Outlook for German Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell for the fifth consecutive day against the mark yesterday after German inflation data suggested that Germany's central bank might contemplate a rise in interest rates.
As the dollar fell through important technical levels against the mark more traders began selling dollars, further weakening the currency and raising skepticism about the dollar's longer-term prospects. 
 "The dollar was a little soft," Debra Larsen, assistant vice president for foreign exchange at the New York branch of Commerzbank, said. "Once you get a move like this starting to jeopardize the sentiment, it takes on a life of its own."
Rebounding strength in the mark, an underlying theme in the foreign exchange market all week, also contributed to weakness in the yen, Swiss franc and the pound. That indirectly helped leave the dollar mixed against other currencies.
In late New York trading, the dollar was at 1.5170 marks, down from 1.5207 on Wednesday and off 1.6 percent from its four-and-a-half-month high versus the German currency reached on Oct. 17. The dollar has fallen every day against the mark since then.
The dollar cost 112.87 yen, down from 112.93. The pound cost $1.5909, down from $1.5990.
The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, left interest rates unchanged yesterday at its regular policy making meeting, after some blunt comments by senior Bundesbank officials the day before, suggesting that Germany's four-year trend toward lower rates had ended.
While the Bundesbank's decision was expected, some traders said they were surprised by preliminary October inflation data released by Germany's Federal Statistics Office, which showed the fastest inflation rate in five months.
The mark strengthened on that news, partly on the presumption that the Bundesbank might raise rates if it concluded that the higher inflation rate was a trend.
Other late dollar rates yesterday in New York compared with those late on Wednesday were: 1.2548 Swiss francs, up from 1.2530; 5.1227 French francs, down from 5.1385; 1,524.00 Italian lire, down from 1,527.50, and 1.3455 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3436.

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
When Lawyer and Co-op Board Clash

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
What happens when a seasoned real estate lawyer -- a man the trial judge called "aggressive" and "savvy" -- takes on his own co-op board?
If the decision rendered earlier this month by Judge Martin Shulman of the Civil Court in Manhattan stands, he loses -- badly. 
 Not only was Steven R. Lapidus, a shareholder at 1050 Park Avenue, ordered to pay the $43,834 he had withheld after a maintenance increase and a special assessment for masonry repairs, but he has now been ordered to pay an additional $398,342, including interest, in legal fees that the co-op board ran up over the four years of litigation.
Although Mr. Lapidus was ordered earlier this month to pay the base amount of the co-op's legal fees, he did not find out the exact amount until yesterday, when the same parties went to court -- again before Judge Shulman -- to fight over the amount of interest, set yesterday at $62,005. Reached yesterday afternoon, Mr. Lapidus vowed to appeal the entire amount of legal fees.
"The judgment was wrong," he said, referring to the amount that Judge Shulman had decided to assess him and his wife, Iris, to pay the co-op's legal fees. "It's contrary to law, among other things. Reasonable attorneys' fees do not include three lawyers doing the work of one."
To Mr. Lapidus, the whole struggle -- for which the co-op board's lawyers billed 2,032.8 hours over four years -- demonstrates "the arrogance of co-op boards."
To Stuart M. Saft, a real estate lawyer who is chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives, the decision sets a precedent that will deter lawyers who live in co-ops and condominiums from going to court with their co-op boards.
"This happens a lot," Mr. Saft said. "Probably the most contentious cases are with attorneys who live in co-ops, because they know how the system works and they can use their own in-house legal services so it doesn't cost them anything, and can enter into endless litigation to wear the co-op boards down."
In his decision on the award of legal fees, issued earlier this month, Judge Shulman wrote of Mr. Lapidus's actions that "every conceivable motion was made to delay or derail the underlying proceeding" and he found that "Lapidus's aggressive defense tactics at every stage were implicitly designed to economically force the co-op to its knees."
Yesterday, Gerald Tanenbaum, president of the board at 1050 Park and also a lawyer, said that the case was important because "it went to the economic viability of the co-op." Mr. Tanenbaum said the board had tried many times -- "before the litigation commenced and at various stages" -- to negotiate the issues but that the board could not come to terms with Mr. Lapidus.
"You know, co-ops are somewhat different than tenements," said Mr. Tanenbaum, who has been board president since 1992, a year before the suit was brought against Mr. Lapidus for nonpayment. "We're a luxury Park Avenue co-op, at 87th and Park, a building built in the 1920's with 61 apartments, lovely apartments -- what you'd expect, with a 24-hour doorman."
"But you'd never know that by reading the court papers," he said.
According to Mr. Lapidus's initial argument as to why he should not pay maintenance (he also refused to pay an assessment of $13,415 for exterior masonry repairs), his apartment at 1050 Park Avenue was plagued, not only by roaches and rodents, but by "excessive heat, odors emanating from a neighboring apartment, cracks in the wall, noise from the upstairs apartment, asbestos, moisture seeping through the walls and a lack of window guards."
In addition, according to an initial judgment by Judge Marilyn Shafer of the Housing Court, the Lapiduses contended that their furniture was damaged by fireplace soot and that the common areas were in disrepair, "including cracks in the ceilings, peeling paint and a rip in the bench of the elevator."
In April 1993, Judge Shafer found that the court "simply does not believe" that the Lapiduses properly notified the board of the conditions and also found that any problems in the common areas were only "cosmetic" and did not have an impact on the building's habitability.
Mr. Lapidus appealed both Judge Shafer's ruling and Judge Arlene Kahn's later ruling that the Lapiduses were liable to pay the co-op's legal fees. He lost both appeals.
Luise Barrack, a partner at the law firm of Rosenberg & Estis, handling the case for the co-op board, said she hoped yesterday's decision would end the case, but noted that Mr. Lapidus had vowed to appeal further -- and pointed out that would only generate more legal bills.

HEADLINE: Wrong Time to Expand NATO

 BODY:
Expanding NATO into Central and Eastern Europe may be a popular idea in the Midwest and other parts of the country with large numbers of ethnic voters. President Clinton told an audience in Detroit this week that he would press for the admission of some new NATO members by 1999. Bob Dole favors expansion by 1998.
But good politics does not necessarily make good foreign policy. Bringing countries like Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic into the NATO alliance before the end of this decade risks making the United States and Europe less secure rather than more so. 
 The key to consolidating peace in Europe lies not in expanding NATO but in encouraging Russia to live in harmony with its neighbors and accept deep negotiated reductions in its nuclear arsenal.
The new democracies of Central and Eastern Europe understandably see NATO membership as a way of ratifying their return to the larger European community after more than four decades of Moscow-enforced separation. Americans want to see these countries reintegrated into European life. But a security alliance is the wrong mechanism.
The NATO candidates also see membership as an insurance policy against any revival of the Russian military power that subjugated them for so long. But for now there is no Russian military threat. Expanding NATO is as likely to provoke Moscow's hostility as it is to deter it.
Admitting new members would rashly commit America to the armed, and potentially nuclear, defense of the newcomers. It would saddle American and European taxpayers with heavy new costs to bring existing forces up to NATO standards. The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that these costs could run as high as $125 billion over a 15-year period. NATO expansion would divide rather than unite Europe, creating new security frontiers that would initially exclude some of the new Eastern European nations, like the Baltic countries.
Worst of all, it would feed defensive nationalism and opposition to arms control in Russia, compromising rather than enhancing European security. Expanding NATO will complicate ratification by the Russian Parliament of the already negotiated Start II agreement, which would reduce Russian long-range nuclear weapons from 6,000 to a maximum of 3,500, and will make it difficult for any Russian leader to negotiate further strategic arms reduction agreements.
NATO began in 1949 as a way to contain Soviet power during the cold war. It committed American combat troops and nuclear weapons to the defense of Europe, offsetting Moscow's advantage in conventional forces. NATO kept Western Europe stable and secure. The bonds of military cooperation it has formed on both sides of the Atlantic are too valuable to dissolve. But there is no logic in rushing to expand an alliance that is still in search of a new purpose.
The European Union, not NATO, should take the lead in incorporating Europe's new democracies into the Continental community. It can assist their continuing transformation into market economies and offer incentives to keep them on the path of political democracy and individual freedom.
The wise way for the West to consolidate its victory in the cold war is not to drive Russia into an aggrieved corner, but to try to engage it in a just and durable peace. If Moscow shows signs of again threatening its neighbors, there will be ample time to expand NATO. Until then, there is no reason to rush ahead.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Vickrey's Zeal Remembered At Columbia Memorial Service

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
What excited William Vickrey the most when he won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science earlier this month was not the personal fame or fortune that came with the prize, but the platform it provided to sell his ideas about how economics can improve society.
His death three days later cut short that opportunity, but friends, colleagues and students picked up that mantle yesterday at a memorial service for the Columbia University economics professor. About 200 of them gathered in St. Paul's Chapel, just across from Professor Vickrey's book-crammed office, to recall the man and his commitment to economic justice through a progressive income tax or full employment. 
 "Bill was a moral economist," said David Colander, a professor at Middlebury College in Vermont who worked under Professor Vickrey as a graduate student. "He said what we had to do was make the economy better and society better."
While Professor Vickrey is known best for his work in setting prices in ways that would make highways and subways less congested and auctions more efficient -- work that he produced 30 or 40 years ago that was recognized by the Nobel Prize committee -- his chief preoccupation in the last decade or so was unemployment.
Sumner Rosen, a retired Columbia professor, said that of all the seminars that Professor Vickrey attended in almost 60 years at the university, the only one to which he was willing to give his name as co-chairman was a seminar on full employment that has continued to meet for about a decade.
"Full employment was Bill Vickrey's central passion in recent years," Professor Rosen said. "When he gave his presidential address at the American Economic Association a few years ago, he said that full employment ought to be the top priority of public policy. And on this, as on other issues, he cared not at all what others thought."
That willingness to depart from what others thought was a constant throughout his life, speakers said. Professor Colander of Middlebury recalled that during the full-employment speech, a person near him turned to his neighbor and asked whether Professor Vickrey was "cuckoo." But while other economists said that unemployment could not drop below 5 or 6 percent because of the way the economy was structured, Professor Vickrey wanted to change the structure, Professor Colander said.
'I always wanted to see that an idea was semipolitically reasonable," he added. "Mr. Vickrey never had that concern."
Other speakers remarked that while some of Professor Vickrey's ideas that seemed outlandish decades ago -- like setting different toll prices for cars going through tunnels or using city streets depending on how much congestion there was at the time -- it turned out that they were simply ahead of their time, in part because of his insight into areas like technology.
"He proposed a system of graduated rates for transit fares that was ridiculed at the time," said C. Lowell Harriss, an emeritus professor of economics at Columbia, referring to an early Vickrey idea that has since become a reality in some cities. "I remember his saying the technology was at the frontier -- and he was right."

HEADLINE: New Times Square Tower Lures a Key Tenant

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
Adding the prestige of a major law firm to the renewed glamour of the Times Square area, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom has agreed to lease space in a new building to be constructed on Broadway between 42d and 43d Streets.
The firm's lawyers and staff are scheduled to move from their present location at Third Avenue and 56th Street in the spring of 2000, according to Douglas Durst, president of the Durst Organization, which is building the 48-story office building on the corner once occupied by Nathan's Famous restaurant. 
 The building at 4 Times Square, to be called the Conde Nast Building after its first tenant, the publishing company, is the first speculative office tower to be started in Manhattan in more than a decade. Several buildings built north of Times Square in the mid-1980's failed financially in the weak office market at the end of the decade, although they are largely occupied today.
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the State Department of Economic Development, said the rapid leasing of the building, which was first announced in May, was an indication of the recovery of the office market in the city.
Others said the attractiveness of the Durst project was a product of the long building drought. "What this says is how desperate New York is for new construction," said James S. Meiskin, president of the Plymouth Partners office brokerage. "There are so few blocks of space in midtown of the size that they need in midtown, that Skadden Arps had little choice but to move to the West Side."
Benjamin Needell, the head of Skadden Arps's real estate practice, said the firm chose the Times Square building because it was new, close to transportation hubs and in a revitalized neighborhood.
Skadden Arps has agreed to lease 660,000 square feet of space on the 21 upper floors of the building. Conde Nast had previously signed to lease 585,000 square feet on the lower floors of the 1.6-million-square-foot building. Mr. Durst described the remainder as "expansion space for our tenants." The first three floors will be devoted to shops and restaurants, although no tenants have been announced. Mr. Durst said the retail part of the building is expected to open in time for the Christmas season in 1998, with Conde Nast scheduled to move in in the spring of 1999.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE STRATEGY;
No Easy Explanations For Dole's Perot Gambit

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Since early summer, the season of promise when political hopes bloom along with the roses, Bob Dole has been trying to do something -- anything -- to alter the shape of a Presidential campaign whose basic configuration has not changed since the end of the primary elections.
Shaking off his innate caution and conservatism, he resigned from the Senate, his political home and power base, to no visible effect. He embraced supply-side economics, which he had always disdained, to no visible effect, and added Jack Kemp, the supply-side guru, as a running mate. He all but abandoned his campaign in the Middle Atlantic and the industrial Midwest, the traditional battlegrounds, in favor of a new effort in California, to no visible effect. 
 Now, like a man with his hands stuck in taffy, he has made yet another abrupt effort to wrench himself free from impending defeat: an appeal, quickly rebuffed, to Ross Perot to abandon his candidacy on the Reform ticket.
It appears to have hurt more than it helped, as have some of Mr. Dole's earlier gambits. Political professionals readily concede that he faced a tough fight in any event, confronted as he was with an notably malleable Democratic President who adopted many policies fashioned by Republicans. But they think Mr. Dole's effort to refashion his political persona has made it even tougher.
"He was doomed from the minute he decided that he had to run as someone other than Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate majority leader," said Peter Hart, the Democratic pollster and strategist, and few insiders disagree.
With little more than 10 days of campaigning left, it is not surprising that Mr. Dole has reached the point where urgent if not desperate measures suggest themselves. He trails Bill Clinton by 22 percentage points, 55 to 33, in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, published on Tuesday. In California, target of his latest do-or-die effort, a Los Angeles Times poll shows Mr. Clinton's job approval rating at 60 percent, the highest since he took office.
And every single member of a panel of political consultants assembled by The Hotline, a political news service, said this week that they expected Mr. Clinton to win -- every single Democrat and every single Republican, too.
But if it is easy to see why Mr. Dole felt he had to take action, it is harder to see why he decided to send his campaign manager, Scott Reed, to Dallas to try to persuade the fiercely independent Mr. Perot to fold his tent. Perhaps it was the advocacy of Mr. Reed, who has a reputation as a political gambler.
Senator Connie Mack of Florida, a staunch Dole backer, was one of the few Republicans who ventured a theory. Without audible fervor, Mr. Mack said, "Any time you can pick up a few points here or there it's worth the effort."
Indeed, in Mr. Mack's state and in Texas, two of the four most populous states, late polls suggest that if Mr. Dole could pick up the votes of all the voters who currently support Mr. Perot that might be enough to swing the states safely into the Republican column. Mr. Dole leads narrowly in Texas, and Mr. Clinton narrowly in Florida; Mr. Perot is at about 6 percent in each.
But there was no known reason for Mr. Dole to expect that Mr. Perot would quit the race after having laboriously and expensively won a position on the ballot in all 50 states for his fledgling party. To do so would not only deprive him of the limelight he so enjoys but would doom the Reform Party before it had contested its first election.
Mr. Perot is faced with the prospect of polling less than 10 percent of the vote on Nov. 5, less than half of the 19 percent he took in 1992. But the feisty Texan is not one to shrink from long odds.
And despite the disingenuous comment of Elizabeth Dole on television on Wednesday night to the effect that the Perots and the Doles were good friends, Mr. Perot was infuriated when the Republican nominee sought successfully to have him excluded from this year's Presidential debates. He is still angry.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Perot today dismissed the effort to get him out of the race as an absurdity that was completely irrelevant to the campaign.
Even if Mr. Perot, for reasons unknown, had decided to stand aside in Mr. Dole's favor, there is no reason to suppose his backers would have followed him, sheep-like, into the Dole camp. They support Mr. Perot, after all, because they have already weighed the major-party candidates and found them wanting.
And even if Mr. Perot had wanted his name off the ballot, in many states he could not have accomplished that. In some the deadline for withdrawal has passed and in others, little short of death can remove a name from the ballot.
Finally, there are strategic considerations. A Presidential candidate who trails badly entering the final days of a campaign has one supreme task: convincing the electorate that he still has a chance, can still catch up, is still worth supporting. If he cannot do that, many of his backers will stay at home, which is why politicians seldom concede that they are about to lose.
What Mr. Dole did in dispatching Mr. Reed to Dallas makes that job a great deal harder for him, and cannot help others on the Republican ticket.
Although some Republicans suggested that Mr. Dole had intended to keep the approach a secret and had been victimized by a leak, many more characterized the whole enterprise as a fool's errand and argued that no one could have thought something so startling could be kept quiet at the peak of a campaign.
"He didn't quite sign his own death certificate with that little maneuver," a Republican state chairman in the Midwest said, "but he certainly told the whole world how sick his campaign is.
"I'm sure he did it in good faith. But in this part of the world Dole is 15 points down and Perot has only 5 percent, so it's hard to see what we gain, and our House candidates are in agony."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bond Prices Decline On Drop in Jobless Claims

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday, after a sharp drop in weekly jobless claims pointed to persistent strength in the nation's labor markets.
The drop in new jobless claims set the tone in the market from the outset, and prices were unable to recover despite reports that the Federal Reserve was buying short-maturity Treasuries for the second consecutive session. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 22/32 , to 9822/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.85 percent from 6.83 percent on Wednesday. The two-year note closed down 29/32 , to yield 5.93 percent.
The Labor Department reported that first-time claims for state unemployment benefits fell by a hefty 22,000 in the week ended Oct. 19, to 320,000, from 342,000 the previous week. It was the lowest since claims touched 317,000 during the week ended Aug. 31.
The drop took Wall Street economists by surprise and reminded investors that the labor market remains tight, which could mean upward pressure on wages and prices.
"We know the labor market is pretty strong, and the claims number reminded us of that," said Josh Feinman, vice president and global markets economist at Bankers Trust. "It was a holiday week so the data might be a little tougher to read but there's no question that the labor market is still strong."
In addition to the Columbus Day holiday, economists said the ripple effects of the recent strike by Canadian auto workers against General Motors in Canada also might have had an impact on the data.
Regardless of any distortions, many in the market said they expected claims to bounce back from their low levels next week.
With prices lingering in negative territory in the aftermath of the claims report, traders said the Fed entered the market, buying two-year, three-year and five-year paper.
"It looked like the Fed came in under the table once again and took the market off its lows," said Theodore Ake, senior vice president and senior trader at Everen Securities.
But Mr. Ake said the Fed-induced price rise was fleeting, giving the market little more than a temporary push up from session lows.
Further weighing on the market yesterday was continuing apprehension about coming economic data. The report on September durable goods orders, due today is expected to show a rebound from weak August numbers.
And widely divergent forecasts for the October employment report, due next Friday, have also created some jitters in the market.
"I think there is a lot of nervousness and concern about next week's numbers," said Marilyn Schaja, money market economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
In the corporate bond market, trading revolved around Tele-Communications Inc. as it has every day this week, traders said.
Tele-Communications' debt was hit early after the company said it had told suppliers to stop all shipments until further notice, traders said.
Prices bounced sharply higher after the company said it expected to report that it had third-quarter revenue of $1.648 billion and operating cash flow of $591 million, traders said, but quickly faded below Wednesday's closing levels.

HEADLINE: Corrections

 BODY:
A chart on Monday with the continuation of an article about the economic rebound in New York City misstated the timing of the most recent recession in the city. It began in 1989 and lasted until 1992; it did not occur in 1988. In some editions the chart also misstated the hotel occupancy rate for 1988. It was 75 percent, not 80.

HEADLINE: In an Ohio County, the Issue Is Public Buses, Not the Presidential Race

SERIES: AN AMERICAN PLACE: The Bus Stops Here

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The most compelling national issue that the people of Stark County face come Nov. 5 is not, "Who will be President?" (Bill Clinton is looking awfully strong in Stark County.) It is, "Will there be any more public buses here?"
In the last two years, the Republican-led Congress and the Democratic President have been chipping away at big government, scaling back welfare, cutting low-income housing subsidies, reducing some public transit grants. 
 Now, either this county of 370,000 people votes to pass an increase in the county sales tax to replace the lost Federal transit revenue, or the buses stop. Will the people of Stark County assume the Federal Government's role of providing this safety net? Bus riders are not too hopeful.
"Rich won't vote for it," said Donnie Long, a dishwasher, waiting downtown in the early morning darkness to catch the bus to Belden Village, the big suburban mall.
"The other ones who don't ride, don't care," said Larae Wagner, a shipping clerk.
This is no Chicken Little situation. "The system will shut down if the referendum fails," said Susan Eslich, director of the Canton Regional Transit Authority.
Community leaders are pushing for passage and there is no organized opposition, but it is still a hard sell in a county that has a strong anti-tax tradition and is heavily suburban, where cars rule and most people have never ridden a public bus. In March, the same tax referendum for bus service was defeated by a 60-to-40 ratio. A majority of residents in every suburb voted no.
Through the years, the transit service has gone through so many cuts that bus service now stops at 6 P.M. Only 2,000 people ride daily. Jack Thompson, a bus dispatcher with 20 years' experience, puts it this way: "Just about everybody who rides the buses now, has to ride the bus. When I started, people rode for convenience."
The riders are mainly the working poor, the handicapped, the elderly.
Bus riders in Stark County are nearly invisible to the suburban eye, although employers and mall shoppers rely on them. Among the riders this morning on the No. 5 bus, from downtown Canton to the mall in suburban Jackson, were Christina Haueter, a kitchen worker at Shoney's restaurant; Charles Newhouse, a groundskeeper at Forest Hill Cemetery; Mr. Long, a dishwasher at John's Bar and Grille; David Francisco, a stockroom worker at the Target discount store, and Rita McMahon and Raenita Wheeler, telemarketers.
Their lives are already constrained by a bus system that makes pickups only once an hour during much of the day and serves only Canton and a few bordering suburbs.
Monica Moore, a preschool aide, quit taking courses at the local community college, Stark State, because the classes she needed were at night when buses do not run.
"With service stopping so early, I don't have the ability to work overtime," said Brenda Allen, a hospital worker. She takes the bus with her 10-year-old daughter, Ebony, and her 12-year-old son, Elon, who ride to school.
Last summer Mr. Francisco had to be at work at Target at 5 A.M., before the buses start, so he pedaled his bicycle six miles along dark four-lane boulevards like Everhard and Whipple, where cars speed by at 50 miles an hour.
Kevin Walker recently quit as an aide at the Altercare nursing home in suburban Louisville even though he was well regarded and liked the work. He could not get there on time for the night shift.
"Kevin was a very good nurse's assistant, very caring," said Stephanie Henderson, the supervisor. "It's a constant problem for me: good aides with no transportation. It causes constant turnover. And when they're here, all they talk about sometimes is how they're going to get home."
Mr. Walker used to work in the kitchen at East Side Mario's restaurant in Belden Village, and some nights, when he got off at 10, the only way home was walking seven miles back to his apartment in Canton.
A survey a few years ago showed that 53 percent of bus riders earned $5,000 to $15,000 a year; 93 percent made less than $30,000.
Conveniences taken for granted in larger cities sound like pipe dreams here. "It would be nice to ride the bus to church and to the grocery store and not have to ask some friend for a ride," said Ms. Wheeler, waiting downtown for the bus to take her work.
Did she think the tax would pass?
"I pray to God that it passes," she said. "Everyone is praying."
Nancy Johnson is director of the senior center in Massillon, a city of 32,000 people in western Stark County that is not served by the buses. A few months ago she got a call from a 67-year-old woman looking for a driving instructor.
"Her husband had died and she'd never learned to drive," said Ms. Johnson, who volunteered to teach the woman for no charge. "We've been doing this a few months, but she's not really comfortable with a car yet. I'm not sure she's flexible enough at this age to be a safe driver. We were supposed to drive tonight, but she didn't want to drive in the rain."
The recent fiscal crisis was set off by cuts in Federal aid to local systems' operating budgets. In 1994 the Federal Government appropriated $700 million; in 1996 President Clinton requested $500 million, and the Republican-controlled Congress appropriated $400 million.
For Canton, that meant a reduction in Federal aid to $523,000 from $1.2 million. Local officials decided that any more cuts would make the system useless. Instead, they proposed increasing the sales tax by a quarter-cent, to 5.75 cents on the dollar, to pay for the buses. If the tax passes, enough revenue would be generated to expand the system dramatically, running buses 21 hours a day and reaching all over the county.
After the tax referendum failed last spring, Canton's Mayor, Richard Watkins, a Republican, asked Bill Luntz, a businessman here, to run the fall campaign for the referendum. Mr. Luntz, the 72-year-old chairman emeritus of the Luntz Company, a scrap metal supplier, was not pleased. He knew he would need to raise money for campaign advertising. "Nothing's more thankless than raising money to promote a tax increase," he said.
But Mr. Luntz is also part of a mainly Republican business establishment that takes its societal obligations seriously. Among other things, he has started a mentoring program at a Canton inner city school.
One of his first calls was to Jack Timken, a vice president of the Timken Company, the largest local employer. For 100 years, Luntzes have sold scrap steel to Timkens, who turn it into roller bearings. Mr. Timken gave $5,000. Several weeks later, with fund raising lagging, Mr. Luntz called Mr. Timken again. "I started to tell Jack the problems. He said, 'Stop, stop, I'll give you another $5,000.' "
Mr. Luntz has raised $60,000, about twice the amount contributed to last spring's campaign. Supporters have put up 2,000 yard signs. "We had enough money to buy air time for radio ads before it was all booked by the politicians," he said.
It will be a test of whether the anti-tax anger has softened here. Seven times in the 1990's, county residents defeated an increase in the sales tax to expand the overcrowded jail. This is a conservative, law-and-order place, yet in 1994, even as the waiting list to go to jail here reached five years and inmates were being released early to free up cells, voters defeated a sales tax increase.
But those feelings may be changing as the economy improves. In 1995 county voters finally passed a sales tax increase for the jail. Last spring seven of the nine local school districts passed budgets increasing their taxes, an unusually high success rate.
Transit officials had been pessimistic about winning, but they are sounding more hopeful lately. "I can see the light at the end of the tunnel and it's a bus," said Mary Cain, the transit board chairman, who believes the referendum could be decided by a few hundred votes.
With unemployment so low, "Help Wanted" signs are everywhere and suburban businesses that rely on low-wage workers are having trouble hiring. Canton is their best bet. Unemployment countywide is 4.8 percent, but in Canton it is 7.7 percent. Employers hope a better bus system will help them tap the city job market. Guy Cicchini, the biggest McDonald's owner in the county, with 17 stores, has all his workers wearing pink Regional Transit Authority campaign shirts.
At 10:30 P.M., cleanup is over at the McDonald's in Belden Village, but Debra Ogden, the manager, does not leave until she is sure everyone has a ride. When Kevin Pohle, 16, is working, she puts his bike in the trunk of her '90 Dodge hatchback and drives him home. "I don't want him riding his bike on busy streets late at night," she said.
Jeff Graber, Target's manager, is letting bus supporters use the store's parking lot for a pre-election rally. He said he had not heard anyone speaking against the tax, but added, "The problem is, I don't hear anyone talking about it too much at all."
The question is whether they can reach people like Lisa Gaetano. The young mother had just parked her car the other day at the Strip, the newest shopping complex in suburban Jackson, and was heading with her daughter into Baby Bath and Beyond. Mrs. Gaetano said she had never ridden a Stark bus, nor had she heard of the tax vote. "It sounds like it might be a good idea," she said.
One suburban resident working for the referendum is Edie Shanower of Perry, an accountant. Her oldest son, Jeff, has cerebral palsy. "Technology has opened up so much for him," she said. "He has a voice-activated computer. He speaks to it and it types his papers." He has earned a master's and gets to his job downtown as a career counselor by bus.
"We took him to a specialist in Cleveland about equipping a car for driving," she said. "They put on all these special controls and gadgets, but it would never work because his eyesight just isn't strong enough. Technology is wonderful, but technology can only do so much."
"He needs the bus," she said.
 
Living midway between Democratic Cleveland and Republican Columbus, the citizens of Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County have a history of voting for the winning Presidential candidate. This is the 31st article in a yearlong series that seeks to explore the forces shaping the political debate at the grass roots. (Previous articles are available to computer users on The New York Times on the Web, at http://www.nytimes.com/specials/canton.)

HEADLINE: Is It a Global Market for Campaign Gifts, Too?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Recent discoveries about foreign money's influence on Presidential politics have spawned much umbrage, but your Oct. 22 editorial ("Dole, Clinton and Asian Money"), like others, omits an important point.
Profit is nation-neutral. It is driven by markets, not by nations. As the world economy becomes progressively more open, the distinctions among dollars, drachmas and deutsche marks become more artificial. So does any distinction between countries headquartered in Indonesia and those in Indiana. And if someone seeks to maximize profit all over the globe, his first allegiance is to no nation. 
 In the United States, it is illegal for foreigners to buy political access, but legal for citizens. I have no reason to believe that the self-interest of domestic access-buyers is any better for the country than that of foreigners.
If anything, in a world economy, the rules look like protectionism: access restricted to the highest domestic bidder.
Why doesn't the citizenry protest to high heaven? Because it was inevitable, and we were benumbed by the domestic access-buyers. We see no difference.
 
GERALD J. DALZELL
Rutherford, N.J., Oct. 22, 1996

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar at 33-Month High vs. Yen And Also Climbs Against Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed against European currencies yesterday but reached a 33-month high against the Japanese yen after a roller-coaster session.
Trading centered on the German mark, which gyrated after several German officials gave conflicting views on the outlook for domestic interest rates, and the British pound, which rallied on strong economic performance in Britain. 
 Three officials of the German central bank said they did not expect to see lower German interest rates ahead, but two of the officials expressed hope that rate cuts were still possible.
The dollar climbed against the mark on the news, since lower German rates would enhance the relative value of assets priced in dollars.
But release of a radio interview with the Bundesbank's president, Hans Tietmeyer, in which he asserted that Germany's economy would grow through 1997 without a rate cut, sent the mark soaring against the dollar.
"There were a number of comments out of German authorities as to the interest rate picture and the dollar reacted to every single one of them," said Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager in New York at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan.
The dollar closed at 1.5210 marks, up from 1.5170 late Thursday. Against the yen, the dollar finished at 113.31, its highest close since January 1994, up from 112.87.
The British pound rose to $1.5973 from $1.5909 late Thursday after reaching a 15-month peak earlier in the session. The dollar rose to 1.2611 Swiss francs from 1.2548.
The pound rallied on a report that the British economy grew by eight-tenths of a percent in the third quarter, exceeding expectations.
"Britain's economy looks good and people are expecting higher interest rates there," said Dominick Presser, chief dealer at the Dresdner Bank in New York.
The dollar benefited from solid United States economic data, dealers said.
The dollar also continued to rally against the yen, helped by Japanese investors selling yen to invest in higher-yielding overseas markets.
But the dollar may have reached a near-term peak as it approached 113.60 yen, the January 1994 high, which dealers said was a crucial technical level.
