HEADLINE: Prices of Treasury Bonds Rise On a Weakness in Home Sales

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended higher yesterday, erasing an early loss, as a slump in sales of existing homes helped ease concerns over inflation.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 14/32 , to 993/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.81 percent from 6.85 percent. A week ago, the yield was at 6.79 percent. The price of the two-year note also rose, driving its yield down to 5.89 percent from 5.93 percent. 
 "There's not a lot for bond investors to be concerned about," said Bob Alley, who manages $3 billion at AIM Advisers in Houston. "There's no overwhelming inflation problem."
Treasury bonds rallied after the National Association of Realtors said sales of previously owned homes fell 2.9 percent to an annual pace of 4.02 million in September -- less than what economists had expected.
If it was not enough to touch off a big rally, the economic news "wasn't bearish for the bond market," said Michael Link, who manages the $165 million Gradison-McDonald Government Income Fund in Cincinnati. "There's no reason for interest rates to go significantly higher."
Other reports yesterday, however, pointed to much stronger growth.
The Commerce Department said that orders for durable goods jumped 4.6 percent last month. Even without transportation goods, orders climbed nine-tenths of 1 percent.
The University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment rose to 96.5, up from last month's 94.7 and a preliminary reading of 94.8 reported two weeks ago, analysts familiar with the report said. The survey, which is released only to paying subscribers, showed that Americans grew more comfortable with their finances and the economy this month.
Nonetheless, a mightier dollar bolstered demand for Treasury securities among foreign central banks, which bought through the Federal Reserve, traders said. The currency rose to a 33-month high of 113.31 yen.
It was not the first time this week or this year that speculation of foreign demand buoyed the market, said Tony Crescenzi, head of fixed-income trading at the New York brokerage firm of Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company. "They've been major backers of this market, and I think that's the primary reason why we're trading well," he said.
On Thursday, the Fed said it was holding more United States Government securities in custody for foreign central banks than ever -- $593.39 billion. Such holdings rose $724 million in the week ended Wednesday, setting the 16th record so far this year.
In the corporate bond market, Mirage Resorts Inc. was among the biggest issuers yesterday. Mirage, based in Las Vegas, Nev., sold $250 million of bonds, $50 million more than expected. The 10-year notes, rated BBB+ by Standard & Poor's and Baa2 by Moody's Investors Service, were priced to yield 7.268 percent.
The Household Finance Corporation, a unit of Household International and a provider of financial, credit card and banking services to individuals and businesses, sold $150 million in five-year notes.
The notes pay a floating rate of interest of 15 basis points more than the three-month London interbank offered rate, or Libor, the rate international banks charge each other.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
3M Earnings Rise 15.7%; Stock Surges

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Oct. 25

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that earnings rose 15.7 percent in the third quarter on strong international sales, especially in Japan, other parts of Asia and Latin America.
The results from the maker of tapes, adhesives, coatings and films beat expectations on Wall Street, and its stock soared $3.125, to $74.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. 3M is one of the issues in the 30-share Dow Jones industrial average. 
 3M, based in St. Paul, said profits rose to $398 million, or 95 cents a share, in the quarter, from $344 million, or 82 cents a share, in the 1995 period, which included earnings of $5 million, or 1 cent a share, from discontined operations.
Sales grew 7.4 percent, to $3.62 billion from $3.37 billion.
The results surpassed analysts' average forecasts of 93 cents a share, according to First Call, which tracks estimates.
The company said unit sales rose 10 to 12 percent internationally and more than 7 percent in the United States.
"A strong flow of innovative, high-impact new products, an intense focus on customer satisfaction and continued expansion internationally fueled our worldwide volume growth," 3M's chairman, Livio D. DeSimone, said in a statement.
3M, which makes products ranging from Post-It notes and Scotch brand adhesive tape to medical imagers and industrial adhesives, said its prices rose just 1 percent in the quarter while unit volume increased 10 percent.
The company's units in Japan, elsewhere in Asia, Latin America and Canada posted double-digit volume increases in the quarter while unit sales in Europe grew 7 percent, despite sluggish economies in many major European countries.
Changes in currency exchange rates reduced earnings in the latest quarter by 5 cents a share, 3M said. That reflected a stronger dollar, which causes earnings in overseas markets to be worth less when converted to dollars.

HEADLINE: Revised Data Show Layoff Rate Constant in 1990's

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Despite the economic recovery and substantial numbers of new jobs, the rate of layoffs in the work force in the middle of the decade remained roughly constant compared with the early 1990's, according to revised figures released today by the Labor Department.
The figures also showed that the number of people who identified themselves as having lost a job increased in the middle of the decade, providing further statistical underpinning for the anxiety and job insecurity that have become staples of the nation's economic and political discourse. 
 Bob Dole's campaign said the revised figures were evidence of why economic anxiety is "spreading like a virus through America's work force." But the Clinton Administration said the figures were contradicted by other statistical evidence that suggests layoffs are down at a time when unemployment is extremely low.
Today's numbers from the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics were corrected versions of figures for the early and mid-1990's that were first made public in August.
The original figures appeared to show that both the rate and number of layoffs had declined in the last few years, despite a wave of corporate reorganizations, the migration of some jobs to low-wage countries and increased automation.
The original numbers, however, contained a statistical flaw that was discovered by a Princeton University researcher, Henry Farber. The Bureau of Labor Statistics agreed to correct the flaw, and the figures it released today take account of the statistical problem, which related to the number of people who failed to respond to the Government's survey.
The revised figures showed that 8 percent of the labor force identified themselves as having lost a job involuntarily from 1993 through 1995, compared with 8.2 percent in the prior survey, which covered 1991 through 1993.
The revised rate remained far above that during the peak of the last economic expansion, in the middle and late 1980's, when the rate of layoffs went as low as 5.5 percent.
In addition to showing that the rate of layoffs did not decline appreciably in recent years, the new figures showed that the total number of people who said they had been displaced actually rose slightly in the most recent three-year period. About 9.4 million people lost jobs from 1993 through 1995, compared with 9.2 million from 1991 through 1993.
The Labor Department originally said that the rate of layoffs had fallen to 7.2 percent in the most recent three-year period from 8 percent in the previous period.
Similarly, the original figures showed a decline in the number of people saying they had been laid off, to 8.4 million for the most recent three years from 9 million in the early years of the decade.
The figures were taken from two surveys conducted for the Labor Department by the Census Bureau, in February 1994 and February 1996.
In each, respondents in 50,000 households were asked whether they had lost a job in the prior three years, and if so, to provide details. The surveys overlapped for the year 1993.
The Clinton Administration seized on the original numbers in August to back up its contention that the worst of the layoffs that had swept the economy was past. Today the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, Joseph E. Stiglitz, said that other data still suggested that involuntary job losses were declining, and he raised questions about the statistical validity of the Labor Department numbers.
Mr. Stiglitz said the best indicator of job losses was the weekly tally of new claims for unemployment insurance. The average for that figure has declined from 484,000 a week in the first quarter of 1991 to 331,000 a week in this year's third quarter, he said, a decline of 31.6 percent. Those claims, however, also include people who are laid off only temporarily and tend to follow the ups and downs of the economy more closely than the layoff figures compiled every other year.
"From the perspective of how well we're performing, the data I find more relevant are how well do we create jobs for people entering the labor force or who are losing jobs," Mr. Stiglitz said.
He said the economy had created 10.5 million net new jobs since Mr. Clinton took office and that unemployment, at 5.2 percent, was about as low as it could sustain over the long run without igniting inflation.
"From a policy perspective, we will continue to be worried about people who are displaced, and we will continue to push forward with programs like portability of pensions and portability of health care to make it easier for people who move from job to job," he said. "The desirability of that is not affected by slight revisions of the statistics."
But Mr. Dole's campaign seized on the revision as evidence that workers had been shortchanged by what the Republican nominee has long lambasted as the weakest economic recovery on record.
"With or without the statistics, Bob Dole realizes economic anxiety is real and spreading like a virus through America's work force," said Christina Martin, spokeswoman for Mr. Dole. "Without underestimated numbers to hide behind, Bill Clinton should now step forward and confess to being responsible for stagnant wages and an increase in layoffs."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;
Clinton, in an Artful Campaign Trip to Georgia, Urges a Tutor Plan for Young Readers

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: MACON, Ga., Oct. 25

 BODY:
During a single hour in downtown Atlanta today, President Clinton managed to make a big splash in a Southern state he wants to win, sit silent as a surrogate slashed away at Bob Dole, chasten a heckler and put in a plug for a Democratic Senate candidate who does not want to be seen as too much in his shadow.
He also floated an upbeat, low-cost idea: using Federal work-study grants to pay college students to tutor third graders in reading. 
 In the last stretch of what may be his last campaign, the President is proving to be a master in the art of doing just about everything while doing nothing in particular.
"I want all of us to be able to say we don't need to look down on anybody else to feel good about ourselves and our families and our future," Mr. Clinton said. "And I want all of us to say we believe that we have an obligation to serve as citizens to help our children to read, to deal with the other problems in our community, to save the generation of our young people who are in trouble still today because they're more vulnerable to gangs and guns and drugs, and other problems that threaten their future."
Along the way, the President wraps bare-knuckle campaigning in motherhood, music and the kind of red-white-and-blue bunting that bedecked Woodruff Park in Atlanta and the City Auditorium in this central Georgia city today.
And while he repeatedly insists that he wants a campaign of "ideas, not insults" on a golden road to the 21st century, if one of his seconds just happens to hurl a well-turned insult in the direction of his Republican challenger, Bob Dole, Mr. Clinton is not a man to stand in the way.
"I like to think of Bill Clinton as the Luke Skywalker of American politics, fighting the dark side with bold new programs and hope for the future," Mayor Bill Campbell of Atlanta said, referring to the hero of "Star Wars" as the President sat on a makeshift stage. "And we all know who Darth Vader is: Bob Dole is out of touch, out of steam and out of time."
A few moments later, Mr. Clinton took his own veiled dig at Mr. Dole. As he started to praise the sacrifice of Max Cleland, the Democratic Senate nominee who lost both legs and an arm in the Vietnam War and who has taken some pains not to associate himself too closely with Mr. Clinton, a heckler demanded to know what the President, who avoided military service in that war, could know about sacrifice.
"You all relax," Mr. Clinton soothed as his supporters booed the heckler. "When people don't have a side of their own to make, they try to shout down their opponents.
"Let me tell you," Mr. Clinton added , "Max Cleland has kept on giving for a lifetime, with a smile on his face and a song in his heart, always reaching out his hand to other people. Now, the other side, their idea of sacrifice is to take Head Start away from 5-year-olds, college loans away from students, to take the environment away from all of our people and to weaken our future economy for short-term promises."
In a single breath, Mr. Clinton contrasted Mr. Cleland with Mr. Dole's reputation for dourness, and his own Administration's poll-tested defense of popular government programs against the Republican-controlled Congress. But the bulk of the President's speech was a hymn to the future -- a proposal to use existing Federal funds that subsidize jobs for college students to help carry out Mr. Clinton's previous call for increasing childhood literacy.
Under Mr. Clinton's plan, which would require Congressional approval but no new money, 100,000 federally subsidized job slots that were added as part of the budget Congress passed this fall would be set aside to pay reading tutors. The President said that could make up 10 percent of the one million volunteer tutors he has called for.
"I want you to support that," Mr. Clinton told several thousand people gathered in downtown Atlanta. "I want you to tell me that you will help to teach a child to read, to help people in this community who need it, to make this community one."
The Dole campaign dismissed Mr. Clinton's proposal as a gimmick, and a spokeswoman for Mr. Dole, Christina Martin, said it was interesting that the President had to "hide behind a war hero" like Mr. Cleland to make his point about sacrifice.
Nevertheless, the proposal is precisely the kind of small idea -- from curfews for teen-agers to cellular phones for neighborhood watch groups -- that Mr. Clinton has used to style himself as an exponent of the upbeat optimism that led President Ronald Reagan to proclaim in his 1984 campaign that it was "morning in America."
Indeed, Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, who is retiring this year and who has not always seen eye-to-eye with Mr. Clinton over issues like homosexuals in the military, recited the President's record in office and asked rhetorically that "if Republicans were in charge and had a record like this, would they be saying liberal, liberal, liberal?" He answered himself with a resounding no.
Later, in a telephone conference call with black clergy from around the country conducted from the venerable Paschal's restaurant in downtown Atlanta, Mr. Clinton made it clear that he would like to be remembered in a second term for more than blocking Republican initiatives.
"Now, all of this depends upon this election," Mr. Clinton said. "I can do a pretty good job of saying no if I have to. I've shown that I know how to sign that veto pen pretty good.
"But we also want to say yes to America, to a new direction, to keep this economy growing, to keep preserving the environment, to clean up these toxic waste sites in our cities so our children will be growing up next to parks, not poison, to continue to expand health care coverage to people when they're unemployed for six months, to expand coverage to a million more children."
At a late afternoon rally here in Macon, Mr. Clinton also showed that he can still laugh at himself occasionally. Thanking local officials for the gift of a T-shirt from the local minor league hockey team, the Macon Whoopee, Mr. Clinton said: "You know, it's Hillary's birthday tomorrow. Maybe I ought to give that to her."
Then he paused and added, "If that gets on the news before I get home tonight, I'm in trouble."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE RUNNING MATE;
In Secure Midwest, Gore Focuses on Congressional Seats

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 25

 BODY:
In a brisk swing through Michigan and Ohio, Vice President Al Gore cheerfully campaigned today as much for the local Democratic candidates as for himself and President Clinton.
These two Midwestern states are traditionally described every four years as critical battlegrounds in the Presidential contests, but this year there are few who believe Ohio and Michigan represent much of a contest at the top of the ticket. A wide range of public opinion polls has Mr. Clinton leading Bob Dole handsomely, in double digits in both states. 
 Although Mr. Gore gave rousing speeches on behalf of the local tickets in both states, he and his campaign exude an air of serenity with less than two weeks to go before Election Day.
Early in the day Mr. Gore made a long-planned campaign stop in Port Huron, Mich., on behalf of Representative David E. Bonior, the Democratic whip.
Speaking before more than 1,000 people, many in hard hats and baseball jackets with union insignia, Mr. Gore said that four years ago the local unemployment rate was greater than 10 percent.
"With the help of David Bonior, we have brought that down to five and a half percent," he said as massive freighters plied the St. Clair River behind him.
Mr. Gore had scheduled the trip to Port Huron, which has thriving steel and auto components industries, months ago when it appeared that Mr. Bonior could face his first real challenge in years. His Republican opponent, Susy Heintz, is a former state Republican chairwoman and a chief strategist for Gov. John R. Engler, a rising Republican star.
But now it appears that Mr. Bonior holds a commanding lead in public opinion polls, and Mr. Gore's strategists said an important goal of the Michigan trip now was to help the Democrats win control of both houses of the state legislature, where narrow Republican majorities have greatly helped Governor Engler.

HEADLINE: Protesters Take to Streets to Defend Canada's Safety Net

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Canadians do not easily take to the streets; it's just not their way. But today thousands of angry people paralyzed parts of Canada's largest city to protest government actions that they say threaten the core of what Canada stands for.
Protesters managed to shut down Toronto's subway, bus and streetcar system, stranding the 600,000 commuters who normally use public transportation. Highways leading to the Lester B. Pearson International Airport were jammed by drivers who deliberately slowed traffic to a crawl. A third of the city's public school teachers did not show up for work, and police officers were needed to keep hundreds of protesters from disrupting the Toronto Stock Exchange. 
 The direct target of the protests was the new provincial government and its leader, Mike Harris, who has become a darling of Wall Street by slashing almost $1 billion from Ontario's budget, dropping more than 180,000 people from welfare rolls and promising to shrink income taxes 30 percent. Eventually the spending cuts will reach nearly $6 billion, but achieving that goal will mean closing hospitals, raising university tuition and laying off civil servants, among other measures.
Labor unions and community groups wanted to send Mr. Harris a message that they considered the cuts mean spirited and excessive. But as they organized their response, they sensed something more going on.
Most of Canada's 10 provinces have adopted the same theme: tax cuts and smaller government. The Federal Government has done its own share of hacking, with deep cuts to the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and other mainstays of Canadian life.
"These are the marks of a caring society and -- no offense -- what sets us apart from the United States," said Linda Torney, an organizer of the protest called Days of Action. She said that many of those who picketed subway stations, government offices and large businesses, had never joined a protest before. But they came out today in support of Canada's social safety net because the Government cuts threaten "a major aspect of what makes us Canadians," she said.
Kathryn McClurg, a librarian at the main reference library on Yonge Street for the last six years, said she is "one of those Canadians who usually sit at home and watch things happen on television." She carried a picket sign in front of the library today not just because of millions of dollars in proposed cuts to the library's budget, "but cuts to all the social programs that have given us the quality of life we have," she said.
This is the fifth, and largest, Days of Action protest in Ontario since Mr. Harris was elected last year. Prodded by labor unions, thousands of Canadians in the largest province have taken to the streets of London, Hamilton and other cities.
The protests have exposed a deep division in Canadian society, said Neil Nevitte, a University of Toronto political scientist, who has written a book about Canadian values. Deference to authority is declining, and Canadians are growing feistier as they seek more control over their lives, he said.
They support Canada's traditional safeguards for the sick, the unemployed and the desperate -- benefits that are far more generous than in the United States, and more costly. They are also worried about high taxes and government deficits, and the number of people laid off because of increased international competition in business.
"What's going on," Professor Nevitte said, "is a fundamental battle over the size and scope of the welfare state in Canada," which is likely to be played out on a national level in next year's elections.
It is not surprising that the Ontario government does not see it that way. "Yes, it's a big protest," said Paul J. Rhodes, a spokesman for Mr. Harris, "but there are no surprises here." Mr. Harris ran on a campaign promise to cut spending, cut taxes and reduce welfare, and he did it, Mr. Rhodes said. He said Mr. Harris thinks unions are simply trying to protect their own jobs.
The Days of Action are the largest mass demonstrations in Ontario since the 1970's, maybe the largest ever. Disruptions did not come close to causing the chaos predicted in local headlines, but for a city unaccustomed to civil disobedience, just the thought of such protests was enough to make hands sweat at city hall.
Earlier this week hospitals canceled chemotherapy sessions and some surgery that had been scheduled for Friday. The post office said it would not deliver mail on Friday, the Sanitation Department apologized because it would not pick up garbage, and City Hall said it would not issue marriage certificates.
Not all of Toronto endorsed the Days of Action. "The business community isn't going to stand for this kind of intimidation," said Elyse Allan, chief executive of the Metro Toronto Board of Trade. A march planned for Saturday is more likely to hurt tourists in town for the Breeders' Cup than local people, she said.
Many resisted the temptation to just take the day off. Hotels were booked weeks ago, and many workers slept at their desks Thursday night. One local restaurant offered a "Protest Day Buffet," and a great number of unusually clumsy bikers could be seen wobbling and weaving through downtown streets.
Some workers made it in, but were not sure why. "I believe in what they're going for," said Michelle Axbey, 24, as she watched the demonstrators during a coffee break from the downtown brokerage firm where she works, "but how do I bite the hand that feeds me?"
The image of noisy street protests is jarring in a city so orderly that even the rare beggar can be counted on to start his pitch with "Excuse me." Predictability is bedrock here, a given in a city that just this week was designated by Fortune magazine as the best place in the world in which to live and work.
Mr. Rhodes, the Ontario government spokesman, admitted that today's demonstrations are likely to hurt Toronto's image, and to the rest of the world, this will look like a day of trouble in paradise. "But for the other 364 days of the year," he said, "there's no place like it."
Organizers hope that once Canadians get the hang of protesting, they will be more likely to come out again. If they do, it's likely to be in their own style.
"We say 'excuse me' and smile at the people who pass us on the way to work," said Melanie Exner, a member of the Ontario Teachers Federation who started picketing the stock exchange at 7 A.M. But Mrs. Exner warned that politeness should not be mistaken for consent. "I won't just sit quietly by," she said, "as our country is changed without our consent."

HEADLINE: In China's Outlands, Poorest Grow Poorer

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: NIUJUAN, China

 BODY:
Life is unimaginably hard in the burnt umber hills of this part of northwestern China. In four of the last five years there has been no harvest and millions of poor farmers are living in a state of hunger, poor health and illiteracy that in some areas approaches the deprivation levels of China's great famine in the late 1950's.
Muslim villagers here in southern Ningxia, known as the Hui Autonomous Region, say that no official from the Xiji County government, 20 miles away, has ever hiked into this desperately poor hamlet to offer assistance to the peasants, most of whom cannot afford to send their children to school and for whom medical care is nonexistent. 
 To add to their misery this fall, a plague of rats has come down from the mountains to feed on the pitifully small potato crop that sprouted after the blessing of a late summer rain and is all that will keep hunger at bay this winter. This year, a farmer named He Delin put it ruefully, "Our life is potatoes."
Although China has made prodigious efforts under Communist rule to eradicate poverty, lifting tens if not hundreds of millions to a higher standard of living through the economic reforms led by the paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, since 1978, from 60 million to 100 million Chinese still live on the edge of starvation and despair.
And according to new World Bank estimates, more than one-quarter of all Chinese -- about 350 million -- are in substantial deprivation, subsisting on less than $1 a day. In addition, for the first time a significant number of urban dwellers -- perhaps 15 million or more -- are falling below the poverty line as moribund state factories jettison workers in cities with no social security or welfare nets to catch them.
The significance of the new estimates is that they show a larger part of China's population being left behind than previously thought, even as the overall economy continues to register impressive growth. Although an average Chinese is better off today than at any time in the last 150 years, a huge part of the population -- more than the population of the United States -- remains on the bottom rung of the economic ladder.
The new World Bank estimates, based on improved data from the Chinese, also show that the big reduction in poverty in the first 10 years of economic overhaul begun by Mr. Deng has slowed substantially, while disparities in income between the rich coastal regions and poor inland regions have only intensified.
Altogether, these new estimates suggest that China will not be the economic colossus in the next century that many experts have predicted. Some now believe that the weight of China's poor, added to the weight of its debt-ridden state industries and the degradation of its environment, will limit the pace of development and may well prevent China's emergence as a dominating power.
And the grievances of millions of peasants and workers slipping closer to the edge can only be a source of threat and volcanic instability for the Communist Party leadership, whose legitimacy now derives solely from its ability to deliver prosperity, not ideology, to the masses.
Here in the village of Niujuan, which means Cow Pen, the weight of poverty can be seen in the faces that reflect the grinding fatigue of malnutrition and the corrosion of untreated disease.
"Last year was the worst," said a farmer, Su Dikua, speaking by the light of the kerosene lamp in his one-room mud house, which is a step up from the cave where Mr. Su had lived for most of his 59 years. His wife has a "skin disease" acquired during those years in the cave. It is possible that it is leprosy, but she has never seen a doctor about it.
Last year, Mr. Su said, they had almost nothing to eat. "Those who had the energy, traveled to the city to beg," he said. Among those who fled because of the hardship was his eldest son, Su Sanwa, 22, and "we haven't had any letters from him since."
It now appears that the Communist Party leadership has little hope of reaching its goal of lifting this huge population out of its misery by the end of the century.
Although Beijing still spends about $1 billion a year to alleviate poverty, with additional help from the World Bank and the United Nations, "no one believes that the goal is achievable," said one antipoverty expert in a major Western aid institution.
Even senior Chinese officials are beginning to hedge.
Liu Junwen, a senior staff member of the "leading group" on poverty reduction under Prime Minister Li Peng, acknowledged in September that to reach the goal, "that means that we must lift 13 million people out of poverty annually, almost three times the figure we have managed to reach in the past few years."
Speaking to reporters after a poverty conference, he added, "the poverty in which these 65 million people are living constitutes the hardest nut to crack due to the various deep-rooted geographical and socioeconomic adversities."
In other words, the first easy step in poverty reduction is over.
The spurt of prosperity that came in the 1980's from breaking up Mao's communes and freeing 900 million peasants to sell their own produce has proved difficult to match in the 1990's. The early gains in living standards were made among the Chinese living in lowland areas with access to roads, markets and ports.
The hardest work lies ahead for hundreds of millions of Chinese who live in mountainous, desert and arid plateau regions where arable land and rainfall are rare. And many of the hard-core poor are from China's minority populations, who were flushed into the highlands centuries ago by conquering armies of the Han Chinese.
"You hike into these villages and people are putting dirt in backpacks to haul up onto these rocky slopes to try to get something to grow," said Alan Piazza, a leading specialist on poverty in China for the World Bank. "When I bring agriculturists to these areas, they look at the landscape and say, 'Declare this a national park and get everyone out.' It's ridiculous; there is just no land."
He was referring to the eerily beautiful karst landscapes of southwestern China, where topsoil is scarce among the humpback limestone formations.
Mr. Piazza is the bank's most outspoken advocate for more focused, small-scale programs to put money into the hands of farmers, while also rebuilding rural education and health care so that families might have a chance to break the generational cycle of poverty.
"Most Americans could not begin to comprehend what 65 million Chinese have to endure and what that level of deprivation is all about," he said in a recent interview in Beijing.
"What you find in these villages is that one in 10 children dies in the first year of life," he said; "in some places it's one in five. Respiratory infections pick them off at incredibly high rates." He added, "In poverty areas, the remnant of the health system that once was no longer exists."
As for education, he said: "In the Southwest, only one child in 10 gets through the sixth grade. There is no way you will eliminate poverty if you don't educate children through the sixth grade."
China's leaders may have begun to realize that their approach to poverty reduction has been flawed. A recent Government survey reported that about $800 million of the $1 billion allocated annually was being spent on subsidies to county governments in poverty areas. Other poverty experts say that money has been squandered by local officials who never travel to the countryside, and that other money has been diverted to rural industries that are favored by local party bosses.
"We have heard about poverty alleviation programs," said He Demin, a 43-year-old farmer with eight children who lives down the gully from the Su family and who sold off farm animals last year so the family could eat through the winter. "But it never arrives here." He added, "The central authorities have a good heart, but their programs are not implemented by the officials below."
A neighbor, Yuan Wenqi, added: "It seems that the county government gets some money, and the township enterprises get some money, but not us."
The greatest failure in poverty reduction is in education and health, many experts say.
China has emphasized raising agricultural productivity on the assumption that rising farm incomes will allow peasants to buy the education and health services they need.
But because of the harsh terrain in China's upland areas, increasing agricultural production "is a pipe dream," Mr. Piazza said. The best solution, he said, is to educate children so they can find jobs in rural townships and small cities and leave the barren mountains behind.
"We are all illiterate here and so we don't know what is happening," said Mr. Yuan, as he offered boiled potatoes to a visitor. "If something is harmful, we don't know it. If something is good, we don't know it."
Ma Xinggui, a neighbor down the road, put it a different way as he paused from digging potatoes with his wife: "Because I have never been to school, I am like a blind person, even though I have eyes."

HEADLINE: Chirac's Goal: Bigger Mideast Role

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Pressing for a greater role for Europe in the American-dominated Middle East peace negotiations, President Jacques Chirac of France showed during a six-day trip through the region this week that Europe might not be ready to be a player, but that France was -- as an outspoken advocate of Arab causes.
Mr. Chirac, whose deficit-cutting economic policies have made him deeply unpopular at home, flew back to France today to both criticism and praise. 
 Some of the accolades were almost as warm as those he got earlier in the week after calling on Israelis to recognize the Palestinians' right to a nation-state of their own and facing down zealous Israeli security guards during his visit to East Jerusalem.
It was a performance that some saw as worthy of de Gaulle, whose mantle had been looking uncomfortably loose and large on Mr. Chirac's shoulders since his election as President in May 1995.
"Jacques Chirac, in the purest Gaullist tradition, has said no," Sami Nair, a professor of political science at the University of Paris, said in Le Monde today. "He has underlined that Europe must refuse the rule of imperial law in the region that enables the American-Israeli axis to impose just about anything it wants on impotent Arab states."
Winning back the leverage that France used to have among the Arab countries of the Middle East but lost to the United States over the years has been a prime goal of Mr. Chirac's since he took office, and there seemed little doubt that he had made progress on that goal this week.
Whether his foreign policy play can help him win back lost popularity at home is another question. Only 32 percent of French voters view him favorably now, according to a poll published in the weekly Le Point taken just before his trip.
By appealing to Arab and Muslim moderation in the Middle East, Mr. Chirac may also have been trying to head off frustration among the millions of Muslim immigrants living in France, frustration that French officials fear could lead to the spread of terrorism here.
There is nothing they fear more. Bombs believed to have been planted by terrorists from Algeria killed several people in Paris and wounded hundreds in several cities around France last year, until the police gunned down the ringleaders.
So some diplomats who know him well believe that Mr. Chirac was also trying on this trip to support people he sees as bulwarks against fundamentalism -- not only Yasir Arafat, but also King Hussein of Jordan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.
And maybe also President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, whom Mr. Chirac, then the Prime Minister, welcomed to Paris in 1975 as "my personal friend." Mr. Chirac's conservative Government, and subsequent Socialist ones, sold enough arms to Baghdad to make France its biggest foreign creditor.
In 1981 Israeli planes bombed a French-supplied nuclear reactor that the Iraqis were apparently planning to use to make atomic bombs, and in 1991 France sided with the United States and its allies in the Persian Gulf war to get Iraq out of Kuwait.
But Mr. Chirac did not support the American missile strikes on Iraq early last month, and in Jordan on Thursday he appealed to the United Nations to lift a ban on limited oil sales to let Iraq to pay for food and medicine for its suffering population.
The United Nations was about to let Iraq sell $2 billion worth of oil for this purpose in September, but held up the sale after Iraq moved forces into Iraqi Kurdish territory and set off the American military reaction. It is probably not coincidental that two French oil companies, Elf and Total, are expected to be the main foreign conduits for the Iraqi oil.
Like de Gaulle, Mr. Chirac also has ambitions to lead Europe to a greater world role, and he consulted his European Union partners before undertaking this trip. But it was not "Europe" trying to get its foot in the negotiating door in Israel and Syria so much as France, which has found little support outside the Arab world in calling for a European negotiator to help the United States put some steam back into the peace effort.
"The conditions aren't there yet," Sir Leon Brittan, vice president of the European Union's executive Commission, said on Thursday of the prospects for a more visible European role. "If we manage to work together and we abstain from any independent actions, then we will have the ability to work with the United States in this region."
Though French officials insisted that Mr. Chirac's suggestions were aimed at complementing American policy in the Middle East, not competing with it, American officials accepted that claim with increasingly tight smiles.
"I salute the U.S. role, but I see the peace process running short of breath because of the loss of trust," Mr. Chirac said. "I see the European and French role in building more trust."
He was careful to stress that he saw Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel as a "friend." But his trip did little to cement French-Israeli friendship, always tenuous, and it might also do more harm than good to the improvement in French relations with the United States that he achieved in his first year in office.

HEADLINE: Reports Show Mild Inflation and Growth

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Durable goods orders rebounded in September, the Commerce Department said today, and sales of existing homes remained strong despite a four-month decline, suggesting to analysts that the economy was expanding at a modest rate and that inflation was under control.
Much of the rise in durable goods orders came in transportation, which includes highly volatile aircraft orders. Without the rise in that area, the gain in durable goods orders was nine-tenths of 1 percent. 
 Bond prices fell initially but rose when investors saw the dip in housing and realized that much of the gain, the biggest in nearly four years, was in aircraft.
"The durable goods report confirms that the factory sector continues to grow modestly," said Mark Zandi, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa.
"The home sales," he added, "suggest that, although housing activity has slowed, it remains at a high level. They show the economy is expanding at a noninflationary pace."
The Commerce Department said that orders to factories for expensive durable goods rose 4.6 percent, to a seasonally adjusted record of $174.1 billion.
Although the increase was the largest since a 7.8 percent gain in December 1992, it was largely because of a 108 percent surge in aircraft orders.
In a separate report, the National Association of Realtors said sales of previously owned single-family homes fell 2.9 percent in September to a seasonally adjusted 4.02 million annual rate, the fourth straight drop.
Still, sales were above a four million rate for the seventh straight month and appeared to be making a run on the record of 3.98 million set in 1978. Sales were 3.8 million last year.
Mortgage rates, after reaching 8.42 percent in July, have been falling recently and averaged 7.86 percent this week. Some analysts believe the decline will help hold sales steady or even produce renewed growth.
In addition to the gain in transportation orders, electronic and other electrical equipment orders posted a 1.9 percent gain because of increased demand in communications.
But orders for industrial machinery and equipment were off nine-tenths of 1 percent and those for primary metals fell 1.7 percent.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods excluding aircraft rose 3.1 percent, the second advance in three months. These orders often are a barometer of business plans to expand and modernize and have been a large source of economic strength in the current expansion.
Unfilled orders rose seventh-tenths of 1 percent, the fourth increase in the last five months. A rising backlog could mean businesses will have to increase production and staffing to meet demand.
Separately, the number of American workers filing first-time claims for jobless benefits unexpectedly fell by 22,000 last week to the lowest level in nearly two months.
The Labor Department said on Thursday that new applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 320,000, the lowest since 317,000 the week ended Aug. 31.

HEADLINE: H. P. Minsky, 77, Economist Who Decoded Lending Trends

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Hyman P. Minsky, an economist and professor who explained, in path-breaking research, how lending patterns and mood swings can push an economy into speculative booms or steep declines, died on Thursday at Northern Dutchess Hospital in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 77 and lived in Rhinebeck.
He died of pancreatic cancer, his family said. 
 For the last six years, Professor Minsky was Distinguished Scholar at the Jerome Levy Economics Institute of Bard College, an independent institute on the Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., campus, where he had continued his research on debt and the economy.
One of his final papers argued that big industrial economies like that of the United States need $2 trillion or $3 trillion in national debt so cautious lenders who want guarantees of repayment can achieve this by buying the Government's very safe Treasury bills and bonds. Without such opportunity, he said, the Social Security Administration would lack a safe place to invest the payroll taxes of working Americans until they are paid out in pensions.
Mr. Minsky was sometimes described as a radical Keynesian whose research nevertheless endeared him to Wall Street.
"He offered very good insights in the 60's and 70's when linkages between the financial markets and the economy were not as well understood as they are now," said Henry Kaufman, a Wall Street money manager and economist. "He showed us that financial markets could move frequently to excess. And he underscored the importance of the Federal Reserve as a lender of last resort."
Mr. Minsky's best-known work came in the late 1960's and early 1970's while he was a professor at the University of California at Berkeley and then Washington University in St. Louis. John Maynard Keynes, the British economist, had written about unstable financial markets, but Mr. Minsky was the first to explain how this instability developed and interacted with the economy. In doing so he incorporated findings of Irving Fisher and other earlier economists.
Basically, Mr. Minsky found that in prosperous times, when corporate cash flow rises beyond what is needed to pay off debt, a speculative euphoria develops and soon lending gets beyond what the borrowers can pay off from their incoming revenues. That produces a crisis. There is a pull-back in lending, even to companies that can afford the loans, and the economy contracts.
"A fundamental characteristic of our economy," Mr. Minsky wrote in 1974, "is that the financial system swings between robustness and fragility and these swings are an integral part of the process that generates business cycles."
Disagreeing with many mainstream economists, he argued that these swings, and the booms and busts that can accompany them, are inevitable in a free market economy, unless Government steps in to control them, through regulation, central bank action and other tools that in fact came into existence in response to the Depression. He opposed the deregulation that characterized the 1980's.
It was at Berkeley that seminars attended by Bank of America executives helped him to develop his theories about lending and economic activity, views he laid out in two books: "John Maynard Keynes" (Columbia University Press, 1975) and "Stabilizing an Unstable Economy" (Yale University Press, 1986).
Hyman Philip Minsky, who was born in Chicago, graduated from George Washington High School in upper Manhattan. He received a bachelor's degree in mathematics at the University of Chicago in 1941, but influenced by Henry Simon, a revered economist, he shifted fields and received a doctorate in economics at Harvard in 1954, specializing in finance.
Mr. Minsky is survived by his wife, Esther, a son, Alan, and a daughter, Diana, all of Rhinebeck.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THIRD PARTY;
Perot Stronghold in '92 Largely Ignores Him in '96

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: BELFAST, Me., Oct. 24

 BODY:
On the morning after the 1992 Presidential election, Waldo County residents could have christened their Down East enclave Perot Country. Ross Perot finished first here, beating Bill Clinton and George Bush as he did in 13 other counties around the nation.
But this year, Mr. Perot is looking less like a leading man and more like a bit player, with many of his former disciples here saying his appeal has worn thin, and with little tangible evidence of support like campaign offices and signs in yards and store windows. 
 Roger T. Newcomb, a retired I.B.M. employee, long proud of his independence from the two major parties, helped put this mid-coast county and his town, Swanville, in the Perot column four years ago. On Nov. 5, he will not.
Mr. Newcomb said Mr. Perot's 1996 campaign was baffling. Mr. Newcomb said he had never heard of Mr. Perot's running mate, the political economist Pat Choate, and did not understand why Mr. Perot had entered the race so late.
"I haven't even paid attention to him," Mr. Newcomb said as he ate a turkey sandwich at Dudley's Diner. "I don't think he can make it, so I haven't paid attention."
Here in the streets and shops of Belfast, where the Passagassawakeag flows into Belfast Bay, more than two dozen voters in interviews offered a blizzard of similar reasons for taking Mr. Perot less seriously.
They said they did not like how he seemed to have tilted the nomination process to the disadvantage of Richard D. Lamm, the former Colorado Governor and Democrat who challenged Mr. Perot last summer. They are baffled because he chose an obscure running mate, as he did in 1992. They said Mr. Perot's economic message sounded repetitive and flat. And they worry that he lacks Presidential temperament or consensus-building skills.
John and Gloria Fugarino, Perot supporters in 1992, said they soured on him after concluding that he had not given a fair shake to Mr. Lamm.
Four years ago, Mr. Perot won 36.2 percent of the vote in Waldo County, and 18.9 percent of the popular vote nationally. His campaign resonated among voters drawn to his third-party mantra of deficit reduction and political reform. And his infomercials in October and November 1992 got high ratings, tying once for second place and once for first.
Today, national public opinion surveys show support for Mr. Perot stuck in single digits: the last New York Times/CBS News survey, conducted Oct. 17-20, gave him the support of 5 percent of likely voters. His infomercials this month have all placed fourth in their time slots.
While Bob Dole has not written off Mr. Perot's appeal -- the Republican challenger dispatched his campaign manager to Dallas on Wednesday to try to win his endorsement -- Mr. Perot's falling support could have serious consequences for the Reform Party. Should his share of the vote fall below 5 percent, the party he created and financed would not be eligible for Federal campaign financing in 2000.
"He is not a fresh commodity," said John Anderson, the moderate Republican and, before Mr. Perot in 1992, the last independent Presidential candidate to register among voters, capturing nearly 7 percent of the vote in the 1980 elections. "The electorate tends to some fickleness, and the twangy Texan is not quite the specialty item that he proved to be in 1992."
Mr. Perot does still have his supporters here. "I think there is going to be a protest vote because of his exclusion from the Presidential debates," said Vangel Asimakopoulos, a Penobscot County supporter who has been active in Mr. Perot's campaigns. But for the most part, it was difficult to find signs of support for Mr. Perot in Waldo County and the rest of the state.
In 1992, when Mr. Perot spent up to $70 million of his own money on his campaign, Maine and other states had campaign offices and telephones. This year, Mr. Perot is spending the $29 million he has received in Federal campaign financing primarily on infomercials and his own campaign travels. And a check of directory assistance found no Perot '96 or Reform Party offices in Waldo County, or in Portland, Bangor or Augusta.
In addition, supporters here, as in other counties and states, have been left to do their own fund raising for signs, bumper stickers and other tools of a get-out-the-vote effort. Nelson Foley, chairman of Maine's Reform Party, said the state's 16 counties should have 5,000 signs by the end of this week.
Mr. Asimakopoulos and Lily Andrews, the volunteer state coordinator of the Perot '96 campaign, say the level of activity and commitment to Mr. Perot is high but difficult to see because volunteers work from their kitchen tables with their home telephones.
Still, with less than two weeks until the election, the Maine Reform Party has yet to issue its cross endorsements of major party candidates for the two House seats and the United States Senate seat up for election. Nor has it announced its positions on ballot initiatives, including one on campaign finance, an issue that is the centerpiece of the Perot agenda.
"The salience of some of his issues has faded," said Mr. Anderson, who had supported Mr. Lamm. "Clinton has drummed away on the thesis that, 'Well, I've done a lot with my willingness to increase taxes in '93 to decrease the deficit.' "
In downtown Belfast, Kief's Barber Shop has three traditional burgundy chairs, heads of two deer mounted on the walls and a blue and yellow 1992 Perot button affixed to a tall glass jar full of "Barbicide," a disinfectant.
"I'm going to vote for Perot," said Bill Kief, a former marine who added that he thought Mr. Perot should have found a running mate Americans knew. "I know I'm going to waste my vote, but I'm going to show my disgust with the current Administration."
Not far from the barbershop, Alan Fouts was renovating a 119-year-old Victorian Gothic building, said, "I'm afraid a vote for Perot would elect Bill Clinton." A charter plane pilot, he said Mr. Perot was a "credible force last time," but not now. "This time he seems to be going through the motions."
Jerry Savitz, owner of two Belfast restaurants, said that he was heavily involved in Mr. Perot's 1992 campaign, but that he would not vote for him again, in part because he found him "so mercurial."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ross Perot carried Waldo County, Me., in 1992, but his support has largely vanished this year. "I don't think he can make it," said Roger T. Newcomb of Swanville, a Perot voter last time, "so I haven't paid attention." (Joel A. Page for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. AND NATO PLAN NEW BOSNIA FORCE

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Although the White House has maintained a deliberate silence for fear of provoking pre-election controversy, the United States and NATO have begun preparations to field a smaller but still sizable international peacekeeping force in Bosnia that would include at least 5,000 American troops.
In a week in which Bosnia's potentially volatile municipal elections were delayed until next year, Administration officials, NATO leaders and European diplomats said active planning was under way for a force of 15,000 to 30,000 troops who would remain in Bosnia at least through 1997. 
 While some details remain unresolved, the officials in Washington and Europe said the new force would have essentially the same mission as the nearly 60,000 troops, including more than 15,000 Americans, who have patrolled Bosnia for nearly a year as part of the peace accords negotiated last fall in Dayton, Ohio, to end four years of civil war.
As they discuss military options with the NATO allies, American officials have taken pains to note that formal approval for an American role has to come from President Clinton.
And the President's aides insist that he will not make his final decision until the United States and NATO agree next month, after the Presidential election, on the exact scope of the mission.
But officials in Europe said that in recent meetings there was unanimous agreement among countries that now have troops in Bosnia, including the United States, that a sizable ground force would be necessary to insure Bosnia's tenuous stability and prevent a resumption of fighting between Muslims and Serbs.
Britain and France, the other main countries involved, insist they will not field troops if the Americans do not.
But NATO officials say the United States has essentially signaled its commitment, most recently at a meeting in Brussels last week and in recent visits to NATO headquarters in Brussels by Defense Secretary William J. Perry and the deputy national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger.
"You know full well that there has to be a military presence," a senior European diplomat in the Balkans said this week. "There will be." And, the diplomat added, the United States would put American troops on the ground "without a shadow of a doubt."
"They haven't said it specifically, but there are nods and winks," the diplomat said. "And there is planning."
The issue is politically delicate for Mr. Clinton.
When he first committed troops late last year, he pledged that they would be home by the end of 1996, although from the start aides said the deadline was merely an approximation. In recent months the Administration has acknowledged that a few thousand troops would remain until March to oversee a gradual withdrawal.
Republicans in Congress have charged the President with deceiving the public about the longer-term commitment, even as Administration officials have insisted that decisions about future troops in Bosnia have not been made.
While the Administration touts the peace accords as one of the President's foreign policy successes, Mr. Clinton's aides worry that a decision to keep troops in Bosnia could become an issue in the Presidential campaign, though the potential for voter backlash may have faded since the operation so far has produced almost no conflict or casualties.
Earlier this month NATO's defense ministers, meeting in Bergen, Norway, ordered military planners to consider four options for an international force in Bosnia, once the current force's mandate expires in December.
They range from a renewal of the current force level to a complete withdrawal. In between, the options are a reduced force or a still smaller force backed up by mobile units stationed near Bosnia.
The United States, however, has all but ruled out the extreme options. "The focus of the study," an Administration official said, "is on the middle two options."
While the immediate threat of war has declined since the Dayton accords and the arrival of the international peacekeepers, Bosnia and Herzegovina remains a volatile place. A number of issues supposed to have been resolved under the peace accords remain potential flash points, including freedom of movement and the return of refugees to their homes.
National elections held last month created a three-member Presidency, led by the Bosnian chairman, Alija Izetbegovic. But the three men have so far failed to establish the national institutions called for or to make much headway against the suspicions left over from four years of war.
With the threat of fighting eased, Administration and NATO officials said they now believed that a smaller force would be sufficient to keep peace. Under the plans now being considered, the new force would continue to operate in American, British and French sectors, but would not require the large, highly visible and heavily armed patrols of the first year.
The force, officials in Washington and in Europe said, would include at least 5,000 American troops on the ground, and perhaps as many as 10,000. Some may be stationed "over the horizon," in mobile units based in neighboring states like Hungary or Croatia, or aboard aircraft carriers in the Adriatic Sea, ready to respond quickly if fighting breaks out.
That, the officials said, was an option favored by some American military commanders.
The United States and NATO must still decide on the extent of the future mission, which will in turn dictate the exact number of troops needed, although officials agreed that it would be in the range of 15,000 to 30,000.
Canada, for instance, has advocated expanding the mission to include pursuing suspects wanted for war crimes, but NATO officials said it was unlikely the force would change its current policy under which troops will arrest suspects only if they encounter them.
Other issues under discussion involve the force's role in monitoring arms-control agreements and in backing up a strengthened international police force.
The decision by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to again postpone the municipal elections has added to the need for a extended military presence.
An Administration official said the municipal elections, now scheduled for the spring, would require "a high security component"; one plan under consideration would beef up the peacekeeping force for the election period and then draw it down again.
"Until they know what all of those bits and pieces of security-related goals will be, they can't know the number of troops," the official said.
NATO's military planners are expected to complete a menu of recommendations by next week or the first week of November. NATO's governing body, the North Atlantic Council, will not consider the recommendations at least until its next meeting, on Nov. 6, the day after the American elections.
An overarching concern still to be resolved is an "exit strategy" for the new force, with specific plans and deadlines for withdrawing, rather than an open-ended commitment.
While some allies have discussed a two-year commitment to coincide with the economic and relief efforts under the Dayton accords, the officials said it was more likely that the United States and NATO would agree on a one-year extension of the peacekeepers.
American officials have said their program of sending heavy weapons to the Muslim-dominated Government, to balance the better-armed Serbs, was needed to allow foreign troops to leave.
That program's start has been delayed, and many European officials think it is misguided to put more weapons into the region.
A senior Administration official said setting a clear deadline was important to the future of Bosnia so that the factions there begin to take on responsibility for keeping peace and promoting stability.
"It's important to remind the Bosnians," the official said, "that the international community is not going to be there for a generation."
 A correction on Monday further misstated the site of the talks; none were held in the United States.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 28, 1996, MondayOctober 31, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about preparations by the United States and NATO for a peacekeeping force in Bosnia next year misstated the location of recent discussions on the issue. Defense Secretary William J. Perry attended alliance meetings in Bergen, Norway; Samuel R. Berger, the deputy national security adviser, met with NATO foreign ministers in the United States. The talks were not at NATO headquarters in Brussels.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about preparations by the United States and NATO for a peacekeeping force in Bosnia next year misstated the role of Samuel R. Berger, the deputy national security adviser, and misstated the location of the talks. Mr. Berger was not involved in discussions on the subject with NATO foreign ministers. And the meetings were in Bergen, Norway, not at NATO headquarters in Brussels.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Your Mission, Should You Accept It

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Whoever wins next week's Presidential election will have to immediately launch an intense round of diplomatic negotiations. Sitting across the table from the next President in these negotiations will be the prickliest of foes: some will be Neanderthals who make the Afghan Taliban mullahs seem like progressives; some will be power-mad egomaniacs; only a few will be allies. The President won't need Air Force One to get to these talks, though. The limo will do. He will, however, need a translator. Because the President's first foreign affairs negotiation is going to have to be with the 105th Congress.
Why? Because the U.S. foreign affairs budget has been cut so sharply (51 percent in real terms since 1984) and the U.S. is now so deeply in arrears to the U.N., the World Bank and the World Health Organization (which are owed more than $2 billion) and the foreign aid budget has been reduced so far (Egypt and Israel now get almost the whole thing) that the ability of the next President to maintain U.S. leadership and conduct real preventive diplomacy will be severely handicapped unless he can cut a new "Grand Bargain" with Congress. 
 There is now so little discretionary money left in the foreign affairs budget that the only way to pay for the recent elections in Bosnia was to take the money away from the NATO expansion program, Partnership for Peace. One reason the Kurds in Northern Iraq got embroiled in a civil war was a fight over money, after the U.S. failed to come up with aid. The only way the U.S. can help fund the Guatemalan peace process is to take money away from the Haitian one.
More U.S. ambassadors have been killed than U.S. generals since World War II. No matter, the Congress ordered the Pentagon to spend $6 billion more than it asked for last year, while telling the State Department to close 30-some embassies and consulates and shut down 25 percent of the U.S.I.A. libraries around the world, which spread the gospel of democracy and free markets. Few people at State have access to the Internet at their computers because there isn't money to buy modems. Craig Johnstone, director of resources at State, noted that we now spend about as much supporting democratization in Russian as we do expanding the H.O.V. lane on Route 66 into Washington.
There is nothing wrong with trimming the foreign affairs budget, or with streamlining the system. But it should be done with a sense of priorities, not by putting on a blindfold and hacking away at it as if it were a pinata. Look where we are today: An increasing share of U.S. income now comes from exports. American values are triumphing from Mongolia to Moscow. American quality of life is now much more threatened by global trends -- the Ebola Virus, population explosions, environmental disasters or the chaos of countries melting down from within -- than from any armed foe. Yet precisely at such a moment we are trashing the U.N., underfunding development banks that help countries help themselves, closing embassies and telling the Pentagon to spend more than it needs. That's insane.
Or as Secretary of State Warren Christopher remarked: "We cannot advance American interests by lowering the American flag."
What to do? The next President must take this issue up with Congress himself. He personally has to make it a priority. The President should also enlist the Joint Chiefs of Staff in his lobbying. Let the generals explain to Congress the importance of having sufficient diplomatic resources so troops aren't the only option. Moreover, President Clinton, if he does win, should appoint several well-known Republican foreign policy figures to his team. Without a real bipartisan approach, no progress on the foreign affairs budget will be possible.
Finally, the next President will have to embark on a major re-education campaign with Congress. That core group of senators who supported foreign aid and who traveled the world is retiring: Sam Nunn, Mark Hatfield, Bill Bradley, William Cohen, Claiborne Pell, Nancy Kassebaum, Paul Simon, Hank Brown and Bob Dole. The President needs to help nurture a whole new foreign policy generation, and he could start by giving them political cover for traveling. Lawmakers, fearful of being accused of junketing, don't travel anymore. Those who don't travel don't know. Those who don't know don't care.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
